PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from moving a motion relating to the conduct of the Business of the Senate, namely, a motion to give precedence over all other business to a motion relating to the proposed censure of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday, in his usual style of gutter politics, referred to this place, to the Australian Senate, as `unrepresentative swill'. This is not an unprecedented performance by the Prime Minister. This is his usual style. In doing so, he degrades this institution and he degrades the office of Prime Minister. The only recourse we have at the moment to such foul action of the Prime Minister is to move a censure motion in this place.

PARA.TAB: Ultimately, the Australian people will have the matter in their hands, hopefully sooner rather than later, and what they will do is throw out this Prime Minister because they are sick and tired of this gutter style of politics. What they want from their representatives is debate on the issues, debate on the important things that are facing Australia, debate on the one million Australians who are out of work, and debate on what can be done in the form of a program that can give them an opportunity for the future, to provide work for them, to provide opportunities for their families and a future for their children. That is what the Australian people are interested in. They are sick and tired of this Prime Minister simply wanting instead to divert the matter by personal abuse.

In this place we are sick and tired of his seeking to drag down the Senate as well. That is why it is urgent this morning that we take up this issue and that we pursue it in this place. I said that it was not unprecedented. It happens continually. I will give the Senate a few examples of what the Prime Minister has said over the years, referring to individuals, with the protection of the other place. He refers to them as `harlots', `sleazebags', `frauds', `cheats, cheats, cheats', `blackguards', `pigs', `mugs', `clowns',`brain-damaged', `loopy crims', `stupid, foul-mouthed grubs'. This is the Prime Minister of Australia speaking—the Prime Minister of Australia, who should be looked up to and respected by the Australian people. Yet he drags down the office to that level and he drags us down by doing it.

Something has to be done about it. As I said, all we can do in this place is protest in the strongest possible form that is open to us, and that is through censure. That is why we come in here this morning at the first opportunity to seek to suspend Standing Orders in order that we can move a censure motion against him, in order that the Senate can put on the record that it regards his performance and his behaviour as intolerable, that he should improve his performance, get out of the gutter, debate the issues that are important to Australia, behave in the way that an Australian Prime Minister ought to behave. Alternatively he ought to get out, he ought to resign, he ought to acknowledge that he is an embarrassment to Australia and an embarrassment to the Australian people. That is why it is important that this matter be debated this morning, and that is why I move for the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear that we will not ultimately oppose the motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders. If anyone else wants to speak on it they are welcome, but I assume that after a few brief comments people might wish to get on with the substantive motion. The reason I wanted to hear Senator Hill speak on why we should suspend the Standing Orders was to hear him say what I expected, which is that the people of Australia want the Parliament to deal with the important issues that are causing them concern. Here we are today, and what has got us in a passion? Someone said something rude about us, and we all have to get excited.
—Someone is damaging the institution.

—Yes, that is the other point. We have this selective passion about democratic institutions. Opposite are the people who have defended for a hundred years rorting the democratic process of the Legislative Council of Western Australia. Every day they defend it, yet they think someone saying something rude about the Senate, undermining the Senate, is in some way undermining our democratic institutions. But rigging the electoral system is not.
—Fancy you talking about Western Australia. Fancy the Labor Party talking about rigging.

—I have never voted to rig the Parliament like those opposite have. I have never voted to rig the Parliament, yet Opposition senators say they are concerned about democratic institutions. We all know that the people want us to deal with the issues, and here we have today on the Notice Paper nine pieces of legislation that need properly to be dealt with. That is what the people pay their taxes to send us here to do—not to get in a passion because somebody says something we do not like. It happens to be a democracy. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) got up and said something. If Opposition members do not agree with it, then they should reply to him. If they think this is a reflection of the priorities that the people of Australia have about what we should be doing, it is a reflection on them and not on the Prime Minister. But let us get on with the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will support the motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders. We believe that this is an important matter, that it is not, as Senator McMullan indicated a moment ago, the Senate being precious about its own standing. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is bringing into disrepute both the Parliament itself and the high office of the Prime Minister. It is about time this sort of thing is put a stop to.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister is also factually wrong. This is a far more representative chamber. One need only look at the way the legislation in many cases is hammered through the House of Representatives on numbers and in this place is dealt with properly and appropriately and quite extensively amended. It is important to defend the very important role of the Senate. I draw attention to the words of Dr Hewson this morning. The Senate was described by Dr Hewson as a brake on the excesses of the Labor Government. I would hope that he would also accept that the Senate may act as a brake on the excesses of any future coalition government, should that happen.

This is an important matter. We should get on with the substantive motion, which we are yet to hear from Senator Hill. We would also like the Senate to consider, depending upon what Senator Hill chooses to put down as a motion, the following sorts of words which we are seeking:

SPEECH.PARA: and the Senate

(a) upholds the valuable role of the Senate in providing checks and balances on executive government, as a result of the consistent decision of Australian voters that no party should have absolute control of the chamber; and

(b) observes that the proportional representation system under which Senators are elected makes the composition of this chamber more representative of the will of the Australian people than is the House of Representatives.
I will defend all these arguments extensively in the substantive debate. They are the terms in which we hope the debate will take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not oppose the suspension of Standing Orders. It is unfortunate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made certain references to the word `swill'. I think the last time the word `swill' was used in the House of Representatives was when Mr Jim Killen said of a particular member of the House of Representatives, `The honourable member is not fit to carry swill to the pigs'. He was asked to withdraw that statement, and he did. He said, `The honourable member is fit to carry swill to the pigs'.

PARA.TAB: I suppose we could pass this matter over, but we are, after all, not dealing with a reflection on individuals here. We can carry swill to the pigs, whosever pigs they might be. But it is a reflection on the chamber itself and it comes on top of a statement by the Prime Minister that this chamber should be abolished. I think that it is important, therefore—

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't he entitled to say that?

—He is entitled to say that, of course. Previous Prime Ministers have indicated that in a similar fashion, but not to the extent of saying that the place should be abolished. Successive Prime Ministers have been rather peeved about the exercise by this chamber of its rightful role of review and its defence of individual rights.
—It is a party House.

—I say to Senator Schacht that so far as I am concerned it is not a party House. Senator Schacht is very selective about his interest in human rights. I will have something further to say about that. When he goes to China, he does not even get the regulations which impose very gross violations of human rights before he goes there.
—Why don't you go to China?

—I would be happy if they would let me. In fact, I now invite Senator Schacht to have me go on the delegation this month. I would be very happy to do that. I would have obtained the information and done the homework which he did not do last time, having regard to that ridiculous report which he brought down. Mr President, I will ignore the interjections. I simply say that I support the suspension of Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
That a motion to censure the Prime Minister take precedence over all other business until determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for degrading the office of Prime Minister and the institution of Parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying some time ago, this denigration of the institution, this practice of public abuse by this Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has got to stop. The only action that we can take in this place properly to register our protest is censure. Ultimately, as I said, the people of Australia will have their opportunity, and I have no doubt at all that when they have that opportunity they will throw this man out of office.

PARA.TAB: They will throw him out of office not only because he has failed the Australian people in his economic plan—his plan, his model, has resulted in one million Australians being out of work, causing so much misery and hardship in this country—but because of his personal style. They are sick and tired of this style of personal abuse. Whenever he is in trouble politically, the answer is to abuse someone, preferably to abuse somebody else, and then preferably to abuse the institution. The Australian people are constantly saying that they will not tolerate that behaviour any longer, that they want something better, and they are entitled to something better from the Prime Minister of Australia.

They want to look up to and respect the Prime Minister of Australia. They want to be able to respect these institutions. They want to be able to respect the democratic process in this country. That is why they are tired of the Prime Minister dragging down the Parliament, the institutions, to his gutter level of politics. That is why, in addition to his failure, his economic failure and the suffering and hardship he has brought to so many Australians, they will toss him out.

A few minutes ago I was giving you some examples, Mr President, of his contemptuous behaviour in this way, because it is important to note that this is one of so many occasions on which he has behaved in a way of uttering such personal abuse. Mr President, I will not repeat the ones I mentioned a while ago, but I will give you a few more out of the Hansard. This is what he says under the protection of Parliament as he seeks to drag this institution down to his level. He has referred to individuals as `scumbags', `scum', `sucker', `thugs', `dimwits', `a swill', `a pigsty'—that seems somewhat opportune—`Liberal muck', `vile constituency', `fools and incompetents', `perfumed gigolos', `thugs of Australian politics', `constitutional vandals', `insane stupidities', `liars', `ghouls', et cetera. `Criminals', he says, within the protection of Parliament, of individuals on the other side of the chamber. He says, `stupid foul-mouthed grub', `piece of criminal garbage', `dullards'. This is the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—It is all right for those opposite to laugh. If they want to get down to his level, they can come in here and laugh at it as well. But we on this side of the chamber are sick and tired of it. The Australian people are sick and tired of it, they want it to end and they want him to go.

PARA.TAB: It is true that there are important matters facing this nation. I have said it and I will say it again. We are pleased to say that on this side of the chamber we have put down a comprehensive plan, perhaps the most comprehensive plan from any Opposition in Australia's history, to get this country back on its feet again and to give Australians an opportunity for the future. We want to debate that plan. We want to debate Fightback. It is a constructive effort by an alternative government to put the detail on the table in order that policy debate can take place and the people of Australia can then make their choice on policy issues.

That is what the parliamentary process should be all about. That is our responsibility and that is a responsibility that we have met. What should the Prime Minister be doing? He should be putting on the table his alternative for the next three years in government. But is he going to do that? He certainly should do it, having regard to the fact that so many Australians are out of work and suffering at the moment. But is he prepared to do that? No. What is his answer? His answer is simply to attack and abuse.
I was listening to radio broadcasts after the Victorian election. I heard the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Howe, say that this Prime Minister is the most offensive in Australia's history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he?

—He said that. Of course, he went on to qualify the statement, recognising immediately what he had said, to say that what he meant was that the Prime Minister goes on the offensive more often than any in Australia's history. In actual fact, he probably got it right both times, because he is the most offensive Prime Minister in Australia's history and he goes on the offensive more often than any others because he has not got a plan. He does not offer Australia any decent future. All he can offer as an alternative to Fightback is personal abuse, and we got it again when he referred to the Senate as `swill', pigs feed—that is his level of gutter politics. That is where he wishes to drag us and we are not prepared to do so. We will stand up and fight against it.

PARA.TAB: What was it all about yesterday? It was about the conspiracy between the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the former Victorian Government to keep from the Australian people the fact that the Victorian Government had breached the Loan Council guidelines. That is what it was all about—ministerial accountability. We have a responsibility to do something about that, and we have done so. We have set up a committee that will investigate that apparent abuse, and it will go further. It will make recommendations to improve the system in the future. Again, that is us acting responsibly within our role.

What is the Prime Minister's response to that? Rather than say that he will cooperate with the parliamentary process, recognising that democracy and ministerial responsibility are integral parts of the system of which we are all so proud, his answer is to say, `My Minister will not attend, and furthermore he won't attend before a chamber that is unrepresentative swill, unrepresentative pig food'.

It is appalling behaviour. It is not good enough and it has to end. The Australian people will bring it to an end. This behaviour reflects the Prime Minister's background, his faction. We have heard before that his own people refer to his faction as thugs. That might be the way they operate within the New South Wales Right, but it is not the way the Australian people wish to see the Prime Minister behave in the parliamentary process.

We gave him a couple of hours yesterday. We thought that perhaps for once he would be prepared to go back into the House of Representatives and say, `I apologise'. But was he prepared to do that? Of course not, because you never apologise. No doubt his answer today will be to come out and pile more abuse on top of that abuse. It seems to be the only way the Prime Minister knows how to carry on the business of politics.

So we have moved this motion of censure today. We have done so because the Australian people are sick of it, and we have a responsibility to register their protest in this way. We move it not so much out of anger but out of a genuine desire to lift the standing of this place and to enable the Australian people again to say that they are proud of their institutions and proud of the way in which we go about our fairly difficult task, if I might say so. They want to hear debate, they want to hear the issues argued out, but they do not want to continually hear this personal abuse.

Perhaps, just perhaps, out of this debate today the Prime Minister might change, but I doubt it. Over the years, personal abuse has been his constant practice. It is his mark. It is the way in which he engages in the business of politics: do not debate the issues; do not debate the substantive matters; do not concern yourself with a million Australians out of work; each time these policy issues are raised, respond to them with personal abuse.

I have moved this motion of censure today because the behaviour of the Prime Minister has been appalling. He has degraded the institution of Parliament, he has degraded the office of Prime Minister, and I trust that the Senate will support the motion and censure him, as it should.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion to censure the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). When I receive the appropriate words, I will be seeking to amend the motion to add the first two parts of the motion I foreshadowed earlier. The Australian Democrats believe very strongly that the Prime Minister has not only on this occasion but also on many other occasions, as Senator Hill has said, degraded the office of Prime Minister, which is one the people of Australia have a right to look up to and respect. He has also degraded the whole process of parliamentary democracy in degrading with those offensive remarks the role of the Senate, which, under our Constitution, is clearly integral to the democratic functioning of the Parliament. As we have seen in recent years, this chamber, far more than the House of Representatives, has been the chamber in which the democratic processes are given effect.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Patterson has just interjected, `Hear, hear!' I think all fair minded senators will recognise that time and again legislation is simply slammed through the House of Representatives. It is a number crunching exercise. Legislation often comes up here ill prepared and requiring extensive debate and amendment. If people look into the record, they will find that time after time the Senate is doing the only work that properly represents the democratic functioning of Parliament. That is not being done in the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: As to the Prime Minister's statement on the unrepresentative nature of the Senate, I simply point to the figures in the 1990 election, in which the Australian Democrats received roughly one vote in eight from the Australian people. Consequently, if the House of Representatives had been a representative chamber, we should have had roughly 18 seats in the House of Representatives. But it is not a representative chamber and we finished with no seats, simply because of the way those votes were distributed across Australia. I contrast that with the National Party, which received approximately two-thirds the number of votes of the Australian Democrats and yet finished up with 14 seats in the House of Representatives.

Yet, when one looks at the Senate, one will see that after the 1990 election we finished with eight senators in a House of 76. The Senate, in that respect, truly represents the spread of opinion among the Australian public. That is precisely what a representative chamber should do. Building on that, one sees again that this is the chamber, and precisely because over the last decade neither of the old parties have had the ability simply to slam through legislation on the numbers, in which proper parliamentary debates have occurred and extensive amendments and extensive improvements have been made to legislation.

It is quite clear, as others have said, that the Prime Minister and many of his colleagues, and indeed some in this chamber on the Labor side, are on the record as saying that they would like to dispense with the Senate. That would be an extremely dangerous, hazardous and very retrograde step. If any chamber were to be extinguished, surely it should be the House of Representatives or, conversely, if we are going to move to a unicameral system of parliament, then we should adopt a multi-member electorate and a proportional representation system for the House of Representatives so that it becomes a representative chamber.

The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, is clearly on record as wanting not to abolish the Senate but simply to control the Senate. Again, one would find that under such a system one would have legislation slammed through on the numbers, and one would abolish the Senate in terms of its proper review function, its debating function. As I indicated a moment ago, Dr Hewson said of the Senate just yesterday that it is an important chamber as it acts as a brake on the excesses of Labor governments.

I simply draw everybody's attention to the desirability of having a proper review of all legislation, irrespective of the party in power, so that we avoid the excesses of Executive government, whether it is a Labor government, a coalition government or any other government. In a democracy—and I am sure all fair minded senators in this chamber will agree—it is appropriate that a representative chamber carries out that review function.

The substantive issue over which this has arisen, that is, the Senate inquiry into the functioning of the Loan Council, is a classic case in which the functioning of the Loan Council, in this case under a Federal Labor government and a Labor government in Victoria, may well have—and I make no judgment—done certain things which need close scrutiny. But, equally, under a Federal Liberal government and a State Liberal government, one could easily imagine precisely the same sorts of conditions applying and the need to establish a similar sort of committee under those sorts of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because the Labor Party does it does not mean that we would.

—Surely Senator Bishop is not indicating that the Opposition is so pure that the same sorts of things it is alleging against the Labor Government will not occur and will never occur under a coalition government. Mr President, this is just too much.

PARA.TAB: The Senate is a very valuable House of review, and I think that has been demonstrated over the last decade. Is it suggested that any of us are so pure and so clean that the temptations of the exercise of executive power are not such that parties and people can be corrupted and, therefore, are in no need of that democratic review process? To argue that is simply to agree with the Prime Minister that the Senate should be abolished. We do not defend that position. We strongly defend the role of the Senate and point very strongly to the fact that the Senate has really come into its own since the Democrats have had the balance of power—since, in the last 10 years, legislation has been reviewed by a parliament in which neither of the old parties have had the power simply to slam through anything that they want, just on the numbers alone.

I well remember the speech made by former Senator Peter Baume when he left this chamber. Former Senator Peter Baume described himself as being so wet that if he were wrung out he would drip, but he was one person who, on several occasions to my knowledge, crossed the floor. Many honourable senators here will remember his closing speech in which he said that in his last few years in the Senate, the Senate had really begun to function in the very important way in which it was intended to function—as a House of review. He drew attention specifically to the fact of this balance of power situation in which no party could simply slam material through on numbers alone, and that is a very important function.

We would have to agree with Senator Hill that it is true we do want to hear the issues argued in this place, and at one level this might be seen as peripheral—a side issue. However, these sorts of slanging matches are getting in the way of a consideration of the main issues and it is for that reason that we join with the Opposition in supporting this censure motion. I now formally move as an amendment to the motion that the following words be added to the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: "and the Senate

a)upholds the valuable role of the Senate in providing checks and balances on executive government, as a result of the consistent decision of Australian voters that no party should have absolute control of the chamber; and

b)observes that the proportional representation system under which Senators are elected makes the composition of this chamber more representative of the will of the Australian people than is the House of Representatives.
I invite both the Government and the Opposition to join in support of that amendment. I hope the amendment has been circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just got a copy of it and it is in the process of being circulated.
—Thank you, Mr President.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will begin by referring to what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said. Part of what the Prime Minister said was quoted by Senator Hill.
—`Unrepresentative swill'.

—Thank you, Senator Parer. The Prime Minister added, `over there where you are into a political stunt'. Those words were not mentioned by Senator Hill in his remarks in moving this censure motion. I see Mr Reith, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, skulking in the doorway there. He was sitting here a minute ago because he is the mastermind of the political stunt. Honourable senators pride themselves on the role of the Senate and its independence. Who put out the press release announcing the membership of this committee of inquiry on behalf of the Opposition? Who put out the press release? It was Mr Reith. Mr Reith tells the Liberal Party House of review which is keen on these committees; he announces to the public who is going to be on the committee of inquiry on behalf of the Opposition. What an extraordinary situation to have that sort of thing going on. That just illustrates the nature of the political stunt.

PARA.TAB: I want to come to what Senator Hill said. Since yesterday, Senator Hill has been very agitated by this matter—very agitated. In conjunction with his Deputy Leader, I understand he went to see the President about it; he did a doorstop about it; he became very agitated. What he complains about this morning is that the Australian people are sick and tired of this language used by the Prime Minister. But the truth slips out all the time. Senator Hill cannot speak on behalf of the Australian people on this issue. He speaks on behalf of himself and Opposition senators here. They are sick and tired of it. That is the point.

Among all the things which Senator Hill got very heated about today, the words which he attributed to the Prime Minister are words used about Liberal politicians—not, if I might say so, a high form of life in the estimation of the Australian people. All the words which were quoted today were words about Liberal Party politicians. That is the objection.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should take the retirement.

—Senator Macdonald is getting on to a good point. We will deal with that in a minute. The fact of the matter is that the real objection is sensitive Liberal Party politicians who cannot stand the heat in the kitchen and get very excited about all these issues. All the things that Senator Hill objects to were said about members of parliament. He says, `We are sick and tired of it. The Australian people with whom we identify'—with an extraordinarily low poll approval—`are sick and tired of it too'. Let us look at Senator Hill's press release. Senator Hill went out yesterday and said that `swill' is defined in the Collins Dictionary in such and such a way, and he invited senators to read the Collins Dictionary definition of what the word `swill' means. This is the rub, the word `swill'. He said in his press release that there are numerous interpretations of the word `swill' as defined in the Collins Dictionary. Some of them he finds offensive—undoubtedly, because of the way he has gone on.

PARA.TAB: How did Senator Hill's press release conclude? It concluded that Mr Keating had demeaned the office of Prime Minister and shown contempt for Parliament, so he should resign. After all these years in opposition, the point that the Opposition has finally got to is that the only way that it can get rid of the Government is to get people to resign. Senator Macdonald interjects every day, saying that I should resign. Mr Dawkins is supposed to resign. Mr Keating is supposed to resign. Everybody is supposed to resign to make way for this lacklustre lot on the Opposition benches, who assume that if everybody on the Government's side resigns they will move into government. That is the latest tactic of the Opposition, to say that everybody ought to resign. That is the easy way into government; the rest is being found a bit too hard. The Prime Minister has used words about Liberal politicians, as I said, that they do not particularly like. Because of that, everybody on the Government's side, including the Prime Minister, should resign.

It is very important to make a distinction between words used about Liberal politicians and words used about the people of Australia. Let us have a look at that, at words used about the people of Australia. Let us look at what Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition, says about people who live in rented homes. He says that in any street it is always easy to tell the rented houses. They are the ones where the lawn is not mowed, the plants are not watered and the fences are not fixed. That is Dr Hewson on people, on Australians, who have to rent their homes.

We may listen to Dr Hewson on other issues. BHP and Ford he calls companies mollycoddled by government. That was said about Mr Prescott, the chief executive of BHP. Dr Hewson's comment on the Catholic Welfare Commission was that it consisted of whingeing, carping critics. What does he say about people who do not have children? People who do not have children are reprehensible, in the view of Dr Hewson. People who do not drive cars are reprehensible, in the view of Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition. Australians are lazy. People on welfare are lazy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Dr Hewson has never said that people who do not have children are reprehensible. That is an untrue reflection upon an honourable member of this Parliament and it should be withdrawn. We do not mind Senator Button going on and quoting, if he wishes, from this aNiMaLS produced document that he has there, but let us get it accurate and let us not incorrectly reflect upon honourable members of this Parliament.
—There is no point of order because it is not up to me to determine whether he said it or not. I think Senator Hill has made his point quite clearly in a debate.

—I accept the point of order. Dr Hewson says that one should be suspicious about people who do not have children; one should be suspicious about people who do not have cars; one should be suspicious about people who have certain other things; or, referring to the Catholic Welfare Commission, one should be suspicious about whingeing, carping critics, people on welfare, basket weavers.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Mr President, if you do not believe that an untruth stated by Senator Button—that Dr Hewson has said that people should be suspicious of people who do not have children; which is a total untruth—is a reflection on another parliamentarian, I am sure the Senate does.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Schacht

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order to the point of order. In view of Senator Walters's point of order, I just want to point out that in the Melbourne Age on 19 October, Dr Hewson is quoted as saying:

INTERJECT.PARA: You've got to be suspicious of a guy that doesn't drive and doesn't like kids and things like that.
That is what he said on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Concerning both points of order, if there has been a statement which honourable members of the Opposition consider wrong, they have the right to correct that at the appropriate time.
—It is not that it is wrong; it is a reflection.
—If it is a misrepresentation of the position, that happens to be a debating point.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Irrespective of whether you judge that the words used by Senator Button are true, untrue or a fantasy of his imagination, that is irrelevant to the point of order. What he said, true, false or otherwise, was a reflection on a person in another place and, as such, you should uphold the point of order and ask him to withdraw. The point of order spoken to by Senator Schacht should have been ruled out of order by you the moment he started to quote from a report in a newspaper in Melbourne. It had nothing to do with the point of order at hand.
—Order! We continually have points of order like this where people claim that others are misrepresenting them or the statements that they have made. There is a correct time for them to be dealt with.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order just so that everybody can understand. The point of order is this: we are not debating whether the question was supposed to be an accurate representation of words used; we are simply saying the words used by the Minister constituted a reflection on a member of another place. That is what you are being asked to rule upon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cooney

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I will just speak to the point of order taken by Senator Bishop. I refer you to standing order 198, which is continually ignored in this chamber. It says:

INTERJECT.PARA: If an objection is taken to a ruling or decision of the President, such objection must be taken at once and in writing. . .

What has happened continually in this chamber—and it has happened here now—is that people get up and take objection to a ruling or a decision and they do not take it in writing. It is time that this chamber started to enforce its own standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr President, it is a pity Senator Cooney did not bother to listen to the point of order that was being made, because it was not relevant to the point of order he made. The point I was raising was a separate point of order, which was that the Minister had reflected on a member of another place. I was saying that the ruling you had made was not a ruling on the point I raised. Therefore, I was not taking exception to your ruling at all. Therefore, Senator Cooney has missed the point. As for the perpetual clatter from the open-mouthed Senator Schacht, I think it would be better if he kept quiet.
—Order! This is not the first time this sort of point of order has been taken. Any misrepresentation can be taken to be a reflection on another member and can be corrected at a later time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, can I get this clear in relation to your ruling? Are you saying that standing order 193(3) no longer applies in this chamber? The wording of that is very clear. I refer you to it. It says, among other things:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on those Houses, members or officers shall be considered highly disorderly.
Are you saying that that standing order no longer applies?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I say something about the point of order? Senator Hill came in and quite clearly raised concern about the accuracy of what Senator Button said. That was the point of order he raised on which you ruled. All these people have been trying valiantly to rescue him from what they think is another mistake he has made. Let us get on with the debate and get rid of the point of order.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, particularly the one raised by Senator Kemp, just before I came into the chamber this morning I read the standing order he referred to. If any alleged misrepresentation were taken to be a reflection on another member, these points of order would be taken all day every day.
—So it does not apply?
—No, I did not say it does not apply at all.
—Tell us when it does?

—Day after day at Question Time Senator Hill comes in here and says, `You should not answer questions like this. We want to debate the issues'. If Opposition senators raise the issue today, I will debate it with them. But the moment I do, we hear, `Point of order, point of order, point of order'.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you whether Senator Schacht's interpretation of your ruling is accurate or not—that it applies only when we on this side make the statement?

—Speaking to the point of order, I want to make it quite clear that I did not say it applied to the Opposition. I said it should apply only to Senator Bishop, who is the biggest disrupting influence in the Senate chamber.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Because honourable senators have short memories, I might recapitulate for a minute. What the Prime Minister said—and he used a term about the Senate which was, let me say, colourful—was that the Senate was indulging in a political stunt. If there were ever any example of that, it is here today. The puppet master—Peter Reith, the honourable member for Flinders—comes in here and sits over there. He wants to see how his puppets behave in the Senate. He announces the composition of the committee of inquiry into the so-called loans business. The puppet master comes in to see how the puppets all behave.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill gets up and makes his impassioned speech. What is it about? It is about Opposition senators' thin skins. They have gone into the kitchen and they cannot stand the heat. They say they want to debate issues. They start the debate and, when things get a bit hot in the debate, they try to silence me by points of order. That is what their form is like. This is the Opposition, the alternative government of Australia.

The point I was making was simply this: the Prime Minister used words about members of the Liberal Party which were quoted by Senator Hill. They are views I happen to share about members of the Liberal Party. But he did not use words about the Australian people in the derogatory manner which their Leader in the House of Representatives uses all the time: renters are inferior people; the Catholic Welfare Commission is a group of whingers; people on welfare are basket cases; the chief executives in major companies in Australia are mollycoddled people.

I could go on and on and look at the words their Leader uses about the Australian people—people who do not drive cars, people who do not have children, and so on and so on. On he goes. No wonder the heavies in the Liberal Party have been meeting recently and having discussions about these sorts of things. They are trying to decide what to do about this man, their Leader, who has contempt for the Australian people. He has contempt for the ordinary Australian people—not contempt for members of the Liberal Party but contempt for ordinary Australians. That is the man they have as their Leader. So they will have a quiet chat over there and they will decide that he is too much in the limelight.

The limelight is on Dr Hewson and the people are seeing him for what he is—a cut-out cardboard figure. The Liberal Party has got to pull him out of the limelight and push some of its other people into the limelight so it will do better in the opinion polls and so on. It must get him out of the limelight because the people of Australia are beginning to wake up to what an amateur theatrical show the coalition is. It is led by a cut-out cardboard figure; it will have to push a few others into the limelight instead.

If I were producing the Liberals' show I do not know whether I would give that same sort of advice. Just look at the people they would push into the limelight as they withdrew Dr Hewson from that position. If they pushed the Deputy Leader into the limelight, people would say, `This is the Moscow Circus. Where did they get this bloke from? This is the Moscow Circus'. If they pushed John Howard into the limelight, people would say, `This is a puppet show. Where did you get this ventriloquist's puppet from?'. Wherever they turned to push people into the limelight, they would get the same sorts of answers. It is a very confused sort of show.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is your defence of the Prime Minister? I would laugh at it too.

—I was laughing at Mr Acting Deputy President. I am just making the point that, if one looks at the Opposition here in the Senate, one gets to understand what it is all about. Senator Baume, who has been interjecting a bit this morning, is shadow Minister for arts, heritage and sport. Would they push him into the limelight? He is the shadow Minister for arts, heritage and sport. He has asked 14 questions in this chamber this year—not one of them about arts, heritage or sport. All of them have been about people's personal characters; all of them have been smearing questions. Senator Baume does the work here for Dr Hewson. He is the shadow Minister for arts, heritage and sport. What good is he? There is Senator Alston. Of the 37 questions Senator Alston has asked here, nine have related to his own portfolio.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is, of course, on relevance. This is a censure of the Prime Minister. We have been sitting here for 25 minutes waiting for Senator Button to start a defence of the Prime Minister and he is yet to commence. He wants to talk about the role and responsibility of Opposition frontbenchers. That has nothing to do with the motion before the chamber. Can I suggest, respectfully, that you tell him to start his defence of the Prime Minister, if that is what he is on his feet for.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—There is no point of order. Senator Button is obviously moving to the point of discussing the office of Prime Minister. He is moving extremely slowly to that point. The other question of the institution of Parliament and the alleged contemptuous abuse of the Senate is a question which, I believe, he may well be addressing at the moment. Senator Button, I presume you are now moving to the question of the Prime Minister and the motion itself?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for that. Those opposite had better understand my essential point. We are in politics up here; it is a hard game, and one has to be tough. Those opposite cannot come here at Question Time day after day and say, `Oh, you should not answer that question like that; we want to debate these issues'. They launched this debate this morning and they are going to get the debate. Then the moment it starts, they want to run away from it. As the Acting Deputy President reminded us, the debate is about the role of a Prime Minister in this country. What I am saying is that we have a Prime Minister at the present time who, in truth, is colourful in his language about Liberal politicians; he denigrates Liberal politicians. In truth he—
—Nasty and vicious.

—`Nasty and vicious', says Senator Alston. He is pretty tough on you lot and denigrates Liberals, members of the coalition. That is bad luck for them. But what I am saying is: have a look at the alternative. Have a look at the alternative Prime Minister who would fulfil this role if those opposite were ever elected to government. The alternative Prime Minister is not bad at denigrating Labor politicians, although he tends to leave that to Mr Reith; and the really slimey bits he leaves to Senator Baume as his agent here. The fact of the matter is that he spends his time showing his contempt for the Australian people—again and again and again. Australian people are second-class people, in his view—lazy, basket weavers, whingeing, all these sorts of things.
—That is a Keatingism.

—No, it is a Hewsonism, old son. You had better learn it. Follow the leader; learn what your leader says about the Australian people—and no wonder you have worries about that particular problem. The Opposition gets on to saying, `We have a bit of a cardboard cut-out here in Hewson; we will have to pull him out of the limelight and raise our profile'.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I would ask you to ask Senator Button to refer to members on the other side by their proper titles.
—Yes, Senator Button, I uphold the point of order. You will refer, of course, to Dr Hewson.
—Thank you. I always try to refer to him as Dr Hewson; I am sorry. It was just that Senator Alston interjected, I think, and said `Keating does that', and I said `Hewson'.
—I said it was a Keatingism.
—A Keatingism and a Hewsonism. I hope I have not upset Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill says, `Have you got any notes there? When are you going to get to the subject matter?'. I have been talking about the subject matter all along. The subject matter of this debate is: `What a whinger you are, Senator Hill'. He gets up here with his nose out of joint because somebody referred to senators as `swill'. His nose is really out of joint about that, and he says that all Australians object to that. I think a lot of them love it. Senator Hill is speaking from the base of a party in opposition which can muster about 41 per cent of popular approval in this country, in most severe economic circumstances which they do not talk about. The Australian people are rightly concerned about those issues. Senator Hill mentioned it for a minute this morning. But what is the big issue in Senator Hill's mind? Not the economy. Not people being unemployed. It is that somebody got under his nose and offended his delicate sensibilities—his and Senator Snort's here. Those two went trotting off—
—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I know it is all a bit too much for Senator Button, but I must ask him to withdraw that one.
—Yes. I think Senator Button may have had an accident in terms of the word there. I presume he meant Senator Short.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, let me say that—
—Senator Button, you will withdraw that, of course. I presume you were referring to Senator Short?
—I was, yes. I beg your pardon.
—Yes, not Snort. `Senator Snort' is unparliamentary.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I might just go directly—
—Senator Button, you have withdrawn, have you?
—Yes, I did.
—You have three minutes to defend the Prime Minister.

—I have three minutes, I am told, to defend the Prime Minister. The fact of the matter is that this motion says that he has degraded the office of Prime Minister and the institution of Parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate. I say that that is a lot of rubbish. That is a lot of rubbish raised by a collection of thin-skinned professional oppositionists who will be there forever and who get very excited about the peripheral issues of politics rather than the major issues that confront this country. Only when an unemployment figure comes out do those opposite get excited—if it goes up. That is the only thing that excites these people, apart from the fact that occasionally they react to what they describe as `contemptuous abuse'.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to them that in the argy-bargy of politics people say all sorts of things about politicians. It is a difficult life, fellas. We say all sorts of things about each other in this place, and it is only the faint-hearted that are worried about these issues. It is genuine people who are worried about the issues of concern in this country, and I do not see any of those opposite in that category. If Senator Hill wants an answer to this problem, it is simply that we oppose the censure motion. It is ridiculous, it is childish, and it should be defeated by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support very strongly Senator Hill's motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating):

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for degrading the office of Prime Minister and the institution of Parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have sat and listened, as have my colleagues, for the last half hour waiting for the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the third most senior Minister in this Government, to defend the Prime Minister. Not one word of defence did we hear. I do not think I have ever heard a more pathetic, out of touch, sad response—obviously with no heart in it—by any Minister in this chamber in the time that I have been in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: When this debate started and, indeed, for the first 45 minutes of this debate, who on the Government side was here to listen to the debate in defence of the Prime Minister? There were four members of the Government; four senators were here. One of them was the Deputy President, Senator Colston, who I think was here in his capacity as Deputy President waiting to take the chair. One was Senator Foreman, who I think is here in his capacity as the Deputy Whip. One was Senator Cooney, who has a great penchant for sitting and snoozing here in the Senate waiting to make his profound and often worthwhile statements. That left one other, namely, Senator Button, who was here because he had to get up and try to put a few words together at some stage later in the debate.

In effect, not one person from the Government side was here seriously listening to arguably the most important debate we have had in this chamber for a long time. Senator Schacht wanders in and wanders out, but he is obviously pretty irrelevant to this scheme of things. Sure, a few more senators turned up once the muster whips were drawn, but even now, I point out to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, we have six members of the Government here. Fewer than one-fifth of the Government senators are here to participate in or even listen to a debate that goes to the core of the institutions of this nation, the core of the institution of which they, I would have hoped, would have been proud members. But no, they are not here because, with their Prime Minister, they have been parties for years and years and decades to the progressive debasement of the institutions of this nation, through a range of Labor governments and Labor Speakers.

I believe that is the saddest part and the most important part of today's debate. As Senator Hill's motion states, what the Prime Minister did in his statements today and yesterday was to continue a long, progressive, continuous line of debasement of the institutions of this nation and to show the contempt and arrogance that he has for the basic fabric of this nation. He has been doing it right through his political career. He has accelerated it in the period since he became Prime Minister. I point out that he does not have a mandate from the Australian people to be Prime Minister. He was elected by his mates as a result of a long and sustained coup which culminated in the political assassination of the former Prime Minister. He is not there as Prime Minister because he was elected by the Australian people to be Prime Minister, and I can assure him that he never will be. He will never be elected by the people of this nation to be Prime Minister in his own right.

Senator Button, in his pathetic speech today, started off by drawing attention to the fact that Senator Hill happened not to have mentioned a couple of words in quoting one of the sentences that formed the basis for this censure debate today. It is quite understandable that Senator Hill omitted those words, but Senator Button pointed out that Senator Hill had omitted the Prime Minister's words that this was a political stunt, referring to the establishment of the Senate select committee to inquire into the Australian Loan Council.

Do the Prime Minister or Senator Button really believe that it is a political stunt that the Senate is concerned about what is nothing less than a conspiracy between the Keating Government and the discredited former Labor Government in Victoria? Does he believe that it is a stunt that the Australian Government, the Federal Government, the Keating Government, has been involved in a cover-up in the form of deliberately misrepresenting and presenting misleading papers, documents and figures in the Budget, which is the premier economic document in the nation? Does he really believe that it is a stunt that the Senate wants to look at a series of events that have significantly eroded the confidence of the financial markets of this nation in the integrity, credibility, trust and confidence that those financial markets can place in the operations of government and those that they have elected to government?

Do the Prime Minister and Senator Button really believe that looking at those things constitutes political stunts? I think they probably do, because they are people who do not believe that integrity and credibility in government are necessary. They do not believe that a nation can function effectively, that the social fabric can survive, prosper and grow, only if the people of the nation feel that they have the trust and confidence of government and that they can put their trust and confidence in government. That is what this very important debate is all about.

The Prime Minister has expressed his hatred for the Senate through his actions over the years, particularly in the months since becoming Prime Minister, and in remarks such as those that he made yesterday in referring to one of the basic institutions of this nation, the Senate. I point out to the Prime Minister that, without the existence of that institution, there would never have been an Australian nation. It was only because there was agreement amongst the States to have a Senate that we had a federation in the first place, and he calls it an unrepresentative swill. That is because he has always hated it and the Labor Party has always hated it. For decades the Labor Party had in its platform the abolition of the Senate.

The Labor Party—we should make no bones about it—hates the Senate. The reason why the Labor Party hates the Senate is that the Senate can provide and does provide the checks and balances to curb the excesses of executive power that have been the hallmark of every Labor government we have had in this nation. If we had not had the Senate and the Australian Parliament, the excesses, the abuses, the wrongdoings, the total destruction of confidence in Australia that occurred under the Whitlam Government with the Khemlani affair would have continued. This nation would have been in the gravest danger of disintegrating. Here we have, in recent days, found again a situation where the government of the day—the Labor government of the day—has been shown simply to be incapable of managing money, incapable of being trusted with the nation's till.

Yet the Prime Minister wants to prevent the Senate, the only institution that can look at these matters and the broader issues of the whole functioning of financial institutions in Australia, from examining properly the most important public financial institution in Australia, the Australian Loan Council. The Senate would examine that Council with a view to improving it in the future, with a view to exposing the excesses of the past and the wrongdoings of the past so that we can get some trust and integrity restored to those institutions and can have confidence once again in our basic institutions.

Senator Button defended yesterday the Prime Minister's right to prevent that. Indeed, he supported the Prime Minister's view that the Senate was an unrepresentative chamber. If the Senate is an unrepresentative chamber, I wonder what Senator Button is doing in this place. What are all his colleagues on the other side of this chamber doing here if they believe that they are unrepresentative of the Australian people? I thought this chamber was democratically elected. I thought it was as democratic and as representative a chamber as any chamber in any parliament in Australia. I do not know of one in the Western world that is more representative or more democratic than this.

What absolute nonsense the Prime Minister is talking when he claims that we are unrepresentative. What absolute incredulity one has for the support by the Leader of the Government in the Senate for the Prime Minister, when he says that the chamber in which Senator Button is the Leader of the Government is unrepresentative. How on earth can Senator Button in any conscience stand here and remain in the Senate as the Leader of the Government if he believes that it is unrepresentative?

One of the other things the Prime Minister said yesterday in his debasing of the institution of the Parliament was that he would forbid any Minister in the House of Representatives to appear before a Senate committee of any kind while he was Prime Minister. He almost went into loop the loops over it. He almost had a heart attack about it. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would forbid him going to the Senate to account to this unrepresentative swill over there . . . There will be no House of Representatives Minister appearing before a Senate committee of any kind while ever I am Prime Minister, I can assure you.

There is no better example than that of the continuing arrogance and contempt of the Prime Minister for the institution of the Parliament. It also demonstrates an overweening ignorance of the simple procedures and processes of this Parliament, of which he has been a member for almost a quarter of a century. If he had the first idea or first knowledge of the procedures of the Senate, he would know that it is not his prerogative to determine whether a Minister of the House of Representatives appears before the Senate or not. It is all laid down very clearly in the Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: A committee of the Senate can invite any Minister to appear before a committee of the Senate. If a Minister in the House of Representatives refuses the invitation to appear, then under the Standing Orders of the Senate—standing order 178—the Senate can, by a message, request the permission of the House of Representatives for that Minister to appear. It is then a decision for the House of Representatives as to whether that Minister appears. It has nothing at all to do with the Prime Minister as Prime Minister; it is a matter for the democratic institution of the House of Representatives.

Yesterday, once again, the Prime Minister allowed that overweening arrogance to subsume the facts of the situation. Indeed, he did not do his homework very well, because there have been two Ministers of his own Government since he has been Prime Minister who have appeared before committees involving senators. Minister Baldwin appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on 6 March of this year; Minister Free appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in May of this year; and there have been Ministers in other years who have appeared as well.

The real reason why the Prime Minister mouthed the words that he did yesterday—his hatred and abuse, his denigration and debasing of the Senate—is that he fears the Senate. He did that because the Senate happens to have a mind of its own; because it is not prepared to be cowed by the bully boy, kneecapping threats and actions of a power drunk, foul-mouthed Prime Minister—a Prime Minister who throughout his whole political career has used threat and invective as his front line, a Prime Minister who has never been endorsed as Prime Minister by the electorate.

He fears the Senate because he wants to hide the Loan Council conspiracy between his Government and the former, discredited Victorian Government. He wants to continue to indulge in a cover-up because the basic problem with Labor is, as I said before, that it cannot be trusted with money and it does not want to have public exposure of that in any shape or form, even by the most democratically elected institutions and representative institutions of this nation.

The Prime Minister abuses his power, he overstates it and he is the best exponent that we have had in our political history, I believe, of gutter politics. Prime Minister Keating is surely the last man in Australia qualified to talk of others as swill. I do not know of any other politicians who, in their common, everyday parlance, when referring to political opponents, use such words as `sleazebags', `frauds', `cheats', `thugs', `brain damaged', `scumbags'. He is the man who uses those words. He is the man who is wanting to pass judgment on us and on this chamber.

Accountability is the cornerstone of the democratic and parliamentary process. This Prime Minister does not believe in accountability. He does not believe in normal democratic processes. He thinks he can say, `This is the way it will be' and that that is the end of it. The records of the Hansard and elsewhere are replete with some of his more arrogant statements. Only the day before yesterday he said in the House of Representatives:

SPEECH.PARA: You don't boss us around, pal; you get what we want to give you.

In 1988, when he was the Treasurer, he made the incredible statement that Question Time is a `courtesy extended to the House by the executive branch of government'. What Mr Keating has got absolutely inverted is the truth of the relationship between the Executive and the Parliament in this nation. The whole basis of parliamentary democracy is that the Parliament is the premier institution in this nation and that the Executive Government, whilst separate, is an integral part of the parliamentary process. That the House is dictated to by the `courtesy' extended to it by the executive branch of government is an absolutely incredible statement.

PARA.TAB: The simple truth is that the Prime Minister wants to get rid of the Senate. That would make life so much easier for him. That is why he is continuing to debase and denigrate the role of the Senate and of honourable senators of his own Party. It is typical of the actions he has taken throughout his political career. It demonstrates the arrogant contempt he has shown for Australian institutions—not just the Parliament but also the Constitution and some of our basic symbols, the Australian flag in particular—over the course of his prime ministership. They are excesses. They are debasements of the institutions of this nation and of the basic fabric of this nation. The Australian Parliament and the Australian people surely can no longer allow this arrogance and this contemptuous abuse of process to continue. For those reasons, the Opposition has moved the motion. It deserves the very strong support of the Senate because I believe it has the total support of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) said, it is a political stunt to divert attention from the basic issues that those on the other side ought to be discussing. One would have thought that the economy would be the number one issue they would be debating, instead of seeking the suspension of Standing Orders. But, of course, when they talk about the economy, they then have to explain the GST and industrial relations—things that are proving very unpalatable to the electorate once people understand what they mean. So the Opposition is seeking to find an opportunity in the Senate to carry a motion attacking the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) personally because it does not like his remarks about the Australian Senate.

PARA.TAB: I think that, in politics, if people cannot take a bit of heat, they should not be in the place. They should try to run a kindergarten club or go and play tiddlywinks or snakes and ladders. In the time I have been in the Senate, I have heard many honourable senators opposite bucket the present Prime Minister up hill and down dale, in this place and outside this place, in the most direct and blunt terms, using all sorts of abuse. The Prime Minister has copped it. He has never complained. He has just given it back. But when he gives it back, those opposite complain like a lot of squealing pigs.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the one with the pigs.
—No. He is actually investing in a productive enterprise, not like the member for Patrick Partners, who diddled shareholders in Australia—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Schacht, I believe that is an unfair reflection on the honourable senator. I ask you to withdraw that comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.
—Stop acting like a swine.
—Order! Senator Baume, I do not think that was very nice either. Would you withdraw that comment.
—I did not call him a swine. I suggested that he was acting like a swine. If it offends him, I will certainly withdraw.

—No, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not want Senator Baume to withdraw. In my five years in the Senate I have never asked anybody to withdraw anything that has been said about me. If I cannot take it, I should not be here. That is true. I have never asked anybody—
—Order!
—Mr Acting Deputy President, you have asked me to withdraw, and I withdraw.
—Yes, I am asking you to withdraw.

—Oh, he now has to withdraw! I did not ask him to withdraw. The only time I have asked anybody to withdraw was one night when Senator Crane was calling me Senator Short rather than Senator Schacht, despite my having tried five times to explain to him that I was Senator Schacht, not Senator Short, with the help of the person in the chair. The only time I have objected has been when I have been identified as Senator Short. In view of what he was saying, I think even Senator Short was objecting to being called Senator Schacht. That is the only time in my five years here that I have asked for a remark to be withdrawn, because I have always believed that, if people cannot take it in this place, they should not be here.

PARA.TAB: I want to say that it really is ironical that the Opposition should be complaining about a remark directed in general about the operation of the Senate—a political statement by the Prime Minister, quite obviously, about how he sees the Senate's performance or otherwise. But I must say it is extraordinary to complain about those words when we see the range of comments made by the present Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, over the last 12 months. I cannot think of any leader of a political party in the history of Australia who has attacked so many different people or interest groups in the most offensive way Dr Hewson has. I want to put a few of them on the record to remind honourable senators opposite just what their great Leader, Dr Hewson, has been going on about. For example, in Sydney on 30 July 1992, he says about even his own mates in the financial market:

SPEECH.PARA: I had lunch with a whole lot of them, they were very interested in my remarks and I think they've been far too myopic for far too long.
He has called his own mates in the financial market `myopic'. He talks about the greens and about environmentalists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strong language, that is.

—Well, that is just a start. We will just start with the lower ones and build up to some of the better ones, Senator Chapman. He says at their annual State Convention in Western Australia in July 1992 about the greens:

SPEECH.PARA: A few of the Green leaders and their mates, and some sympathetic leaders of the Aboriginal Heritage Movement.
That is all who are concerned about the environmental movement. He just dismisses green leaders and the Aboriginal heritage movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —No strong language there.

—Okay, Senator Chapman might say that is not a very strong remark, but it is just an attack on the Aboriginal heritage movement, on the green movement. Dr Hewson then says about Phillip Toyne, the former leader of the Australian Conservation Foundation, in February 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he's (Phillip Toyne) tried to paint it that I'm not interested in the environment, that I don't care—if you want to use the caring word—about the environment.

But I do, and I've spent an enormous amount of time on environmental issues. But I don't have to talk to Phillip Toyne to get the environmental policies right, or to strike an appropriate balance between development.

It's the fact that they've been so blatantly dishonest in the way they've represented green issues, and they have done a deal in the past with the Labor Government, to deliver preferences to the Labor Government. It is pointless talking to people that have their own personal or party political agendas.
So he says of the Australian Conservation Foundation, the green movement, that it is pointless to talk to them. He says they are `blatantly dishonest'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the abusive language?

—Well, `blatantly dishonest'. One cannot say `blatantly dishonest' here. If I said Senator Chapman was blatantly dishonest I would have to withdraw it. But Dr Hewson says it about Phillip Toyne. He says about the press gallery in Canberra:

SPEECH.PARA: They're out of touch as much as the Government is. Keating's only mates these days are in the Canberra Press Gallery.

Talk about sensitive—250 journalists and they are all mates of Paul Keating! To read what they have written about Paul Keating over the last several years, I must say they would all be astonished. Yet he says they are all mates of Paul Keating. Talk about sensitive feelings! He says this about the New South Wales Right:
We should not forget that the New South Wales Right is the nearest thing this country has had to the Mafia in decades.

He describes members of this Parliament, members of this chamber, as representing the Mafia. Now that is an astonishing statement. If that was said in this place, senators would probably object to being called members of the Mafia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson confirmed it.

—If I stood up and said, `the Liberal Party in South Australia has been part of the Mafia for several years' or a decade or so, Senator Chapman would be standing up whingeing and whining and asking me to withdraw it. But Dr Hewson just blithely lets these all go. Of course, he had a go at Mr Ray Groom, the Premier of Tasmania, because Mr Groom does not agree with the Opposition agenda about the APPM dispute in Tasmania. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I am surprised, quite frankly, that he (Ray Groom) hasn't given the company more support. . .

He lined up with the company against the workers. Mr Groom, a Liberal, former member of the House of Representatives, former Minister in the Fraser Government, actually went out and supported the workers in that dispute and immediately got bagged by this ideological zealot called Dr Hewson.

PARA.TAB: Then we get into the area of the business community, normally the natural constituency of the Liberal Party. This is from September 1991, about the business community:

SPEECH.PARA: And I am not just talking here about people that have become dependent on welfare and that is indeed part of the problem; but we have a welfare state mentality if you like that is spread across other parts of economy, to the business community for example.

He has just dismissed the business community as being part of the welfare mentality of Australia—and he wonders why large sections of the business community are not too happy with the Liberal Party when they get this sort of abuse.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no intemperate language there.
—I am just running through the long list of what Senator Chapman's Leader has put on the record—and he is complaining about one remark about the Senate.
—They have not got any friends under Labor.

—I must say that a lot of people in the business community were not too pleased to be bagged like that, as though they are part of the welfare mentality. `Welfare mentality' is not intemperate language? Go back and tell Mike Quinn at Mitsubishi Motors that he is part of the welfare mentality of Australia. Go and tell Ray Gregg of General Motors-Holden's in South Australia that he is part of the welfare mentality. They will give Senator Chapman a big drop-kick right out of the State. Of course, then Dr Hewson, on 18 March 1992 in Sydney, said:

SPEECH.PARA: And of course the business community is now dependent on government.

Go and tell the business community—John Prescott, John Ralph and these other senior leaders in the Australian business community—that they are dependent on government. They would be rather astonished and upset about those remarks, I am sure.

PARA.TAB: One of the pet hates, of course, of the Liberal Party is actually the organisations that represent the poor in the community. Listen to what Dr Hewson said about ACOSS. He actually said it to ACOSS at its congress, and I must say that I give him credit that he said it to their face; but it is still an astonishing remark. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: By concentrating on expanding and improving the provision of welfare, in one sense at least, ACOSS is just reinforcing the Biblical reminder that the poor are always with us.
That is an astonishingly insensitive remark about how he thinks the poor ought to be dealt with in Australia. On the same occasion he said:
If ACOSS was dedicated solely to tackling poverty and not, in addition, to boosting the welfare sector, this (the Opposition's reform package)—surely—would be a rather appealing package.
If ACOSS was examining the real issues rather than reacting in a conditioned knee-jerk fashion, the Coalition would seem like the best friend the poor are likely to have in this country.

It is a laughable comment. Finally, there are his comments to the Western Australian Liberal Party Annual State Convention. I have to say to Senator Chapman that the Western Australian Liberal Party Annual State Convention in July 1992 probably was the most appropriate branch of the Liberal Party to speak to. It is the most right wing in Australia, as a result of Senator Crichton-Browne's branch-stacking, arm-twisting, ballot-counting efforts. So one can speak roughly about the welfare lobby to the Western Australian branch. This is what he said:

You can go through the welfare industry—the same. You've got your mates, you've got your professional lobbyists; the professional basket weavers; the massive community that has been built up in the welfare bureaucracy—most of them are the winners.

I bet he got a big round of applause from Noel Crichton-Browne's right wing mates at the Western Australian State Conference. Then about the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, on 11 June 1991, he said:

Unfortunately, the bit of their report I've read it was a bit of carping, whingeing, negative assessment of a proposal in isolation whereas you have really got to look at that proposal in the context of the present system, the present system is a lousy system, most people agree with that. . .

When the Catholic Social Welfare Commission did not agree with that, he described it as carping, whingeing and negative. That is a pretty astonishing comment to make about one of the longest serving community groups dealing with welfare in Australia. He spoke about the ethnic community, about multiculturalism. About that he said:
All we do is elevate a few professional ethnics.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, just on relevance, Mr Acting Deputy President. The fact is that we are debating whether the Prime Minister has been, in a very adverse way, talking about this place; and the honourable senator is meant to be defending the Prime Minister. I would like you to bring him back to the point of the debate.
—Senator Schacht can defend the Prime Minister in any way he wishes. I do not believe there is a point of order.

—When he was bagging the ethnic leaders of Australia, that was again at Senator Noel Crichton-Browne's Liberal Party annual State convention in Western Australia and again would have got a big, rousing reception from that branch of the Liberal Party. On 18 June 1992, he said to the Castlemaine Club luncheon, about Australians:

SPEECH.PARA: In many senses we've become lazy, we've settled for second best . . .
To this extent, Australians are all lazy now, according to the Leader of the Opposition. These are the people that elect us as senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not elected. We are unrepresentative swill. That is the point.

—I can tell Senator Boswell that at least the Prime Minister does not go around bagging members of the public, Australians, as being lazy, as the Leader of the Opposition does. One of his favourite pet hates is Canberra. I do not know whether Senator Reid agrees with this remark, but he said in the Australian on 27 July 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: People who are close to animals do well in Canberra and probably working with animals will be good training for living and working in Canberra.

I did not see Senator Reid jumping up to ask Dr Hewson to withdraw that reflection on people living in Canberra—only about 300,000 people. So Dr Hewson has bagged all of Canberra. We then get to a couple of astonishing remarks he made about renters in Australia. On 31 August, addressing the Australian building industry, he said:
In any street, of course, it's always easy to tell the rented houses. They're the ones where the lawn isn't mowed, the plants aren't watered and the fences aren't fixed.
That is what he thinks about the 30 per cent of Australians who live in rented homes—an astonishing remark. He said about nurses:

In the health system the queues are getting longer and longer every day and look after the health bureaucracy and suddenly powerful nurses union leaders and so on, they're all part of the club if you like, but the rest are excluded.
