And the one thing that's struck me as I've gone around Australia quite consciously almost every day that Parliament isn't sitting, what has struck me most is that average Australians feel like we're outsiders in our own country.

He is the one who is the outsider, bagging every other Australian. He has called all Australians lazy. In one of the most insensitive remarks he has ever made, trying to be funny—Dr Hewson has a very warped sense of humour, but I did not hear anybody in the Opposition complaining about this remark—he said:
Go back to Whitlam. What was his greatest contribution to Australia? AIDS—Acquired Income Dependency Syndrome.

One of the great tragedies in international health is the AIDS plague, yet all we get out of Dr Hewson is a remark that this has to be related back to Gough Whitlam. I must say that I would not have thought those people who have, unfortunately, been afflicted with AIDS would have laughed much at having their illness—which is ultimately going to cost them their lives—made into a political joke. Where did he say that? Again it was at Senator Noel Crichton-Browne's Liberal Party convention on 25 July 1992. I must say for you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Senator Crichton-Browne really scored a big hit at that convention with a speech from John Hewson.

PARA.TAB: Every time he goes to speak to a Liberal Party convention, the Leader of the Opposition ends up putting his foot in it. I read out the quote from the WA convention. I have here a report of what he said recently to the New South Wales State convention:
Dr Hewson told the NSW Liberal conference on Saturday that Mr Carr could not compete with the new NSW Premier, Mr Fahey, who was a popular "knock-about sort of bloke".
"You've got to be suspicious of a guy that doesn't drive and doesn't like kids and things like that," Dr Hewson said.

SPEECH.PARA: There was such an outcry in the community about that personal remark against Mr Carr, the New South Wales Leader of the Opposition, that Dr Hewson had to make some sort of apology. As I understand it, the apology, made in a radio interview in Adelaide, was that he himself and his wife were also trying to have children.

PARA.TAB: In Australian politics, at any level, one should not be drawn down into talking about the personal details of one's family, even if one is trying to recover from a gaffe used to attack somebody else. Dr Hewson is quite willing, off the cuff, to smear somebody, to say that somebody is unAustralian or not a fit human being because he does not like children, or cannot have children, and does not drive a car. It was an astonishing comment to make. I did not hear anybody opposite in this place say, `That really is a dreadful personal reflection on another member of the Australian community who is in public life'.

We can compare that with what Mr Keating said about the Senate yesterday. He did not attack anybody personally. He made a comment about what he thinks of the Australian Senate. It was a political comment about an institution. People may disagree with it, they may dislike it, but he was not attacking anybody personally. In my view, he has very good reason, if he wants it, to attack any number of individuals in this chamber for their recent performances. Senator Bishop turns Estimate committees and public hearings of standing committees of the Parliament into a joke, a charade, to seek publicity. That is all her performances are about. Then in this chamber we have Senator Bishop and others smearing and using innuendo about the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations, hour after hour, not waiting for a proper inquiry to be conducted. All of that smearing goes on.

They are the sorts of things that bring the Senate into disrepute. The privileges of this chamber are being used to smear individuals, and people such as Senator Bishop in the Opposition are the greatest smearers. I notice that Senator Bishop has been given one of the three Opposition positions on the select committee to inquire into the Loan Council. The reason for that, which is all around the gallery, is that this will be a triumph. Senator Bishop can pound the table, stand up and shout, denigrate public servants and abuse them. Unfortunately, Senator Bishop believes that shouting and screaming as a publicity stunt are substitutes for intellect.

My old grandfather, who grew up on a farm in Victoria, used to say about people who did not have much intelligence that, if their brains were maggots, they could not get themselves flyblown. I think that really does apply to Senator Bishop in this case, because all she does is use stunts to substitute for intelligence and intellect.

Finally, let me talk about quotes. As I said before, to my recollection, apart from the time when I was called Senator Short, I have never objected or sought withdrawal when I have been attacked in this place. When Mr Chaney was Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, I was called a thug, an apparatchik, a standover merchant. I did not seek withdrawal of his remarks when, in one debate, he accused me of having no standards. I did not even object in this place or make a statement when Dr Hewson said, on 4 June 1992, in the House of Representatives, talking about my role in the pay television debate:

We have no better example of that than the way the pay television decision was taken. This was described in graphic detail by Senator `Shat' or Schacht. I am never quite sure how you say that but I will say Schacht because `Shat' is not very nice.

SPEECH.PARA: That is in Hansard. When I was asked by journalists the next day how I responded to that remark and whether I was upset, I just ignored it. If the Leader of the Opposition of Australia can make comments only in a scatological way, if that is the level of his humour, he is certainly not fit to be Prime Minister or even Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: That is the Leader of the Opposition those people have. All he can do is make a joke, as he has of other people's names and about mine. I did not object. Other people will make a judgment about his quality when the best he can do in a political comment is to try to mispronounce another politician's name. I accept the fact that I have inherited a difficult family name from five generations ago. I accept the fact that it can easily be mispronounced, but I think I have been around long enough in the Parliament that even Dr Hewson may have been able to know how to pronounce it properly. I have heard five-year-old kids mispronounce my name and think it is a bit of a joke—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about starting to defend the Prime Minister?

—My name has been confused with Senator Short's by one of his colleagues. That may have been an accident. All Dr Hewson could do when he was talking about my role in the pay TV debate was mispronounce my name deliberately and make some scatological joke about it. That is fine. All it does is prove to me that, while honourable senators opposite are ranting and raving about the remarks of the Prime Minister, I have never heard the Prime Minister get up and mispronounce somebody's name in this place or in the other place to try to make a political point like the Leader of the Opposition does in the House of Representatives.
—I have never heard our Leader refer to people as scumbags.
—Senator Short may not like the word `scumbag' but I do not know—
—What do you think of it?
—If I were called a scumbag I would have to take it on the chin, just as I took being called `Senator Shat' on the chin. I did not whinge and whine about it at the time. I was bemused by it.
—Presumably, that was an unintentional slur.

—It was not unintentional. If Senator Alston reads the Hansard of 4 June, he will see that it was a deliberate comment made by Dr Hewson in the pay TV debate. He got some stick the next day from the media about it. What I want to say in conclusion is that for the other side to be sensitive about a remark on the operation of this institution is absolutely extraordinary.
—It goes to the whole basis of the parliamentary institution, and you know it.

—It does not go to the whole basis of the institution. People have the right to say the Senate should not be in existence; that the Senate should be abolished. I certainly do not believe that the Senate should exist in its present form; that is absolutely correct. I do not believe it should have the power to thwart the legislation of the popularly elected House of Representatives.
—You would like a dictatorship.

—Senator Spindler from the Democrats says that he wants this system operating in the lower House so that he can have the balance of power and try to form some coalition of government, I suppose, with the majority party—that is what he is after. He is only here because in 1948 the then Minister for the Interior, Mr Calwell, introduced proportional representation. Until that time it was a first-past-the-post system where either one of the major parties had an overwhelming number.

PARA.TAB: I have to say to the Opposition that it is probably a system that it wishes it had, because after the last Senate result in the 1990 election it would have had about 50 members in the Senate. Under that system if the Opposition got into government at the next election it would have an overwhelming majority in the Senate to pass whatever it liked about the GST. So it is a fluke of the voting system introduced in 1948 that has given the balance of power to the Democrats. If they choose to change the voting system, they will get another result.

I want to conclude with Senator Short's remarks about a House of review and the establishment of the Senate. The House of review lasted all of about three years until the party system was established in Australia by about 1903. After that, this place has voted not as a States House but as a party House, even more so in many ways than the House of Representatives because we all get elected on party tickets. If people do not get endorsed on the party ticket they do not get elected, unless they end up like a senator here in the previous Parliament who, by a fluke of the PR system, got 1.5 per cent of the preference vote and everyone else's preferences. He fell in here for a year until they found out he was not eligible. That was a fluke of the PR system.

So do not go around telling me that this Senate is operating automatically as a House of review when it is a fluke of the voting system we chose as politicians to give ourselves. Do not go on saying that it is a House of review when nobody on either side will break the party discipline to vote against their party if it means their States being badly affected. We all toe the party line and we all know that if we do not, we do not get preselection, we do not get re-endorsed and, I suspect—

TALK.START.PARA: —Speak for the Labor Party.

—Senator Walters should not disgrace herself by saying that. Honourable senators opposite all voted to knock off the forestry Bill to allow a timber industry to be developed in Tasmania against the appeals of their own party, their own State government. Senator Walters voted with the Liberal Party in here; she stuck with the party room. She sold out Tasmania because she had to follow the discipline of the Federal Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: That is a clear example that this is no longer a House of review; it is a party House. If people are lucky enough to get the majority, they do what they like. If they do not have a majority, they do a deal with a minority party to get the legislation through. That is how it is done, so those opposite should not give us this amazing claptrap about a House of review. This is a party House once and for all. Therefore the bleating that comes from the other side about the Prime Minister is just hypocrisy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an amazing contribution by Senator Schacht but it completely missed the point. I think that what should be read into the Hansard at the moment is what we are genuinely debating at the moment, and that is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for degrading the office of Prime Minister and the institution of Parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate.

That motion has not been defended by any of the Government speakers. Certainly it was not addressed by Senator Schacht or by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. What the Government has attempted to do is bring the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) into the debate and not defend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Obviously the reason those opposite cannot defend the Prime Minister is that his statements are completely indefensible.

PARA.TAB: I have never in my lifetime complained about personal abuse. I think when one nominates for a political position it is part of the job. I have been called everything and it does not particularly worry me. I can take it on the chin as well as the next person. But this is not what the debate is all about today. This is about the Prime Minister of Australia, the man who is responsible for the institution of Parliament, attacking that institution. It is totally different, totally separate, from anyone making personal attacks.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one out there cares about it.

—I think there are a lot of people who do care. I think there are a lot of people who care about what the Prime Minister is all about. They care about the fact that a man who is leading this country is not representing their views and is attacking the institution of Parliament. The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the Treasurer wished to go there or not, I would forbid him going to the Senate to account to this unrepresentative swill over there. . .

That is clearly a statement by a man who is under tremendous pressure, a man who has lost it, a man who has to face an election in the next three months, who sees himself slowly ebbing out of office and sees the Government slowly disappearing before him as the opinion polls reflect that he is 9 per cent behind. He is a desperate man. He does not know whether to go to an election today or wait for three months. There is pressure on him from everywhere, wherever he goes. He may as well put himself out of his misery and go now and put the rest of Australia out of the misery that they have lived under for the last 10 years under the Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: When you examine what the Prime Minister is, if you take his rhetoric away, if you take out the insults, all you have left is a hollow man. He has virtually no depth. He has no quality. He has very little vision. He is a silk tie and an Italian suit dressing up a carcass. That is what the Prime Minister is all about: a silk tie, a $2,000 Italian suit, no vision, no quality and no depth. If you take his insults away, he has got nothing. He has traded on his ability to throw an insult around this Parliament and that is all the man has ever had, all the man ever will have. The people of Australia are getting sick and tired of continuous insults. The Prime Minister has developed it to an art form. He is the only man who has ever had a book of insults written about him.

That is what we have: a Prime Minister who can only insult. That is the only line he has. While he has insulted and while he has been on the bridge of government—even if he has not been the captain over the last 10 years, he has certainly been up there where the decisions have been made—what have we seen? We have seen a million people unemployed; the national debt rising to $148 billion; $15 billion of trade deficit every year—and promises that things are getting better, that we are just about to go round the corner, that there is a better future and that we just have to endure the pain a little longer. We have endured the pain for 10 years, and we have never seen any evidence of the gain. We have copped a lot of pain in this country, but we have never had any gain. All we have had is insults. This Prime Minister relies totally on his skill in insults. He has led the nation into misery. The only strength or talent he has developed is the talent to insult in every way. This is a very serious motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe that.

—I certainly do believe it. I believe that, when the leader of the country, who is in charge of the institution of Parliament, attacks that Parliament as `unelected swill' we have a massive problem. The people of Australia are very proud of their Parliament. They want the parliamentary institution to exist and they are sick and tired of these continual insults.

PARA.TAB: If the Prime Minister is genuine and wants to get rid of the Senate, then I challenge him to hold a referendum at the same time as the next election and to put the two questions together: `Do you want me to continue to be your Prime Minister?' and `Do you want a Senate?'. I challenge the Prime Minister to do that; I challenge him to put his money where his mouth is. Not only will the Prime Minister get kicked out of office, but the Australian people will want their Senate.

We ought to look at what brought on this debate, because it is very important. There is no doubt that the previous Victorian Government tried to circumvent the Loan Council. It tried to borrow over $1 billion more than its global limit. When the National Party Government in Queensland was quite open about it and said to the Prime Minister `We want to borrow more money to increase the State's assets and so forth', it was told in 1988 that legislation would be invoked against it. It was written into the Loan Bill that any money it borrowed in excess of its global limits would be taken off its grants; that went into a Bill. No-one argued against that. In fact, I believe it received the support of the Parliament.

Now we find that, in exactly the same circumstances, when the Labor Party Government circumvents its global limits and borrows over those limits, the Treasurer at the time does not even reprimand it—or, if he did, he did it very privately and it was never brought to the attention of this Parliament. That is what this Senate is all about. I will read into Hansard something that Senator Gareth Evans said in 1982:

SPEECH.PARA: The job of the parliamentary committee confronting the Executive is not to become an alternative government, but rather it is to probe, enlighten, deter and squeeze to make it as difficult as possible for ministerial and administrative misbehaviour, neglect or maladministration to be pushed under the carpet and to create a political environment in which even the most thick-skinned Minister or official will feel the heat.
That is Senator Evans's quote. Odgers says:

The Senate's committee system is a major development in the strengthening of the Australian parliamentary system of Government. In particular, the committee system furthers the effectiveness of the Senate's role as a House of review.
No modern legislature can discharge its functions fully and effectively without the assistance of committees.

They are comments from one of the Government's leading frontbenchers, a very senior Minister, and from Odgers, who is considered an authority on Parliament. When we use that parliamentary system of committees, we are accused of getting into political stunts. There is no political stunt about this. Obviously, the Senate is going ahead with this Committee. Already on this side we have put forward our nominations for the Committee, and it is going to try to unravel why, on the one hand, in 1988 the government of the day reprimanded the National Party Government and, on the other hand, in 1992 the same Government, with the Prime Minister at the helm, condoned the abuse of going over the global limits.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who did you nominate for the Committee, Ron?
—Let us get this straight on the record. The nomination of the Committee was a joint nomination. It was a

SPEECH.PARA: joint nomination between Senator Hill and myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was your nominee?
—I did not nominate anyone. I nominated three people. It was a joint nomination and the nomination went with Senator Hill and myself and we put in a joint nomination.
—Who was the Leader of the National Party's nomination? Tell us that.
—I was the Leader of the National Party and I nominated the three people who are on the Committee, jointly with Senator Hill.
—You were entitled to nominate only one. Who was it? Tell us that. Come on; come clean.
—Certainly I will come clean. The nominations were Senator Short, Senator Alston and Senator Bishop.
—Who was yours? Come clean.

—Look, you know, you are very thick, Senator Faulkner. If Senator Faulkner cannot understand that one letter went in nominating three people with two signatures on it, then he does not deserve to be there. Mr Acting Deputy President, what we are debating now is why the Prime Minister of Australia called this institution of Parliament `unrepresentative swill'. `Swill', as defined in the dictionary, is `liquid refuse and pig food'. If that is what the Prime Minister is calling this institution, this Senate, then I certainly object to that. I do not object personally. He can call me that, if he likes; he will not worry me. But if he calls the institution, the Senate, in those terms, if he nominates it in those terms, then he deserves to be censured. He deserves the highest reprimand this Parliament can give to him. I would, therefore, support the censure motion. It deserves to be carried. In fact, it deserves to be carried unanimously at the highest level.

—I rise to support the motion, but as amended by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter. There is a considerable difference, I believe, between the `pig-swill' term about which the outrage is fulminating and the `unrepresentative' accusation that the Prime Minister has levelled at the Senate. I am very much less concerned by the abuse he has levelled against the Senate, as he is wont to do and has done on many occasions. I believe that it does not reflect on the Senate; it reflects on the person that makes that sort of remark.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of regret that our Prime Minister, the leader of the Australian Government, sees fit to allow debate in the Australian Parliament to descend to such levels. He should lead the way, as indeed should the Leader of the Opposition, to talk on issues and to debate issues such as the one million unemployed and the current tariff policy of the Government and the Opposition, which is aiding and abetting further increases in unemployment. I would like to address my remarks more to the `unrepresentative' content than the `pig-swill' which, as I said, reflects on the Prime Minister rather than on the senators in this chamber.

It has already been stated quite clearly by Senator Coulter that quite obviously this chamber is much more representative of electors than the House of Representatives. I shall not repeat the figures. I would rather address the consequences—what happens when, in a two-chamber situation, we do not have a second chamber that can act as a check on government, that can act as a House of review. We currently have that situation in Victoria, where Mr Kennett, of all people, now has control of both Houses.

Perhaps understandably, the people of Victoria wanted to punish the previous Labor Government for some of its mismanagement. But in their haste, I believe, they have disregarded the danger that lies in handing to the executive government of the day total power over both Houses. As a result, we have the sorts of things that have happened in the first 30 days of the Kennett Government, which I believe will come back to haunt that Government and the community as a whole. They will be a salutary reminder of the position at Federal level and the need for the Senate, as a House of review, and yes, the need for the Democrats in that House of review, to actually provide a check on the executive government of the day.

Let us look at the record of the Kennett Government. Perhaps its latest action, although it has received relatively little publicity, is one of its most reprehensible. It strikes at the very root of development of just government in this country. I refer to the abolition of the Victorian Law Reform Commission, a body that has consistently provided substantial and valuable reports on how the law in this country, particularly in Victoria, should be reformed. I wonder whether it is a coincidence that one of the principles that were being pursued by Mr Kelly, the Chairman of the Law Reform Commission, was reform of the legal profession itself. He was pointing out that the profession, as it is currently organised, serves its own more than it serves the community. Some of the reforms that were going to be instituted, which were recommended by the Victorian Law Reform Commission, went a long way towards breaking the position of privilege that the legal profession, over the decades, has been able to wangle unto itself.

There is more, of course. We have the notorious provisions of the Kennett Government abolishing penalty rates and leave loadings right across the board. I wish to put on record that the Democrats are prepared to concede that there may be a case in some industries, in some areas, to review penalty provisions and to review leave loadings. There may be very good reasons why some of these awards should be amended to reduce or even exclude them. In particular, I put forward the view that holiday loadings could well be abolished for people who earn incomes well above average weekly earnings. But I take strong objection, on both humanitarian and social grounds as well as on economic grounds, to abolishing leave loadings for people on average weekly earnings or below. We all know that those people are essentially on the breadline, only just making ends meet, cannot take their children on a holiday because they have still got to meet their commitments—commitments to pay mortgage interest, the school fees, or whatever else they have. They are really not in a position to take their families on holidays. I believe they should have that opportunity.

If the Government had said `Let's review holiday pay loadings above average weekly earnings', the Australian Democrats would have lent a sympathetic ear and looked at each case, in each award. But we find leave loadings being abolished across the whole field, across the whole range of awards. What will happen, of course, is that we will have reduced travel; we will have reduced holiday expenditure; the tourism industry in Victoria will suffer; and economic recovery will be put off by yet another year or more.

Let me also address the industrial relations legislation in general terms, and in particular penalty rates. Again, there may well be industries—and the hospitality industry is possibly one of those—where penalty rates should be reviewed, where we should look at the effect they have not only on the people working in that particular industry but also on the economy as a whole. There may be a case to review them.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance. I really find it very difficult to draw any relationship between Senator Spindler's remarks and the motion we are debating, so I rise on an issue of relevance. I think there is no relevance in Senator Spindler's remarks.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President, I believe Senator Spindler's remarks are entirely relevant. If Senator Short had not been wandering around the chamber and had actually been listening to what Senator Spindler is saying, he would have realised that the point Senator Spindler is making is very relevant. It is simply that when both Houses of the Parliament are controlled by the one party, the people of that State or the people who are governed by that government are in grave danger of not having proper review. That goes very much to this question of unrepresentativeness in the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What Senator Spindler has been saying is absolutely relevant.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I cannot uphold the point of order. I believe that Senator Spindler is entitled to speak to both the motion and the amendment. Certainly, the amendment gives him adequate scope to traverse everything that he has traversed so far. As Senator Coulter particularly pointed out, lack of representativeness does in fact open up the avenue for a fair degree of straying from the original motion moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I shall develop the point a little further. We do see, of course, the actions of the Kennett Government. Quite appallingly, combined with all the cuts it is visiting upon people who are on low wages—people who are struggling to make ends meet—it has seen fit to increase ministerial salaries by amounts ranging from $8,000 to $21,000. I am not sure about the latter figure, but it does not matter. The very action—the very arrogance, the disregard for the social well-being of the community it is now charged to represent—of voting that for themselves within days of coming into government is absolutely breathtaking in its arrogance.

PARA.TAB: I believe that that too will be visited on that Government, as I suspect it will on the Opposition, which is trying to put itself into the same position as Mr Kennett is in now in Victoria. We have on record, in a very informed article by Mr David O'Reilly in a recent issue of the Bulletin, stated quite clearly and documented, that it is the aim of Dr Hewson to obtain control of both Houses. Clearly, he would love to be in the position Mr Kennett is in now. I suspect that, even if Dr Hewson manages to get into government, he will still, unfortunately, have to face a Senate where the position of the Australian Democrats will be confirmed by the electorate at the next election. I am sure that people in the community, when they look at how they are going to vote and how they may differentiate in their vote between the lower House and the Senate, will look at who will be able to make sure that they will not be subjected to a 15 per cent consumption tax on everything they buy.

It is quite clear that the Australian Labor Party, if it is not in government, will not have sufficient numbers to make sure that the Senate stops that sort of regressive tax, which will hit poor people more than anyone else. So it will have to be the Democrats. It is quite clear that people in the community will have to decide, if they want to make sure that they are not going to be subjected to that additional tax or that additional load at a time of recession, when they are struggling to make ends meet, that the Australian Democrats should retain their position of holding the balance of power in the Senate.

In closing, I would like to advert briefly to some of the similarities between the program Mr Kennett is initiating in Victoria at the moment and the Fightback package that Dr Hewson has elevated to the status of the Bible in his bid for total control over both Houses of Parliament. Since we were talking before about access to the legal system and about the abolition of the Victorian Law Reform Commission, which I believe is a barbaric act, let me refer briefly to one or two of the points that are on public record in Fightback as to how the Opposition is going to pay for some of the goodies, or the abolition of some taxes, which it holds out for Australian industry generally and which, I submit, are not going to go anywhere near making us a more competitive nation in world trade terms.

One of the things the Opposition is saying it will abolish or reduce is legal aid. Legal aid, which provides for people who cannot normally afford to pay the exorbitant fees that many of our lawyers charge, is going to be reduced by $10m. We now have a situation where some 50 per cent of applications for legal aid are rejected—some of those for relevance but most because funds are inadequate. The criteria being used have been progressively tightened. What we have in Fightback is a further reduction of $10m. Where are we going? Are we going to reject 60 per cent or 70 per cent of applications for legal aid? Are we going to leave people unrepresented?

That is not where it stops. If Fightback is ever implemented, we will be coming into a regime where greed will be elevated to the new religion. It will be the new incentive to work. It is quite clear that, when you set people against each other, when you have a community where people fight against each other, you increase family breakdown and you increase crime. Only last year we heard that our prison population had risen by 10 per cent due to the recession.

We now hear that the Opposition parties do not wish to know what sort of consequences their policies would engender, so they suggest we abolish the Institute of Criminology. We do not want to hear what the causes of crime and the rising crime rates in our country are. We do not want to examine what we should do; we just get rid of things. We close our eyes and ears. In the same way, the Opposition parties voted against my attempt to establish a Senate inquiry into tariffs and industry development. They said that people did not want to hear what sorts of effects the tariff regime—down to zero tariff, according to Dr Hewson—would have on our community.

That is not where it ends. Foreign aid is going to be reduced over two years by $209m. I thought this was a reasonably civilised nation. I thought that, despite the recession, it was also a nation that was reasonably well off. Certainly it is compared with Somalia and other nations on the African continent and in other parts of the world where children are starving. I want to put on record that the Opposition's wish to reduce foreign aid by $209m is an act of sheer barbarism.

That is not where it ends either. In Medicare we will have reductions in rebates and tightening up of bulkbilling of $213m. The Opposition will abolish public housing. Why can people not go and buy their own homes? Why can they not have a terrace house in Balmain, Parramatta or Toorak? Why can they not do that? Why do they need public housing? That is what the Opposition is asking. The Opposition will abolish public housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with the censure motion?

—I say to Senator Panizza that it has a lot to do with it. I am pointing out what the Australian community will have to put up with if the Democrats are not in this chamber. This chamber can only have the Democrats in it because it is more representative than the Prime Minister has claimed.
—It's still got nothing to do with the censure motion.

—It has a lot to do with the censure motion because we are claiming that if we fall prey to the notion that we should have a second chamber elected in a way similar to the way in which the lower chamber is elected, we will sooner or later hand control over both Houses to the executive government of the day. Senator Panizza might like that if Dr Hewson were the Prime Minister; I wonder whether Senator Panizza would enjoy it if the boot were on the other foot, if the Labor Party were in control of both Houses. I suspect that he would not enjoy it. I certainly would not and I believe the community would not. I believe that this chamber, because it is elected on a representative franchise, has the opportunity to fulfil the function of being the House of review and, more than that, of protecting people from the excesses of government, as it has done in the past and as it will do in the future when at the next election the electorate confirms the position of the Australian Democrats in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister's frustration is obvious. He would like to have control of both Houses. I think it is fortunate that he does not. It is also fortunate that whichever executive government will be in place after the next election will have to face this chamber, because it is elected on a more representative basis than the lower House, as a check on its excesses. The Australian Democrats in the Senate will protect the Australian community from any excesses that a Hewson Government may wish to visit upon the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far from being irrelevant, I think Senator Spindler's speech was perhaps the most relevant that has been made here today. What he has brought out is that if the Opposition joins, as it will, with the Democrats to support this motion, then the Senate as it is now constituted is the body that deserves the premier place in the institution of Parliament. In that case, if the Opposition were ever to get to government and the Democrats were ever to vote with the Labor Party to obstruct legislation, today should be quoted again and again to prove and to show that the Opposition is very much in favour of the Senate being the superior body.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short berated the Government for not being present during the debate. I note that the Opposition benches at the moment consist of Senator Reid, the Whip—a great Whip, too; Senator Ferguson, who has come in to adorn this place; the redoubtable Senator Bishop; and nobody else.

The case for the Government—and this is why I will be voting against the motion—is this: the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has not degraded his own office and he has not degraded the institution of parliament. A case that he has done so has not been made out. The only case that has been made out is that people opposite and the Democrats do not like Paul Keating and they do not like the language he uses. Why do they not say that? The Senate has not been degraded. Words may have been used such as `insulted' or a `reflection upon it' but the Senate has not been degraded. It still has as much capacity, as much strength, as it had yesterday; it is still as powerful; it still has as much respect in the community as it had before. Simply to say that it has been degraded is nonsense. What might have been said is perhaps that the Prime Minister should not have used the word, perhaps that he has `reflected upon' the Senate, perhaps that he has `insulted' the Senate, but how has he `degraded' it? Of course he has not degraded it. It is nonsense to suggest that he has.

The other point I want to make is one that has been made all morning by people on this side. This is the defence. The term `unrepresentative swill' is certainly not a term of flattery. It is certainly not a term that we would use; it is certainly not a term that we would approve of. But—this is the point—in the Senate, again and again we have allowed a course of conduct to occur where there have been disruptions, challenges to the Chair and most abusive language across the chamber. We have allowed that conduct to continue; we have allowed that conduct to progress. Suddenly, in the middle of that flow, we say that because somebody uses the words `unrepresentative swill' about us, we will now censure that person.

Why do we allow this to occur? Why do we allow ourselves to be put into a situation where we get up and give ourselves, in effect, a character reference? That is what this is: it is a character reference for the Senate, given by the Senate for the Senate on behalf of the Senate, when we ought to be looking to other people to give us character references rather than giving ourselves one. In any event, even if we do that, why do we allow this chamber to be disrupted again and again, abused again and again? Why do we allow such language to be used across the chamber from both sides but then, when somebody outside the chamber uses the phrase `unrepresentative swill', spend hours and hours debating it and attempt to censure him?

Why do not we censure people when they disrupt the chamber? We all sit here, cop it, take it. We cop all that but as soon as somebody else outside, who cannot be here to defend himself, says something we get very upset. I would like people this afternoon, if disruption occurs in this chamber, to take the strong position that they are apparently taking now. When, during Senator Button's speech this morning, there was disruption in this chamber, we allowed it to occur.

All I say is: why do we allow conduct to occur whereby this chamber, by its own actions, is brought into disrepute? Why do we let that happen and yet try to stop a course, a culture, a flow that has occurred until now in terms of one particular incident? I simply say that we, as a chamber, appear hypocritical, weak and unable to conduct our own affairs in this chamber in the proper fashion when we have to choose somebody from outside the chamber to condemn because he has, on one occasion, used the words `unrepresentative swill'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to Senator Cooney—and honourable senators could be forgiven for not being in the chamber to listen to Senator Cooney, because he really was not addressing the motion at all—I would remind the chamber of the precise wording of the motion. It is:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister for degrading the office of Prime Minister and the institution of Parliament in his contemptuous abuse of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would refer the Senate to the Constitution. Clause 1 of the Constitution says:

The legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in a Federal Parliament, which shall consist of the Queen, a Senate, and a House of Representatives, and which is herein-after called `The Parliament,' or `The Parliament of the Commonwealth'.

In other words, the Parliament is composed of both Houses together with the head of state, and it is the entire Parliament which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has brought into disrepute by his abuse of calling the Senate `unrepresentative swill'.

PARA.TAB: I think plenty of senators have dealt with their distaste for the word `swill', but the implication that somehow the members of this chamber are not representative of the people is quite frankly historically incorrect and factually inaccurate, and again displays the lack of knowledge of Australian history which this Prime Minister has. I refer him again to the Constitution, and to section 7, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting, until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate.

If one chooses, because one has a respect for history, one would go back, as I would recommend to the Prime Minister, and read the eminent writings of Quick and Garran. Indeed, if one chose, one would see that the learned writings from 1901 remain constant, are the definitive work on our Constitution and, indeed, were endorsed by Professor Geoffrey Sawyer as late as 1976. I think some of the quotes from Quick and Garran are very relevant to just how representative and how important the Senate is in our system of government, our system of constitutional democracy. I read from page 414 of Quick and Garran, the section dealing with the Senate:

The Senate is one of the most conspicuous, and unquestionably the most important, of all the federal features of the Constitution, using the word federal in the sense of linking together and uniting a number of co-equal political communities under a common system of government.

In other words, the Senate is fundamental and integral to our system of government, which in turn has given us an unprecedented set of liberties and of protections for individual rights and which, quite frankly, makes us the oldest constitutional democracy in the world, when one counts universal suffrage and the participation of women. I am pretty proud of that. That makes Australia a pacesetter. We do not have to copy anybody. We led the way. Again, I will read from Quick and Garran:
The senators for a State are to be chosen by those of `The People of the State possessed of the qualifications prescribed. . . This provision marks a great advance in a democratic direction.
Then it goes on to say:

The principle of popular election, on which the Senate of the Commonwealth is founded, is more in harmony with the progressive instincts and tendencies of the times than those according to which the Senate of the United States and the Senate of Canada are called into existence. In the Convention which drafted the Constitution of the Commonwealth not a single member was found in favour of a nominated Senate.

Right from the beginning, our founding fathers said that we were to be elected by and responsible to the people. We were at the cutting edge of making democracy more responsible. Indeed, in the judgment that came down in the ad bans legislation case the other day, when this Government in power tried to curtail the freedom of speech, the High Court said that representative and responsible government was, in fact, enshrined in our Constitution and our freedoms could not be taken away.

PARA.TAB: In this chamber, in this House, we have on many occasions protected those freedoms. It was this chamber that stopped the Australia Card coming into existence. It is in this chamber that we scrutinise and make sure that there is no cosying up between Executive and bureaucracy such as we have seen occur in Western Australia. In that report brought down by the Western Australian commissioners into Western Australia Inc. we have seen them say that it only occurred because there was not sufficient scrutiny.

Our founding fathers said about this chamber that we were to have powers, we were to be based on a House that was to be powerful and we were to exercise those powers in a responsible way. But because we were to be representative of the people, that means that those powers we carry out are in fact for and on behalf of the people. Unrepresentative, Mr Prime Minister? I think not.

I think the Prime Minister could well find that his appreciation of Australian nationhood, the Australian identity and the symbols of the Australian people would be understood by him if he perhaps undertook a course in study of this great Australian nation. Who else but an ill-informed man, a man who had not bothered to inform himself, would denigrate our Parliament in the way he has done? Who else would go to a foreign land and denigrate our flag? Who else would say, as he did the other day, that he had to lie to the Australian people by omitting the financial particulars of the State of Victoria's borrowings because otherwise he would upset the markets? He had to lie to the Australian people in their interests. That is truly the most corrupt of all statements.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! I think some of those descriptions of `lying' and `corrupt' are unparliamentary. If the Prime Minister did say, `I lied', to the Australian people and that was a direct quote, obviously, that would be acceptable. I understand the word `corruption' was your interposition, so would you mind removing those words.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the word `corruption' was applicable to what one does to a market when one does not give it correct information. If one tells lies or gives misinformation to the market, the market becomes corrupt. That is what I am saying.
—You are referring to a corrupt market.

—I am referring to a corrupt market, I am referring to the corruption in Western Australia and I am referring to the fact that the defence of omitting from the Budget papers all reference to the $1.3m overborrowing outside the Loan Council agreement was, in fact, a deliberate act which led to the corruption of the market.
—I will read your speech with interest later. For the moment your explanation is acceptable.
—You're the only one who will read it.

—To the contrary; I put it to Senator Faulkner, if he too could enjoy reading the history of this country and showed pride in this country and the people who have forged and formed a great nation of which we are the inheritors, he too would serve the people of New South Wales better.

PARA.TAB: I will refer now to a couple of points that were made earlier in the day by Senator Coulter. He said that he felt we should have reference in our motion to the fact that no single political party could have a majority within the Senate. I find those words are difficult to accede to for the following reason. Very simply, that would be circumscribing the right of the Australian people to elect whom they will. If the Australian people decide that they wish to elect senators who form a majority of one party, that is the will of the people. There is no way in the world that I could ever countenance a restriction on the will of the people to elect whom they will. I think that some of Senator Coulter's earlier remarks were intending to do that.

I will go back to Quick and Garran and go back to that point about `unrepresentative'. I think I have shown that our founding fathers very strongly set out to make sure that this chamber was truly representative of the people and was elected directly by the people, and that not one voice dissented from the concept that it should be truly democratically elected. Quick and Garran talks about the functions of this House. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: As we have already seen, the functions of the Senate are of a double kind: first as a chamber of revision and review in matters of general legislation; and, secondly, as a chamber to represent the particular views, opinions, and interests of the States, in matters admittedly within the sphere of the federal authority but respecting which differences might arise, as well as for the purpose of resisting proposals not within the sphere of the federal authority. For the purpose of exercising powers such as these it was contended, with unanswerable force, that the Senate of the Commonwealth could and should be chosen by the process of popular election, and that there was no occasion to vest the choice in the State legislatures.

In other words, our founding fathers said that, if we were truly to exercise the powers that were to be given to us in our Constitution, adopted by the people of Australia, we must be elected by the people of this country—by popular election. They are truly the foundations of democracy. I would say to the Prime Minister: is that unrepresentative? I would again ask him to reflect upon the history and the facts of the way our system of governance is put together.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the sorts of issues we might discuss with regard to the States' particular concerns, we find that a very good example will be coming up soon. That is the way in which the Medicare money is to be paid to various State governments and the abuse of section 96 to contrive a socialisation of medicine in the way the current policy is desirous of doing. In other words, it is penalising States that have a larger percentage of self-insured people, to the benefit of those States that do not. It is attempting to reward States that encourage people not to self-insure. This is truly an abuse of the system. It is a question we will debate in this chamber because it is relevant to the quality, equal opportunity and rights of the people of New South Wales, in the case of my State, to have their voice heard, to be truly treated fairly by the Federal Government and not to have an abuse of the section 96 powers.

When the Prime Minister decided that he could with impunity debase and degrade his own office by his own behaviour and, as well, try to bring into disrepute this institution of the Senate, all Australians should truly have been affronted. It is only our system of governance, it is only our respect for our institutions, that at the end of the day ensure that we remain a free nation. We have seen many examples of totalitarian states which purport to have a constitution but which give the people no freedom at all. It is the institutions that hold up and protect that precious commodity of democratic freedom. So, when we say that we are today censuring the Prime Minister for his behaviour, it is because we are upholding not only our Constitution but also the institutions that make it valid and that protect the rights of the people.

It is a sad and sorry day when we see that we have a Prime Minister who is unable to appreciate the preciousness, the worth and the value of our having spent nearly 100 years exercising that freedom and making our laws in accordance with that. I will conclude with the words of Sir Henry Parkes, speaking in the Convention debates:

SPEECH.PARA: What I mean is an upper chamber, call it what you may, which shall have within itself the only conservatism possible in a democracy—the conservatism of maturity of judgment, of distinction of service, of length of experience, and weight of character—which are the only qualities we can expect to collect and bring into one body in a community young and inexperienced as Australia.

Young and inexperienced we may well have been then, but Sir Henry Parkes gave us a fine tradition to live up to, and I for one cannot bear the thought that we have a Prime Minister who wishes to bring it into disrepute.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! At 12.45 p.m., under sessional order, the Senate normally proceeds to matters of public interest. Senator Hill's motion, however, provides that the censure motion takes precedence over all other business until determined. The Senate has two options: to continue with this motion until it is determined, or adjourn the debate on the motion by leave and resume it at a later hour or another time determined by the Senate. It is my understanding that the Senate wishes to continue with this, at least for some time, and that there will be no determination of the issue during the period 1 o'clock to 2 o'clock.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion. I am interested to follow in this debate that most bombastic and self-important contribution from Senator Bishop. I am used to hypocrisy from Opposition senators but in terms of both sanctimony and hypocrisy that really does take the cake. Of course, what the Senate is used for by the Opposition is a forum for absolutely baseless smear and innuendo. It is done in the quest for power of the Opposition. There are a couple of senators in this chamber who have become expert at it. In Senator Bishop's case, she probably takes the cake.

PARA.TAB: It is this chamber, and the committees of this chamber, that have been used for the shameless and baseless attack on Mr Boucher, without any opportunity at all for him to respond. It is typical of the sorts of attacks that have been launched by Opposition senators using this chamber as the vehicle. Of course, when there is any questioning at all—the slightest question—about the probity of those inquisitors, they run for cover. But there is no similar sensitivity to the rights of the defenceless public servants who come before committees, those who do not have the opportunity to protect their good names. That is what the Senate is all about and that is why, I assume, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has attacked the way this chamber operates. Of course, the processes of the Senate end up in a log-jam such as we have had this morning. This will be used as an excuse later in the year when the Government tries to see some of its legislative program enacted. There will be no suggestion at all that these sorts of techniques and this sort of strategy on the part of the Opposition will be responsible when the Government needs to get some of its legislative program through.

What the Prime Minister has said about the unrepresentativeness of this Senate is true. It is categorically true. If one looks at the number of electors in each State represented by 12 senators in this chamber, the State that I represent, New South Wales, has 3,837,326 enrolled electors represented by 12 senators. In the State of Tasmania—I will use your State, given that you are in the chair, Mr Acting Deputy President—there are 317,168 enrolled electors represented by 12 senators. The quota for the half-Senate election in 1990 in New South Wales was 476,878. In Tasmania it was 41,614. So your vote, Mr Acting Deputy President, was 12 times more valuable than my vote as an elector enrolled in New South Wales. If that is not unrepresentative I do not know what is. It is proof positive that this chamber is unrepresentative. I am not ashamed to say that I support the principle of one vote one value and that this chamber is totally unrepresentative. I would support any reforms to this chamber to see a more representative parliament established. I am more than happy to give my support to any member of the Government or the Prime Minister if that is their desire.

Let us not forget that in this Parliament and in our political system there are often vigorous attacks on others. On this particular occasion the Prime Minister has made what some consider a vigorous attack on honourable senators or the Senate. So what? We are all in Parliament and able to defend ourselves. Is it any worse or any more vigorous than what Dr Hewson said about renters, people who do not have the right to defend themselves? He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: In any street, of course, it's always easy to tell the rented houses. They're the ones where the lawn isn't mowed, the plants aren't watered and the fences aren't fixed.
Is it any more vigorous than that? Is it any more vigorous than what Dr Hewson said about the Leader of the Labor Party in New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr? He said:

PARA.TAB: You've got to be suspicious of a guy that doesn't drive and doesn't like kids and things like that.

SPEECH.PARA: He continued:
When he's up against a full-blooded Australian like John Fahey, he has not got a hope.
Is it any more vigorous than that? Bob Carr is not in the Australian Parliament to defend himself. Renters are not here to defend themselves.

PARA.TAB: You know, Mr Acting Deputy President, how the processes of the Senate have been abused day in and day out by the Opposition. It is used as a vehicle for smear, for baseless allegations, for innuendo, for attacking public servants and others in the Australian community who cannot defend themselves, for blackguarding ordinary Australians and slandering anyone the Opposition wants to put in the gun sights. That is what this chamber is used for. We all know it; those opposite all know it. This is being promoted today only because the Opposition apparently thinks there might be an election called in the next couple of days. By gee, it is tempting to rub their noses in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's do it. Let's go to an election.

—I am looking forward to it and I am looking forward to seeing the Opposition wiped out when the Prime Minister calls the election. But from the way the trends are going in the public opinion polls at the moment, with the growth of the Labor vote and the diminution in the Liberal Party vote as the Party falls away to nothing under the leadership of John Hewson, if we leave it a little longer the result is going to be even better.

PARA.TAB: This motion of censure is a nonsense. It ought to be rejected by this chamber and we ought to get on with the job that we have all been elected to this Parliament for, to get on with addressing the Government's legislative program instead of this sanctimonious hypocrisy from an Opposition bereft of ideas and bereft of any political program for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a most extraordinary speech by Senator Faulkner. We are well aware that it is Labor Party policy to get rid of the Senate altogether.
—It is not.
—Senator Tate says that it is not.
—You moron.
—Senator Faulkner, you cannot call Senator Walters a moron.
—I withdraw.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for defending me. It is usually one of the courtesies of this place, when someone has spoken, to remain in the chamber until the next person has spoken. But Senator Faulkner has just walked out. We have at the moment a censure motion against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) but only two Labor people in the Senate are prepared to even be here. We have not heard Senator Tate defend the Prime Minister. I ask Senator Tate whether he agrees with the Prime Minister's words.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate has not responded. I can only presume, because Senator Tate is not one that refuses to interject—indeed, he interjects on many occasions—that by refusing to answer my question he does not support the words of the Prime Minister. There has never been a time in the history of Australia when the people have had so little regard for members of parliament. We have seen it in their votes. We have seen it and heard it in every electorate. There would not be a member on either side of this chamber that has not been told by the people of Australia that they want better behaviour and less abuse in the Parliament of their country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Tate says, `Oh'. Can Senator Tate truthfully tell me that he has not been told that by Labor members at his branches? We certainly find that the whole of Australia wants the people in this Parliament to behave in a more responsible fashion. Yet we have the Prime Minister, who is without doubt the most foul-mouthed of any member of parliament, once again losing control. Because he is aware that the Senate, in its legitimate role under the Constitution, has the ability to inquire into the loans affair and to inquire into why the Budget did not cite the correct figures as to how much this country is in debt, he lost his temper. What were the words he used? When it was said that the Treasurer should come before the Senate Committee, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . whether the Treasurer wished to go there or not I would forbid him going, forbid him going to the Senate to account to that unrepresentative swill over there, where you are into a political stunt.

I do not know why the Labor senators do not rise up in wrath about being called that by their leader. I do not understand that. I do not understand why the Labor senators do not take grave exception to their leader calling them `swill'. I really can assure the Senate that we would not accept that in our party. Senator Button, Senator McMullan and Senator Faulkner have all said that the people do not care. Why do they not ask the gallery? I am sure that every one of those in the gallery will let them know that they do care how the members of this Senate and the members of the House of Representatives behave. They are represented by the members of this place, just as well as they are represented by the lower House.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner has stated that we here are not representative and that he agrees with the Prime Minister in that regard. Senator Faulkner may well decide that he does not represent New South Wales. Senator Schacht told us that this was not a House of review—that it was a political House and a political House only. We have only to look at the statistics of the number of amendments that are passed through this Senate to know how well this Senate works as a House of review.

We have a piece of legislation coming up later today or early next week on the National Health and Medical Research Council. It was rushed through the House of Representatives, with no great or in-depth debate allowed by the lower House. It was not until it got to the Senate and was sent to a Senate committee that sense prevailed.

Senator Tate was the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe), who was the Minister in the House of Representatives. The Government itself has put forward 12 amendments; we have further amendments; and I am not sure that the Democrats have not too. So this Senate is certainly a House of review and this is not a one-off occasion; it happens all the time. I am not sure how many amendments on the broadcasting legislation were put forward by the Government in the Senate but it went into tens. There were something like 20 or 30 amendments.

The amendments that go through the Senate are numerous, not only from members of the Opposition and the Democrats but also from the Government. So this is truly a House of review and could never be claimed to be unrepresentative. If we were members of the House of Lords, I would agree with the Prime Minister that we would be unrepresentative. I was certainly voted in as a member of the Senate by every voting member in my State, as are the senators in both other parties.

When Senator Button spoke on this censure motion, in making an effort to defend the situation that has arisen he treated it so light-heartedly that it was disgraceful. I do not believe the people will accept for one minute that the language the Prime Minister continually uses in the lower House is acceptable and that he will ever become Prime Minister again.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not sure what you think about this; I am not sure what Speaker McLeay was doing when this foul language occurred. I do know that Speaker McLeay in the other place did not ask the Prime Minister to withdraw. We have standing orders in this chamber and in the House of Representatives that forbid someone to say something uncomplimentary about the other chamber. Yet Speaker McLeay in that place refused to make the Prime Minister withdraw his very rude comments.

It is time the Government decided whether it wants a Senate or not. When I said a moment ago that the Labor Party's policy was to get rid of the Senate, Senator Tate said it was not. It was in its written policy until Senator Evans said, `Let's take it out of the written policy because it is fairly unpopular with the people, but let us work from within. Let's go into the Senate and work from within'—these were the words he used—`to white-ant it'. He said, `We will white-ant the Senate from within'.

We have heard from Senator Schacht. We have had many honourable senators opposite saying today that the Senate should be abolished. Mr Keating has said that the Senate should be abolished because he cannot control it. They too believe the Senate should be abolished, and yet Senator Tate says that it is not part of the Labor Party's policy. No, it is not in its written document; Senator Evans said that they must get it out of that because it was not popular, but they would work from within and white-ant it. So it is part of the Labor Party's policy still and, indeed, it will remain so because it believes in the very centralist government that the people have already turned down on many occasions.

This censure motion against the Prime Minister is justified. We have been told today that we are thin skinned because we cannot take criticism, but this is without doubt a most important debate because if we allow the Prime Minister of the country to degrade every politician by the language he uses and set the situation where the people of Australia have no faith in their politicians—no faith at all—then we have reached the stage where the Parliament may as well give up and we just have open anarchy.

TALK.START.PARA: —During this elongated debate this morning on, one would think, a matter of crucial importance to the people of Australia, particularly the unemployed of Australia—we have been on it now for some three hours—I was reminded on a number of occasions of a speech by a Western Australian Senate colleague of mine, Senator Crichton-Browne, some months ago in the chamber. Unfortunately, I do not have staff in the building at the moment to do the research for me and pick it out but, as I recall that particular speech, he talked about standards—standards that we all ought to operate to. I think he made a salutary speech on that occasion. It was perhaps directed against this side of the chamber rather than against his own side of the chamber but I think it would be important for all elected senators to this place, on every side of the chamber, to read it before we rise in our places and make comment about the subject matter of the censure motion this morning.

PARA.TAB: I suggest what we are engaging in today is an act of hypocrisy because we are not abiding by any form of standards. The Senate has been asked to take exception to some words that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used in the House of Representatives yesterday. Those words included the word `unrepresentative'. Senator Faulkner earlier addressed that matter and gave some numbers which prove that this chamber is not as representative of the people as is the other place in terms of one vote one value. There is no way in the world that it can be claimed that it is as representative.

That is not to say, though, that it is not representative, because it is. Unlike upper Houses in many other countries of the world, it is directly elected by the people in general elections, half Senate elections or double dissolutions. The Prime Minister was partly right when he talked about an unrepresentative chamber, but was not completely and totally correct in his statement.
The second word that the Prime Minister used was `swill'. He was partly correct in that too. There are a number of `boars' in this place—and I say that not on a gender basis, I might quickly add.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a rather `sow-er' remark!

—I thank Senator Ray. I do not make that comment on a gender basis but there are some boars in this place who pad up for the fight that is going to take place. We do, from time to time, behave like swine. We have, in the very recent past—and it is not, I might add, the first occasion—taken advantage of the very privileged position that we, as senators, are given by the people in our respective States and Territories. We have used and abused the privileges given to us in this place.

PARA.TAB: An instance of that abuse occurred on the recent occasion when Mr Boucher was attacked by smear, by innuendo, by slander and by vilification in a chamber where he did not have the right to stand and counter the accusations and innuendo that were being directed at him. Some months previous to that, we saw one of the Australian ambassadors, Mr Butler, being attacked in the same disgraceful manner—a disgraceful manner it was indeed. That individual, that high ranking official of the Australian Government serving overseas, was not in a position to defend himself because we were taking advantage of the privilege of the position that we are given.

I opened my short contribution to this debate by making reference to Senator Crichton-Browne's comments because one could say that, okay, it was directed at this House. But I do re-emphasise the point that from time to time we all can learn from the words of our opponents. Whilst we might fight in this place, nonetheless some sense came from the other side of the chamber. There has been quite a deal of nonsense and quite a deal of hypocrisy as well. It has been mentioned that the Labor Party is about abolishing the Senate. That particular policy was removed from the Labor Party platform quite some years ago. I had some support for that position, and from time to time, particularly when I am waiting in airports, I might still support that position. But usually one does not make comments like that until one is in one's last term in this place—and I do not believe that I am in that position as yet.
Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray is listening to me; I am glad he is. It is worth noting, though, how overgoverned this nation is. How many politicians have we got representing people? When one counts the number of people elected to serve in the national Parliament, and counts up all those people elected to serve in State parliaments—and we have one in each State and one in each Territory, most with upper Houses—and then add local government on top of that, is it any wonder the people of Australia do not have a high opinion of politicians? There are far too many of us. If there is something that parliaments of Australia could do now in getting together, it is to reduce the number of politicians.

PARA.TAB: I also heard, in short snippets of earlier contributions to this debate, mention of factions. I discovered in a newspaper today that there is yet another new faction in Australia. There are factions in the Labor Party, as Senator Kemp would know, because he watches them very closely, but we have found another one coming from Senator Kemp's State. The new faction in Senator Kemp's State is actually an Opposition faction. It was in the newspaper this morning, and it is called the trough faction. It does relate to the debate that we are talking about, because swill is pig food.

There are some people down in Victoria who have quite firmly got their snouts in the trough. They are slashing and grabbing eight hundred bucks off every householder in Victoria, and at the same time, in the dead of night, giving huge salary increases to themselves. That is a standard that politicians can be judged by. It is not a very good standard and it is no wonder that, collectively, we are not held in high esteem by the people of Australia. I support the Prime Minister's remarks. It is unfortunate that name-calling such as this has to take a three-hour debate when there are so many more important issues this chamber could be debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before this chamber to censure the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his remarks of yesterday and, in particular, his attitude to the forming of the Senate committee to look into the Victorian loans scandal because of the conspiracy that occurred there. Before I get into the substance of what I want to say, I want to pick up what Senator McKiernan, and Senator Faulkner prior to that, said when they talked consistently about there being more important things to do than have a three-hour debate. I point out that last night, when the Appropriation Bills should have been continuing, when we should have been debating the reports of the Estimates committees, the Government was not ready. It was not prepared at that time to go through with that debate. That is absolutely correct.
—No, it's not.
—It is; it is absolutely correct. We went on to other business because the Government was not ready.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Those honourable senators on my left, if they wish to have a meeting, should either go outside or resume their seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am quite certain that you do not need Senator Ray's help to remove people from the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Let me get back to the substance of the motion, which relates to what the Prime Minister said yesterday. What the Prime Minister was trying to do was to shoot the messenger before the inquiry had been held. He wanted to denigrate the committee that has been appointed by the Senate to investigate the loans scandal, and he did it in a number of ways: firstly, by continuing to use what I would term unacceptable language; and, secondly, by his statement that he was not going to let the Treasurer of this country, John Dawkins, appear before the committee. That poses a couple of very important questions. First of all, is Mr Dawkins not big enough to stand up for himself and put his own case as to whether he appears or not? Secondly, in view of the position the Prime Minister has taken on this, what is he trying to hide? If there is nothing there, it is in the Prime Minister's interests to clear it up. It is in the interests of everybody to clear it up. But the position he adopted first of all was to say, `My little boy, Mr John Dawkins, will not appear'; and, secondly, he tried to denigrate the committee before it had even started its work.

In the process, he attacked the institution of this chamber. As I have said in this place before, I am a very strong supporter of this chamber. One must refer back to Federation. Without the Senate there would be no Federation of Australia. It would never have been formed. If State representation were changed along the lines suggested by Senator Faulkner, I suggest that that would be the end of the Federation of Australia. It would not hold together. The role the Senate plays is a very important aspect of having a federation or a nation of Australia. Of course, it would suit the Prime Minister not to have it. He comes from New South Wales. He is linked to the Right of the Labor Party in New South Wales. He would love to be in the dictatorial position to attack the States that have smaller populations, and he would do it. There is no question in my mind about that.

My State, Western Australia, has about 10 per cent of the population of Australia, yet it produces 25 per cent of this country's total primary product exports. Of course, that is what his attack is all about in the medium and longer term. In the short term it is about denigrating the structure this institution has put in place—a committee to examine precisely and exactly what has occurred and to get accurate evidence on the record of what has occurred in the blow-out of the Victorian loans affair.

What the Prime Minister has done is very consistent with what he has done in a number of other cases when he has been under pressure, when he has had a bad week or when he has had a bad time. I want to refer to a couple of those here, just to show that it is very consistent behaviour when he says these things off the top of his head, before he has his brain in gear. He should be brought to account for them. In this case, the Senate is in a position publicly to bring him to account through a censure motion.

The first thing I want to refer to is the announcement of the sale of Qantas. That is a very good example of how the Prime Minister acts off the cuff. He announced the sale of that on a Saturday after he had a very bad week in Parliament. It is interesting to note in terms of that announcement that half, if not more, of what he was selling was leased planes anyhow. Unfortunately, I have not had the time to get the precise figures on that. The other example in more recent times is the pay TV issue. Once again the Government had a particular position. The Prime Minister was going bad so he changed the agenda. He suddenly announced, off the top of his head, a totally different position. The Government has been on a bicycle going backwards ever since. This type of behaviour is very typical.

There are pages and pages of the type of language that this Prime Minister uses. I have said in this place before and I will say again that this Prime Minister has presided in his 10 years over the worst slide into unemployment this nation has seen, the worst slide into underemployment that this nation has seen, the worst situation we have had in this nation as far as bankruptcies are concerned. It was reported today in the West Australian that there were 324,700 married couples where either one or both partners were out of work—a 20 per cent increase on the previous year. The number of long term unemployed rose, from September 1991, from 219,300 to 326,300. As I have mentioned, this is the Prime Minister who has presided over the worst situation we have had in terms of underemployment. Further, once again under this Prime Minister and former Treasurer, in the last financial year we have seen bankruptcies increase another 25 per cent.
