On top of that, one can say that there is no doubt that with this Prime Minister we have seen the introduction of the worst and foulest language that has ever come into the Parliament of Australia since it was formed, back in 1901. Those are the legacies that this Prime Minister is leaving this country. He has done it; it is not anybody else who has done it. It is interesting to note that the so-called defence by people who sit on the other side of this place has not been a defence of the Prime Minister. They have gone off at all sorts of tangents and tried to blame everybody else.

I just want to quote a few of these things so as to highlight the approach of the Prime Minister. I think it was Senator Schacht who said that we should not be whingers. He said words to the effect that he was not a whinger and he did not believe that the Prime Minister was a whinger. Let us have a look at this. Back on 26 May 1983 the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, can I get some protection from the drones on the back benches?
Let us look again:
Mr Deputy Speaker, am I continually to be abused by the honourable member for Mitchell and the drone beside him, the honourable member for Braddon?
This Prime Minister who can dish it out can also whinge. We can go through pages and pages of it:
. . . the honourable member to be a liar . . . the brain damaged Deputy Leader of the Opposition . . . the champion liar of 1982-83.
On 6 December 1983:
. . . in the middle of his vile insinuations.
We have also:
He lied his way out of that too.
It goes on and on and on. He said on another occasion:
. . . sit with a criminal intellect . . . The honourable member is a half-baked crim . . .
On 5 March 1984 he said:
. . . I will be ripping her to shreds . . . She can go and shoot her big mouth off . . .
That is the Prime Minister we have of this country and the way that he has denigrated the institution of Parliament by the language that he uses. Once again, on 28 March 1984, we see:
Mr Speaker, can I have some protection from the clowns on the front bench opposite?

This Prime Minister dishes it out and then, we are told, he does not whinge. He whinges and he whinges and he whinges, and he does these things under the protection of Parliament. Here is another quote:
We are not interested in the views of painted, perfumed gigolos.
Then again:
They are cheats. As well as being incompetent, they are cheats.
One can go on and on. This is not the first time he has used the word `swill'. On 12 November 1985 he said:
A swill, a pigsty, and that was the limit of their capacity.

There are pages and pages of such quotes, but I want to conclude my remarks in this way: the Prime Minister does deserve to be censured for the denigration of this chamber and the institution. He also needs to be brought to account as to why he would want to say that the Treasurer himself is not capable of determining whether he appears before the Committee. In fact, if the Prime Minister really wished to clear up this particular situation which exists in Victoria, where there certainly appears on the surface to be a conspiracy to keep the accurate figures in terms of the Budget from the Australian people, and if he had nothing to hide, not only would he see that the Treasurer appeared before the particular Senate Committee but, I suggest, he would also be prepared to go before it himself and clear the matter up and get the accurate record put down in the public arena.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noted before that these debates bring out the incestuous nature of the Senate. When we bring debates into this chamber on unemployment, trade matters, defence matters or health matters, a modicum of passion goes across the chamber. But whenever we introduce a subject that concerns the great Senate of this world, we have the most passionate debates in this chamber. We are so self-important and we are so self-centred that these become the most critical debates that we ever have.
—The institution is important.

—A senator over there says, `No, it's the institution'. The institution is an extension of his own ego. What we have seen this morning is another great exercise in group therapy when every senator could come in, ignore the actual substance of the debate, get all the angst out of his or her system and walk out of here a much more stable and unemotional person, having got all the accumulated stuff off the liver.

PARA.TAB: Very rarely have any of those in the Opposition here concentrated on the actual issue. Neither have some of the Democrats. Senator Spindler went off on his tariff debate. Senator Crane went off on the Qantas debate. They are all off on some favourite subject so that they can all get on the record. But really this is about the egos of the people in this chamber and their being hurt by a remark from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

What a bunch of pathetic wimps we are looking at! The Prime Minister can make one remark and everyone over there spits the dummy and gets upset. Some of them were shaking with rage yesterday. Boy, it must be easy to needle them. One of the reasons why they were shaking with rage is that this is basically no longer an adversarial chamber and those in the Opposition really have to confront difficult debates. Because of the anarchistic swamp in terms of legislation of this chamber, they generally do not get contested in debates because all on our side have to pull off so that we can get the legislation through. So whenever an adversarial situation comes up, what do those opposite do? They try to amend the Standing Orders to circumvent Question Time because they cannot stand the heat. They get up on spurious points of order time and time again because they cannot stand the heat of debate.

We have listened to some very pious pieces of repetition today. They have all been trundled out. We even had Sir Henry Parkes, that old conservative, trundled out here today. It is the same old theme that we in the Labor Party have been listening to for 92 years; that is, that the Australian people cannot be trusted to elect a government and a conservative institution is needed as a brake on it. It was almost a wistful reference to the House of Lords from Senator Walters here today.

We have heard the same garbage, that this is a States House. Rubbish! It has not been a States House for 89 years. We have heard the argument that this is a House of review and a good thing. Rubbish! Those views are not held by those in opposition; they may be held by the Democrats and the minority groups here.

We have heard a view from Senator Faulkner that is not far wrong, that this has become a house of assassins where smear is just a by-word in the activities of senators. But I say it is none of those things: what this House has become is a house of total political opportunism. At least we on this side are willing to state where we are coming from in our approach to politics; it is a day-to-day issue based thing and occasionally we take a stance for political advantage. All one hears from the other side is total humbug where its members use ideological and policy proposals for their own personal aggrandisement.

The interesting thing, of course, is that we have heard here how important it is that this is a House of review, yet Dr Hewson, a potential Prime Minister, has on several occasions stressed just how important it is for the coalition to win a majority in this place. Why is that? It is because the coalition does not want to be part of the sort of guerilla warfare tactics of delay and frustration that it has used against this Government. We have seen this hypocrisy every time the guillotine comes up here, when the same people who voted for it year in, year out under a Liberal Party majority now come in and oppose it on the principle that they will never do it. I put the challenge to the Opposition members last time a guillotine motion was moved that they should come around to my office and sign up to say that they would never, ever vote for it in a future coalition government. It must be hard to find my office because not one of them came around to sign up. So we all know that if they win government they will be moving a guillotine when the situation gets desperate on the legislative program.

But it is even more interesting to look at these proposals when one looks at Victoria. Is there any suggestion from the Kennett Government that it does not want a majority in the upper House? When proposals were put by the Labor Government to introduce proportional representation—the very system esteemed and espoused by honourable senators opposite, and they say it is a wonderful system—did they vote for it in Victoria? No. They used their upper House majority to knock over that particular legislation. So when they come in here and spout about proportional representation and houses of review, it is nothing more than smarmy hypocrisy.

There is an interesting sidelight on that. I have sat in this chamber and listened to debates on legislation including retrospectivity. I have not only been told that it was politically wrong; I have been told by people on that side of politics that it is immoral. What about Mr Jeffrey Kennett's retrospective legislation abolishing holiday leave loadings? What about his retrospective legislation knocking off workers compensation cases going to the courts? Once they get a majority, not only does their political position change, but so do their morals. It is okay for retrospective legislation in Victoria; it is not okay for those who sit on the Opposition benches.

We have also heard the usual quota of hypocrisy today about how people on the Liberal Party or coalition side have some sort of free will in this chamber. That has got to be the greatest joke in history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Remember George Georges?
—Yes, I do remember George.
—You kicked him out of your Party.
—Unequivocally, Senator.
—And we don't.

—The Liberal Party does not! What happened to Mr Francis, the member for Caulfield in Victoria, when he bucked the line? It expelled him. What happened to Mr Jennings, the member from down Western Port way who bucked the line under the Hamer Government? The Party expelled him. What happened to Senator Hannaford when he would not go along with the Party on the Vietnam War? He was not endorsed. What the Liberal Party prefers to do when it has relatively free spirits on its side is to assassinate them through preselection. That is why Senator Puplick is here no longer, because he was assassinated at preselection. That is the Liberal Party way. This is the great hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: What happens to these great free spirits when they do not get party endorsement? What happened to Senator Vigor and Senator Siddons, who would not serve under a female leader? They suddenly discovered a new philosophy, that they would no longer toe the party line in the Democrats. They went out and they were judged by the people and they got absolutely annihilated at the polls, as do most other rebels. Rarely, if ever, does someone without party endorsement get here. We will have another example in Victoria, but that might well depend on where we send our preferences. Senator Kernot had better be nice to us because I am watching her attitude.

How representative is this chamber? One thing that can be said about proportional representation is that it is an excellent way of distributing representation and an appalling way of distributing power. Senator Faulkner has been through the figures. This is not the most representative chamber we could have in this country by a variety of means of electoral process, and I think the Prime Minister is quite right when he describes this chamber as unrepresentative. Where one has to make the judgment is in how much more representative it could be, or indeed how much more unrepresentative it could be. That is the difficulty of judgment. But there is no need to censure the Prime Minister on his view of that. We are unrepresentative. It takes twelve times as many votes to elect a senator in New South Wales as it does for one in Tasmania and so on. So this is not necessarily a representative House.

On the actual issue that sparked all this off, about whether House of Representatives Ministers should be compelled to attend Senate committee hearings, in the end there will be no difference in that between a Labor government and a coalition government. Neither would contemplate it, nor should they. They are responsible to their house, as Senate Ministers are responsible to this House. There should be no obligation on a House, even though it does not have a majority of one party or another, is prone to political opportunism and is prone to setting up witch-hunts—one has only to look at the Murphy case for that—to say that a Minister could be compelled to attend.

There are a few other curious aspects about this which I might mention in conclusion. Firstly, there was the Reith press release that announced the three Liberal Party members to serve on this committee. It was apparently not chosen by the party room or anyone else. The shadow Treasurer has determined who the Senate representatives are. Of course, the committee was set up to have two coalition members and one National Party member. They have obviously been through the National Party ranks and have not found anyone with the talent or the application to be able to serve. So we now get the big cover-up from Senator Boswell. The Leader of the National Party, without the ability to have a front bench portfolio, without the ability to be trusted with any portfolio, actually signed a joint letter with Senator Hill to say who the three representatives are.

We want to know who the National Party representative on the committee is. Is it Senator Short, is it Senator Alston or is it Senator Bishop? Which one will be the National Party representative on the joint Senate ticket in the next election? Who is the hidden rural hick amongst these three? Who, in fact, is the secret National Party supporter that Senator Boswell has nominated? To cover that up we get a joint letter, so we will never know. Maybe Senator Hill can inform us later on which is which.

I conclude on this point. When people talk about the value of Senate committees, I say, `The jury is out'. Over the time I have been in it, the Senate has had some excellent committees. It has had a majority of good committees. I am a strong supporter, on the public record, of the Estimates committee process and of the standing committee process. But it is not perfect. We have so many committees in the Senate these days that the reports are being written less and less by senators, attendance is becoming poorer and poorer, and in some cases we are not even now in the position where it is the committee's secretary that writes the draft report. More and more there is a demand for consultants, especially in some of the joint committees, to come in and actually write the committee's reports. We are moving more to the American system than we should. The true value of Senate committees is when the senators themselves take the responsibility for the questioning, the writing of the report and the recommendations in the report.

Before we get on our high horse too much about our pride in the Senate committee system, it should be recognised that by no means are the committees perfect and by no means can they not be improved. The one particular point of disgrace for this chamber is the use of the committees for character assassination. The question of Mr Boucher has been raised. Let me tell the Senate of my experience in 1982 when I served on Estimates Committee C and we were in the middle of the bottom of the harbour, if honourable senators understand what I mean. In the Senate Estimates process we brought in the Tax Office—
Senator Crane interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We gave them a great working over. Senator Crane should go back and read the thing.
—I have. Mr Dawkins knows all about it.

—Mr O'Reilly had to come, and he struggled, quite frankly. I remember they brought in a new bloke to defend the Government. He had icy cold blue eyes and he cut me to ribbons, he cut Senator Walsh to ribbons, he cut Senator Gietzelt and, more than that, he knocked over Feathers McLaren. I turned around and said, `I hope this bloke never becomes Commissioner'. That was Mr Boucher. The Liberal Party was quite happy to use him as a public servant in his proper role to defend the Government record. He did that. That was his duty, to give advice and to defend the Government and the Tax Office. He did that then. Yet, 10 years later, an irresponsible senator comes in and, in this chamber and through the committee system, accuses him of political bias, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: Nothing will destroy the committee system more than mindless witch-hunts that are patently unfair and patently untrue. If we allow that to proceed we will not be able to set up with any credibility a Senate committee to look into the question of the Loan Council and the borrowing rates in Victoria. The committee would have no credibility whatsoever.

Today is, I repeat, just one large session of group therapy when the Prime Minister has been the subject for people to get a bit of angst out of their systems. The only penalty we pay in this particular process will be four hours wasted debate. The censure, as a tool of Opposition, has been debauched and debased in this chamber in the last few years—ho hum, another Senate motion to censure someone, based on political opportunism. No-one cares about these Senate motions.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Mr Acting Deputy President, I just heard an interesting speech from Senator Ray but it did not seem to be a defence of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). As a matter of interest, it did not seem to address the censure motion at all. It certainly was taken as an opportunity to get a few things off his chest in relation to Opposition senators on Senate committees but it did not seek to defend the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: I think what we have witnessed today in the debate is a clear difference across the chamber as to what is the appropriate standard of behaviour and conduct of a Prime Minister, a very different attitude between the parties as to the importance of the institution and the importance of behaving in a way in which the Australian people can have some pride, both in the office of Prime Minister by the Prime Minister's personal behaviour and in the institution of Parliament by the way in which we behave in the Parliament. When the Prime Minister abuses those positions of trust in the contemptuous way in which he did yesterday, it is appropriate, whether Senator Ray likes it or not, that the Senate censure him for doing so.

Censure motions in the Senate are rare. The last one was in relation to Senator Richardson, which was carried. I cannot even remember the one before that. Certainly, in the other place, there are quite a lot. I can remember a censure motion in relation to Senator Tate a couple of years ago. Senator Ray should go back and check the records: censures in the Senate are relatively rare. They are rare from my perspective because censures are, in effect, the highest sanction that we have, and therefore we should not debase the currency. We should only censure when circumstances demand that it be done.

When the Prime Minister, under the protection of the other place, refers to senators, to the Senate, as `unrepresentative swill', unrepresentative pig food, in effect, then that is an appalling standard that requires response from this chamber; and it requires it in the proper way that is open to us, and that is censure.

I commend the motion to the Senate. I regret that really the Government offered no defence. What I would have liked its members to do, in effect, is come in and apologise for the conduct of their Prime Minister, but they were obviously not prepared to do that. I think that is disappointing, but I hope that the Senate will now record its censure of the Prime Minister and at least demonstrate to the Australian people that a majority in this place regard such conduct of an Australian Prime Minister as unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not normal to take votes during the luncheon break, so in a moment I might move that the Senate adjourn until 2 o'clock and then we can have the vote at 2 p.m. I also draw everyone's attention to the fact that the bells will go from five to two until two and almost immediately again, and we would not like anyone from any part of the chamber to be confused by the fact the bell for the division will be a continuation of the five-minute bell for some reason. I assume that the Whips and others will inform people that we will be probably having two votes at 2 o'clock.
—I think the debate on this matter would be suspended until 2 o'clock, anyway, so that the Senate can deal with the matters of public interest that are on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Ray is happy that the matters of public importance be brought on.
—All right. The agreement reached mutually is that we bring on the matters of public importance and that the vote be taken at 2 p.m.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate the ridiculous actions by Mr Bob Brown, the Minister for Land Transport, over the F3 freeway which only served to highlight the embarrassment he must be feeling over his very curious handling of this issue. I would like to briefly remind honourable senators of the story of the F3 freeway, which heads north from Sydney and is supposed to form part of the national highway and link into the New England and the Pacific highways near Beresfield.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the F3, which is 150 kilometres long, stops in the middle of a swamp eight kilometres short of its intended intersection. Instead of the dual carriageway of the northbound F3 connecting with the dual carriageway of the other northern highways, the plan at present is to feed the F3 into a single-lane road in a residential area called Lenaghans Drive. This means that the northbound traffic out of Sydney will be caught in a bottleneck as the freeway becomes a residential street with traffic lights and intersections. It also means that the safety of residents is endangered as traffic volumes increase dramatically; and this is in spite of Mr Brown's national road safety strategy, which he recently announced.

Surely, running a dual carriageway into a residential single-lane road is creating a traffic nightmare, not a case of avoiding new traffic problems. It makes the whole intent of the Minister's road safety strategy a bit of a joke, certainly in the case of what is happening with the road system west of Newcastle.

What makes it even more ridiculous is that the authorities already have figures that suggest that the current increase in traffic down Lenaghans Drive means that traffic volumes are already sufficient to warrant a dual carriageway. This is before the extensions of the F3 are fed into Lenaghans Drive, with the associated massive increase in traffic volume from that.

This ridiculous plan led to a residents delegation from the Lenaghans Drive area coming to see me about what could be done. I immediately took up the matter, and I have tried to move Minister Brown out of first gear because of the urgent need to have completed a proper plan and timetable for the completion of the F3. I have made several speeches in this place on this matter of getting this freeway finished as quickly as possible. I have also issued several press releases on the issue and have had local television come out with me to see exactly the nature of the problem created by finishing an expressway in the middle of a swamp.

Given all the actions on the F3, honourable senators can imagine my surprise when I read for the first time in the Newcastle Herald two weeks ago that the Minister for Land Transport had invited all local parliamentarians from the Newcastle region to inspect the new extensions of the freeway. He was running a bus tour along it. I asked my staff where my invitation was. I had not received an invitation. When I contacted the Minister's office to point this out, I was told that I could not be offered an invitation because, if he invited me, he would have to invite all the other 11 New South Wales senators.

Clearly, I am the only senator from the northern region and certainly the only one that has taken a keen interest in this F3 debacle. So the Minister's excuse was really rather pathetic. Given the snub, I then attempted to find out when and where the bus tour was to be held. Again, I was consistently denied this information from the Minister's office. But I managed finally to find out when and from where the bus was leaving. I went to the city hall to board the bus to have a look at the new extensions to the freeway which the Minister was so proudly displaying, despite the fact that it ends in a swamp and feeds into a residential area. However, the Minister decided to physically bar me from entering the bus, the passengers of which were all members of the ALP. Instead, he offered me a separate tour of the F3. I pointed out that this was a bit of a waste of money seeing there were 15 spare seats on the bus, but to no avail. The Minister would not relent. He stood in the doorway of the bus and drew himself up to his full height of five feet, and really looked like a Senator Button when he is very angry. He prevented me from actually boarding the bus.

I believe I had every right to join in with Mr Brown's bus tour as a representative of the people of New South Wales, particularly to ensure that the $700m that has been spent on the F3 freeway—and it is Federal money—was spent properly. Mr Brown prevented this, I believe, because he was ashamed of the disgraceful situation where this freeway now ends in the middle of a swamp. The money that is spent on the F3 freeway is poorly spent unless it connects properly into the New England and Pacific Highways as part of the national roads system. Mr Brown should act immediately to ensure that the F3 is completed properly by avoiding Lenaghans Drive and joining the F3 directly into the other highways. This will avoid the safety hazard to residents that has been created, and will ensure that the transport links between Sydney and Brisbane are as efficient and as safe as possible.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Parliamentary Inquiry into Tariffs and Industry Development

TALK.START.PARA: —The time remaining is not really enough for me to develop the topic that I wish to address. However, I shall take as much time as I possibly can. During the adjournment yesterday, Senator Kemp queried the status of the independent parliamentary inquiry into tariffs and industry development which I have initiated. This followed my tabling of the interim reports covering the first three public hearings that were carried out by the inquiry. I was grateful to the Senate for giving me leave to table those reports. Before I go further in my remarks, the queries raised by Senator Kemp addressed the origin of the inquiry and the status of the inquiry. In my tabling statement I addressed the history and the way in which the inquiry was established. I therefore seek the Senate's leave to table my tabling statement so that those facts can be on record.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think it is important, in view of the remarks made by Senator Kemp, to go back to the origin of the inquiry. Senator Kemp actually queried whether it was, in fact, a parliamentary inquiry and why it was necessary. I wish to put on record that the beginning of that inquiry actually occurred because I attempted to move a motion establishing a Senate inquiry into tariffs and industry development. The Opposition—Senator Kemp and his colleagues—supported the Government in rejecting it. In fact, the Opposition was very quick to reject it. It simply did not want to know about the damage that was being done in the community. So I decided it was important to have that inquiry anyway.

PARA.TAB: I am well aware, as Senator Kemp pointed out, that as a result this inquiry has no formal status. But the only legal consequence is that I am not able to offer parliamentary privilege to witnesses appearing for the inquiry. When I was in utter frustration after the rejection of my motion, which sought to put on record over time the consequences of the current policy, of a rigid and inexorable step by step tariff reduction program, I went to the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Harry Evans, and I put to him whether, as a parliamentarian, I was entitled to establish such an inquiry and specifically whether I was entitled to use my normal parliamentary entitlements in terms of staff, communication facilities, premises and so on for such an inquiry. I was advised by the Clerk of the Senate that this was indeed so and that for a senator to inquire into an issue of public interest, such as this one no doubt was, was indeed part of the responsibility of a parliamentarian. Therefore, it is quite clear that this inquiry is, indeed, a parliamentary inquiry.

Senator Kemp also raised the problem that some of the people appearing before us, or some of the people reading the report, might mistake the inquiry for a parliamentary inquiry that had been initiated by a resolution. So I am taking the precaution of advising, at the beginning of each public hearing, all those present, as well as people who have sought to give evidence, that this is an inquiry that was initiated as a result of the failure of the Opposition and the Government to support such an inquiry being established by the Senate. I can assure Senator Kemp that, in one sense, it pleases me that I can put on record the frustration that I feel, the failure on the part of the two major parties and the total lack of responsibility displayed by Senator Kemp towards his electorate in refusing people a forum in which they can put these matters on record.

Addressing now the consequences of this action, it is rather sad that an inquiry of this nature must be carried out as I am doing. I believe it is a matter of great importance, looking at the continuing rise in unemployment that this community is facing. According to the evidence before the inquiry, as a direct result of reductions in tariffs, despite some of the figures that Senator Button, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, tabled yesterday, the message is coming through loud and clear. I think it is a great pity that Senator Kemp and his colleagues simply did not want to know what the consequences of their actions were.

TALK.START.PARA: —You set out to mislead the people; that is what you did.

—I will accept that interjection by Senator Kemp because he was not in the chamber when I explained that I am at great pains to explain that this is not a formal inquiry due to the failure of Senator Kemp and his colleagues to support the motion for a formal inquiry. I take great pleasure, in one sense, at the beginning of every public hearing, in informing the people who come before us of that fact.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m. and pursuant to the motion that was agreed to earlier, I will put the amendment moved by Senator Coulter to the motion of censure of the Prime Minister.

TAB.TAB: That the resolution of the Senate censuring the Prime Minister, as agreed to by the Senate this day, be communicated by message to the House of Representatives.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, is overseas on government business and will be absent from Question Time today and on Monday, 9 November. During Senator Evans's absence, questions relating to his portfolio should be directed to the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray.

PARA.TAB: I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, is attending a funeral in Darwin and will be absent from Question Time today. Questions normally addressed to Senator Collins should be directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which follows the censure motion, is directed to you, Mr President. I refer you to the Prime Minister's comments in Parliament yesterday when, in relation to whether the Treasurer would be appearing before the Senate inquiry into the Loan Council cover-up, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . I would forbid him going to the Senate to account to this unrepresentative swill over there—

Mr President, did you speak to the Prime Minister to request an apology for those remarks? If so, what was his reply? What other action have you taken to protect the standing of this institution in light of the Prime Minister's contemptuous abuse?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In reply to Senator Hill, I had a copy of the statement that I issued last night here ready for the debate this morning. I do not have it at the moment, but I will give Senator Hill a complete answer before the end of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen a report in today's Australian Financial Review in which the Opposition's spokesperson on industrial relations, John Howard, said that the minimum wage for workers on individual employment contracts under a coalition government would be based on their award classification rate? Following this shift in policy by the Opposition, does the Government now intend to adopt a similar individual employment contract policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked whether I intend to adopt a similar employment policy to that of the Opposition—or that policy as it is interpreted from time to time by the shadow spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard. There are a number of reasons why one would not adopt that policy. The first reason, of course, is that the Opposition is as confused about what the policy means as is the Australian electorate to whom it is directed. There is no consistency at all between what it actually says in the black letter of the policy and what Mr Howard says from time to time in his press releases trying to interpret it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. A point was detailed from the Australian Financial Review, apparently, and the Minister was asked whether he would adopt that. He is now apparently answering in a different form in that he is saying no, he would not adopt our policy and he is entering into a debate upon that policy. That is not answering the question as it was asked. It is outside his responsibility; he should be answering questions relating to his administration. Therefore, I ask you to bring him to order.
—As I understand it, the Minister is replying to a question he was asked about whether or not he would implement a certain policy. I will ask him to continue.

—Thank you, Mr President. I know the Opposition is running scared on its industrial relations policy. Why would it not be? It has the working model of it in Victoria under Jeff Kennett where it is clear that the coalition in opposition in that State has actively misled the Victorian electors about what the intent of the policy was.

PARA.TAB: Coming back to the question that I am asked, the actual policy that is being referred to says in the relevant part, `not less than the base hourly minimum rate'. What I have constantly complained about in this debate is that what is said of the policy is not consistent with what the policy itself says. There is misrepresentation about that. Indeed, Mr Howard in his press release today said, `the minimum hourly rate for the full adult employee'. What he declined to do was actually quote his own policy accurately. He did not include the word `base'. So, in his press release today, he has tried to reinterpret his policy. The problem for him is that the policy remains the same and it is absolutely clear—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Kemp

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I refer you to two rulings that you made on this particular issue in February 1987. What you said then was:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Minister cannot accept responsibility for matters that are contained in or are alleged to be contained in the policies of the non-government parties.
A Minister cannot be responsible for or comment on what the Opposition's policies are supposed to be.

They were very clear rulings by you. Mr President, I put it to you that the Minister is flouting your rulings. All he is doing is trying to comment on the Opposition's policy, and I ask you to enforce your previous rulings.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, which is made two or three times a day, Mr President, you have consistently ruled that it is open to a Minister to say whether a government will adopt a particular policy. If that happens to be coincidental with an Opposition policy, so be it. This tactic of taking these points of order is merely to disrupt the chamber and they are vexatious in the extreme.
—Order! I have listened to the Minister's answer so far. I believe it is in order.
—So those rulings are hopeless, are they? They count for nothing?
—Mr President, I ask Senator Kemp to withdraw that. He has challenged your ruling. He has said across the chamber that your rulings are hopeless.

—On the point of order: I can provide some guidance to Senator Ray. I said, `So those rulings are hopeless, are they?' That is what I said and I suggest Senator Ray listen more carefully before he gets to his feet.
—Order! I call Senator Cook.

—What the policy proposes is that, irrespective of the classification a worker or employee is on, he will go to the lowest rate in the award. That is what the policy says and that is why the Opposition is backtracking. That is why these points of order have been taken today—to try to conceal that. It is clear in the policy and it is misrepresented in the press release.

PARA.TAB: That does not offer workers in this country any protection either, even if it were the minimum base rate, because under that policy there is no guarantee to protect payment for public holidays, overtime, shift allowances or any penalties whatsoever. It is genuinely a low wage, high price policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister advise as to whether paid public holidays are protected under the Government's system of workplace bargaining? Would they be protected under any move to individual employment contracts?
—I raise a point of order. That cannot possibly be a supplementary question. It has nothing to do with the original question.
—On that point of order, Mr President: Senator Cook explicitly referred to that matter in the course of his answer. It is quite clearly a supplementary question.
—It wasn't in the original question.

—But it was part of the answer. If people want that sort of criterion applied to all supplementary questions, we probably would prefer that; but if we are to be consistent and accept all the scattergun supplementaries that come from the Opposition, this is classically in order.

—Order! I was placed in a very difficult position. An attendant was giving me some documents and I did not hear the question. In view of the points of order that I have heard, I will allow the supplementary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —As to whether our system of workplace bargaining protects payment for public holidays, the answer is yes, it does, because our system of workplace bargaining is based on the entitlement of an award and an award is protected in full, as is the Industrial Relations Commission, which is the official body that issues awards and gives them legal force.

PARA.TAB: Under individual work contracts, there is no guarantee that public holidays will be paid because, while public holidays are prescribed as an entitlement to people in many State Acts of Parliament, it is not the case that those Acts always prescribe that public holidays be paid for.

The provision that they be paid for is an award provision. If the award is removed, there is no guarantee at all that a public holiday will be paid for and the statement issued by Mr Howard today on that point is absolutely wrong. He ought to learn his industrial law.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the Minister to the latest report by the reputable economic forecaster Syntec, which yesterday said that Australia faced another major economic downturn within two years because of a looming current account crisis. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the revelation that international banks have voted Australia as having the world's worst current account deficit prospects and that the shocking September balance of payments deficit of $1.5 billion was just a taste of things to come? In the light of this report and the current account deficit blow-out, will the Government have to slow the economy down again, thereby ruling out any reduction in unemployment, which now stands at an appalling 10.8 per cent and means that a million Australians are out of work?
—I have not seen the Syntec commentary which Senator Ferguson refers to.
—Part of your policy of not reading the papers.
—I gave up reading Syntec forecasts of this kind some years ago because I did not find them particularly useful.
—You could not put up with the bad news.
—I started reading them when those opposite were in government, and I gave up reading them when they were in government because they did not prove to be very accurate.

PARA.TAB: As far as the current account deficit is concerned, we have already achieved the conditions for lowering it. It fell from 4.1 per cent of GDP in 1990-91 to 3.1 per cent of GDP in 1991-92. Despite weak commodity prices—commodity prices being the backbone of this country's international export earnings until a year or two ago—and world trade growth, it was 24 per cent lower in 1991-92 than in 1990-91. The trend in export growth continues unabated. I recommend that Senator Ferguson take a look at some of the export growth figures because they are very encouraging.

The fall of 10 1/2 per cent in the trade weighted index since April, and the lower inflation rate, will enhance our competitiveness, but that is a two-edged observation in terms of the current account. It is possible that the current account deficit may increase in response to a recovery in economic activity. I think we saw that in the August current account figures; we did not see it in the September figures; and we saw it a little more again in the October figures. Monthly figures vary, and it is impossible to draw any conclusions about those at this stage.

Part of the deterioration in the trade account will flow from growth in business investment, which all adds up to productive potential. The current account deficit should stabilise relative to GDP in the mid-1990s, as the Government's policies to improve competitiveness bear fruit. That is something which we have said in the past and which we still believe in. It is totally supported by the figures I have given for the decline in the current account deficit as a percentage of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Government examined the impact of a goods and services tax on the community, in particular, the compliance costs for business arising from various forms of taxation? What impact would the imposition of a GST have on business and consumers in the community?

—Before Senator Kemp hovers too closely over his Odgers pleading and practice, let me say that Senator Maguire has always taken a constructive view on public policy issues in this country. Public policy issues relate to taxation and other matters. In answer to his question, the Government, for its part, is aware of the compliance costs arising from the imposition of a goods and services tax. A number of studies have been conducted on this question. In Australia it is estimated that the GST would require at least 700,000 small business people to become tax collectors for the government. A GST would bury every small business person in a mountain of new paperwork. By comparison, only 75,000 businesses pay the existing wholesale sales tax—
—What about the FBT?

—Senator Panizza should not interject about the FBT. People opposite opposed it when it suited them and accepted it later on because they are slow learners. So it is their policy as well as ours. Senator Panizza should not get too excited about that. In relation to the GST, in New Zealand, Professor Cedric Sandford and John Hasseldine of the Institute of Public Policy Studies have found that the compliance cost of a GST is 7.3 per cent of its net revenue.
—Are you reading this?

—Yes, I am reading it. Nearly 60 per cent of the cost falls on small business—businesses with turnover below $250,000. As a matter of interest to honourable senators, a lot of these businesses have no payroll tax; 600,000 of the 700,000 to which I refer are businesses to which payroll tax is not applicable.

PARA.TAB: In a study of the GST, Dr Terrence Dwyer has concluded that the administrative costs for business arising from the GST should not be underestimated. He said that many businesses will find that they are partially exempt suppliers and will have to do complex pro rata calculations to ensure they reclaim as much of the GST on their inputs as they can, without it provoking a charge of GST fraud upon audit by the Tax Office.

I make it clear that a GST in this country would shift the tax burden from the rich to the poor. Members of the Opposition are advocates of the view, eloquently expressed by John Kenneth Galbraith years ago, that the poor will not work because they are paid too much and the rich will not work because they get too little.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade Policy of United States of America

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the United States election result. What can Australian farmers expect from a Clinton Administration which proposes `a fair but not free trade policy' and fully supports the use of subsidisation under the export enhancement program? Secondly, what measures is the Government prepared to take to ensure that our farmers do not suffer further economic hardship in the face of greater protectionism under a Clinton Administration?

—I do not think there is any question that Governor Clinton so far has shown his approach to be internationalist both by way of intellect and instinct. The main priority for him is to re-establish the economic strength of the US. That was the constant theme of his campaign. Certainly, he has put the proposition that America's first foreign policy and first domestic policy are simply the same; that is, renewing the American economy.

PARA.TAB: In pursuing this goal, Governor Clinton has avoided supporting any isolationist and protectionist policies. I would expect, therefore, for there to be a considerable degree of continuity between his policies and those of his predecessor. Throughout the whole campaign Governor Clinton has been fairly careful, I think, in his comments on trade policy. He has consistently claimed to be a free trader. We would not expect him to be hostage to the familiar list of Democrat protectionist special interest groups. However, it also has to be conceded that the Democrats did relatively well in the Congressional elections. That is where a lot of the protectionist pressure has come from.

During the campaign Governor Clinton indicated that he consistently supported the Uruguay Round and hoped for a positive outcome on it. I do not think we as a government at this stage can make an absolutely definitive assessment about US trade policies. Clearly, there may be more use of section 301 in a direct rather than retaliatory manner, in which there will not be the sort of collateral damage as EEP. We will obviously gear up our representatives overseas to make the highest level representations and let our views be known at the earliest possible stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, which expresses the hopes of the Government, and I suppose at this early stage that is reasonable up to a point. Nevertheless, Governor Clinton is on record—and there is no reason to suspect that he will change his views once he is the President—as supporting the EEP scheme. The EEP scheme and the massive subsidies, recently increased again, are those that are giving our farmers the greatest problems. The question still arises: has the Government any measures in mind? It must surely be prepared for what it should do to protect our farmers.

—Governor Clinton's views on this program were also shared by his predecessor. But the distinction is always drawn whether EEP is a weapon to get an eventual end or just an end in itself. Both President Bush and President-elect Clinton have always argued that EEP was only a means towards an end—that is, to spur on the Uruguay Round and to bring a proper conclusion to it, especially with regard to primary products. Even though Governor Clinton may be on the record as supporting EEP, it is in exactly the same way as President Bush supported EEP. Our Government's attitude has not changed in any way. The sooner EEP comes to a conclusion and disappears, the better.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. It is a simple question in two parts. What action is the Government taking to confiscate from convicted criminals the financial rewards of their crime? Secondly, are these proceeds of crime being used to help the law enforcement effort?

—The Government has established a trust fund into which the profits of crime, stripped from those who have been convicted of serious Commonwealth offences, particularly the importing and trafficking of drugs into Australia, have been placed. At the moment, there is some $2m in that trust fund, and many tens of millions more are available to go into that trust fund should convictions be secured against those who, as I say, are accumulating vast profits from crime through trafficking in drugs principally.

PARA.TAB: It is the intention of the Government that 50 per cent of the moneys in that trust fund be paid to drug education and rehabilitation projects and that 50 per cent be paid for law enforcement. This morning I was able to make the first payment out of that fund to the Federal Police for the construction and setting up of an assessment centre for those who enter the protected witness program. This program is an extremely important one and allows for the secure, safe haven and refuge of those who are prepared to undertake very considerable personal risk to themselves and their families by promising to give evidence against those who are charged with serious crimes such as drug trafficking.

It is a very nice twist to the story of organised crime in Australia that the profits which those involved accumulate that would otherwise be available to fund further criminal activities or perhaps to be laundered in the economy will instead be confiscated from them and be used for drug rehabilitation and law enforcement purposes. In particular, to have the first payment made in relation to the protected witnesses program is extremely important. Over the last several years, 80 per cent of those cases where protected witnesses have appeared in relation to matters brought to the court after Federal Police investigations have resulted in successful trials where convictions have been recorded and an average of eight-year sentences awarded to the criminals concerned.

So the protected witness program is an integral part of this law enforcement effort against organised crime. It is now to be partially funded by profits taken from those who have been convicted of such crimes. I believe that that is a situation which commends itself certainly to the Senate and to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber on my right of a parliamentary delegation from Argentina, led by Senator Orlando Britos. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming the delegation to the Senate. I trust that the visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber on my left of a parliamentary delegation from the Supreme Rada of the Ukraine, led by the Chairman, or Presiding Officer, Mr Ivan Plyushch. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take pleasure in welcoming the delegation to the Senate. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite the Chairman to take a seat on the floor of the chamber.
Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TAB.EMPHASIS: Mr Plyushch was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the Prime Minister has apparently said in the House of Representatives today that the Government, and therefore the Labor Party, believes that the Senate has no right to obstruct the principal policies of the Government in the lower House and that therefore the Labor Party will support a coalition government's goods and services tax, are we to interpret that to also mean that the Government has now decided to support the coalition's industrial relations reform?

—Mr President, I was not listening to what was taking place in the House of Representatives. But I am sure about one thing—that the Prime Minister did not say we would support a GST. He said we would not oppose it, which is a slightly different principle, and one which indeed has mainly been honoured by both political parties in this place.

PARA.TAB: The point which the Prime Minister is making is clearly a different one from the point which Senator Hill puts to me. It is not saying that we would support a GST in the Senate. It means that we would not obstruct the passage of a GST in the Senate if that issue depended on the votes of the Labor Party. That is a principle that, by and large, has been honoured here by both political parties since the fiasco of 1975 when the party of which Senator Hill is a member tore up that tradition. From memory, since then, with almost no exception, it has been honoured by both sides of the House. With some exceptions, honourable senators opposite have not voted against or rejected in the Senate major economic measures of this Government. That does not mean that they support them. They have made it quite clear that they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask for clarification in relation to a specific part of my question—that is, the statement by the Prime Minister and whether all principal policies of the coalition would be supported and not obstructed in the Senate. Are we to interpret that to include that the Government has made a decision not to obstruct the Opposition's industrial relations policy?

—I interpret what the Prime Minister said as meaning what I just said in answer to the question, namely, that there has been a general understanding in the Senate that the opposition party does not reject major economic planks of the platform of a government which has been elected by the Australian people. I very much doubt whether that extends to industrial relations because the tradition has been one related to major economic legislation.

—Further to the question that has just been asked and in view of what has just been reported by the Prime Minister to the House of Representatives, I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: does the collapse of Labor with respect to its opposition to the GST mean that it would not even oppose the GST on the necessities of life—of clothing, food and shelter?
—Matters of detail relating to major economic policies are all determined at a particular point in time.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. How many waterside workers who have retired and taken golden handshakes—in some instances of more than $100,000—under the Government's inadequate waterfront reform program have returned as casual employees to the wharves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure of what the number is—I think it is very small. I will obtain the number and provide it to the honourable senator shortly. Senator Chapman has drawn the Senate's attention to the waterfront reform initiatives of this Government, although he was unkind enough to do so in an unflattering way. I think the record should be corrected. The Government has succeeded in achieving major micro-economic reform on the wharves in Australia. The number of waterside workers on Australian wharves has been reduced by 56 per cent—a reduction in labour of 56 per cent—while at the same time productivity per head has been increased dramatically. Container handling times at Australia's major ports, on average, compare favourably with world averages at leading ports around the world.

PARA.TAB: I know that from time to time the Opposition tries to misrepresent this by selectively choosing ports internationally that perform better than the international average—and the Opposition is good at that—in devaluing the efforts being made by Australians who work on the waterfront to make their industry efficient. However, the Government gives credit where it is due.

Credit is due here and we acknowledge the reduction in manning, the increase in efficiency and the fact that this major reform was conducted without any real disputation. That ought to stand in contradistinction to the threat made by Dr Hewson, on behalf of the coalition, at the National Press Club when he said that he would be prepared to put troops onto the waterfront in Australia in order to force waterfront change.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I asked a very specific question of the Minister which he was unable to provide a specific answer to. The answer which he is now providing is entirely irrelevant to the question which I asked.

—On the point of order: the question contained innuendo and insinuations about waterfront reform. Since Senator Chapman included those erroneous references, surely I am entitled to correct the record so that the truth can speak.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I support the remarks of my colleague. The question was very specific indeed: how many waterside workers who have retired and taken golden handshakes, in some instances of more than $100,000, under the Government's inadequate waterfront reform program, have returned as casual employees on the wharves? It is a very straightforward question which has nothing to do with what the Minister was talking about.
—Order! In reply to the point of order, the Minister towards the end of his answer was not being particularly relevant. I would ask him to conclude his answer.

—I will conclude my answer—in any case, I am nearly out of time. The references in this question to our record on waterfront reform are not true; they propound the myths that the Opposition wants Australians to believe. The exercise now for waterfront reform is to see that the people along the chain—the shipping companies and some port authorities, namely, the New South Wales Port Authority, which paid a dividend to the State Government of $35m, a tax on exports and imports in Australia—actually pass through the real benefits of reform to the users. I refer to the companies that ship goods in and out of Australia. That is the next step of the reform, and I will be saying something about that shortly. The reform is genuine, real and true and I congratulate the Australians who have been part of it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note with interest the Minister's inability to answer the specific question that I asked him. When the Minister does find out how many of the waterside workers to whom I referred have returned as casual employees, will he ensure that the golden handshakes that they have received are repaid to the authority and are perhaps used to pass on some cost benefits to the shippers which, despite his ramblings in his answer to the question, have still not received any benefit from the Government's claimed waterfront reform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition cannot help itself, Mr President. Although the full benefit has not been passed through, the figures I have show that the charges to shippers have been reduced by between 20 per cent and 25 per cent, and at a time in which one expects prices to go up, a reduction of between 20 per cent and 25 per cent is quite an achievement.

—On a point of order, Mr President: again, I asked a specific question of the Minister, which was whether he would require those workers who have returned to the waterfront, contrary to the intention of the waterfront reform program, to repay the golden handshakes they have received. I ask the Minister to answer that question.

—That is another vexatious point of order. Senator Chapman also asked whether the benefits had been passed on, as did other interjectors. If Opposition members want to interject and make points, the Minister is at least entitled to defend himself.
—There is no point of order.

—Let me come to the question. I did not specify exactly the number, because I am not quite sure of the number, but I did say that it was very few. When the number is produced it will be revealed as very few. I like to give accurate information to the Senate to the last figure. In terms of whether labour picked up on a casual basis to meet short term needs because of efficiency requirements should be made to pay back benefits received when the employment was terminated as full time, ongoing employment on a secure basis, the answer is no.
—Order! The time for the Minister's answer has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it true that annual leave loading payments are a small proportion of wage costs? Does the Government have any plans to remove annual leave loadings from Federal awards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Foreman has indicated, that the total value of annual leave loadings to total labour costs is very small. In fact, it is less than one per cent. As a percentage of the annual wage cost in isolation it is about 1.3 per cent. In the middle of last night the Victorian Government took away annual leave loadings by legislative fiat for Victorians under State awards, and did so retrospectively. This is a Government used to taking away rights when people sleep—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. The question was put in two parts: firstly, is it true that annual leave loadings are a small part of wage costs and, secondly, does the Government have any plan to remove them? The Minister is now telling us what was happening in Victoria last night, which seems to be totally irrelevant to the question that he was asked. He has said that it is a small part. He can now tell us whether his Government has any plans to remove it.

—Mr President, I know that today we have obviously got some Opposition tactic to raise pointless points of order, but this is the most ridiculous of all because it is directly relevant to the question that was asked—what is going on with regard to exactly the subject matter about which the question was directed. It is not as if the Minister is talking about some other matter of policy. He is speaking directly about annual leave loadings, which is exactly the point of the question.
—I do not think there is a point of order. I will allow Senator Cook to continue.

—The Victorian Government did not do what it could have done and taken its case—if it believed it had one—to the Industrial Relations Commission in the State, allowed those who opposed its views to be heard in argument and allowed an independent tribunal to make a judgment about whether justice, equity and the substantial merits of the case would apply in the views of the Victorian Government on annual leave loadings.

PARA.TAB: We do not have any plans at all to cut out in that manner annual leave loadings, or in any other manner, for that reason. Why do we not have such plans? One of the reasons is that the annual leave loading allows mum, dad and the kids to have a holiday at Christmas time. It allows people whose wages would be lower, because they are on the base rate of their award when they are on annual leave than the rate they normally receive at work, to make up the difference and to have a holiday. All those caravan park owners and small chalet owners who rely on internal tourism for their business, all those small business people, would suffer as well. It would be a crippling blow for them.

It is also true that annual leave loading is a feature of many other countries in the world. It is not exclusive to Australia. Indeed, the level of annual leave loading in Australia is low by international standards. Let me name some of the countries that have annual leave loadings of some sort or another: Belgium, Denmark, Greece, the Netherlands, Norway, Portugal and Sweden. Of that list we are the second lowest, and the second lowest by a long streak.

I know it is the obsession of the coalition in its State or Federal manifestations to cut wages and to reduce the income of ordinary Australians, and to work against people rather than work with them. We will not be party to that. The Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Alan Stockdale, let the cat out of the bag when he said just last week that he knows that what they are doing in Victoria is what the Federal Opposition intends to do, if it gets a chance, in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is addressed to you. If any member of the Senate used the same unparliamentary words regarding members of the House of Representatives as the Prime Minister used in referring to the Senate—as `unrepresentative swill'—would you demand an apology or a withdrawal?

—I point out to Senator Walters that we have standing order 193(3), which applies to remarks that are made about the House of Representatives. I have always applied that rule and I will continue to apply it in the future.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The House of Representatives has a similar rule and I was wondering whether you could tell me why that was not put into action yesterday?
—I am in charge of the Senate, not of the House of Representatives.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice. In view of the completion of the national strategy on violence against women, can the Minister report on recent discussions by Federal-State Ministers responsible for monitoring community standards in relation to levels of violence shown in films and on television?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am generally aware of the response by the Federal Government to the recent strategy concerning violence against women in our community. Only late last week, the Prime Minister indicated that any society which tolerated acts of violence against women—whether by way of general physical assault, or particularly sexual assault—was a society which needed proper reforming, particularly of the underlying cultural values which allowed that to occur. I think this mostly occurred on the day of or on the eve of the `Reclaim the Night' marches, principally by women but in some cases supported by men. The need to demonstrate to Australian society that women had a perfect right to walk our streets, particularly at night, without fear of being molested or sexually assaulted was made very clear.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Government certainly supports that and has been very welcoming of the national strategy put forward by the National Committee on Violence Against Women. That had several elements, and one that I know will be of interest to Senator Reynolds and

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crowley is the strategy which speaks of the need to educate lawyers and judges, amongst others, about the changing community attitudes concerning this matter. Whilst, of course, that could not affect the question of the guilt or innocence of a person being tried, it should lead to a proper appreciation of the sentencing and the corrections which ought to be visited on a person who is convicted of such violence.

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned many times in this chamber the need for the euphemism `domestic violence' to be shed in favour of the true recognition that one is speaking of criminal violence in the home. Of course, home should be a refuge from violence, but it is often a place where women and children either experience violence or have their minds and values formed by observation of violence against another member of the household.

Whilst I am aware that the Federal Government provides much money for women's refuges—I think there are over 260 refuges throughout Australia—and has other programs, I am not at the moment well acquainted with the meeting which Senator Reynolds referred to as a joint meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers. I am quite sure that they would share the sentiment of the Federal Government and its response to the national strategy concerning violence against women. I am not particularly aware of what practical programs or policies have been enunciated by that joint Commonwealth-State ministerial council, but I will certainly make the resolutions of that conference available to the Senate as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former Senator Jo Vallentine and I wish her well on her return to Canberra.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Tate referred to the reform of cultural values. I would be very pleased to be kept informed of progress in limiting the amount of violent material approved for general viewing. I ask the Minister to add that to the other material he was going to refer to me.

—I know that the Prime Minister certainly shares the view that there is a tremendous amount of violence shown on television and other media which needs to be constantly monitored by parents. That creates great difficulties within a household. I am quite sure that this general view put by Senator Reynolds is shared in the community. There is a need to deal with that matter, as Attorneys-General and Ministers concerned with censorship matters did a year or so ago in instructing the Film Classification Board to be more stringent in the classifications which it awarded to particular films.

PARA.TAB: Senator Reynolds has raised a matter of very real concern and I believe it merits further attention by the Government and, indeed, by this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister acting for the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. What scientific evidence is there that the husky dogs which have been at the Australian Antarctic base of Mawson since 1911—80 years—are or have ever been a threat to the ecology or the environment of the Antarctic? Is it a fact that the British and Argentinians are leaving the dogs they have at their bases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —In my capacity as Minister representing the Minister who represents the Minister for the Environment, I will take that question on notice and see that an answer is given to Senator Crichton-Browne in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and it refers to an OFLC/ABT survey of 1,076 persons aged 16 and over which supported the sale and hire of X-rated videos. Was not that survey seriously flawed in that the respondents were not fully informed of the true nature of those videos? Is it not a fact that the respondents were merely told that X-rated videos contained scenes about actual sex between consenting adults and were not told that X-rated videos are officially described as `hard core pornography'? Is it not a fact that the survey respondents were not told that the Joint Select Committee on Video Material observed that X-rated videos treat women as sexual objects—
—Order! The time allowed for asking the question has expired.

—I am not aware of the exact form in which certain questions may have been put in a survey being undertaken for the Office of Film and Literature Classification board. I will get the exact form of the words that were used. I think it would be unlikely that respondents were asked about the question in the context of the particular resolutions, recommendations or conclusions of a Senate committee, but I will check the exact form of the wording and make it available to the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am fully aware of the wording. They were merely told what I mentioned they were told. I understand that there are ethical problems in describing or showing to respondents 16 years of age and over `sexploit' material contained in X-rated videos, but, even so, if they were told of the true nature of the videos, as described, would it not be a possibility that there would have been another result?

—I have no reason to suppose that the respondents were not aware of the general nature of X-rated videos when the question was put to them. The way in which they responded accordingly may not require any modification in the light of not being further and fully informed in the way that Senator Harradine would have liked the question to be contextualised. All I can do is offer to provide to the Senate the exact wording of the questions that were put.
—I have it here.
—If Senator Harradine has the wording, why did he ask me the question?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Is the Minister aware of the high volume of paperwork being experienced by hostels subsidised by the Commonwealth Government as a result of the new personal care assessment procedures? Is he aware that the new system has placed additional procedures upon staff, added work, reduced the time for care by the supervisors and placed financial responsibilities upon care staff? Is he also aware that as there are no departmental guidelines, forms and interpretations for these assessments, the staff in these hostels feel that the extra paperwork and reduced patient care could be all to no avail if the paperwork submitted is not accepted by the Department? What action will the Minister take to streamline the paperwork and thus allow hostel staff to spend more of their time performing their primary duty of caring for patients?

—I think it is obviously very important that a proper balance be struck in terms of what Senator Bjelke-Petersen calls care of patients in hostels. If they are in hostels the better term would be residents, or people who are not so frail or ill that they are required to be upgraded and assessed as being proper for nursing home care and attention. Nevertheless, in relation to those who are receiving the security and the safe haven of a hostel as elderly people within our community, it is important that the care they receive is not diminished by an undue emphasis on the need to provide proper records as to the care that is being provided at taxpayers' expense. That is the other factor that has to be brought into the balance.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that many hundreds of millions of dollars are spent in recurrent and capital costs in support of these hostels. It is very important that not only from the technical point of view of the Auditor-General of the Commonwealth, for example, but from the point of view of us all as taxpayers and as parliamentarians who scrutinise these matters that the payments made to these hostels be properly accounted for and that the services that are contracted to be provided are indeed provided. So there is a question of balance.

If in any particular instance there is evidence that the forms are proliferating and that completing them is so time consuming that care of residents is being very unduly affected, that would be a matter which I am sure the Minister with responsibilities for the care of the aged in our Australian community would want to take up. I believe that if we had some—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell him now because it is.

—If we had further evidence from Senator Patterson or Senator Bjelke-Petersen in regard to specific instances, that might indeed aid a review of the sort of paperwork and administrative procedures that those who are involved in nursing or other positions within these hostels have to undertake.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. During the last recess I visited a number of these hostels and nursing homes and those concerned realise that there has to be accountability. But they said that accountability in terms of handling all these forms and details takes up time that could be spent in looking after their patients. I would be very grateful if Senator Tate could bring the matter to the attention of the appropriate Minister and ask if it is not possible to have something done about it?
—I have already undertaken to do that, and I certainly reaffirm that intention.

—My question is directed to Senator Cook in his capacity as Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer the Minister to recent press reports that Mr David Hardman, the Civil Aviation Authority's noise expert and chairman of a working group on airport noise, is pushing for northerly take-offs to be allowed from the planned third runway at Sydney Airport. Can the Minister guarantee that no such northerly take-offs will be allowed, as originally stipulated by the Government in the third runway environmental impact statement?
—I call the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Cook.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in my full capacity, I think, Mr President.
—Precious to the end.
—The record should be accurate, and I think that even Senator Alston would agree with that.
—No, he wouldn't. He is a lawyer.

—I am wrong. He probably would not agree that the record should be accurate. The answer to this question is that the Government said in March 1989 that there would be no take-offs to the north on the third runway when it was constructed at Sydney Airport. That remains the position, and nothing has happened to cause us to change that position.
