PARA.TAB: The David Hardman report that is referred to in the question from Senator Faulkner relates to a document prepared as a technical paper. This was prepared in full consultation with the community representatives as part of a process to develop environmental management plans for the airport. It has been speculated about in the Sydney Morning Herald and doubtless that is the reason why this question now arises so that the position can be clarified.

The paper has no formal status as far as we are concerned. It was prepared solely to assist the technical working group in examining options which may have noise benefits to the community. The information in the technical paper is not new. Similar information was contained in the environmental impact statement prepared for the third runway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: what research and analyses have been commissioned by the Government into what went wrong with the management of the economy at a national level, so that in future an economic recession of such length and intensity will be avoided?
—I do not know, but there may be some global organisation that is looking at those issues and looking at the recession in Britain, which is deeper than ours.
—It is not. It is 10.1 per cent and yours is 11 per cent.

—Is this the measure? There have been nine quarters of negative growth, and the recession in Britain marks the end of Thatcherism, a cause which the Opposition has espoused so diligently over the last few years. Yesterday's election in the United States—where there is a very deep recession—happened for the same reason and it marks the end of Reaganism, which the Opposition has espoused with such enthusiasm over the years.

PARA.TAB: One can go around the world—to North America and Europe—and ask precisely the same sort of question as the one that Senator MacGibbon has just asked as to why the recession in those countries is as deep as it is.

As to analysis and frankness about the recession in Australia, we have said over and over again in this place at Question Time that the tight monetary policy administered by this Government in 1989 and 1990 was kept on too long. We have said that on numerous occasions. Every economic commentator in this country who assessed the question at that time said that the Government was right.

Another economic commentator had views on this matter because, when we proposed to loosen monetary policy, who opposed it on every occasion?—Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition. The first six times it was proposed to loosen monetary policy, Dr Hewson opposed it. He said the Australian economy would take off into another boom if we did that.

Senator MacGibbon should not come in here and ask me silly questions about analysis. All of us here are in politics and I hope we know the name of the game. We know what Dr Hewson thought about these issues at all relevant times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. For the information of the Minister, this is not a silly game. This is a matter of the utmost seriousness because the national debt is at about $150 billion and there are over one million unemployed. Since the Minister does not recognise that there is any body of scholarship in economic theory, is he prepared to appoint consultants to look at where the Government went wrong?

—It would be a huge exercise. If Senator MacGibbon wants to bring the question of the current account into this matter, it would be a huge exercise. It would have to go back over 30 years of conservative government in this country when there was no diversification in the economy.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition thought that this country would live off the sheep's back forever. The last coalition government in this country did nothing about opening the economy to international competition or improving the export orientation of this economy. It did not do a thing. Senator MacGibbon should have a look at the figures. In 1991 exports were at 23 per cent of GDP, which was the highest figure ever attained. That was a hard thing to do. It was not easy, but when the coalition was in government it always took the soft options, and run away from it. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —At the start of Question Time today I received a question from Senator Hill concerning the remarks that were made yesterday by the Prime Minister. I would like to point out to honourable senators that I received a delegation yesterday afternoon from Senator Hill and Senator Short about this matter at approximately 20 or 25 minutes to six. I mention this because I had a meeting with the Ukrainian delegation at a quarter to six, and a meeting with the Western Samoan delegation and a dinner, which lasted from a quarter past six until approximately 9 o'clock, but I did put out a statement. I was able to get in touch with the Prime Minister and I told him of the statement I had made.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the remarks the Prime Minister made yesterday were made in a political debate. I did not believe that there was a row between the two Houses. I did not believe that it was my role to enter into a political debate and, naturally, as the chamber would be aware, I am not in charge of events that happen in the House of Representatives. I think I should read to all of you the statement that I made because, at the same time as I received the delegation, I had a number of requests from the news media. I said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I have been asked for my reaction to the statements in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister concerning the Senate and Senate committee inquiries.
It is my role as President to preside over the proceedings of the Senate and to ensure they are conducted in accordance with the rules of the Senate.

It is not my role to defend the Senate from any public criticism, whether by Prime Ministers or any other persons. The standing of the Senate in the community will depend on public appreciation of its work, and not upon any statements which I or others might make.

It is not my role, and it would not be proper for me, to enter into a political debate between members of the two Houses. Other Senators are free to do that and I am sure that I can safely leave it to them.

I believe that that is what happened today. The Senate made a decision on the remarks that the Prime Minister made. I have had the opportunity today to go back through the records of my predecessors and I can say that this is the role that my predecessors have taken in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question.
—Oh, come on! Question Time is over.
—The President said that he would answer the question before the end of Question Time, so he ought to be prepared to take a supplementary question.
—I am not sure it is in order, but I will take it.
—Mr President, in the light of that answer I remind you of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice, which you have no doubt checked yourself. Page 213 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The traditional comity between the two Houses is observed by refraining from reflections on the proceedings of the other House and by the general rule that it is not in order for a member to use words in reference to a member of the other House which would not be allowed if applied to a member of his own House.

Mr President, do you agree that the conduct of the Prime Minister was contrary to that tradition? Do you maintain the position that you have just outlined to us, despite the continuing contemptuous abuse of the Prime Minister in Question Time today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, I believe that I dealt with the point you made in your supplementary question in my answer to your main question. I also take this opportunity to point out that we did pass through this chamber a Parliamentary Privileges Act, the result of which meant that what the Prime Minister said yesterday is now no longer a contempt of Parliament.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order under standing order 193(3) relating to offensive words and personal reflections. I want to ask you, Mr President, in the light of a ruling made in another place today, whether, if I refer to Senator Button as Senator `Pansy' Button, I am in order and that is quite parliamentary.

—Order! It is not a point of order. However, there was another question today from Senator Walters, and I said that we have a rule in the Senate, standing order 193(3), which I have always enforced and will continue to enforce.

—Could I ask you a question following on from that? Could I ask you how it is that you could have a term which is parliamentary in one chamber and not parliamentary in the other. May I refer to Senator Button as Senator `Pansy' Button?

—Order! This whole procedure is out of order, but I do not mind answering. What I endorse in this chamber has nothing to do with what is endorsed in the other chamber. I said that I will endorse the Standing Orders here and I intend to do so.
—If Senator Bishop wants to call me `Pansy', I do not mind. It will be the nicest thing she has called me. I like pansies; they are very colourful, nice things.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday, Senator Short asked me a question about the Victorian Government's borrowings. I undertook to seek a response from the Treasurer. The Treasurer has advised me that the issues in this matter have been comprehensively dealt with. I regard that as a bit of an understatement. It is clear that he has in all respects acted properly and in accordance with established, longstanding processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —A week or two ago, Senator Herron asked a question concerning the access to Medicare benefits of Australian missionaries from Papua New Guinea who recently returned to Australia. I have provided a copy of the answer to Senator Herron. I seek leave to have the answer to be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Why were Australian missionaries in Papua New Guinea, who recently visited Australia, denied access to Medicare?

PARA.TAB: From the outset I (Howe) want to stress that in a program as complex as Medicare that anomalies can exist. In view of recently raised issues relating to Medicare eligibility requirements, it is proposed to review these requirements, in particular compatibility with other Commonwealth legislation.

Eligibility for Medicare is governed by the Health Insurance Act, and is based on residence in Australia, not citizenship. In the case of Australian citizens, they must be permanently resident in Australia to be eligible for Medicare. The Act was amended in 1988 to ensure that eligibility was restricted to bona fide Australian residents.
To be regarded as residents under the Act, expatriate Australian citizens must show a clear intention to resume residency in this country.

When enrolling in Medicare the missionaries indicated to the Medicare office that they were no longer permanently resident in Australia. The Health Insurance Commission then wrote and explained the requirement in the Act for residency, and invited further information before deciding on their eligibility. No reply has been received. I understand that the missionaries have approached another Medicare office but an enrolment form has not been submitted at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the President, in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the response by the President on 4 November 1992 responding to remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).
Senator Button interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know Senator Button is disinterested in issues of standards. However, I do not believe, Mr President, that your statement should rest simply with what you have put to us today, because I for one would certainly wish to register my disappointment at that statement. I think, with respect, you have failed to appreciate the proper functions and responsibilities you have towards this chamber.

PARA.TAB: We all have a role to defend the institution because it is a critical part of this democracy and nobody has a greater responsibility in that regard than the President of the Senate himself. I will not argue with you when you say that it is not proper for you to enter into political debate between members of the two Houses. That is not in dispute. What is in dispute apparently, sadly, is your role when this chamber—this institution—is abused in the way that it was by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday; and in relation to that you wash your hands of it.

I want to register my disappointment about that, Mr President. I would expect more of the President of the Senate. I disagree when you say, `It is not my role to defend the Senate from any public criticism, whether by the Prime Minister or any other persons'. I believe it is your role and I am disappointed that you do not appreciate that it is so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to this motion. Firstly, I endorse the comments made by Senator Button when Senator Hill raised the matter. It is now 20 minutes past 3 and we are still dealing with this monumental, self-interested exercise of staring into the mirror, saying, `Aren't we wonderful? How can anybody criticise us?'. What a scandalous waste of the taxpayers' money for those opposite to be going on and on about this when there are nine pieces of legislation that the taxpayers have sent us to vote on.

PARA.TAB: I want to say something in support of the President. I think that Senator Sibraa is an excellent President of this Senate. He bends over backwards to be fair. I would have to say this is not always to the advantage of those on this side of the chamber. From time to time we have a go at him because we wish he was more on our side. But he is very objective.

Senator Sibraa is entitled to have the very proper view about the role of the President of the Senate—which, as I understand it, is entirely consistent with the role which all Presidents of the Senate have taken—and his or her function in relation to the political debate that goes on, particularly in the House of Representatives. I do not want to retrace the question that was raised in the urgency motion earlier because much more time than was justified was wasted on that this morning. The President has stated carefully and reasonably what is his role in terms of the proceedings of the Senate and what is not his role, which is to become its advocate in the public debate about its role.

As a senator, Senator Sibraa is entitled to do that, as we all are. That is a right which, at great length and through tedious repetition, was exercised this morning. Nevertheless, it is a right which was exercised. The President has it—we all have it—but he has no special obligation in terms of the political debate. He has a proper role to explain the functions of the Senate and to protect the proper proceedings of the Senate in here, but his role is not to defend it from any and every public criticism that takes place in a robust democracy where people healthily get up and make their comments about the House of Representatives, which we do in here often, the Senate, which people do in that other chamber from time to time, or any other public institution. It is time that we supported the President in his proper and impartial role, which he discharges very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add a couple of words to this debate to support the words of my colleague and leader, Senator Hill. In doing so, Mr President, I take care not to reflect on your capacity as President. Most of us would agree that you have done, and do, overall a very objective job as President.

PARA.TAB: I find it quite concerning, to say the least, that you, as the President of the Senate, feel it is not your role as President in any way to defend the institution of the Senate from criticism by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or anyone else. I do not believe that it is a matter purely of words said in the course of political debate. We would certainly agree with you that you should not get involved in the thrust of political debate. But I do not believe that it is a matter just of the thrust of political debate for the Prime Minister of this country to get up and contemptuously abuse the basic underpinning establishments of the nation. Surely the Senate is one of them, along with the House of Representatives, as part of the Parliament.

Mr President, Senator McMullan said in his response that it was not your job as President to defend the Senate from any and every criticism. A criticism of the nature that the Prime Minister levelled at the Senate and its role yesterday is not criticism from anyone and everyone; it is from the senior public figure in this nation. Mr President, I hope that you will be able to inform us in due course—and I hope that you do it sooner rather than later—of what you see as your role in terms of defending the Senate from criticism.

If the President of the Senate does not feel able or believe that it is his role to defend from criticism the institution over which he presides, I believe that we run a very grave risk of continuing the debasement of the Senate in the way that the Prime Minister and others have done. Mr President, I very much regret the answer that you have given today, because it puts the Senate at very serious risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think that you have acted correctly in this matter. I say that for the following reason: your function here is to keep order in this chamber. It is for the House of Representatives to take such actions against its members as it thinks proper. Much of the debate that has taken place in this chamber today should have taken place there. Mr President, you have been challenged again and again today on the rulings that you have made. You are now being criticised. It has been said that you have not been criticised in terms of your office, but that is what has happened. I suggest that that brings this place into more disrespect than anything else.

PARA.TAB: If we gave you much more cooperation than you are presently getting, we would be helping you, ourselves and this chamber. Your rulings are constantly, implicitly, if not explicitly, challenged. The whole place is very difficult to keep in order. You are criticised for not complaining about a couple of words which were used by a Prime Minister. We have to remember that debate amongst politicians in this place and in the House of Representatives is sometimes very robust. It is a great pity that your answer has been taken note of. I think the debate that is going on at the moment will do more harm than anything else to this chamber and to you.

If the chamber wants to, it can exhibit and express its view. The chamber itself has already done that. Why should you have to do any more than what you are obliged to do under the Standing Orders, which is to keep order in this chamber?

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the remarks of my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Short. Mr President, I, too, am concerned about the ruling and answer that you have given. Unlike Senator Schacht and some of the people on the other side of this chamber—and, I suggest, perhaps unlike you—I do see that the role of the President goes further than merely chairing this chamber. I believe that the office you hold is one of great honour and prestige in the governing of this country. The powers which you exercise can be traced back in many ways to Presidents and Speakers—Presiding Officers—who have stood up for the rights of their chambers. I put it to you that today you have defined a very narrow role for the President of this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, we do not expect you to defend the Senate from any and all attacks which are made on it. We do not expect you to get involved in public debate. But we do suggest to you that the great challenges in history which have typically been faced by the Presiding Officers have been to defend their chambers against the Executive—in ancient times the King, and in more recent times, Prime Ministers.

I put it to you that when a Prime Minister acts in the way that Mr Keating has acted in the last day or so, it is up to you to defend this chamber and to make your views known to the Prime Minister that the sort of language he used and the attack he made are absolutely unacceptable. Mr President—I am sorry to have to say this—I feel that you have failed in your duty; I feel that you have defined a very narrow role for your office.

In recent days I have noticed that your portrait has been hung in the great hall of this Parliament. You are regarded as one of the most important people in this Parliament. You are more than just a chairman of this chamber; you are far more than that. You are far more than just an administrator of a government department. Primarily, you are the most senior officer of the Senate and the man whom we look to to defend the Senate when it comes under attack from the Executive. I urge you to look more closely at and reflect on what you said. Perhaps at a later time you could inform us of the precedents you referred to in your comments which have inclined you to take such a narrow view of your duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to support the answer that you gave to Senator Hill and the statement that you issued yesterday. I think it is appalling that Senator Hill has taken the opportunity to accuse you of not carrying out your duties properly as President of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, Opposition senators want you to become a partisan participant in a political debate when they think it suits them, and only then. If I had a criticism, Mr President, it would be that in recent times in the Senate I have noticed that you have been far too lenient on endless points of order raised by Senator Bishop, Senator Kemp and others to disrupt the proceedings of this place. On a number of occasions, you have been far too soft. I think those honourable senators should have been named and suspended from this place for 24 hours. But, in the non-partisan way you run and chair this place, you have bent over backwards to be fair to all honourable senators to give them every opportunity to express their views, even when they have transgressed your standing as a President.

Senator Kemp implied that you have let the Senate down, in the same way as happened in 1688 or 1648 in the Westminster Parliament. That was absolute sanctimonious hypocrisy on his part. As Senator McMullan said, the Opposition has had all day on this issue, going around and around trying to squeeze every bit of moisture out of this particular issue. Now it is down to an attack on the integrity of the President of the Senate.

In the five years I have been a member of the Senate, you as President have chaired this chamber very fairly without partisanship. You administer the running of the Senate very well, again, in a non-partisan way. Unfortunately, a group of rump senators in the Opposition have chosen to abuse your goodwill again and again in this chamber by endless points of order as a political stunt, and that is what we have had today.

The answer you have given, Mr President, is excellent and ought to be supported unanimously by the Senate because you have quite correctly identified the difference between involving the position of a President of the Senate in a political stunt and the true duties of a President of the Senate in administering and chairing this Senate in a non-partisan way, which you have done excellently in the five years since I have been here. As I said, occasionally you have shown far too much lenience to the stunt merchants opposite who are more interested in making political points than the fair standing of this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, one does not need to make the obvious observation, but let me say that I have always found that you have sought to discharge your obligations and your duties in this chamber with fairness, reasonableness and with measured judgment to the extent that, in a party-political system, it is possible to be thoroughly impartial to everybody with the enormous pressures.

PARA.TAB: I do not rise now to criticise you but just to remind you that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has reflected upon this chamber, the institution of this chamber, all members of this chamber and the functioning of this chamber in a very disparaging, unsavoury, unpleasant and, quite frankly, thoroughly unnecessary way.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the frank bit, is it, Senator?

—Mr President, I would ask you to reflect on the fact that there is an obligation upon you, as President of the Senate, to convey to the Prime Minister, on behalf of the institution of the Senate, your disapproval of his reflection upon this chamber. You can do it with more effectiveness than can anybody else. And I put it to you with the force that I am able: in many respects, it is an incumbent responsibility of yours.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister demonstrated his normal conduct; that is, the moment he is challenged, the moment this Senate used its powers to scrutinise, examine, contemplate or reflect upon the performance, the operations or the functioning of the Government, with the crude discharge for which he is well known, the Prime Minister then turned with vile viciousness and in a bitter way upon those who sought to fulfil their obligations as legislators.

There is something very unsavoury about a Prime Minister who fears the full force of scrutiny of a parliamentary committee that is set up to examine the conduct and the operations of the Government and its relationship with the various arms of government and the various State governments. The Prime Minister has attacked this chamber using the vile language for which he is well known—infamous, in fact—and which he seems to take some pride in and some credit for. Thank goodness hippies do not vote for hippies, and we can expect him to get ignominiously dumped at the next election, not only for his own conduct but also for his conduct of the Government.
I ask you, Mr President, to reflect on whether or not you should convey to the Prime Minister on behalf of the Senate your disapproval of his reflection upon this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to indicate that certainly in my view and, I am sure, in the view of most of my colleagues there has been no dereliction of duty whatsoever on your part in the way you have responded to the various issues that have arisen over the last day or so. There has been no failure to fulfil any obligation upon you as President of the Senate. Indeed, Senator Kemp spoke collectively of yourself and the Speaker as Presiding Officers, and there is no doubt that that is the primary and principal function that you have to discharge, that is, to act as the Presiding Officer in this chamber and to ensure that order is kept. I think it is a very wise and prudent course that, in order to ensure that you have the confidence of the chamber in discharging that principal role, you do not get involved in day to day political controversy, even if it does go to the role of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the test of the propriety and prudence with which you have conducted yourself is to ask this question: what if the motion that was put by the Opposition and supported by the Democrats today had not been passed and you had gone out and made statements as President of the Senate in terms which were later embodied in that motion? We would have found a situation where the Senate chamber had voted against some expression that you might have made in those same terms. That illustrates how very wise and prudent you were not to enter into that controversy.

Honourable senators ought to reflect on this point: that the motion having been passed by the Senate, the President, as I understand it, has already very properly conveyed a message embodying that resolution of the Senate to the House of Representatives, I suppose to the Speaker of the House of Representatives. So the President, insofar as he has a duty and an obligation and insofar as those terms have been used, has indeed discharged that duty and fulfilled that obligation to the Senate chamber. I believe that that is his proper role. I am not sure whether you were in here for the vote on that, Mr President, but whatever your personal view on the matter of political controversy you have fulfilled your duty and obligation and conveyed the resolution of the Senate to the House of Representatives. That is what can be properly required of you by this chamber. I believe that you have done that and I believe that in so doing you have preserved the proper role of the Presiding Officer of this Senate chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some points that Senator Tate just made that are pertinent to what I have to say. Basically, what Senator Tate had to say would have some validity, Mr President, if you had not chosen to make this statement in the form you have so chosen. The point that has to be made is that when you accept the office of President part and parcel of accepting that office is the responsibility to uphold the dignity of the Senate without fear or favour. If one ever gets to the point of feeling that one cannot carry out that duty, then one should relinquish it. When we had the censure motion early in the day, a matter of tremendous importance to the Senate and to the Parliament as a whole—and as I pointed out earlier in the day, the Parliament is composed of the Queen, the Senate and House of Representatives together—you did not even bother to stay in the chair for the debate of that particular motion. You may say, Mr President—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I think that Senator Bishop's remarks are clearly a reflection upon yourself carrying out your duties as President of the Senate. She has no idea what other duties you were performing or why you could not be in the chamber all the time. I think she should withdraw that remark, which is a clear imputation against the standing of the Chair.
—Order! There was a reason why I was out of the chamber. I will make that point later.
—In response to what Senator Schacht raised—
—There is no point of order.

—There is. On the same point of order: it is a very important feature of the Senate when a censure motion of this nature is used. I am sure there may be the occasion when it is not possible for the President to be in the chamber, but one would want that to be a particularly good reason because the motion was of great seriousness.
—Order! In reply to the point of order, I was outside organising a committee meeting at the request of the Opposition Whip. I call Senator Bishop.

—Mr President, if you had allowed me to make the point I was making, I said that you had not remained in the chair and I was going on to point out that, presumably, you had some duty which was attached to the importance of your office. I was going to make a presumption that it had been to do with a visiting delegation and that you were carrying out a duty that was attached to that. Quite frankly, merely attending a committee meeting, I think, has some difficulty.
—No, I did not.
—Senator Bishop, you are just a slanderer!
—Order! Senator Faulkner, will you withdraw that? You are not helping the debate.
—I withdraw, Mr President, if it is unparliamentary.

—There is a difficulty within our system where we have the tradition of the Presiding Officer remaining an active member of a political party—and the office of President is so important it is mentioned in the Constitution. Whether or not we want to debate the question of that convention on another day is another point. But while we have the tradition of the Presiding Officer remaining an active member of a political party, there is a continual balancing act between the duty that you have in accepting the office of President of the chamber and the duty you have as an active political party member.

PARA.TAB: The point that I made in saying that Senator Tate's point of view had some merit in it was quite correct—if this statement had not been made. But for you, Mr President, to walk away from the obligation you have to uphold the dignity of the Senate is another question. Had you chosen not to make this statement but had merely chosen at the end of the day—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to take one or two minutes of the Senate's time to take note of your statement. I refer the Senate to the third paragraph of your statement. You said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my role to defend the Senate from any public criticism, whether by Prime Ministers or any other persons. The standing of the Senate in the community—
and this is the key point that you are making—
will depend upon public appreciation of its work and not upon any statements which I or others might make.

You have never spoken a truer word, Mr President. What we do in here determines what the public thinks of us. What the public thinks of us determines the status and the privileges and the rights of the Senate. When we fall foul of the public, when we waste time, when we cannot organise our day in order to debate issues properly, when we cannot organise public inquiries to make sure that those inquiries, for example, are debated here productively and effect the work of the Executive, then that is a problem for the Senate. But it is a role for us to maintain.

PARA.TAB: You, sir, have shown yourself to be scrupulously fair in that chair on many, many occasions. You have been as fair, I believe, as any President can be, given that you are a member of a political party. My view is well known: I think the two officers, the President and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, should not be members of political parties; they should resign from them when they take office and be protected against challenge. I believe that if that were the case, you would still be elected President because of the way you have handled yourself in this chamber and in that role.

Nevertheless, if the Liberal Party is concerned about that issue, it ought to support discussions in relation to parliamentary reform. You, Mr President, would be protected against having to seek pre-selection in a bad position on your ticket; you would not be challenged in an election. That, in your particular case, would be a just approach.

The way for the Senate to respond to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is not to pat itself on the back, to get all unctuous and moral because, to be quite frank, when we are unctuous and moral as a House, we are pretty unpalatable; we are awful. It does not matter where we are looking—whether I am looking at those opposite or they are looking at me—unctuousness and sanctimony is an awful thing to observe. Occasionally the Senate whips itself into a froth of indignation which is awful to behold. Quite frankly, the Prime Minister and a number of other Ministers have, in this Government and in previous Governments, said a great deal about the Senate and a lot of it has been true because on the very next day we, as a House, have gone out and proved that they were right.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not saying necessarily that I agree with that. Pigs have in fact taken up a lot of time in this chamber. We have had the pig controversy and pigs have flown and all sorts of things. I do not agree with that comment, but what does it matter? Who cares? I do not agree with a lot of comments made by my colleagues and I certainly do not agree with the comments made by a number of people on the other side when, for example, they describe renters, as Dr Hewson did, as people of a lesser kind than anyone else in the community, and other insults that he is prepared to throw at people. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Hill and to say that much of the debate since then has strayed from the central point that Senator Hill made, that is, to take issue with the words of your statement:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not my role to defend the Senate from any public criticism, whether by Prime Ministers or any other persons.

The issue is not your integrity or your fairness in this chamber. Mr President, I believe all in the Senate respect your integrity and your fairness, but this is an overstatement and I request that you give consideration to withdrawing and clarifying the element of your statement that I have referred to. I believe that it is appropriate, guided by this Senate chamber, guided by the Constitution, by the Standing Orders, by the clear resolutions of this chamber, for the President of the Senate to defend the Senate.

PARA.TAB: No-one wishes you to become politically embroiled, but I believe it is appropriate for you to bring to the attention of the Senate the transgression of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his reflections upon this place and to allow this Senate to have its debate, as it did today; to have that resolution adopted, as it was today; and for you, as you have done, to bring that resolution to the attention of the Prime Minister and, indeed, to the House of Representatives. It is an unfortunate overstatement, one that we wish not to be associated with, that you would say in such categorical terms, `It is not my role to defend the Senate from any public criticism, whether by Prime Ministers or any other persons'. I am not here to debate the straw men that were put up by my good friends Senate Cooney or Senator Schacht or, for that matter, Senator McMullan. I have a great deal of resonance with the central element of Senator Tate's remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for debate has expired. Before I put the question, I will give consideration to the remarks made by members of the Opposition. I will take advice, if I require it, on precedents that have been made in the past, and I will give a fuller response, in writing, to all honourable senators. The question is that the Senate take note of the answer.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to extend the time for debate on answers to questions without notice for a maximum of four minutes to enable Senator Crane to take note of the answer given today by Senator Cook to a question from Senator Childs. —Is leave granted?

—The Government is opposed to granting leave. Those opposite have been engaged in a bit of a stunt all day today in here. They started at 9 o'clock this morning talking about all of these issues. PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who are not only believers in the Lord Jesus Christ but persons whose fellowship is based on regard for the absolute authority and recognition of God's Word as contained in the Holy Bible. Your petitioners draw to the attention of the House that the requirements of God's law are completely disregarded by the Family Law Act in that:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1992
This Bill introduces a new scheme of compensation and rehabilitation for seafarers who are injured in the course of their employment.

PARA.TAB: It will replace the outdated and inadequate Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 with modern and comprehensive rehabilitation and compensation arrangements similar to those applicable to Commonwealth employees.

In 1987 the Government commissioned Professor Harold Luntz to conduct a review of the policy basis, and the operation, of the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911. The terms of reference of the review required Professor Luntz to consider the desirability of consistency between the seamen's compensation legislation and the proposals being developed at that time for the new Commonwealth employees workers compensation legislation. These proposals were subsequently enshrined in the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, or CERC Act for short.

Professor Luntz's review of seamen's compensation was tabled in Parliament in June 1988. Since that time, the Luntz review recommendations have been the subject of extensive consultations involving shipowners, the maritime unions and the ACTU.

The outcome of this process is a Bill which radically moves away from the outmoded compensation regime which the Seamen's Compensation Act provides. The new scheme will combine fair, earnings-related, benefits with comprehensive rehabilitation requirements and other measures aimed at getting injured employees restored to health and back to work as quickly as possible.

The Bill also restores the former nexus with the workers compensation legislation applicable to Commonwealth employees. This is consistent with the unitary compensation structure applying across public and private sector employment in all the state and territory workers compensation schemes.

This is a large and complex Bill with many essentially technical provisions. These are described in detail in the explanatory memorandum. It is appropriate, however, to draw the attention of the honourable senators to the main features of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Liability and Insurance

PARA.TAB: The new arrangements will be based on individual employer liability. This acknowledges that the individual employers and their insurers already have the necessary infrastructure in place to manage such arrangements and that the imposition of a Government fund on such a small industry (with around 6,000 employees) would not be cost effective.

In order that employers will be able to meet their liabilities, the Bill requires them to be insured with an insurer authorised under the Insurance Act 1973 or be indemnified by a protection and indemnity association which is a member of the international group of protection and indemnity associations.

There will be a special industry-wide `safety net' fund to provide coverage for industry trainees and for temporarily unemployed seafarers while attending seafarers engagement centres in accordance with industry labour pooling arrangements. Both these categories of persons are employed by the industry as a whole, rather than by individual employers.

The safety net fund will also be the `nominal insurer'. In other words, if the employer or the employer's insurer is unable to meet liabilities because of bankruptcy for example, the fund will meet those liabilities.
There is provision for the industry-wide fund to be established in one of two ways—a fund operated by employers collectively as a corporate entity; or a fund operated by the administering authority.

The Bill provides for the Minister to approve a corporate body as the fund, provided it meets stipulated conditions. Industry employers have already established such a corporate entity. However, if the industry fund should ever fail to meet the stipulated conditions, the minister has the power to revoke the approval of the corporate body and declare the administering authority to have the functions, powers and obligations of the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Benefits

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the benefits which will be payable under this legislation. These benefits will be aligned with those currently payable to injured public sector workers covered by the CERC Act. Like the CERC Act, the benefits will be indexed annually in line with consumer price index movements.

SPEECH.PARA: Incapacity

PARA.TAB: At the heart of the new scheme is the change from a system of fixed long-term benefits adjusted by regulation, to one of weekly benefits calculated on the basis of the individual employee's normal weekly earnings.

Employees who are totally incapacitated for work will receive weekly benefits equal to normal weekly earnings for the first 45 weeks of that incapacity. Partially incapacitated employees will receive benefits to bring their wages up to normal weekly earnings during that period.
After 45 weeks of incapacity, the basic rate of benefits applicable reduces to 75 per cent of normal weekly earnings.

The rate of benefits payable to partially incapacitated employees who are able to work will be on a graduated scale. For these persons the combined total of compensation plus earnings will be between 75 per cent and 100 per cent of normal weekly earnings, depending on the number of hours that the employee actually works.
Weekly payments will not normally be paid beyond the age of 65.

SPEECH.PARA: Permanent Impairment

PARA.TAB: In addition to the weekly benefits for incapacity which I have just outlined, the Bill provides for the payment of lump sums for permanent impairment.

Under the current Seamen's Compensation Act, lump sum payments are made on the basis of a table of maims. The range of maims compensated is exclusive and does not recognise the broad range of work-related injuries and diseases.

This outdated and crude approach will be replaced with a much more comprehensive and fair method using the modern concepts already adopted in assessing permanent impairments for war veterans and injured commonwealth employees.

SPEECH.PARA: Non-economic Loss

PARA.TAB: In conjunction with an assessment of permanent impairment there will be an assessment of related factors defined as non-economic loss. These factors include pain and suffering, loss of quality of life and shortened life expectancy.

SPEECH.PARA: Attendant Care and Household Services

PARA.TAB: The Bill makes provision for injured employees to receive financial assistance for the cost of any necessary household services and for necessary attendant care services.

SPEECH.PARA: Death Benefits

PARA.TAB: In the case of an employee who has died as a result of a work-related injury or disease, there will be a lump sum benefit, which will be apportioned between the dependants. Additionally, dependent children will receive weekly benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Rehabilitation

PARA.TAB: I now turn to the most important feature of the new scheme—rehabilitation.

Early and effective rehabilitation cuts the human and monetary costs of serious industrial injury by helping to repair the physical damage and, equally importantly, by overcoming the "compensation mentality" that can so easily overwhelm injured employees when left to their own devices.

Comcare attributes a major part of its success in reducing its compensation costs to the similar rehabilitation arrangements applicable to Commonwealth employees under the CERC Act. Since the CERC Act came into operation in late 1988, the number of incapacity cases lasting more than four weeks has halved.

The Bill requires employers to arrange a rehabilitation assessment of any injured employee whose incapacity lasts, or is expected to last, 28 days. If that assessment concludes that a rehabilitation program is appropriate, the employer will be required to engage an approved program provider to develop and conduct an appropriate rehabilitation program.

To encourage a positive attitude towards the program, the injured employee will be required to be fully consulted in the development of the program arrangements. However, if the employee refuses to undertake the program, there is provision for compensation benefits to be suspended.

The Bill requires the employer to take all reasonable steps to provide suitable employment for an employee who has undertaken a rehabilitation program, or to assist the employee in finding alternative employment.
The employer will also be required to provide any necessary aids and appliances, or home, vehicle or workplace modifications to enable an injured employee to have as normal a life as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Reconsideration and Review Process

PARA.TAB: The Bill establishes a two stage process for reviewing cases in which an employer's determination of a claim is disputed by the employee or dependant.

The first stage requires the employer to reconsider its initial determination on request by the claimant. If the claimant is not satisfied with a reconsidered determination, the claimant may seek a review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

The Bill sets down special procedures for the first stage reconsideration process, requiring the employer to obtain the assistance of either a Comcare officer or an industry panel. The Comcare officer or industry panel, as the case may be, will provide the employer with an independent assessment of the merits of the claim. The claimant will also receive a copy of this assessment. The assessment will not be binding on either party but the process is expected to result in most cases being resolved quickly without recourse to the AAT.
The costs of the services of Comcare, or the alternative industry panel, will be met by the relevant employer.

SPEECH.PARA: Common Law Actions

PARA.TAB: I now turn to common law actions for negligence.
Common law negligence actions are counter-productive to the fundamental objective of helping injured employees rebuild their lives and return to employment as quickly as possible.

Accordingly, the new legislation, like the CERC Act, will restrict common law actions against an employer or fellow employee to non-economic losses and cap the amount of damages that a court may award.

Furthermore, the employee will be required to make an irrevocable election that he or she intends to pursue a common law action before any lump sum compensation benefit for permanent impairment and non-economic loss has been paid. No lump sum compensation is payable once an election to pursue common law has been made.

There will be no restriction on employees pursuing common law actions against third parties. Similarly, there will be no restrictions on dependants pursuing common law actions against the employer or fellow employee of a deceased employee, or against third parties.

However, in the event of an employee or dependant receiving damages, the employee or dependant will be required to pay the employer either the amount of compensation received or the amount of damages, whichever is less.

SPEECH.PARA: Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority

PARA.TAB: The Bill establishes the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority. This authority will consist of six persons to be appointed by the Minister—an independent chairperson, a deputy chairperson and four part-time members representing the interests of industry parties. This structure will allow employees and employers to participate directly in the administration of the compensation and rehabilitation system.
The primary functions of the Authority will be:

SPEECH.PARA: .To monitor the operation of the Act;
.To promote high operational standards of claims management and effective rehabilitation procedures by employers;
.To co-operate with other bodies or persons with the aim of reducing the incidence of work-related injuries;
.To publish material relating to these functions; and
.To advise the Minister about anything relating to the Authority's functions and powers and other matters relating to the compensation and rehabilitation of employees.

PARA.TAB: The Authority will be serviced by the Department of Transport and Communications.

There is provision in the Bill for the Authority to take over the fund's responsibilities as an employer if the Minister either does not approve an industry fund, or withdraws approval of the industry fund.
In such an event, all costs of compensation and rehabilitation incurred by the Authority and its administrative overheads will be recoverable from industry employers.
Separate Bills are being introduced to enable a levy to be applied to employers, on the basis of the number of seafarer berths on their ships.

In conclusion, this Bill will create a progressive compensation and rehabilitation system, comparable with other modern workers compensation arrangements in Australia. The measures will ensure injured seafarers are quickly and effectively rehabilitated. This, in turn, will cut the time lost through work related injuries and the associated compensation costs and human suffering.

This reform represents another step in the Government's comprehensive shipping reform program which has resulted in significantly increased Australian shipping competitiveness including a 50 per cent reduction in crew sizes on modern, technologically advanced ships.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992
This Bill provides the transitional arrangements from the current Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 to the proposed Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992.

PARA.TAB: In essence, this Bill will facilitate a smooth and equitable transition of benefit entitlements and other arrangements under the current Act to those which will be provided under the new legislation.

The Bill also repeals the Seamen's Compensation Act 1911 and makes a number of consequential amendments to the Navigation Act 1912, the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 and the Social Security Act 1991.
The provisions of this Bill are described in detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION LEVY BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for a levy as a contingency arrangement to enable the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority to operate the "safety net" fund provided under the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: There is provision in the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill for the Minister to approve a corporate body, established by maritime industry employers, to operate the fund. If this occurs (and it is expected to occur) the corporate body will be funded directly by industry employers and the levy provided for by this Bill will not need to be triggered.

In the unlikely event that the corporate body fails to materialise, or if it fails to meet the criteria prescribed in the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill, this Bill will enable the Commonwealth to collect monies for the Authority to operate the fund.

If the levy arrangements are triggered, the levy will be payable by all employers who employ or engage seafarers on prescribed ships. The basis for the levy is the number of seafarer berths on a prescribed ship.
The Governor-General will be able to make regulations prescribing the amount of levy payable for each seafarer berth.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: SEAFARERS REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1992

This Bill sets out the necessary procedures for the collection of the proposed Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Levy. It provides penalties for the non-payment of levy, and allows for the detainment of a prescribed ship if necessary.

PARA.TAB: The levy will be payable quarterly, following the lodgement of a return by the employer. The Bill prescribes penalties where employers fail to lodge returns, or where the returns are inadequate or false and misleading.

The Secretary of the Department will have the power to authorise certain persons to enter premises with the permission of the owner, or with a warrant issued by a magistrate, to search for documentation or other evidence relating to the number of berths on a prescribed ship.
The Governor-General will have the power to make regulations in respect of the manner of payment of the levy, and other procedural matters.
To summarise, this Bill provides the administrative framework to give effect to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Levy Bill 1992.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Superannuation Schemes Amendment Bill 1992 will amend a number of Acts under which superannuation benefits are payable to Commonwealth employees and office-holders and their spouses and children. The purpose of the amendments is to remove discrimination on the basis of marital status from certain provisions of the superannuation schemes. The removal of discrimination in superannuation on the grounds of sex and marital status has been identified in the National Agenda for Women as a priority area for Government action. Action has already been taken to review and limit the exemption in the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 for superannuation and to increase superannuation coverage for women.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has for many years followed a policy of providing adequate superannuation coverage to its office-holders and employees. In more recent times, as the Government has taken steps to extend superannuation coverage in the broader community, we have been committed to that coverage being provided in a fair and non-discriminatory manner. The 1991 amendments to the Sex Discrimination Act will oblige private sector employers to limit sex and marital status discrimination in superannuation only to those limited superannuation practices which remain exempted from the Sex Discrimination Act. These amendments, consistent with the Government's commitment to the equitable provision of access to superannuation benefits, will ensure that Commonwealth superannuation is also in conformity with the Sex Discrimination Act.

The legislation being amended is the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Governor-General Act 1974, the Judges' Pensions Act 1968, the Parliamentary and Judicial Retiring Allowances Act 1973, the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, the Superannuation Act 1922, and the Superannuation Act 1976.

These amendments will ensure that the Commonwealth's own legislative superannuation schemes are consistent with amendments which were made last year to the Sex Discrimination Act. Those amendments narrowed the previous exemption from the Sex Discrimination Act for superannuation so that most forms of discrimination on the basis of sex or marital status in superannuation will be unlawful, subject to a number of limited exemptions relating to particular superannuation practices. Those amendments come into effect two years from the date on which that legislation received Royal Assent, that is 25 June 1993, in order to permit the necessary changes to be made to superannuation schemes. This legislation amending the Commonwealth's own legislatively-based superannuation schemes will come into effect on the same date as those amendments—25 June 1993. It will apply to benefits payable as a result of the death of a person on or after that date, while the existing provisions of each of the legislative schemes will continue to apply to benefits which became payable as the result of the death of a person before that date.

Honourable senators will note that the Superannuation Act 1990, which establishes the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme, is not being amended by this Bill. The detail of the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme is contained in a Trust Deed and Rules made under the Superannuation Act 1990. It is intended that the Trust Deed and Rules will be amended along the lines of the amendments made by this Bill to remove discrimination in the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme. Similarly, the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991 is not being amended by this Bill. However, it is intended that the Trust Deed and Rules made under that Act will also be amended to remove marital status discrimination. It is anticipated that the amendments to both of those Trusts Deeds and Rules will be made prior to 25 June 1993, the date of effect of the changes to the Sex Discrimination Act.

The legislative superannuation provisions being amended by this Bill are those which provide for reversionary benefits to be paid to the surviving spouses, and in some cases children, of deceased superannuation scheme members or beneficiaries. Some of the schemes at present do not recognise de facto relationships for the purpose of entitlement to reversionary benefits, while others apply qualifying periods to de facto relationships which are not applied to legal marriages. Further, some of the schemes discriminate against ex-nuptial children in the allocation of benefits.

The changes will result in some additional costs to Commonwealth superannuation schemes in some situations. These will chiefly be where, in future, de facto spouses of deceased scheme members or pensioners are able to establish the existence of a bona fide domestic relationship where that relationship does not meet the existing eligibility criteria for payment of reversionary benefits. However, the Department of Finance has advised that, because most schemes already recognise spouses, including de facto spouses where the relationship has existed for some years or where there is financial dependency, the additional costs would be very small. There is insufficient data on the incidence, rate of formation, duration of, or extent of financial dependency in de facto relationships among members of existing Commonwealth schemes to enable the additional cost or Budgetary effect to be estimated with any certainty. Any additional costs would be offset by social security and taxation clawbacks.

The amendments in this Bill will apply a standard and non-discriminatory approach to the assessment of eligibility of spouses for reversionary benefits and will remove the provisions which discriminate against ex-nuptial children.

The key criterion for eligibility of a surviving spouse to reversionary benefits under the amended legislation will be the existence of a permanent and bona fide domestic relationship. The Bill provides tests for establishing that such a relationship exists: either that the couple were living together as husband and wife for at least three years, or, where the couple were living together as husband and wife for a lesser period of time, that there is other evidence to establish that the relationship was a permanent and bona fide domestic relationship. The Bill provides a list of the types of evidence which may be considered, but will not restrict decision-makers to that list alone. The assessment will be made on the basis of all relevant evidence.

Provision will continue to be made for the payment of reversionary benefits to persons who were legally married to but separated from the deceased superannuation scheme member or beneficiary at the time of death but were wholly or substantially dependent on that person. These persons will be deemed to be spouses for the purposes of the legislation although they will not have been in a permanent and bona fide domestic relationship at the time of death.

The non-discriminatory definition of spouse will mean that a person could have more than one `spouse' for the purpose of benefits entitlement, for example a separated legally married spouse and a current de facto spouse. Additional amendments will accordingly be made to some of the schemes to provide that in such cases benefits are to be allocated among the spouses having regard to their respective needs and, where relevant, the needs of eligible children.

In the case of the Superannuation Act 1922, it is already possible to recognise more than one spouse. However, there can be discrimination in the way in which benefits are divided in such circumstances. Accordingly the Superannuation Act 1922 will also be amended to provide that benefits are to be allocated among spouses having regard to their respective needs.
In addition to the amendments dealing with the entitlement of spouses, some of the Acts are being amended in the provision for children of deceased superannuation scheme members or beneficiaries.

The Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act will be amended to remove the necessity for ex-nuptial children of the superannuation scheme members to prove dependency. A child or ex-nuptial child of a spouse of a member, who does not come within the amended definition of child, will still be required to prove dependency at the date of death.

The Judges' Pensions Act will be amended to provide that a pension will be payable in respect of a child of a Judge or retired Judge, a child who is wholly or substantially dependent on the Judge or retired Judge at the time of death, and a child who would, but for the death, have been dependent on the Judge or retired Judge. The amendment reduces the coverage of the current Act by excluding as possible beneficiaries the children of a spouse or former spouse of a Judge or retired Judge who have no dependent relationship with the Judge or retired Judge.

The additional amendments to the Superannuation Act 1976 will improve equity in eligibility for children's benefits and will ensure that the classes of children eligible for benefits reflect the recognition of additional marital relationships.

I commend the Bill to the Senate.
