SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I table the revised explanatory memorandum relating to the National Crime Authority Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The speeches read as follows:
The purpose of this Bill is to implement a reform package for the Pipeline Authority (TPA) to enable it to achieve a more commercially orientated approach to its operations.
In just over 20 years, natural gas has grown from a small base to become Australia's third most important energy source, accounting for 17 per cent of primary energy demand.

The recent supply/demand study by the Australian Gas Association (AGA) indicates that the Australian gas industry is now on another threshold of growth, not only as a major, reliable supplier to the domestic energy market, but as a major exporter of liquefied natural gas (or LNG) in the 90s and beyond.

The AGA study indicates market opportunities for natural gas are expected to grow strongly in the years ahead, with new market opportunities, including greater use in power generation, particularly co-generation, and in the transport sector.

Australia has already made an impressive entrance onto the world LNG stage. Exports from the North West Shelf project are forecast to grow to 7 million tonnes per annum by 1995. At these levels, the export value of LNG, oil and condensate from the North West Shelf could approach $3 billion per annum.

The project is already making a significant and sustained contribution to our balance of payments, and there are excellent prospects for further major expansions of the industry. Shell Australia, for example, has identified a $6-8 billion expansion opportunity for Australia's LNG industry over the next five years, based on growth in Asian markets.

The Federal Government strongly supports LNG exports, and as a major element in the National Gas Strategy, has assisted future growth of the industry through removal of volume controls on LNG exports. This move has been welcomed by the industry as a positive step to assist the development of LNG export opportunities.

Industry responses to the National Gas Strategy have been unanimous in supporting the Government's view that a truly national approach is needed to help develop our natural gas reserves fully. The promotion of free and fair interstate gas trade is one of the key points in the National Gas Strategy.

I share the industry's belief that it is essential to free up markets to provide the incentive for future development of Australia's domestic and export gas industry. In particular, unrestricted interstate gas trade is essential for the exploration and the development of markets and related infrastructure. There can be no compromise on this point if we are to move towards an efficient national market in natural gas.

The AGA Gas Supply and Demand Study reinforces the need to move towards a national gas market and provides a timely warning of the costs involved if parochial attitudes and self interest by the State and Territories prevent free and open interstate trade in gas.

The AGA estimates that the cost to Australians of higher prices due to restricted interstate gas trade would, over the period to the year 2030, be in the range $1.5 to $4 billion in net present-value terms.

Producers are already seeking additional markets for gas from areas such as south west Queensland and the Amadeus Basin in the Northern Territory. These, and other reserves, are likely to remain under-developed unless State and Territory administrations lend their support to unrestricted gas trade.
An additional plank in the National Gas Strategy was reform of Government instrumentalities.

The Government's direct role in natural gas operations is restricted largely to its ownership of TPA. In turn, the Authority owns and operates the natural gas transmission pipeline that extends approximately 1,300 kilometres from Moomba in South Australia to Wilton, on the outskirts of Sydney. At Wilton, the natural gas is delivered to the Australian Gas Light Company (AGL) whose subsidiaries are responsible for gas reticulation throughout the Sydney, Wollongong and Newcastle regions. Lateral pipelines supply natural gas to regional markets, including the Cootamundra, Wagga-Wagga, Young, Junee, Canberra and Bathurst/Orange regions and soon, to the Riverina.

The Government announced in late 1989 that it would develop a reform package for TPA as part of the Government's wider agenda for micro-economic reform. In November 1991, as part of the National Gas Strategy, the Government reaffirmed its commitment to implement reform of TPA to make it more efficient and competitive.

In the 1992 Budget, the Government announced the inclusion of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline system in its program of asset sales. The sale of the pipeline system is unlikely to be completed before the 1993/94 financial year at the earliest. This was recognised in the Budget Statement.

In these circumstances, the Government believes that reform of TPA, including putting its commercially-based operations into a Government Business Enterprise style subsidiary, is essential and should not be delayed further. These reforms will enable the return on TPA's assets to be optimised in the lead up to the proposed sale.

The reforms proposed in this legislation will enable TPA, through a subsidiary corporation, to compete on a more equal footing with other participants in Australia's natural gas industry and to be involved in a wider range of commercially based activities than its present Act allows.

The reforms will provide the means for TPA to become a more effective operator in the gas sector and to take advantage of commercial opportunities as they arise. This approach will ensure optimal returns to the Government from TPA.

The central feature of the reform package is to provide for the creation of a subsidiary of TPA to undertake those operations of TPA that are based on a commercial rate of return. This will include the Canberra and Oberon laterals and the proposed Riverina pipeline extension to Griffith.

TPA has contracts with AGL covering the carriage of gas through these pipelines. The Government has consulted with AGL on the proposed transfer of assets and has taken that company's concerns into account in the preparation of the legislation. There is no element in the reform proposals embodied in this legislation which would be prejudicial to AGL's existing contracts.

The proposed legislation requires the approval of the Minister for Resources before a subsidiary can be created. The Minister's approval will outline the reporting requirements whereby strategic Ministerial control will be exercised over the subsidiary consistent with the Guidelines for Government Business Enterprise Accountability.

TPA has, in the past, been significantly constrained by its Act in the type of activities it can undertake. The current Act limits TPA to constructing, owning and operating pipelines within Australia. It cannot be involved in other activities, such as operating a pipeline it does not own and it has been limited to providing consultancy services within Australia—and then only after obtaining Ministerial approval.

The new subsidiary will be able to undertake any of the activities related to the design, construction and acquisition of petroleum pipelines. In addition, the subsidiary will be able to operate and maintain pipelines throughout Australia and provide consultancy and transmission support services relating to petroleum pipeline construction, design and operation for clients in Australia and overseas.

The new subsidiary will be subject to taxation and will be required to make dividend payments. To all intents and purposes, it is designed to behave as a private company carrying out the business of a Government enterprise and be subject to corporate law and regulations.

While the subsidiary will operate as a commercial Government Business Enterprise, TPA will continue to operate the Moomba to Sydney mainline and the laterals to Lithgow and Wagga Wagga on the cost recovery basis determined by existing contracts between TPA and AGL.

The reform package that has been developed is consistent with the Government's latest guidelines for Government Business Enterprise Accountability. These guidelines emphasise strategic Ministerial control over the enterprise, while enterprise Boards are responsible for development of business strategies and the handling of day-to-day management policies.

With this in mind, Ministerial control over the subsidiary will be imposed by Ministerial oversight of the subsidiary's Strategic Corporate Plan, annual operating plans and financial targets. Any major changes to these plans, and other major issues and opportunities identified by the subsidiary's Board and management, will be reported promptly through the Authority to the Minister for Resources for consideration and action as appropriate.

The subsidiary will be required to provide, on an annual basis, a Strategic Corporate Plan covering a three year period for Ministerial consideration and response. Information on any material variations in the corporate plan, and any other changes in circumstances that would require disclosure under the Australian Stock Exchange or Australian Securities Commission rules, must be reported through TPA to the Minister immediately. In addition, the subsidiary will be required to provide more regular reports outlining progress towards meeting the Corporate Plan and any proposed changes to that Plan. The subsidiary will also be required to work to an Annual Operating Plan, including a financial target and dividend policy, approved in advance by the Minister for Resources in consultation with the Minister for Finance.

As at present, TPA will be required to produce an Annual report which will be tabled in Parliament. This report will include coverage of the operations and performance of TPA's subsidiary, so there will continue to be full disclosure of TPA's pipeline operations.

The assets to be transferred from TPA to the subsidiary are to be revalued prior to approval of the first corporate plan associated with the establishment of the subsidiary. Assets of the subsidiary and TPA will subsequently be revalued every three years in accordance with normal commercial practice.

A key factor in establishing the appropriate capital base for the subsidiary is to enable it to borrow in the commercial market without Government guarantees and maintain an "A" credit rating. To achieve this aim, it may be necessary to transfer some retained earnings from TPA to the subsidiary along with the designated assets. The capital and financial resources provided by TPA to the subsidiary in exchange for share equity, plus the revenue earning capability of the Canberra and Griffith pipelines, should permit payment of dividends by the subsidiary to the Government (via TPA) at an early stage.

Subject to passage of this Bill and completion of the necessary legal formalities, the Government envisages the early reorganisation of TPA. The legal separation of TPA's commercial and non-commercial operations will facilitate assessment of the subsidiary's performance against the criteria outlined in its corporate plan. It will provide the correct commercial incentives for the management of the subsidiary and ensure the financial and operating results of each organisation are separate and transparent.

The proposed reforms highlight the need for TPA Board to include an appropriate mix of qualifications, abilities and business acumen. Given the greater requirement for financial and corporate expertise, it is proposed to expand TPA's Board by two new directors.

The Bill allows for TPA's Chief Executive Officer to be appointed by the Authority and be subject to dismissal by the Authority. TPA directors will also now be appointed by the Minister for Resources rather than the Governor General in Council, and be subject to dismissal on grounds which have been expanded to include on-going under performance. The Board of the subsidiary will be appointed by the Authority.

Mr President, the reforms that I have outlined today have the potential to provide substantial benefits. They will provide a sound basis on which to improve the overall performance of TPA. The reforms will allow the management of TPA and its proposed subsidiary greater flexibility in their day to day operations on a range of issues that previously required Ministerial approval, while retaining adequate accountability under the Guidelines for Government Business Enterprise operations. This will enable TPA, through its subsidiary, to take advantage of a range of commercial opportunities that are emerging in Australia and overseas as a result of growing demand for natural gas.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

Honourable Senators will recall that in November 1991 the Parliamentary Joint Committee (PJC) on the National Crime Authority (NCA) tabled its evaluation of the NCA in a Report entitled `Who is to Guard the Guards?'. The Report supported the continued existence and activities of the NCA, and made eleven recommendations.

The Government's response to the PJC Report was tabled on 1 June 1992. The National Crime Authority Bill (No.2) 1992 amends the National Crime Authority Act 1984 in the manner foreshadowed in that response.

The Bill establishes an office of Inspector-General of the NCA, endows it with appropriate functions and powers, and provides a mechanism for resolving disputes between the NCA and the PJC about access to sensitive information held by the NCA. It also makes some small but important corrections to existing provisions of the NCA Act.

The most significant change to the NCA Act introduced by these amendments is the new office of Inspector-General of the NCA. Clause 10 of the Bill will insert a new Part IIIA in the NCA Act to make provision for this office. The PJC Report proposed that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security be given jurisdiction to investigate complaints against the NCA and its staff. Because the role of the Inspector-General in relation to the NCA will differ in some respects from the role of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, the Bill will establish a separate office of Inspector-General of the NCA under the NCA Act. However, the Government intends that the occupant of the office of Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will be appointed as Inspector-General of the NCA also and, with this in mind, the new Part IIIA is based, as closely as practicable, on the relevant provisions of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986.

One major difference between the role of the Inspector-General in relation to the NCA and in relation to the intelligence and security agencies will be that he will not have the broad monitoring function in relation to the NCA which he has in relation to intelligence and security matters. General monitoring of the work of the NCA remains the responsibility of the Commonwealth-State Inter-Governmental Committee (IGC) and of the PJC both of which are established under the NCA Act. A second major difference is that, in relation to the NCA, the Inspector-General will not investigate complaints which can be dealt with satisfactorily under existing complaints legislation or procedures applicable to a police force from which the subject of the complaint has been seconded to the NCA.

Under new section 55AA, the recommendation to the Governor-General that a person be appointed Inspector-General may only be made after consultation with the IGC. The person so appointed will be able to hold the office in conjunction with another, and section 55AC will preserve the judicial status of a judge appointed to the office. The terms and conditions of the Inspector-General, as set out in Division 6 of the new Part IIIA, are compatible with those of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security. Under section 55AZE, where the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security is also appointed Inspector-General of the NCA, staff may be appointed to assist him in both capacities.

The functions of the Inspector-General are set out in proposed new section 55AD. His principal function will be to investigate complaints about the actions of members or staff of the NCA, whether such complaints are made directly or are referred to him by a member of the IGC or by the PJC. Further, on request by the Minister, he will investigate whether NCA information to which access is sought by the PJC on the NCA is `sensitive information' as defined in the Bill, and will advise the Minister accordingly. Lastly, where the Minister so requests, the Inspector-General will monitor compliance by the NCA with directions or guidelines in relation to privacy issued by the Minister under section 18 of the NCA Act.

Division 2 of the new Part IIIA will provide for the receipt and investigation of complaints. It is proposed that the Inspector-General be obliged to investigate all complaints including those which may have arisen before the passage of this Bill. As is appropriate, however, discretions are built into section 55AG which will enable him not to inquire into complaints which, for instance, are frivolous or vexatious or where, having regard to all the circumstances, an inquiry or further inquiry is not warranted. The latter category would include past complaints which, in the view of the Inspector-General, have been dealt with satisfactorily by the informal means of investigation which have existed hitherto.

Division 3 will deal with the conduct of inquiries. The Inspector-General will be required to inform the Minister and the Chairperson of the NCA before commencing an investigation. His inquiries will be conducted in private and will not be subject to formal procedural requirements.

He will be entitled to compel production of information and documents and to make such use of the documents as may be needed for the purposes of the investigation. He will also be able to compel people to attend before him and give evidence on oath or affirmation, including evidence which they would otherwise be entitled by privilege, or obliged by law, to withhold. The Inspector-General will also have reasonable access to NCA premises for the purposes of an investigation, and special provision is made for the receipt of complaints from persons in custody.

There will be a two-stage reporting process, with a draft report given to the Chairperson of the NCA for comment before the final report is submitted to the Minister and the Chairperson. The report should include reasons and recommend any restitution considered appropriate for a complainant. The Inspector-General will be required to advise the complainant (and the IGC or the PJC, if they referred the complaint) of the outcome of the investigation, so far as this will not prejudice NCA security. The Chairperson of the NCA will be required to advise the Inspector-General of his action in response to each report. If dissatisfied with that response the Inspector-General will be entitled to discuss the matter with, and make a written report on it to, the Minister.

The Inspector-General will be required to provide an annual report to the Minister, commenting on the investigations he has conducted during the past year. The Minister will be required to table the report in each House as soon as practicable after receipt. Provision is made in clause 9 of the Bill for an amendment to section 55 under which the PJC would examine the Inspector-General's annual report. This is intended to provide a means by which the PJC may better inform itself in the performance of its principal function under that section—the monitoring and reviewing of the NCA's performance. The provision is not intended to suggest accountability on the part of the Inspector-General to the PJC.

The second main aspect of the Bill is the provision of a mechanism for resolving disagreement over what is often termed `operational' or `sensitive' information. In its recent Report, the PJC sought clarification of its rights of access to information held by the NCA. Disputes about such information in the past have given rise to questions of Parliamentary privilege. As foreshadowed in its response to the PJC Report, the Government has decided to deal with this issue by providing, in a new subsection 55(2), that in the performance of its duties the PJC is entitled to require the Chairperson of the NCA to produce to it any document held by the NCA or to divulge or communicate to it any information held by or known to the NCA—except to the extent that it is or contains sensitive information. `Sensitive information' is defined in an amendment set out in clause 3 as information the disclosure of which might prejudice the safety or reputation of a person, the fair trial of a person who has been or may be charged with an offence, the effectiveness of an investigation by the NCA, or the operations of law enforcement agencies.

Where the PJC requests access to information and the Chairperson of the NCA refuses access on the ground that the information requested is `sensitive' as defined, the amendment to section 55 will allow the PJC to refer the request to the Minister administering the NCA Act for written resolution of the dispute. The Bill provides that the Minister may require the Inspector-General of the NCA to inquire into the matter, and the Inspector-General must do so in accordance with the inquiry provisions of the new Part IIIA of the NCA Act. When the Inspector-General has reported to the Minister, the Minister will have to decide whether or not the information is sensitive, and notify the Chairperson, the PJC and the Inspector-General of his decision. The Bill will also authorise the Minister to include reasons for the decision in the formal determination, where this can be done without disclosing sensitive information.

Of the minor amendments included in the Bill, one affects section 29A of the NCA Act. This section only came into force in January this year and provides that NCA process issued under section 28 or 29 may include a notation prohibiting disclosure of any information relating to the process. This conflicts with the credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act 1988, which require agencies to record any disclosures on an individual's credit information file and to ensure that an individual can obtain access to his or her file. Access by an individual to a credit reference file bearing a note of disclosure to the NCA could seriously jeopardise an NCA investigation. Accordingly, clause 7 of the Bill will amend section 29A of the NCA Act to provide that, where the Privacy Act would require that a note be made of a disclosure made in response to NCA process and that process includes a notation requiring secrecy, the requirement to record the disclosure is postponed until the effect of the notation expires. The Privacy Commissioner has indicated that this proposal is acceptable because of the particular circumstances. Disclosure is only temporarily prohibited and the policy underlying s.29A was thoroughly debated during its passage through Parliament last year.

The other minor amendment affects section 12 of the Act. As indicated in its response to the PJC Report, the Government and members of the IGC have considered the position of subsections 12(4) and (5), which were criticised as unclear by the South Australian Supreme Court in the 1989 case of Carbone. Clause 9 of the Bill repeals those subsections.

In conclusion, I would like briefly to reiterate some of the general points made in the Government's statement tabled on 1 June. I believe the work of the NCA over the past eight years has by and large been very successful and that this reflects both the qualities of those who have worked in the NCA and the essential soundness of the legislative scheme into which Parliament put so much effort in 1983 and 1984. Nonetheless, there will continue to be a need for fine tuning of the legislation from time to time and I take this opportunity to thank the PJC again for the important contribution it has made to this process through its Report "Who is to Guard the Guards?".
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Mergers, monopolies and acquisitions: adequacy of existing legislative controls. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in relation to "Mergers, Monopolies and Acquisitions—Adequacy of Existing Legislative Controls

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this document is to provide the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled "Mergers, Monopolies and Acquisitions—Adequacy of Existing Legislative Controls". That report, completed on 19 December 1991, has frequently been referred to as the "Cooney Committee Report" in recognition of Senator Cooney's chairmanship of the Committee.
2. The Government has already announced publicly its decisions on several major issues, in view of the widespread interest in these issues. This response addresses the issues in more detail.

3. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs prepared a report in 1989 on similar issues, entitled "Mergers, Takeovers and Monopolies: Profiting from Competition?", which has subsequently been commonly referred to as the "Griffiths Committee Report" similarly in recognition of the then chairmanship of the Committee by the Hon Mr Alan Griffiths MP. On 22 August 1991 the Government's response to that report was tabled. In so doing, it was noted that the Senate had referred substantially similar matters to its Standing Committee, and that the detail of the response would be reconsidered as necessary in the light of the views expressed by the Senate Committee.

4. That reconsideration has now occurred. This response therefore presents the considered view of the Government on the wide range of matters considered by both Committees. The Government will now move to prepare and introduce into the Parliament for passage at an early date legislation to give effect to the changes affecting the merger test, penalty increases, unconscionable conduct and enforcement of undertakings and, in the case of other issues such as pre-merger notification and enhanced remedies, will prepare detailed legislative proposals for exposure and public comment.

5. Both Committees reviewed the operation of the Trade Practices Act within the context of its present constitutional reach, and neither examined the present constitutional and statutory exclusions from the ambit of the Act. Extension of the Act to matters currently beyond its reach, whether by amendment of the present express exclusions contained within the Act or by some enabling mechanism agreed with State Governments, is a separate and distinct matter that is being addressed by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments.

6. The significance of trade practices laws in our economy is not something that needs to be emphasised—it is universally recognised. The work of both Committees has also had the important effect of widening the public debate on a number of very important and fundamental trade practices issues.

7. Before addressing the specific recommendations of the Cooney Committee Report, the Government thanks the members of both Committees and of all political persuasions whose hard work has now ensured that important issues under consideration have been widely debated and that those with an interest in them have had ample opportunity to air their views. Both Committees adopted novel approaches to soliciting views on matters within their terms of reference. The Griffiths Committee held a workshop attended by a large number of distinguished practitioners and other interested persons. The Cooney Committee held its hearings in a plenary debate style which ensured that the issues were fully explored. While the Government has not been moved to adopt every recommendation of each of the Committees, it has been greatly assisted in its deliberations not only by the Reports of each Committee but also by the submissions made to each Committee and by the transcripts of Committee hearings.
8. The Government's response to the specific recommendations of the Cooney Committee Report follows. As appropriate, references are made to the relevant recommendation of the Griffiths Committee.
Mergers and acquisitions: the appropriate test
Recommendation 1:
9. The Cooney Committee recommended (by majority) that:

"section 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 be amended to prohibit mergers or acquisitions which would have the effect or likely effect of substantially lessening competition in a substantial market for goods [or] services.
10. By contrast, the Griffiths Committee recommended (again by majority) that the test set out in section 50 not be amended.
11. The Government has decided to accept this recommendation of the Cooney Committee.
12. Section 50 currently prohibits, unless authorised on public benefit grounds, mergers or acquisitions which would enable a corporation "to dominate a [substantial] market for goods or services".

13. The recommended amendment would introduce into section 50 phraseology used elsewhere in other provisions of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act dealing with conduct within existing market structures when it is necessary to show an anticompetitive effect as part of proving a contravention.

14. A "substantial lessening of competition" test would subject to scrutiny more mergers and acquisitions than are currently caught by the existing test. Such would, however, remain capable of prior authorisation on public benefit grounds. The purpose therefore would be to provide the Commission with enhanced ability to satisfy itself that significant mergers and acquisitions were not likely to unjustifiably stand in the way of the benefits of a more competitive market place.

15. Views expressed to the Committee on this issue were starkly divided and there is no clear answer which can be reached on the basis of empirical evidence. Nevertheless, the recommended change would place increased emphasis on the competitive process and is therefore consistent with the Government's philosophy and belief that competition is a key element in the successful attainment of micro-economic reform.

16. The Cooney Committee sought to assess the success or otherwise of section 50 in achieving the aims set for it when it was first introduced. Prior to 1977, section 50 did contain a test of "substantial lessening of competition". In that year the then coalition Government introduced the present test. In so doing, its stated aim was to enable Australian businesses to compete more effectively on export markets. In testing the achievement of that aim, the Committee reviewed the results of a number of research studies. Its conclusion was that:

"The Committee finds that the empirical evidence on the effects of mergers is conflicting and not conclusive. The economic evidence that mergers actually result in productive efficiencies remains equivocal. Nor is it clear that efficiencies, where they have occurred, have improved the international competitiveness of Australian films, or resulted in demonstrable benefits to consumers.
17. The Committee also noted that:

"There is a poor bank of available studies based on empirical research into the Australian economy. There is no work of which the Committee has been made aware which would compel it to come to a particular conclusion. However, there is material which provides it with significant help. The Competitive Advantage of Nations by Professor Michael Porter has been quoted already. Generally it was treated with considerable respect by those who made submissions to the Committee. The thrust of Professor Porter's work supports a change in section 50.

18. In reaching its conclusions, the Committee examined a large number of mergers which the Trade Practices Commission claimed it had been unable to appropriately deal with under the present test. It noted that:

". . . there is a substantial body of material before the Committee expressing concern about mergers and acquisitions such as that of The Herald and Weekly Times by News Limited, that of Berger and British Paints by ICI (Dulux), that of McPherson's Steel by Tubemakers, and the joining together of Coles and Myers.

19. While the Government believes that the analysis of these past mergers is to some extent indecisive, it is nevertheless concerned that there are some mergers of significance which might escape the present net but which should, in the public interest, be subjected to scrutiny.

20. The Government notes that the case for change is not so compelling that contrary arguments are untenable. Its conclusion that this recommendation of the Committee should be accepted is formed on balance. The Government believes that this change is important, but, at the same time, it views it as a refinement of the present Act and not as a change which so fundamentally alters direction that it should be rejected. While some proponents of the change have argued that it would introduce undesirable uncertainty into the law, it is noted that the present law uses the same terminology in other contexts. Moreover, the Attorney-General has indicated to the Trade Practices Commission that he considers there is a need for it to revise and reissue its merger guidelines to provide the maximum possible information to business as to how the Commission will administer the changed test.
Recommendation 2:
21. The Committee recommended that:
". . . to make clear the ambit of the new test, guidelines be incorporated in the Trade Practices Act 1974.

22. The Government believes that there is good sense in including in the Trade Practices Act a non-exclusive list of factors to which the Commission, the Trade Practices Tribunal and the courts are to have regard when taking section 50 decisions. While such factors would not compel any particular conclusion in the individual case, they would nevertheless provide guidance to the public and to the Commission, the Tribunal and the courts in the formulation of their own views and would assist those making submissions to these bodies to ensure that they address relevant criteria.

23. These guidelines would only relate to the threshold question of whether or not a particular transaction would have the requisite effect on competition. They would not inhibit the range of matters to which the Commission and the Tribunal can have regard in deciding an authorisation application. In this regard, the stated concern behind the original move to a dominance test, ie the desirability of enhancing the competitive position of Australian firms in overseas markets, can properly be argued in the authorisation context. While the Government believes that it would be undesirable to seek to codify the many and diverse elements which might be relevant to "public benefit" in any particular case, it nevertheless considers that there should be specific reference in the Act recognising as a public benefit matters going to export potential and the substitution of domestic products for imported goods.
Recommendation 3:
24. The Committee recommended that:
". . . the guidelines should contain criteria including:
the level of concentration in the market;
the likely level of foreign competition in the market;
the availability of product substitutes;
barriers to entry;
whether one party to the merger is a failing firm;
the likelihood that the proposed merger would remove a vigorous and effective competitor;
the extent to which effective competition remains or would remain in the market;
change and innovation in the market;
the ability to significantly increase prices following a merger; and
any other factors relevant to competition in a market.

25. The Government accepts this recommendation in principle. It has elaborated on the Committee's suggestions so as to reflect the range of factors that will most commonly provide assistance to the courts, the Trade Practices Commission, the Trade Practices Tribunal and to private litigants in determining if there has been a substantial lessening of competition. The amending legislation will set out the following factors while making it clear that there may be others that are relevant:
(a) the actual and potential level of import competition in the relevant market;
(b) the height of barriers to entry;
(c) the level of concentration in the relevant market; (d) the degree of countervailing power;
(e) the ability of the merged firm to increase prices or profit margins significantly and sustainably;
(f) the extent to which acceptable substitutes for the products of the merged firm are available or likely to be available;
(g) the dynamic characteristics of the market, including growth, innovation and product differentiation;
(h) the likelihood the merger would result in the removal of a vigorous and effective competitor, and
(i) the nature and extent of vertical integration.

While it may well be thought that each of the above factors should already be considered in a proper application of the present test, there are real benefits, particularly when coupled with the move to a substantial lessening of competition test, in including such a listing of indicative factors to emphasise the focus of the test on competition.
Recommendation 4:
26. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . where a proposed merger fails to meet the test including the guidelines the Trade Practices Commission should nevertheless have the power to authorise it when it is for the benefit of the public.
27. The Government accepts this recommendation. Except for those limited examples of anti-competitive conduct which are declared by the Trade Practices Act to be `per se' unlawful (eg,
price-fixing agreements), it is a consistent principle of the Act that anti-competitive conduct should be capable of authorisation where the ensuing benefit to the public outweighs the detriment.
Compulsory pre-merger notification
Recommendations 5 and 6:
28. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . it be obligatory for a notice to be given to the Trade Practices Commission where mergers or acquisitions of a substantial nature are proposed. What is a matter of a substantial nature should be defined in the Act. The matters of which notice is to be given should be limited so that undue burden is not cast on those who must comply
and that:

" . . . proposals for what the notice is to contain should be drawn up by the Attorney-General' s Department and released for public comment. The proposal should be drawn up on the basis that those seeking a merger or an acquisition should not have to comply with requirements that are too vague, onerous or vexatious.
29. The Government accepts these recommendations in principle.

30. In the Attorney-General's statement to the House of 22 August 1991 he announced that the Government had rejected the recommendation of the Griffiths Committee that a system of pre-merger notification should not be introduced. The Attorney-General said in an associated press release that the Government would move to amend the Trade Practices Act to include:

" . . . an administratively simple pre-merger notification scheme designed to give the TPC adequate opportunity to examine mergers before they take place, while at the same time ensuring that the Trade Practices Act places minimum impediment in the way of business—this scheme will allow mergers to proceed prior to the grant of authorisation on the basis of enforceable undertakings given to the TPC, as an alternative to requiring authorisation prior to the merger . . . .
31. The scheme to which the Attorney-General then referred is outlined in more detail at paragraph 4.34 of the Cooney Committee Report.
32. The Committee was concerned that this scheme should only be implemented if it can be developed so as to operate in a simple and non-intrusive way. The Government shares that concern.

33. Accordingly, the Attorney-General's Department will develop draft legislative proposals for introduction and exposure for public comment as soon as possible. It is intended that the notification requirements will be simple, and the Government is concerned to avoid creating a notification "net" which is cast too widely or is too complex. At the same time, it is important that the Commission should receive timely advance notification of significant transactions. The preparation of these exposure proposals will not be undertaken until legislation to effect the other amendments outlined in this statement has been developed.
Mandatory authorisation and sensitive industries
Recommendation 7:
34. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . section 50 should remain legislation aimed at protecting competition generally. Where there are other than economic issues involved in industry structure or ownership, they may well be dealt with in specific legislation. For example, at the moment, there are issues arising in the banking and media industries which could be dealt with in terms of discrete legislation.
35. Other Committees of the Parliament have in recent times separately considered the treatment of mergers and acquisitions in two specific industries.

36. First, the Martin Committee recommended that the Treasurer, in exercising his powers under the Banking Act, should seek the advice of the Trade Practices Commission as to whether or not a proposed banking merger would substantially lessen competition. Implementation of that recommendation would not necessarily require legislative amendment.

37. Second, the Lee Committee recommended that, whatever the generally applicable section 50 test might be, mergers and acquisitions in the print media should be subject to prohibition unless authorised where they would have the effect of substantially lessening competition.

38. The Government's decision to accept the recommendation of the Cooney Committee to revert to a substantial lessening of competition test for mergers is consistent with the recommendations of each of the Martin and Lee reports.
39. The Government accepts the thrust of this recommendation of the Cooney Committee in the following senses:

section 50 should remain a provision of general application; the test embodied in that provision should not be unduly influenced by the special needs of any particular industry; the Trade Practices Act should not contain any broad power to apply a special regime to mergers and acquisitions within particular industries which may be thought from time to time to be particularly "sensitive"; whether or not the Trade Practices Commission should have a role in the application of any special test to a particular industry should be decided on a case-by-case basis; where the issues to be decided involve an assessment of anti-competitive impact and a balancing of such against public benefit, a role for the Commission is prima facie applicable; and where the issues do not involve such an assessment and balancing, prima facie the Commission should not have a role.
Authorisation Processes
Recommendation 8:
40. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . parties proposing a merger should have the option of either approaching the Trade Practices Commission for authorisation, with a right of appeal to the Trade Practices Tribunal, or of approaching the Trade Practices Tribunal directly.

41. The Government has decided not to accept this recommendation. Under the present law, the Trade Practices Commission is the primary decision-maker and the Tribunal is the review body. This hierarchy has been established in the interests of the most efficient use of limited resources, the availability of merits review, and accountability to those most affected by decision-making.

42. There seems to be little point in abandoning this two-tier mechanism. There is either merits review, or there is not. If proponents of a merger are to have the option of seeking a decision that is not appellable, they can currently put themselves in that position at present by themselves deciding not to appeal to the Tribunal from an unfavourable Commission decision.

43. Apart from these systemic issues, there would be practical difficulties in implementing the Committee's recommendation. The Tribunal would need to have resources made available to it in duplication of those already available to the Commission if it were truly to be able to undertake the primary decision-making role of the Commission. Alternatively, if it were to adopt only an adjudicative role as between two adversarial parties, the Commission could be put in the position of having to contest before the Tribunal a merger that it had not investigated and on which it had formed no view as to either the effect on competition or public benefit.
Recommendation 9:
44. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . strict time limits be imposed on the Trade Practices Commission and the Trade Practices Tribunal within which they are to determine authorisation applications or appeals. The Commission should continue to be required to determine applications within 45 days. Any appeal from a decision of the Commission to the Tribunal should be determined by the Tribunal within 45 days. Where the Tribunal is approached directly, it should be required to determine an application within 60 days.

45. The Government is conscious that the new merger test will result in some increase in applications to the Commission for authorisation of a merger on public benefit grounds. It therefore wishes to ensure that decisions on authorisation applications are taken by the Commission, and on appeal by the Trade Practices Tribunal, in as short a time as is possible. The current 45 day time limit on the Commission will in most cases be reduced to 30 days, while the Tribunal will generally be expected to complete a review within 60 days unless it orders otherwise.
Recommendation 10:

46. The Committee recommended that adequate funding should be provided to the Commission and the Tribunal to enable implementation of Recommendations 8 and 9. The Government's belief is that both bodies are adequately resourced to meet their present workloads and that adequate procedures exist to allow supplementation of present resources to meet any increase in workload, including any increase in workload that may flow from the changes the Government is proposing.
Misuse of market power: s.46
Recommendation 11:
47. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . section 46 be amended by adding a further subsection to provide that, although the Trade Practices Commission has the overall onus of proving breach of that section, when it has brought forward evidence which makes it as likely as not that one has occurred then one will be taken to have occurred unless the corporation in question shows otherwise.
48. The Government has decided that it cannot accept this recommendation.

49. It is apparent from the Committee's report that the Committee, having rejected (and correctly so in the view of the Government) suggestions that an "effects" test be included within section 46, was trying to find a way of assisting the Commission in the difficult task of proving intent.

50. But the proposal embodied in this recommendation (which was apparently not debated in the public hearings of the Committee) is, in the view of the Government, either self-contradictory and will not work or alternatively is ambiguous and should not be implemented.

51. If the Commission is to retain "the overall onus of proving breach", then such shall remain to be done on the balance of probabilities and it will not have satisfied that onus if it is able to demonstrate only that a proscribed purpose is no more likely than an innocent purpose. Accordingly, if the respondent remains silent, the Commission will necessarily fail in its prosecution notwithstanding the temporary shifting of onus to the defendant.

52. Alternatively, if the Committee intended that, in effect, the standard of proof for offences bearing potentially severe pecuniary penalties should be reduced from the balance of probabilities to "as likely as not", such a recommendation cannot be accepted. Where action is taken for an innocent purpose, an obligation to create contemporaneous proof that it is not undertaken for a proscribed purpose cannot effectively be imposed. In the absence of such an obligation and positive proof of proscribed purpose, the Commission's case would always be defeated by a mere denial of unlawfulness.

53. Sub-section 46(7) of the Act, to which the Committee's report makes no reference, already contains a provision to facilitate the finding of a purpose contrary to section 46. This enables the proscribed purpose to be inferred from the conduct of the corporation or of any other person or from other relevant circumstances.
Recommendation 12:
54. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . section 46 be amended to provide that where persons engage in conduct for the purpose of eliminating from or harming a class of persons in a market they shall be taken to be doing so in respect of a specified member of it.
55. The Government accepts this recommendation for the reasons set out in the Committee's report and in the submission to the Committee by the Attorney-General's Department.
Recommendation 13:
56. The Committee recommended that:
" . . . serious and persistent misuse of market power be dealt with by increased monetary penalties [and that] divestiture not be made available as a remedy.

57. The Government accepts this recommendation. It notes that there is little if any evidence of serious and persistent breach of section 46. In any event the increases in the level of monetary penalties should be effective in discouraging serious and persistent misuse of market power in the future. The Government would be extremely averse to extending the present divestiture power (for breach of section 50) in the absence of that evidence, having regard to the serious limitations on that remedy detailed in the submission to the Committee made by the Attorney-General's Department.
Unconscionable conduct
Recommendations 14 and 15:
58. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . section 52A of the Trade Practices Act be repealed . . . [and that] legislation be introduced giving the Trade Practices Commission the ability to bring proceedings on behalf of a person who has a right of action at common law arising from the unconscionable conduct of another . . . .
and that:
" . . . appropriate funds be made available to the Trade Practices Commission to enable this to be done.

59. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology (the `Beddall Committee') report recommended in 1990 that section 52A of the Act, which prohibits unconscionable conduct in consumer transactions, should be extended to small business transactions.

60. By contrast, the Griffiths Committee considered that if the Trade Practices Commission wished to pursue the proposal to extend s.52A, it needed to develop persuasive arguments to counter the concerns of the business community and legal profession.

61. On 22 August 1991, the Attorney-General announced that the Government had decided to extend sub-section 52A(1), but not other provisions of section 52A, to all transactions in trade and commerce. Sub-section 52A(1) prohibits unconscionable conduct while other provisions of that section seek to define and expand on the meaning of that term. The intention behind that decision was to reflect in statute the Government's opprobrium of conduct meeting the description of "unconscionable" in the existing law; to impute the equitable meaning as it applied from time to time; to make available Trade Practices Act remedies; and to enable the Trade Practices Commission to undertake representative actions in appropriate cases.

62. The Committee, in considering whether section 52A should be extended to commercial dealings, was influenced by the view that the section "may not have the ability to develop in the way the common law has".

63. The Government believes that it is important both that the existing section 52A be retained to ensure that consumer rights are not diminished, and that a new provision be enacted in the Trade Practices Act prohibiting corporations from engaging in unconscionable conduct in trade and commerce. The Government considers that it should be possible to draft the new provision to meet the underlying concerns of the Committee quoted above.

64. So far as funding is concerned, the Commission and the Department of Finance review from time to time the Commission's need for litigation resources on a case-by-case basis and there is no reason why that process should not be adequate in this instance. While this amendment could be one of importance, it is not expected that representative actions by the Commission would be frequent or regular.
Pecuniary penalties
Recommendations 16 and 17:
65. The Committee recommended that:
" . . . subsection 76(1) of the Trade Practices Act be amended to substantially increase penalties available to punish breaches of the provisions of Part IV of the Act . . . ";
and that:
" . . . subsection 79(1) . . . be amended to substantially increase the pecuniary penalties to punish breaches of the provisions of Part V of the Act.
66. The Griffiths Committee recommended that penalties be substantially increased for breach of sections 46 and 50.

67. On 22 August 1991, the Attorney-General announced that the Government had decided to increase penalties for breaches of those sections to $10m for bodies corporate and $500,000 for individuals, and that the Government was still to consider the range of penalties which should be applicable to sections other than sections 46 and 50.

68. In its submission to the Cooney Committee, the Attorney-General's Department argued for the following levels of penalty to be generally applicable: for Part IV: for bodies corporate—$10m; for individuals—$500,000; and for Part V: for bodies corporate—$200,000; for individuals—$40,000.

69. The Government is committed to ensuring that the Trade Practices Act is enforced effectively. It takes the view that pecuniary penalties are a necessary component of that enforcement, and that they should be set at a sufficient deterrent and exemplary level appropriate to the nature of the offence involved. The present level has been widely recognised as quite insufficient, particularly in the light of the financial benefits that can be derived from conduct which is proscribed by the Act.

70. The Government has decided that the increase in penalties should not apply in relation to sections 45D and 45E: that is, the existing level of penalties will continue to apply to those provisions.

71. It is instructive to examine the history of the use of those provisions. In the more than 200 cases brought under sections 45D and 45E since their inception, a pecuniary penalty has never been sought in any case. Only the Trade Practices Commission or the Minister are able to take action for pecuniary penalties. The primary objective of both the Commission and the Minister should be the resolution of the underlying dispute rather than the imposition of a penalty.
72. The history of the provisions, administered by Governments of both persuasions, clearly indicates that pecuniary penalties are not necessary for effective enforcement.

73. In almost all actions brought under these sections, the underlying dispute has been resolved by interim or final injunction, or by arbitration or negotiation brought about by the threat of litigation to seek injunctive relief. In a very few cases, damages have been awarded for breach of injunction; in other cases, costs of litigation have been awarded.

74. It is clear then, that the effective operation of these sections does not depend upon the level of pecuniary penalties, and therefore there is no need to increase them for infringements of the sections.

75. There has been some criticism by the Business Council of Australia and others of the proposed maximum $10 million pecuniary penalty for other Part IV provisions. The present levels of penalty for Part IV offences were introduced in 1974 and have not been updated by any Government since that time. Both the effects of inflation and community acceptance of the need for business to abide by the standards of conduct dictated by the Act warrant a substantial increase. So too does the level of penalties for comparable conduct in other countries, and this was specifically recognised by the Committee—for example, $10m in the United States and Canada, potentially considerably more in the European Economic Community, and $5m in New Zealand.

76. On these bases, the Government has decided that the level it proposes is not inappropriate. It needs to be borne in mind that the maximum penalty is applicable only to the worst possible breach. That may be, for example, for a long-standing price fixing agreement which has netted the parties far more than the maximum possible penalty in artificially inflated profits at the expense of the Australian community generally. The courts will ensure that the penalty imposed in any particular case is no more than is appropriate to the severity of the particular offence.
Private right to injunctive relief
Recommendation 18:
77. The Committee recommended that:
" . . . the private right to injunctive relief in relation to mergers not be reintroduced into the Trade Practices Act 1974.

78. The Griffiths Committee had supported reintroduction of the right subject to it not being available to use by target companies or "white knights". On 22 August 1991 the Attorney-General announced that the Government was prepared to accept that recommendation subject to reconsideration in light of the report of the Cooney Committee. As noted, the Committee has now recommended against reintroduction of the right, because it was not convinced that the potential for abuse of the right could be adequately limited. On subsequent reconsideration, the Government has concluded that this is the better view and thus it has accepted this recommendation.
Enforceability of undertakings
Recommendation 19:
79. The Committee recommended that:
" . . . the Trade Practices Act be amended to provide remedies for breaches of undertakings made between the Trade Practices Commission and another person or persons.

80. This recommendation accords with the conclusions of the Griffiths Committee and with the Attorney-General's announcement of the Government's decision in this regard on 22 August 1991. The Government accepts the recommendation.
Other Remedies
Recommendation 20:
81. The Committee recommended that:
" . . . consideration be given by the Attorney-General to introducing a range of appropriate remedies for contraventions of Part IV of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

82. In the Attorney-General's announcement of 22 August 1991, it was stated that the Government had agreed upon enhanced remedies for the Trade Practices Commission and private litigants. Further details of these proposals were set out in the submission of the Attorney-General's Department to the Committee. The Government accepts this recommendation.
Implementation of recommendations
Recommendation 21:
83. The Committee recommended that:

" . . . the details of any proposed amendments to the Act should be developed by the Attorney-General's Department following consultation with all relevant parties and released by way of Exposure Draft Bill for public comment. Public comment should occur over a reasonable time period of not less than three months.

84. The Government is firmly committed to the development of laws in consultation with those affected by them, and particularly so in relation to business laws. It is thus supportive of this recommendation in principle. It will be adopted for those matters which have not already been the subject of discussion and debate as to the details—the introduction of pre-merger notification and new and enhanced remedies. However, for the other matters of the merger test and the factors to apply in its application, enforcement of undertakings, unconscionable conduct, penalties and the minor amendment to section 46, the Government considers that the processes of the Griffiths Committee and the Cooney Committee, and associated consultations which the Attorney-General and his Department have had with relevant interests, make it now appropriate to move to final implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on the John Curtin School of Medical Research. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The report read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 21 October 1992
Senator the Hon T Aulich
Chairman
Senate Standing Committeeon Employment
Education and Training
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Aulich
I am writing to formally provide the Government's response to your Committee's report entitled `The John Curtin School of Medical Research', which was tabled in the Senate on 30 April 1992.

There are three matters in the Report that call for a Government response. These are the introduction of 5-year rolling appointments for non-tenured members of the School; the provision of funds for the School via the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services (HHCS); and having future committees of inquiry make explicit and public the procedures they intend to follow.

In response to the Committee's recommendation on the `introduction of 5-year rolling appointments for non-tenured members of the School', the Government is totally in support of such a mechanism to ensure the best researchers are employed by the School, and retained over a longer period than was the case in the past. This initiative will be taken up within the new arrangements agreed between HHCS and the Australian National University.

The Government is proceeding with the transfer of funds from the Department of Employment, Education and Training to HHCS. The Government sees merit in the argument that there is advantage for the School being linked, through association with HHCS, to the mainstream Australian health and biomedical research networks. To this end, an agreement was signed between the ANU and HHCS on 12 May 1992. This agreement includes the establishment of a Liaison Committee to oversee the implementation of the arrangements agreed between the University and the Department and these arrangements will be monitored by the Government as they are progressively implemented. The agreement also provides for quinquennial reviews of the School which will be coordinated with the reviews of the other research schools. Such reviews will provide the JCSMR with the opportunity to confirm its standing in the research community.

The Government accepts that it is desirable for committees of inquiry to make explicit and public the procedures they intend to follow. However, it believes that prescribing such procedures is not a practical option, as the circumstances of various inquiries differ. Committees should be free to decide the most effective way of conducting their inquiries having regard to their terms of reference, time constraints and resources.

The Government believes that the new arrangements for the JCSMR will be of benefit to the School and is looking forward to constructive relationships between HHCS, the ANU and the School which are aimed at further enhancing the School's scientific reputation.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN HOWE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the Government's overdue response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on the John Curtin School of Medical Research. This response is typical of the poor attitude that the Government has had towards this whole issue. As shown in the report, the Senate Committee looked at the actions of the Government with regard to the funding of the John Curtin School. The Government has taken funding as part of the Australian National University and placed it in the hands of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. In this way, the Government has the facility to directly influence the projects and research undertaken at the John Curtin School.

PARA.TAB: This is an outrageous action by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe). It, in effect, circumvents the will of the Parliament. It is amputating a dynamic and integral part of the university. It is an invasion of the autonomy of the university. It has been done against the will of those involved at the John Curtin School, as indicated by their staff meetings on this issue. It has been done against the will of the Australian National University, as indicated by the resolutions on this issue by the ANU Council. It has been done against the will of two of the founding fathers of the University, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs, both of whom have voiced vehement opposition to the actions of the Minister, and now the Minister also has this very chamber standing against him.

Since the Senate Standing Committee handed down its report, the Senate has passed a private senator's Bill introduced by me requiring the Minister to return the funding of the JCSMR to DEET where it belongs. This Bill ensures the autonomy of the ANU and has overwhelming support from the Australian National University. The Government refuses, however, to bring this Bill on for debate in the other place, as it knows it is wrong and it knows it should never have interfered with the autonomy of the ANU in the first place. It is clear that the Minister must not be allowed to continue with this action.

The Senate Standing Committee looked at the basis on which the Minister had made his decisions to intervene so radically in the internal affairs of an autonomous university. The actions of the Minister were precipitated by the findings of the Stephen Committee. The Stephen Committee was established to look at the operations of the Institute of Advanced Studies within the ANU. The result was that Committee singled out the John Curtin School of Medical Research for considerable criticism and recommended the radical moves that the Minister has instituted.
Let me quote from the report we presented to the Senate and to which the Government is responding today:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee is unanimous in its concerns over shortcomings in the processes followed by the Stephen Committee during its review of the Institute insofar as this related to the John Curtin School. The Senate Committee considers that such shortcomings diminish the value of the decisions arrived at.

There is no doubt that the findings of the Stephen Committee can be seriously questioned. The process of collecting evidence, communicating with the School and consulting with the Australian National University left a lot to be desired. Bound by the evidence before it, the Senate Committee believed that the shortcomings of the Stephen Committee review process detracted from the validity of its conclusions and brings into question the actions predicated upon its findings.

PARA.TAB: It is clear from the evidence presented before the Senate Committee that the proposed funding changes have disadvantaged both the John Curtin School and the ANU. The Minister has failed to demonstrate any overriding benefit from this transfer. It is also clear that the autonomy of Australian universities in general is threatened by these new arrangements.

The JCSMR is unlike any other medical research institute funded through the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. The difference with the John Curtin School is that it is an integral part of a university and not merely affiliated with one. The removal of funding from DEET sets a precedent for a situation where any faculty from any university could be removed from the purview of DEET and placed in the hands of other departments whose operations are viewed as being congruent with the subject matter of the faculty concerned. Clearly, this is an undesirable situation and cannot be tolerated.

This response to the original report only addresses three of the issues that were originally raised by the Senate inquiry. Thankfully, the Government agrees with the Committee's recommendation on the introduction of five-year rolling appointments for non-tenured members of the JCSMR and I look forward to the prompt implementation of this recommendation.

The report then goes on to advise that the Government is ignoring the report of the Senate Standing Committee and proceeding with the transfer of funding from DEET to the DHHCS anyway. This is simply a pig-headed attitude by the Government, and in particular the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, Mr Baldwin, in the face of overwhelming opposition. The Government has the JCSMR against it. It has the ANU against it, including the founding fathers, Sir Mark Oliphant and Dr H.C. Coombs. It has the Senate Standing Committee against it and, with the passing of the ANU Amendment (Autonomy) Bill through this chamber, the Government has the Australian Senate against it.

The Government has also failed to address properly one of the key recommendations in the JCSMR report. Given the poor information gathering procedures of the Stephen Committee, and the way in which it changed its terms of reference over the period of the inquiry, the Senate Committee suggested that in future such inquiries make clear their intentions and make their information gathering procedures explicit and public.

In this response the Government accepts this suggestion, but misinterprets the Senate Committee by suggesting that the Committee wanted such procedures prescribed for all such inquiries. Clearly, this is nonsense and the Senate Committee at no stage suggested this. It is unfortunate that the Government has not properly considered this report.

The most desirable mechanism for the control and administration of the John Curtin School is through the ANU as it was originally established. This means that the funding must come through DEET. Given the findings of the Senate Committee, the Minister must reverse his decision and return the funding arrangements to DEET. The decision by the Minister has been based on poor information and it cannot be demonstrated that the Minister's actions will actually correct any problems that were identified.

I urge the Government to properly consider this report of the Senate Standing Committee and bring the ANU Amendment (Autonomy) Bill on for debate in the other place and pass that legislation to return the funding of the JCSMR to the ANU where it rightfully belongs. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Social Security Performance Standards 1992-93

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved this motion because I briefly want to refer to one experience that constituents of mine had with the Department. The Department answered questions at the Estimates Committee hearings recently as to when this report would be presented and referred specifically to the matters I had asked a colleague to raise as to the length of time it takes to get an age pension. The answer was 21, 28 or 56 days.

PARA.TAB: Although this may be the only case that has caused delay, I would emphasise that it has caused considerable distress to my constituents. They wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) not because it will help them, but perhaps in the hope that some action can be taken to save others the distress they experienced.

My constituents put in their application for the age pension prior to the man retiring, as they had been told they were entitled to do. The first thing they received was a letter saying that the woman was not eligible because her husband was in employment. That matter was cleared up. They went back to the Department when the man in question retired and had the papers copied. They were told that it would be about six weeks before the pension would become available.

Subsequently they received a telephone call saying that their birth certificates were needed for proof of identity, even though the original form they had dealt with listed birth certificates as an option for proof of identity. When this form was lodged, such proof was not raised as a necessity. This caused some problems because they did not have ready access to their birth certificates and considerable delay was caused at this point. I hope that the new performance statements contained in this document will clear that matter up. People will then know precisely what they need when they apply for their pension and it is to be hoped that this sort of delay will not occur.

These people had been led to believe that they would be eligible for a full pension, but in fact got a half pension. That is not the aspect to which they refer, although they found it somewhat distressing. Certainly they find the position bemusing because they only have some insurance policies that will not mature for several years and a small amount of money in the bank. However, that matter can be followed up.

It took them over three months to get any pension. This was highly distressing at a time when they found that, having worked for many years and having had a regular income, they suddenly were not in receipt of income at all. They were in no way prepared for the sort of delay that occurred, nor did they have the expectation that this would happen. That is the reason why they have asked that their case be highlighted. It took four months before they received any pension. I will quote from their letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Trips to the Social Security office are no picnic. Each trip—and we had three—involved about one and a half hours, much of that standing either to be registered or at the counter being interviewed.

They go on to say in their letter to the Minister that during all their phone calls and interface with staff they felt that the staff appeared to know what they were doing and were always polite. However, they felt that the delays that they suffered should not have occurred and that the forms and information which are provided should be sufficiently clear in the first place so that this kind of delay will not happen.

PARA.TAB: It is my hope that the performance standards which have now been put together by the Department will alleviate this problem. Even though the staff are knowledgeable and helpful, there is a certain level of stress involved in going to Social Security and embarking upon an application for something in a totally different environment from which that person has been involved in previously. There is a level of stress associated with that. When it then results in delays that really need not and should not occur, that is very unfortunate indeed. I hope these performance standards will mean that others in the future will not have the same experience as did my constituents.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the Finance Minute on the Committee's report No. 315, Social responsibilities of Commonwealth statutory authorities and government business enterprises. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 319th report of the Committee, entitled Review of the Independent Auditor—watching the watchdog. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: It gives me a great deal of pleasure to be tabling the 319th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Review of the Independent Auditor—watching the watchdog. This is the first review by the Public Accounts Committee of the Independent Auditor to the Australian National Audit Office. Under the Audit Act 1901 the Independent Auditor is appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the Minister for Finance to audit the work of the Australian National Audit Office specifically to examine the accounts, records, financial statements and efficiency of that office.

PARA.TAB: As the Audit Office audits government departments and government business enterprises and agencies such as the National Rail Corporation—and I might add that the Senate has confirmed this particular duty—the Independent Auditor is truly the watcher of the watchdog and the watchdog, of course, is the Auditor General. The position thus forms an essential link in the accountability chain which, we believe, is an integral part of the Westminster style of government which is practised here in Australia.

The provision for the appointment of an Independent Auditor was introduced in 1979 by an amendment to the Audit Act. I remind the Senate that the first Independent Auditor was Mr Evan Duff Cameron, a partner of the then Peat Marwick Hungerfords accounting firm. He served until May 1988, having been reappointed on a three-yearly basis. The last occupant was Mr Michael John Sharpe, an audit partner of the firm Coopers & Lybrand. He was appointed on 1 June 1988 for an initial term of three years, which was subsequently extended until this year.

I take this opportunity of commending Mr Sharpe on his professionalism and experience. This was amply demonstrated by his review of the Australian National Audit Office.
