Indeed, he made a significant contribution in introducing private sector practices to the Australian National Audit Office within the constraints of public sector audit, and thus contributed to maintaining the high status of the office through ensuring the highest professional accounting standards.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts would also like to take this opportunity of congratulating Mr David Boymal, who is a partner in the Melbourne firm of Ernst and Young, on his recent appointment to the position of Independent Auditor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear. Well done.

—The Committee fully endorses the decision of the Minister for Finance and is confident that Mr Boymal will undertake his task in the best traditions of the profession, being both impartial and meticulous. The Committee notes that the new Independent Auditor has indicated that he will conduct efficiency audits of the Australian National Audit Office on a rotating basis, covering specific activities on alternate years.

PARA.TAB: The role of the Independent Auditor was briefly reviewed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its 1989 report of an inquiry into the Australian Audit Office appropriately called, The Auditor-General: ally of the people and Parliament. In acknowledging the critical role of the Audit Office, the Committee believed that parliament's evaluation of the work of the Independent Auditor was appropriate in terms of reassuring the parliament, government agencies and the public that the Australian National Audit Office was performing in accordance with the highest professional accounting standards, and was being evaluated to meet such expectations.

In June 1991 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts called for submissions as part of its review of the Office of the Independent Auditor. It subsequently received 16 submissions from Commonwealth Government departments, private accountants and State Auditors-General. Overseas contributions came from Canada, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. The Committee subsequently took evidence at a public hearing in Canberra on 8 May 1992.

The Committee noted that it has been past practice for arrangements for the exercise of the powers and the performance of the function of the Independent Auditor to be documented by memorandum rather than by legislation or regulation. However, evidence received indicated that there was a preference for an increased role of the parliament in the appointment process and in interactions with the Independent Auditor. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts considers that there should be a more formal arrangement between the Independent Auditor and the parliament and has recommended that either an audit committee of parliament or the JCPA is consulted in the appointment of the Independent Auditor and in the formulation of relevant legislation. I may add that as part of that consultation, meetings took place between the Committee, the Department of Finance and the Australian National Audit Office today.

Recommendations have also been made to increase the formal contact between the Committee and the Independent Auditor. There is an advantage in bringing to the position a completely independent perspective and enabling a sound comparison to be drawn between the operations of public and private sector audit offices. The current practice of appointing the Independent Auditor from the private sector is endorsed by the Committee.

The Committee has addressed the possibility of conflicts of interest by recommending that the Independent Auditor is precluded from other contracts with the Commonwealth Government. As well, the Committee recommends that secrecy provisions similar to those applying to the Auditor-General and staff of the Australian National Audit Office should prevail.

The Committee has made several other recommendations to be considered during the drafting of revised legislation. For example, the selection criteria should be broadened and specified in legislation, as well as provisions providing appropriate procedures for resignation and removal of the Independent Auditor. The requirements of the Audit Act should also be brought into line with the current auditing practices and standards in Australia. I believe this will be the case when the new Audit Act comes to fruition. While the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is here, I urge the Government to expedite the procedure for these three new Acts of Parliament covering financial administration to be introduced to the Parliament as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I have been listening to you. You ask politely and nicely; who could but respond in the same way.

—And I thank Senator Button for his salutatory comments about the appointment of the new Independent Auditor. I also take this opportunity to thank the Committee and its Secretariat for their work. In particular, I wish to thank Mr Stuart Alford—who, incidentally, is also from the firm of Ernst and Young—for his technical assistance in the inquiry. I do not think there is any relationship between his assisting the Committee and this appointment. I believe that the new Independent Auditor brings to his office a high degree of professional skill and judgment and experience in the industry.

PARA.TAB: The Committee is of the view that the Independent Auditor has performed a valuable role in ensuring that the Australian National Audit Office conducts its affairs in a financially and operationally efficient manner, and commends the report to the Government for implementation at the earliest opportunity. I commend the report to honourable senators.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the National Capital

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Capital, I present the first report of the Committee entitled, Our bush capital—protecting and managing the national capital's open spaces. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate as to why this is the first report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital. This is the Committee which replaced the joint parliamentary committee on the Australian Capital Territory, the name of which was changed to this name just a few months ago. It fits in more closely with the present role of the Committee now that the Australian Capital Territory has its own government. The responsibility of the Committee relates to those areas which have been retained by the Federal Parliament and, thus, the name, the Committee on the National Capital.

PARA.TAB: This was our first inquiry—inquiring into the aspects of the national capital open space system. We are indebted to the assistance we had from Ms Ann Lyons Wright, Ms Lindy Smith and Mrs Marlene Lyons, the staff who assisted in putting the report together and running the Committee.

Most Canberrans believe the open space system has been there for all time, and in fact it has. The name itself is of more recent origin, but many Canberrans think that it is a name that in fact has been there for many years. It reflects the view that not only Canberrans but also other visitors to the national capital have of the sort of place this is—the bush capital, as the report is called. From a tourism point of view, that is an important feature to retain. We have referred to this aspect in the report, where we say in the summary at the beginning:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is committed to the continued existence of what most people believe is the essential character of the national capital, a bush capital where the open spaces will be protected as the population continues to grow.

There are some 40 recommendations, and I hope that they will be looked at most carefully. We recognise that a number of them involve the expenditure of money. We are not able to give precise costings because we do not have that information. I read again from the summary where we say:

The Committee recognises that there are costs involved in the recommendations which we have made. They are made on the basis of what we believe is necessary to achieve the long term goals of protecting the values of the National Capital Open Space System. We recognise that they can only be implemented as funding becomes available.

We feel that it is important to have the recommendations set down so at least those administering the areas on behalf of the Commonwealth will know what we believe should happen. We also recognise that the Commonwealth retained unto itself many of those responsibilities, through the legislation that was passed in the Parliament, given by the Commonwealth to the National Capital Planning Authority and the former Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to administer. So the Commonwealth, having retained responsibilities, has an obligation for funding in the areas for which it is now responsible.

PARA.TAB: One matter that needs to be pointed out relates to the planning, management and administrative arrangements of the system because of complexities. There are two land managers. I read again from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: National land . . . is managed . . . by the NCPA on behalf of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories . . . The remainder, Territory Land, is under the administrative responsibility of the Territory government . . .

There are also two plans. The national capital plan determines the general land use plan for the ACT and the specific planning policies for designated areas. The Territory plan covers all other areas of the ACT and must not be inconsistent with the national capital plan.

PARA.TAB: It has always been a bit like that in Canberra, but I think it is important, if this Territory is to flourish, that confusion between the ACT role and the national role be kept to an absolute minimum; that we do not drive people away because of the bureaucratic nightmare that they encounter when they attempt to do business in Canberra. The two Federal and ACT departments responsible at the present time are endeavouring to work well together.

There is a specific recommendation, No. 10 at paragraph 4.38, that I wish to highlight. I hope the confusion about the names that are used to identify the open space system will be resolved quite quickly. The Committee was concerned to find that the NCPA uses the term `National Capital Open Space System'. It is embodied in the national capital plan. But the ACT Department of Environment, Land and Planning uses the term `Metropolitan Open Space System. I read from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that if the system were only a metropolitan system there would be no call on the Commonwealth for a funding contribution to its planning and management. It is because the system is national in character and fulfils Commonwealth policies expressed through the National Capital Plan that the Committee feels strongly that the Commonwealth should make a greater financial contribution.
We also urge that the using of two different names for similar areas be removed as quickly as possible.

PARA.TAB: I shall not go through many of the worthwhile recommendations in the report in detail. Open spaces are important to Canberra and, I believe, to the nation in a number of ways. They are particularly important to various faculties of the education institutions in Canberra. Research is carried out in them and they are used by the faculties—the CSIRO, University of Canberra and the Australian National University. That is important: education as a part of our economy is a very important aspect of it.

Many students come here from the regions and from overseas. A centre of excellence in education is very important to our economy. For that reason, of course, it is particularly disappointing to find that the CSIRO is moving part of its headquarters from the national capital to Melbourne. No good reason has been given, to my knowledge. I am disappointed that the Federal Minister has not told CSIRO that it should not occur. Popular rumour as to why it is happening is less than acceptable.

The open space system is also important for tourism. It is an area which people enjoy when they come here. The recent research of the National Capital Planning Authority into people's attitude to Canberra clearly shows that people like to come here because it is the national capital. All those things which make it attractive as a tourist destination are very important.

The area is used also for recreation. We refer to that recreational use to which the open spaces can be put in the report. We recognise that some recreational use has a down side of wear and tear. We also recognise that there is no point in keeping places nobody ever visits and sees; that recreational use is very important and should feature in the management of the areas that we are referring to.

We have dealt with the role of the rural lessees in Canberra. Rural leases have been a shrinking part of the Australian Capital Territory which, in many ways, is important. The rural nature of this area is significant and ought to be part of the heritage of the ACT. It was important rural land long before Canberra was built. It is very much a part of our history. I hope we will always have some rural leases here because of the buffer zone, for the delight that they are and for the purpose that they fulfil.

We also refer to the impact on the open space system of feral animals and intrusive plants. We deal in chapter 7 with feral animals relative to the impact they have on the property of the rural lessees. We heard evidence from the lessees about the impact of feral animals. A suggestion was made to us that pigs were being brought into the ACT for the purpose of capturing or shooting them for sport. If there is any substance whatever to that, I hope it will be tracked down and dealt with very harshly indeed.

Feral animals make an enormous mess of the whole place. I include cats; we have dealt with cats in this report. We have referred to feral and domestic animals in the open space system—specifically, cats, dogs, pigs, horses, rabbits, goats, foxes and other introduced species. There is really no point in spending large sums of money on the open space system unless a fair amount of attention is paid to the feral animals living in the open spaces. They are certainly very costly to those people with rural leases in the area. The rural lessees concentrate, as they have to, on keeping these feral animals away from their properties, but there is really no point in having an open space system unless the Government gives the keeping of feral animals out of the open spaces a very high priority.

There is a reference in the report to the Burley Griffin-designed parts of Canberra being given World Heritage listing. We have not dealt with that in detail, but we have suggested that the Federal and ACT governments look at whether that would be beneficial to Australia. Other capitals are listed as World Heritage sites. We believe that the two governments which have responsibility for this area could look at that possibility. It may be very worthwhile indeed.

One is aware of the lack of funding in the past few years. One only needs to go on a short walk from here around the Parliamentary Triangle to see how it has been allowed to run down in recent times. A great deal of work needs to be done if it is to maintain its status as the central part of the national capital. I believe that the Minister has starved the National Capital Planning Authority of funds for this work, which really comes into the category of maintenance. It is not in the best interests of the national capital from any point of view for this to be allowed to happen, because undoubtedly the costs in the end will be a great deal more.

We have indicated that we believe in a review of the fire brigade and voluntary fire brigade services. It is important that the volunteer contribution be recognised and preserved. We say in the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee commends the idea of volunteer fire brigades to assist in the protection of the NCOSS, particularly in the urban fringe areas, and suggests that it be considered by the ACT Government in its review of the emergency services.
Many more things could be dealt with, and I hope that people will read the report.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting to read the speech given by the Chief Minister of the ACT just recently in the 1992 Walter Burley Griffin lecture entitled, `Keeping Canberra Canberra'. She referred to the Griffin plan a number of times in her speech and indicated his desire that it have a well-developed public transport system. She indicated that it is a part of her Government's policy that there should be a well-developed public transport system.The Chief Minister also referred to the Griffin concept of variety in housing. Walter Burley Griffin specifically referred to variety in styles of housing and its benefits.

The Chief Minister referred to the urban village concept.I was disappointed to find that in her speech she did not take up the challenge of the urban village design that has been presented to the Government in relation to the central portion of the suburb of Gungahlin, which is presently under construction. It is a well-designed, well-thought-out plan that incorporates the use of a public transport system and a different style of housing. I thought that it would have been an occasion for the Chief Minister to have given some substance to her wish when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our government hopes to ameliorate this trend, to increase the range of house types and to provide opportunities for an "urban village" lifestyle.
I urge her to have a close look at that and not miss the opportunity to do something with a bit of imagination in the development of Gungahlin.

PARA.TAB: I also noticed that she seemed a little ambivalent about the relationship of the ACT Government with the Commonwealth Government when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: From a Territory perspective the Commonwealth seems to have embraced the idea that self-government has relieved it of its responsibilities towards Canberra, beyond that which is required in the general run of relations between the Commonwealth and other partners.
For some unstated reason, she then went on to say:
The current opposition have made it clear they want to retreat from even that role.

There is no evidence whatever to substantiate that aside. The Chief Minister challenged the Commonwealth Government to remain involved and to make its contribution. Later in her speech she was critical of that Government wanting to have a say in Canberra. So clearly there are areas where things still need to be worked out.

PARA.TAB: In summary, my view is that the open space system is a very important part of the Australian Capital Territory of the national capital. The Commonwealth has retained it unto itself and, having done so, cannot now walk away from the responsibility of maintaining it. Our report recognises that there is a vast difference in maintaining an open space system from the days when there were 60,000 or 80,000 people living in the Territory to now, where the population is approaching 300,000. The pressures on open space areas are quite different when a larger population is living on the edge of them. So the role of the National Capital Planning Authority and the other departments in looking after the open space system will be critical.

No-one expects that everything we have suggested in the report can be done in a year or two. But it is hoped that this will be used as a blueprint for how the open space system can be managed, that in time it will be in a better state than it is at present and that the areas we have referred to that still need to be identified and gazetted will be. Our Bush Capital sets out our views as a result of consulting widely with the departments and the community. I hope that it will be of value and read by other senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Margaret Reid on the report of the Joint Committee on the National Capital entitled Our Bush Capital. I was a recent conscript to this Committee, and I was very pleased to be able to join it. Unfortunately, I was involved only in the very final stages of this report, so in my considerations I have relied very heavily upon the work of my colleague Senator Reid.

PARA.TAB: It is a pleasure to work on a committee that involves the national capital with someone of the calibre of Senator Reid, who obviously has a commitment to this city and its people. Senator Reid has a dedication, understanding and even a love for the city that is her home. It was very beneficial for me to be able to take advice from her in my limited deliberations on this report.

Canberra is our national capital and is a very fine city. At times, it suffers a deal of what has been referred to as `Canberra bashing' by people who in many instances should know better. It is rather wrongly placed criticism at times. People confuse the government of our nation with the city of Canberra. In other words, people who live in other parts of Australia sometimes refer to Canberra in derogatory terms when they are really referring to the government of the nation which sits in Canberra at present.

I can well appreciate why people around Australia rightly criticise this Government for the recession and the huge unemployment that it has brought us, but it is wrong to blame those problems on the city of Canberra and its people. I repeat that Canberra is a very fine city and is a national capital of which all Australians can be justly proud.
The Committee said in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is committed to the continued existence of what most people believe is the essential character of the national capital, a bush capital where the open spaces will be protected as the population continues to grow.

I certainly agree with that statement and sentiment. It is a very fine city and one that attracts an enormous amount of tourism and will continue to do so more and more in the years ahead. It is important that the Government should now be looking at things such as better transport facilities to this area. Even international airports should be considered in an attempt to enhance the tourist potential of this region, and in particular our national capital.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of recommendations in the report. However, because I was only a recent entrant I was not able to join the Committee in making its recommendations. When I was appointed, the Committee inquiry had virtually been completed and I did not have the benefit of hearing all the evidence and examining all the relevant documents. Some of the agreements are ones that all senators would agree with, while others require further consideration and investigation.

I just want to mention a couple of the recommendations. Senator Reid has referred to recommendation 10, which states: The NCPA and the ACT Planning Authority urgently clarify and resolve the inconsistencies with regard to definitions, the range of permitted land uses and the boundaries of open space between the National Capital Plan and the Draft Territory Plan and/or take measures to ensure this information in those documents is presented in a form which is readily understandable to the community.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a very important recommendation. We must ensure that there is certainty and that people who deal with the plans understand exactly what they say.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 11 relates to the appointment of a national capital open space advisory committee. Recommendation 12 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee could include, in addition to representatives from the NCPA and the ACT Department of Environment, Land and Planning. . . nature conservation groups; rural lessees—
as Senator Reid mentioned, this is very important—

professional groups such as the Institute of Landscape Architects, Royal Institute of Parks and Recreation; TESAL; Park Care groups; the scientific community; special interest groups. . . and recreational interests.
It is important that that committee operate to assist and give advice to the board. The committee should be made operational as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 18 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A group of Friends of the National Capital Open Space System be established by the NCPA to involve the community in the planning and management of the NCOSS.

Again, it is important that we get the widest possible involvement in the open space system. I am sure Canberrans would very much welcome the opportunity to be involved in the planning and management of the national capital open space system.

PARA.TAB: Recommendation 19 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of whether the ACT Land (Planning and Environment) Act 1991 applies to areas designated under the National Capital Plan as having the special characteristics of the National Capital be resolved as a matter of urgency.
Again, I think that is self-evident.

PARA.TAB: The final recommendations of the report—recommendations 38, 39 and 40—refer to catchment management systems and catchment protection schemes. River catchment management systems and schemes and projects are needed right around Australia. In every part of Australia there is an urgent need for proper management and administration of catchment systems. In the past governments have given too little notice to this need. It is something that should receive greater attention. In the context of an increased Australian-wide interest in river catchment management, certainly the recommendations of this report, as they affect the national capital, should be looked at.

Again, as Senator Reid has mentioned, the Committee recognised that there are costs involved in implementing the recommendations of this report. But the recommendations are made on the basis of what the Committee believed was necessary to achieve the long term goals of protecting the values of the national capital open space system. The Committee wisely acknowledged that those recommendations can only be implemented as funding becomes available. That is an important and sensible qualification in the report, bearing in mind the difficulty governments currently have, particularly this Government, in funding anything at all. It is essential that priorities are looked at and that governments do not get involved in spending money that they do not have.

I should note for the record that the cover of the report is quite magnificent. It is a very fitting cover to the report on our bush capital. The report is an in-depth look at these issues. It certainly raises a lot of issues which will be of interest to Canberrans and all others who have the interests of the national capital at heart. I join with my colleague Senator Reid in commending the report to honourable senators and to anyone else who has the interests of the future of our national capital at heart.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to draw attention to this report. I understand that my colleague Senator Panizza has an interest in this matter. As he is now in the chamber, I might forgo my opportunity to speak.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Senator Macdonald, that is now considered a speech and you are in Hansard as having made one—a remarkable speech!

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Rail Corporation has been in existence for some eight or nine months, having been delayed because the rail unions would not cooperate with the Government. I can see a future for the railways of Australia under the one umbrella of the National Rail Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The aim of the Corporation is to link up all the main Australian cities on the one main line under one jurisdiction, one industrial award and one signalling system. It originated out of a statement by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke—I forget which one because there were so many of them and it was quite a few years ago. It should also be borne in mind that Australian rail loses in excess of $4 billion a year. Any move to reduce those losses and provide better rail transport in Australia is certainly to be commended.

In the case of interstate rail, I believe that it should be the cheapest and fastest transport of goods between States or between capital cities, but that has not always been the case in the past. All modes of transport, whether rail, road, air or sea, should complement each other rather than try to destroy each other. In time to come the Corporation will have a major role to play, and I certainly look forward to its continued success, even with its belated start.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Panizza's comments on the National Rail Corporation remind me of something I wanted to indicate at one time. Recently, I had the opportunity of travelling from Adelaide to Perth on the Indian Pacific.
—Pity the poor person sitting next to you.

—I thank Senator Ray for his very pleasant comment. I might respond by saying I was in a private, single compartment, and there would not have been room for Senator Ray and me in the one compartment. I would be so unkind as to say that I doubt whether he would have fitted in even by himself. However, I do want to make some more constructive comment on the Indian Pacific.

PARA.TAB: It is a great concept and it is one of the great railways of the world. It traverses some very interesting country—country that is very specifically Australian. I thought the staff on it were trying their hardest to do the right thing. But I might say by way of helpful criticism that, not long before that, I had the opportunity of travelling overnight on one of the new Queensland trains. There is not much I can ever find to congratulate the current Queensland Government on, but I must in this instance say that it operates that new train that runs from Cairns to Brisbane in a very business-like, efficient and proper manner. The Queensland train was staffed by young people who were obviously trained in hospitality skills. Everything on that train from Cairns to Brisbane was done well. It was very good, high-class accommodation—and I say that without being snobbish, but it was just done very well. It was indeed a pleasure to travel on that train and a pleasure to be dealt with by the staff. The way they ran that particular train was quite magnificent.

By contrast, while the people on the Indian Pacific tried, it was just nowhere in the same class. I urge the people that operate that train to have a look at the Queensland operation because the people who operate the Indian Pacific could learn a lot from the operation of that Queensland train. The way the meals were done, the way all the meals were presented and the way the tourists and passengers were looked after was just so much better.

I make these comments in the hope that the people involved might just have a look at that, because it is a magnificent train which traverses magnificent country. The train is a great asset for Australia but its operation just needs a little bit of finesse and shining up. I hope the people who operate it will have a look at that some time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (ISOLATED AREA ZONE EXTENSION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 1 April, 1992, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate my colleague Senator Panizza on presenting the Income Tax Assessment (Isolated Area Zone Extension) Amendment Bill 1992 for the Senate's consideration. I draw the attention of the Senate to an unsuccessful action involving a claim in respect of certain rigs.Had Senator Panizza's Bill been passed, it would have put a different complexion on the matter. Court action would not have been necessary because, under the circumstances, the taxpayer would have been able to claim a legitimate deduction. I congratulate Senator Panizza on identifying a problem. I hope the Government proceeds to accept this Bill so it can proceed through the lower House.

—in reply—I thank those honourable senators who have spoken on the Income Tax Assessment (Isolated Area Zone Extension) Amendment Bill, and the Australian Democrats for their promised support of the Bill. I brought in this private member's Bill because of an anomaly whereby zone A and zone B rebate allowances in isolated areas cease at the shoreline of Australia and its offshore islands. However, no area in between falls into zone A and zone B—namely, the man-made platforms that have been constructed in the last few years.

PARA.TAB: I introduced this Bill on 1 April last year because of concerns that were expressed to me by taxpayers living in the remote areas of Western Australia on offshore platforms who were not able to get this rebate, unlike those who lived on the mainland. As Senator Watson pointed out a moment ago, I brought attention to this myself in the Tax News this week in regard to a Z40 zone rebate case. The Tax Commissioner appealed to the AAT and the AAT held that an offshore natural gas platform worker was not a resident of zone A or zone B and was not entitled to the zone rebate.

The AAT held that, for the platform to fall within zone A, it had to be either part of the Australian mainland or an island forming that part of Australia. The gas platform attached to the continental shelf, 135 kilometres offshore, was held not to be part of the mainland, nor could it be regarded as an island.

That is why I spoke to my Whip the other day—to see whether I could bring this matter on for debate. This Bill grants extra rebates, thereby going on the expenditure side of the accounts of the Government rather than the receipts side. However, the Government has never been slow in passing legislation for the extra collection of tax when the expenditure sites are not within the shoreline of Australia or the shoreline of offshore islands.

Cases in point where special—I emphasise special—legislation has been passed include sales tax where there has been expenditure on equipment used in offshore areas that are not on offshore islands and the collection of fringe benefits tax where fringe benefit has been paid to workers working on those oil platforms, whether they work there one day, one month, six months or 12 months. Those same areas are covered by the resource rent tax under the Submerged Lands Act.

I believe that living on a platform should be treated in the same way as being in Zone A or Zone B, whether people are living permanently or flying in and flying out. Of course, if one is flying in and flying out, as Senator McMullan might know, one has to make up the six-month minimum to qualify. I hope that the Government picks up this idea. It has been sitting on the Notice Paper for six months. I thought that the Government might have taken up the idea and put it in a tax amendment Bill itself.

I thank the Democrats—who are not in the chamber at present—for their promised support. I also pay recognition to the chartered accountant in Western Australia who brought this matter to me to bring before the Senate in the form of a private member's Bill. Hopefully, we will see an amendment from the Government. Incidentally, that chartered accountant happens to be my oldest son, Francis John Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a few comments on the second reading. I assure you that, given that Senator Panizza has summed up, I will not attack him or be provocative, but I think it would be appropriate to put on the record the Government's position on the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The Income Tax Assessment (Isolated Area Zone Extension) Amendment Bill 1992 is, as I understand it, in the same terms as a Bill introduced by Mr Filing in the House of Representatives—which is just as well because it is that Bill which I have had a chance to look at, rather than the one with Senator Panizza's name on it. But I was assured that they are the same.

PARA.TAB: I understand the concern that both members are seeking to address, but the Government will not as such be supporting the legislation on this occasion. Nevertheless, there are some anomalies. I have had a look at some of the things that were said in the second reading speech on the Bill and I am not yet persuaded that we have a major anomaly with which to deal, but I accept the sense in which Senator Panizza spoke in summing up: that he was really seeking our taking this up in a subsequent amendment. I am prepared to continue to look at that. I do not want to give an assurance that we will.

We have some concerns: for example, the circumstance where a worker is working in a remote area or on a ship passing through adjacent waters but whose ordinary place of residence is outside a remote area zone; for example, a person might have a place of residence in a capital city and be working on a rig. I acknowledge that this was some time ago, but the public inquiry into income tax zone allowances in 1981 specifically addressed the questions of ship crews, people in the fishing industry and oil rig workers, and it did not see a need to change the existing arrangements for these groups where workers had a place of residence outside a zone. There was not a need for a change for people whose principal place of residence was within an area which qualified for a zone allowance simply because they already had it.

The inquiry observed that these workers normally received free messing and accommodation while on duty. Consequently, they are to a large extent cushioned from high costs associated with remote living while they are working. This is not normally the case when they are at their place of residence. Here they face the same cost structure as their neighbours, and they should receive the same tax zone benefit, if any, as their neighbours.

Our concern is that we have here people who, on the evidence available on the most recent review, do not face all those factors that apply to zone rebate application. They face some of them, I acknowledge, but not all. At this stage, we are not persuaded that the balance is such that the rebate need apply. There are some technical problems with the Bill. This does not seem to be the appropriate time to go into them. Senator Panizza is not pretending this is the be-all and end-all; it is simply a statement drawing to the Parliament's attention concerns about anomalies and seeking to have the Government take it up. If we were to do so, it would be for us to remedy the technical problems. I will not take up the Senate's time with that because people have been trying to cooperate in expediting the proceedings more recently.

I draw attention to one problem we have which is the treatment of people working in the zone of cooperation with Indonesia in the Timor Gap. There is a problem there that this Bill does not cover and which would not be easy to deal with, but on the basis of consistency, we would need to.

We will not be supporting the Bill at this stage, but I indicate that we are prepared to look at any particular anomalies in the working of the present zone arrangements which either Mr Filing in the House of Representatives, or Senator Panizza here, has raised with us. I am not giving any undertakings about action to flow from it, but I understand the purpose of their initiative in this regard. Although the Government will not be voting for it, we will have a look at the issues that have been raised to consider whether it is appropriate for inclusion in a subsequent tax Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words on the Income Tax (Isolated Area Zone Extension) Amendment Bill 1992. It is perhaps my only chance to address some of Senator McMullan's concerns. I am asking for platform residents who are there for more than six months, people who live in the territorial waters off zone A, to be treated equally with those who are living on land in zone A. I think Senator McMullan accepted that, except that he said that those living on a platform have good living conditions and are not suffering any great hardships. By way of interjection, I tried to let him know—and he did not want to listen—that their conditions are no different from those at, say, Argyle Diamonds, where they fly in and fly out and have very good living conditions; and there are other places like that in the Pilbara and the iron ore mines. It is exactly the same type of situation.

PARA.TAB: I want to address the problem for those on the platforms who are living in just as much isolation. In fact, they can travel far less from the platforms. Being in that isolated area, they can travel only the length of the platform—otherwise they go over—whereas in those other northern towns they have a lot more freedom. That is the point which I would have liked Senator McMullan to have taken up. I reiterate that the Government has never been slow in passing legislation to pick up sales tax on expenditure, FBT and rent resource tax.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This report on the Christmas Island rebuilding program is very important because, as many honourable senators will know, Christmas Island is attached to the Northern Territory for voting purposes and is therefore part of the constituency that I represent in the Federal Parliament. The report has attracted considerable attention because it arises from a proposal by the Government to proceed with a rebuilding program on Christmas Island that will, in effect, over a long term period commit the Commonwealth to in excess of $130m worth of expenditure. On first looking at this, a lot of people immediately recoil and ask why there should be such a large expenditure for 1,300 people located in such a remote locality.

PARA.TAB: It is important to recognise the historical importance of Christmas Island to Australia. This is canvassed in many places. In precis, Christmas Island was originally a colonial situation that was taken over by Australia as part of a partnership deal for the development of a phosphate mine on that particular island. The economy and the opportunities have changed over the years. The phosphate mine has waxed and waned in its fortunes. I am pleased to say that the mining activity on Christmas Island is currently in a period of very good rapport. This week I read the annual report of Phosphate Resources NL, the locally owned mining company on Christmas Island and was pleased to see many of the issues that have arisen.

The community on Christmas Island comprises a number of expatriate Australians serving in the local administration, a number of Australian citizens who have taken up residency, and a number of foreign people who choose to live on Christmas Island and participate in the life and community that is there.

The other recent private sector economic development that has been canvassed for Christmas Island is the development of a casino. Again, the fortunes of the developer there, like the mining establishment, have waxed and waned. There have been some problems in the last year or so with the development program of the casino and its construction. I have asked a number of questions in this place and in the Estimates Committee which relate to the development of that casino. I am well aware that many of those questions have still not been answered by the Department of Territories, particularly as they relate to foreign police investigations surrounding the developers and a number of activities. I await those answers with interest because of the long term economic advantages that could flow to the island from a proper tourism development.

This particular report deals with a proposal to expend $130m of Commonwealth funds on an infrastructure program for the island. Admittedly, much of the infrastructure on the island is in a deplorable condition and is very run down. A lot of that is to do with the fact that historically the island was essentially run as a mining community and a mining town. It is now accepted that if the permanent community is to be sustained at at least 1,300 people, there will need to be a massive improvement in the infrastructure on the island.

I appeared before the Public Works Committee following a visit to the island in May earlier this year. I expressed a number of concerns. I did not in any way seek to thwart the proper provision of services to people living in such a remote locality, but wished to question the very large commitment that will be required by the Commonwealth in financial terms. There will be a major necessity to ensure that the continued life of the mine is sustained, that tourism as an economic industry is developed and that we also recognise and underpin the important defence implications of maintaining Christmas Island in Australia's interests. In effect, it is our base in the Indian Ocean; indeed, it could be argued that it is an aircraft carrier for Australia in the Indian Ocean.
I called into question the commitment of funds. I am pleased to note the second recommendation of this report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that prior to the final commitment to the total ten year rebuilding program there should be an assessment of the success of the initial funding program which may lead to changes in priorities and/or funding levels.

Given that reservation in the recommendations, I believe it is important that this project proceeds. I think the initial commitment for the first four or five years is in the order of $37m. That is still a very large and significant Commonwealth contribution to such a community. Since we are making a commitment to very long term needs, I feel there will need to be a review.

PARA.TAB: I also flag for the attention of the Senate the role of Australian Construction Services. To date, that section of the Department of Administrative Services has carried out most of the initial assessment and initial planning for this major reconstruction program. I have been critical, as I am sure Minister Bolkus knows, of a lot of the activity of Australian Construction Services. But in a location such as this, Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean, I would not want to see ACS being given an exclusivity with respect to either the planning or construction phases of such an important project as this.

I believe it is important that the private sector be involved and, as Christmas Island has such an important commercial link with Western Australia, I hope that many interests from Western Australia will take advantage of this particular program. Similarly, I hope that commercial interests from my own electorate, the Northern Territory, because of their close geographic proximity, will also seek to take advantage of the commercial opportunities that are there in providing such an important service.

For that reason, I will be monitoring very carefully the continued involvement of Australian Construction Services in this project. I would argue that the involvement of ACS is probably not needed at all in this and that the services could be carried out either by contractors already on the island or by services that are available in the private sectors of Western Australia or the Northern Territory.

Christmas Island, and indeed the neighbouring islands of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, are very important in the long term development and security interests of Australia. I hope that the Parliament will monitor very carefully these 18 recommendations of this particular report, that all of them get close and careful scrutiny over the next few years, and that the improvement of infrastructure proceeds at a very careful, planned and constructive pace.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
