SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on this legislation on the Opposition's behalf. We have before us the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1992 and the second reading speech of the Minister for Justice (Seantor Tate), which was incorporated into the Hansard. I must say it was a brief and, I believe, quite cursory summary of what is involved in this Budget decision.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Opposition, I note that, however inadequate this Government is in the handling of education matters—and this Labor Government has built up a deplorable record on education matters—on this particular matter, because it is in large degree a response to the kind of flexibility for assisting students that the Opposition has called for for some time, we will not be opposing the Bill. The Opposition has a second reading amendment, and accordingly I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to adequately address the problems in the administration and targeting of student financial assistance to ensure that it is fair and accessible to all.".

PARA.TAB: The Student Assistance Amendment Bill puts in place a loans scheme which will enable what the Government calls the financial supplement. It enables those receivers of Austudy undertaking tertiary study to trade in a dollar of their grant to gain a $2 loan, which is technically $2 of financial assistance. Either that additional or enlarged assistance is then repayable directly with a 15 per cent discount in the first five years of what is called a contract period, or, if not repaid during that period, it is then repaid under the higher education contribution scheme mechanism, known popularly as HECS.

The kinds of tax debts that are accruing at the moment for the contribution towards tuition fees—some 20 per cent or thereabouts of a student's cost of tuition—are currently for many students a HECS liability which is to be subsequently paid back under a formula out of their graduate earnings when those students are employed. That same HECS formula will apply to this financial supplement that students will be able to receive should they choose. The commendable elements of this scheme are choice and flexibility. That is why the Government is at least to be commended for improving student assistance to incorporate these two elements which the Opposition has been urging for many years.

Currently student assistance is met by $1.5 billion of the Commonwealth Budget each year. About $1.3 billion is for Austudy and another $190m is for the Abstudy scheme. This is about 19 per cent of the total Commonwealth outlays on education. The Commonwealth is providing a very substantial amount of money for student assistance. The taxpayers of Australia are providing $1.5 billion each year for the recipients of Austudy and Abstudy, the two student assistance schemes. This is meant to provide for the living costs of students and is, of course, in addition to the provision by the taxpayer of the lion's share, that is, 80 per cent of the cost of tuition.

In regard to student assistance and the $1.5 billion which is spent each year, the Labor Government has an atrocious record of poor administration and poor targeting. Even though there has been a House of Representatives inquiry that has brought deficiencies to the attention of the Government, and even though the Government has been forced to set up its own consultants to inquire into these matters, such as Dr Bruce Chapman, the Government has not responded adequately to even these inquiries. That is why I have moved this amendment to the Bill.

The Government is not only condemned by the Parliament, but also by students around Australia as a result of their experience of its unfair, inadequate administration of student assistance schemes. In addition, of course, the Government is condemned for not having an answer with regard to the 50,000 students turned away from tertiary education each year.

It has given me no pleasure to come in here at least twice each year for the past 10 years and, on behalf of the Opposition, reiterate again and again the inadequacies of the Labor Government. I have said, and honourable senators present will understand—Senator Reid knows very well as do you, Mr Acting Deputy President—that the only remedy for the students of Australia and for education is a change of government and all the reforms and all the additional resources which have been clearly set out in the promises of the Liberal and National parties.

Therefore, it is some relief from this pattern of inadequacy and failure that we have this one refreshing decision of the present Labor Government, and that we see this legislation before us. As I say, it is commendable for its flexibility and the choice that it gives to students.

Typical of the criticism that I have just reiterated one more time here in the Senate is that which we in the Liberal and National parties have made with regard to the hardship of many families suffering in the rural recession. We have called again and again in this place for the rules regarding Austudy to be amended, so that we have adequate hardship provisions for assisting such families whose children are being denied access to education because of the way the rural recession has affected those students.

I refer in particular to families which are asset rich, but income poor—even income negative. Because an assets test for the Austudy program has been brought in by the Labor Government, such families, despite their dire circumstances, are being denied access to Austudy for their children. I remind the Senate that on 13 May last year I moved the following motion on behalf of the Opposition:

That the Senate calls on the Government to immediately introduce emergency educational assistance in the form of hardship provisions so that families excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test, but whose income has collapsed in the rural

SPEECH.PARA: crisis, will not be forced to withdraw their children from education on financial grounds.

That motion was adopted in the Senate. Did it make any difference to the Government—a hard-hearted government; an inflexible government? It did not make any difference. There is now no adequate hardship provision in the rules related to Austudy. I say again that the Liberal and National parties, on coming to government, will put that adequate hardship provision in place. We will exclude the operation of the assets test in circumstances that we have defined clearly with regard to families suffering in the rural crisis, and any other families in like circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The only comprehensive answer to student assistance in this country will be that given by an incoming Liberal and National party government. We have undertaken—and I repeat the promise now—to have a complete review of Austudy and Abstudy arrangements so that they are fair and administratively sound. This review can begin only when we are elected to government. I look forward to the positive support of my Australian Democrat colleagues for that amendment when we come to the end of the second reading stage of the Bill.

The House of Representatives committee inquiry led the Government to take only this one step to appoint Dr Bruce Chapman to produce a consultants report on matters that have been raised. He brought down a very commendable report, one which gave a great deal of support to the statements that I have been making here in the Senate over many years about the inadequacies in the present Labor Government's performance. Similarly, it very much reinforced the statements made by the spokesman of the Liberal and National parties in the House of Representatives, my colleague Dr David Kemp.

The Bill before us is only one action that the Government has taken following Dr Chapman's report. In essence, the objectives of this Bill, set out in clause 6, will enable a larger resource to be available to tertiary students. They will be able, if they wish, to choose to forgo one dollar of grant to gain two dollars of loan to a maximum of $4,000 in any one year, on the basis that that money is available from a financial corporation yet to be announced by the Government. This money is off-Budget. It will not come in the immediate five years from the taxpayer; it will come from a financial institution, presumably a bank, to be announced in the next few weeks by the Government and under the contractual guidelines that are set out in this legislation.

The money up to $4,000 available to students accrues, and if it is paid back within the first five years there will be a 15 per cent discount. To the extent that it is not repaid at the end of the five years, that debt will be taken over by the Commonwealth Government and become an actual bill to the taxpayer. That money will then be repayable by the student according to the HECS formula to which I have referred. There is a bill that will fall to the taxpayer in the intervening period, and that is the interest owing to that financial institution on monies that are advanced to students; and, of course, the 15 per cent discount is made up by the taxpayer. The Government estimates that in the next five years there will be savings to the Budget because, as is evident, for students to take up this option they must forgo some of the grants that otherwise would be paid to them.

A second group will be able to gain loans of up to $2,000, and that is those students who are currently denied Austudy or Abstudy but whose joint family income is less than $50,000. Students who are in every other respect eligible for Austudy, but who are denied Austudy only because their family incomes are beyond the threshold for the minimum payment but up to $50,000, can take up loans of up to $2,000.

Again, it is a question of opportunity and choice. As Dr Chapman clearly set out in his report, this gives very commendable flexibility to the Austudy scheme. In different cities there are different costs, different courses and different financial pressures. Students at different points in their university careers will have different pressures for gaining immediate financial support. Depending upon all those circumstances, in the judgment of the student himself or herself, they will be able to make flexible arrangements for additional financial support. As I have said, the Opposition commends the choice that this gives to students and the fact that it improves the targeting of the support in a non-bureaucratic way, on the basis of students themselves making the choice and assessing their own circumstances.

Underlying these advantages is the basic principle that higher education produces benefits both for the community and the individual and that there is a contribution for a student undertaking studies provided by the community and also by the individual. This Bill sets out a good balance. In fact, I urge my own incoming government, the Liberal-National party government, in the coming months, or this Government, in the event of its being able to do something about this in the next few weeks, to incorporate a more flexible use of the HECS currency, as I put it, into student assistance and enrolment opportunity for Australians.

I put it in a general way. Once upon a time we had the ability to enrol only upon the payment of cash. The currency used to gain access to a university place was cash. Then we had scholarships, which gave a second currency. Then we had a bureaucratic entitlement that one did not have to pay cash and did not need a scholarship but that if access was gained, mostly on merit, to a place—the number of places was limited—one could go ahead and enrol in the university. So we have a third currency in terms of access of Australians to higher education.

A user pays element of 20 per cent was then introduced. That was to be an amount payable through the tax mechanism out of graduate earnings. That currency was a considerable gain in flexibility and in making possible a user pays element that would work. I commend the way in which that particular currency—HECS—has been applied to this loan scheme. I believe that it can be extended even more: for example, combined with up-front cash would be an ability for students to enrol in places beyond the present quotas.

The Liberal and National parties have a distinct policy coming into the forthcoming election: we will allow a university to enrol any students on whatever basis that university sees fit. We envisage the university requiring an appropriate fee for those enrolments. It is within the flexibility of government to determine that such students who are putting up large up-front payments for that tuition can also gain some access to HECS, and an appropriate and fair combination of those two currencies will enable students to gain access to the system. By passing in their initial year subjects that they undertake, they will then be able to gain access in the normal way to a Commonwealth scholarship for 80 per cent of their tuition costs and the user pays element of 20 per cent under HECS. That sort of flexibility in this Bill in the use of HECS can be extended in combination with the flexible and open-ended policy that the Liberal and National parties offer.

In the Minister's second reading speech there is reference to the savings that will accrue as a result of this Bill. Budget savings are estimated to be $42m in 1992-93, rising to almost $115m in 1993-94 and $138m in 1994-95. That is for the reasons that I mentioned earlier. But we do not know what they will be in the financial years following. It is clear that there will be losses in five years time. I put a question to the Minister, which I hope will be answered in the summing up of this debate, as to what precisely those estimates will be for all financial years through to the end of this century. There is an indication of their effect on the Budget in the financial year 2002, but I want to know what the estimates are—surely they have been made—for the next 10 years.

Further, I ask the Minister to respond to these questions: what are the Government's detailed plans for the selection of the financial institution involved? What sort of competitive process has been involved? When will the outcome be known? I understand that it is a few weeks away, but I want to know precisely. In addition, what are the financial arrangements for the next 10 years? In the few minutes that remain, I want to make clearer the reasons why I have moved an amendment to the second reading condemning this Labor Government for its inadequacies in the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because you have been told to.

—I have not been told to. I know that Senator Faulkner, Senator Bolkus and my very good friend Senator Cooney will want to be reassured that we have a well thought out education policy which we will implement as soon as we gain the support of the Australian people in the coming election. In these few minutes I will indicate, in great contrast to the inadequacies of the Labor Government, some of the reforms we have in mind. Austudy will increase by 6 per cent across the board on 1 October 1994. This is more than compensation for the tax reform package that is outlined in Fightback.

PARA.TAB: The coalition will introduce a properly constructed hardship provision that will assist many rural families to overcome the present denial by the Labor Government of access to Austudy for them, even when they are in dire financial circumstances. We will increase the boarding allowance for students who are away from home and ensure that it is free of the Labor Government's asset test.

There are also direct benefits for those students who may be earning some income from part time work. The tax threshold will be increased from the current $5,400 to $7,000. Many students with low incomes from part time work will be direct beneficiaries of that easing of the tax threshold. The petrol excise will be abolished. The saving of $11 a tankful when filling a car with petrol will be as much a gain to a student, who is saved from paying the excise on petrol for a car, as it will be to all Australians.

The abolition of the wholesale sales tax will be of direct benefit to those students and their families who are rightly investing in a computer, or software related to a computer, to assist them in their studies. The sales tax on computers will be abolished by a Liberal-National government, and students will find that they are better off. I should also point out that there will be eligibility for a tax credit for thousands of students who are paying some income tax but are not fully compensated by the change in the tax threshold. These tax credits are set out in great detail in the Fightback document.

I should not overlook two general and very positive gains that will assist all students. Firstly, we will create jobs, jobs and more jobs. As a result of getting the economy right, there will be increased numbers of jobs for students when they graduate and—
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Bolkus says jobs are rubbish.
—Jobs are not rubbish. They are needed by Australian students as much as by every other Australian.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. There is a misrepresentation which I want to bring to your attention as a point of order. It is totally inappropriate for Senator Knowles to claim that a policy from Dr Kemp, who says that he wants a fair go for rich Australians in his education policy, will create jobs. The point I made and the point that my colleague Senator Faulkner made was that that policy will not create jobs and that the policy is rubbish.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! That was not a point of order. Senator Bolkus, if your colleague next to you who was interjecting at the same time was doing it from his seat, I might have been able to hear what was said.

TALK.START.PARA: —This present Government has created one million unemployed. We, through the Liberal-National party economic policy, will get those Australians back to work. That means that students will have better access to part time jobs while they are studying. They will also have much better access to full time jobs as soon as they graduate. The only positive policies for the students of Australia now lie with the Liberal and National parties. The sooner we have an election, the better, because then we will see those policies put into effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1992. I guess if one were to believe the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), this is the sort of nonsense that the Senate makes the order of the day. This is what the Prime Minister so astonishingly said on the 7.30 Report tonight. This Bill is an extremely important piece of legislation. The lives of thousands of Australia's students are affected not only through the primary provisions of the Bill but also through the regulations that will be enacted later on in the year which will once again substantially change the way that Austudy is administered.

PARA.TAB: This Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 to introduce a student loans scheme. It also seeks to amend the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Act 1983.

First, I would like to express my concern about the hasty way in which the Government has handled this legislation. After a controversial debate in the wider community this year, this Bill was rammed through the House of Representatives and has jumped to the top of the Senate agenda. Astonishingly, in addition to that, on Tuesday we were given a further five pages of amendments to this Bill. This suggests to me that the drafting of this legislation has been hasty in the extreme. Before the Bill has even been enacted, we are looking at a quite substantial amendment which, I am told, seeks simply to clarify and amplify the provisions of the legislation that is before us. However, I submit to the Government that perhaps it would have been preferable if it had got it right in the first place rather than simply presenting to us pages of amendments that we are asked to consider.

The Democrats do not support this legislation. From the outset we have made our opposition to a student loans scheme very clear. In fact, we have done so since the release of the Chapman report earlier this year. The implementation of a loans scheme would, in our view, further entrench user pays education in this country. It is my belief that in 20 years time we probably will not even have an Austudy student assistance scheme as, over time, governments of all colours will seek to wind back its provisions and the support that it gives. They will incrementally change a scheme which has served to support thousands of Australian students over the last decade.

Instead of redressing the blatant inequities in Austudy, this scheme is what the Government is actually offering the struggling students of this country. Loans will be available to those students eligible for Austudy and Abstudy—those students who are, by definition, the hardest hit and the poorest in our community. Through the loans schemes, students can trade in in whole or in part their grant for double the amount in a loan form. Despite being a voluntary loan, many students will be forced by their economic circumstances to take out the double loan amount.

The Democrats have maintained their opposition to the introduction of a loans scheme for students since the release of the draft Chapman report, which was intended as an investigation into Austudy and which was to recommend ways to make the system more equitable and better targeted. Of course, we all know what happened to that process. Dr Chapman ended up by recommending in his final report a whole series of changes to Austudy that were acceptable to all sides of the debate. He did so in order to pull himself out of the political quagmire in which he had been placed by the Minister, Mr Baldwin.

The Democrats have maintained their opposition to the introduction of a loans scheme for students. The Democrats maintain that loans are a disincentive to enter and to participate in further education. This affects students from lower socio-economic backgrounds and other traditionally disadvantaged groups, including women and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.

The loans debate is not a new one. The Liberals introduced the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill in 1982. This legislation was repealed in 1985. The feature of that debate was that the Democrats did not stand alone in defence of an accessible and equitable public education system. They were joined by the Australian Labor Party, which upheld the belief that `Loans are a further extension of the discredited user pays principle; it is knowledge on hire purchase, and a tax on investment in people, in our most important national asset'. These were the words of Senator Colston, one of the many Labor senators who condemned the scheme at the time. There are many more Labor senators who would be ashamed of their backflip on this issue.
Senator Zakharov, another current senator, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Loans as a basic means of financing study. . . are intrinsically inequitable and can have a deleterious social effect. They are inequitable as. . . they give an advantage to those who are already advantaged.

I could not agree more. Senator Zakharov continued to report student concerns that `any loans scheme could be the precursor to an attack on TEAS or even a precursor to the reintroduction of tertiary fees'. Of course, we already know that the Opposition plans to reintroduce a form of tertiary fees if it is elected after the next election. It will do so by allowing universities to charge fees to top up a student voucher system. How right she was.

PARA.TAB: Senator Zakharov's anticipation of further attacks on the public system of higher education are well founded, given that her Party introduced tertiary fees in a new form—HECS—less than four years later. Today it represents the next stage for this Government towards the entrenchment of user pays education in this country. It is for this reason that the Democrats support the Opposition's second reading amendment. We are doing so not because we believe that the Liberals have the best interests of students in mind. It is because we agree that the Government should be condemned for its failure to address adequately the problems in student financial assistance and to ensure that assistance is fair and accessible to all.

Nor do we credit the Opposition with a fair education policy. Under Fightback! students would be subject to up-front full cost fees and severely narrowed Austudy eligibility, and important educational programs such as Aboriginal studies would be cut. There would be no joy for students under a coalition government, with threats of voluntary student unionism, HECS hikes and limited financial assistance.

I would, however, agree with the concerns that Senator Teague expressed in relation to the targeting of Austudy for rural students. It is well known that many rural families hit by the assets test would greatly benefit from having that test removed. This would allow their young people to participate more fully in education. I certainly hope that, if elected, the Opposition will implement that reform posthaste to assist rural families.

But I cannot understand why this Government has not seen that some real inequities have developed in rural Australia as a result of the assets test on the family farm. Therefore, support for rural students is welcomed by the Democrats. The terms of this support are couched in Senator Teague's second reading amendment and for that reason we will be supporting it.

However, it is a pity that the Opposition's call for better targeting did not extend to supporting the Democrats' motion to exempt the family farm and small business assets from the parental assets test. The Government's failure to address student financial assistance is evidenced by a litany of regressive changes, even this year. Changes to Austudy regulations this year resulted in a hefty 20 per cent interest rate on the late repayment of Austudy overpayments. Students are now slugged with 20 per cent interest when they do not or cannot pay these overpayments which are often a result of administrative bungling or genuine error.

As I pointed out in my motion to disallow the regulation, this impost is out of line with any market rate and even corresponding provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Once again the Democrats stood in isolation on this issue as the Government and the Opposition combined forces to defeat this motion. This is an increasingly apparent aspect of higher education policy over the years. It is strikingly apparent today as the Liberals see no more wrong with this legislation than its name.

The fact that the Government refuses to call a spade a spade is another sign of its unwillingness to face the realities of student financial assistance in Australia. The financial supplement is—and is so defined by the Bill—a loan. We cannot understand why the Government could not face up to the reality and actually call it a student loan in the legislation. Of course, this would have been politically too damaging for the Government which is already on the skids with the student movement around Australia.

Those students who take up the loan enter into a legally binding contract with a financial institution, as the Government will not provide loans to students but, rather, will farm this out to a bank. This, we can see, is a privatised loan scheme.

Within the first five years students are responsible for payments to the bank if they choose or can wait until the Government assumes the loan, where they will pay it back through the taxation system. All this time the loans are indexed to the CPI.

The Government has gone to great pains to emphasise that these loans are interest free or have no real rate of interest, as in the case of the higher education contribution scheme or HECS. Depending on the rate of the CPI, students will accrue additional debt, which will add to their disadvantage.

Studies have shown that the income contingent HECS style arrangement has adversely affected the participation of people from a number of low income and disadvantaged groups in higher education. Despite Government assurances that the HECS would not be increased above the level of the CPI, last year's Budget increased HECS by $144 per annum. What assurance can the Government give that the rate of repayments for loans will not likewise be increased?

In part 4B of the Bill the maximum living allowance under the Austudy regulations will be indexed to the CPI. This is a welcome but overdue measure. It is certainly a proposal for which the Democrats have argued for many years. Nevertheless, this legislation does not safeguard the availability of grants to those currently receiving them.

The regressive changes in this year's Budget pave the way for a further erosion of Austudy and a narrowing of the eligibility criteria. The Democrats also seek to amend this section to include the indexation of the income threshold for Austudy recipients, which is an obvious omission, otherwise the Austudy benefits are indexed while the various thresholds that apply to Austudy are not indexed. Our amendment would iron out this inconsistency.

Also, the National Union of Students—the NUS—a body representing more than 450,000 tertiary students in Australia, has condemned the loans scheme, claiming it will threaten the integrity of the grants based system. The release of the Chapman report and its discussion of the replacement of Austudy grants with a loans scheme sent a warning to student and academic groups and the wider community that the Government's commitment to accessible and equitable education was dwindling.

These groups expressed their strong opposition to the proposal for a loans scheme through faxes, letters, comprehensive reports, meetings and, for some, marching on the streets to display their frustration and desperation at the Government's move. The Minister's claim three weeks ago in the House of Representatives that there is support from students for this scheme flies in the face of this protest and is clearly wrong. A final show of resistance from students and academics has streamed into my office, and no doubt into the Minister's office, over the last week.

Students from nearly every tertiary institution have denounced in no uncertain terms a scheme that would double the amount of debt many of them currently face. I have many more letters, which I will table, along with a copy of the NUS response to the loans scheme by Mr Robert Houghton, NUS education officer—a substantial document which belies the Minister's claim in his second reading speech that students had been unable to offer any arguments against a loan scheme.

Why is it that our graduates, the graduates of the so-called lucky country, are to be distinguished not by their brains but by their debts? Over and over again students are grappling with this inconsistency. The education officer at the Students Association of the University of Adelaide quotes one student who claims, `So much for the clever country!'. A University of Tasmania student writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Overseas experience shows. . . that shifting financial assistance from grants to loans will alter the social composition of higher education participants . . . in the direction of the elite and will dramatically increase student indebtedness.

These sentiments are echoed by NUS, the higher education round table, which includes the Union of Australian College Academics, the Federation of Australian University Staff Association, the Australian Teachers Union and the Council of Australian Post Graduate Associations.

PARA.TAB: Add to that the opposition of the Federated Teachers Union of Victoria, the South Australian Institute of Teachers, the Victorian Secondary Teachers Association, the Association of Professional Engineers and Scientists Australia, Australian Salaried Medical Officers Federation (New South Wales), the State Public Services Federation (Victoria), the New South Wales Nurses Federation, the Australian Nursing Federation (Victorian Branch), the Construction Forestry Mining Employees Union, and the list goes on.

Austudy remains full of inequities, despite the push for reform of the spouse income test, the personal income thresholds, the independent age rate and the level of benefits by the Democrats and students which the Government has failed to implement time and time again. Instead of reforming the scheme in a way that would encourage further participation in higher education and secondary education for disadvantaged groups, the Government, with the Opposition's blessing, has chosen to punish students even more.

One option in the Chapman report that deserved more consideration was institutional based loans—a means of securing emergency-type loans on a campus level for students in immediate need. This was a recommendation of the Chapman report that the Democrats supported. I did take time to discuss this with both Minister Beazley and Minister Baldwin as a much more preferable way of widening the means of financial assistance to a whole range of students who are not currently included in the loans scheme that we have before us.

It was suggested in the Chapman report that funds could be provided to institutions, that those loans could be based on a HECS style mechanism and that institutions themselves could administer the application of those loans by vetting candidates for those grants and would be in a much better position to assess the financial need of students as they were closer to their particular needs. However, this option was not considered, as I understand it, because the Government would not have saved so much money.

I hope that perhaps at some stage the Government would consider providing additional funds for institutional loans which would have certainly ensured that the tremendous chorus of opposition that has arisen as a result of the proposal currently before us would not have been so great as students have been campaigning for additional funds for university based loans for quite some time.

I do not expect to persuade the Liberal Party that student loans threaten the basis of a fair and distinguished education system, as support for loans has been a feature of its education policy for too long. I do hope, however, to stir the conscience of the Labor Party whose original commitment to free education and the abolition of tertiary fees in 1977 heralded a new era in higher education where entry was not based on privilege or wealth.

Gradually, this Government has reversed these policy decisions and, with them, reneged on its commitment of offering people from different cultural, socio-economic and geographic backgrounds the possibility of further education. Student fears have already been realised: the downgrading of student financial assistance has taken place in the Budget, with changes to the minimum annual payment that will deny 38,000 students Austudy benefits.

The very arguments that the Government so swiftly dismisses today about the potential erosion of the value of grants are the very same arguments it self-righteously used in this forum in 1985. The Labor Government has sold out students and has sold out education. If the Government's expected take-up rate figures are correct, within three years 85 per cent of students will be incurring further debt in the form of loans. In this respect this scheme is little more than a revenue raising exercise that will do little to alleviate the financial burden of these students. The Democrats reject this Bill and reject condemning students to debt. I seek leave to table the letters I referred to earlier.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1992 amends the Austudy and Abstudy schemes and introduces financial supplements to both schemes. This supplement, in fact, is a loans scheme that allows students to trade in some or all of their Austudy and Abstudy grants for a loan twice the size, up to a limit of $4,000.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also introduces automatic indexation of Austudy and Abstudy in line with inflation. The Opposition will not be opposing this legislation as it moves towards the coalition's policies as outlined in Fightback!. In response to some of the points that Senator Sowada made, I would point out a few things about what is happening in this area of student finance.

She really harked back to the good old days of the Whitlam Government which moved towards a system where education was free. Since the Hawke Government was elected, the Government has gradually backtracked more and more on that approach. The Australian Democrats really have to ask themselves why the Government did this. Here we have a supposedly socialist Government which under Whitlam brought in free tertiary education. Yet throughout the 1980s it found itself increasingly unable to maintain that sort of scheme. The basic reason for that was the harsh realities of Commonwealth budgeting.

We need a higher level of education in this country, in particular, university education; we have a small nation and education makes huge demands on its Budget. The only way that that sort of thing can be achieved is to bring in other ways of funding. To its credit, the Government over the years has gradually introduced some of these, although we believe it has not really gone far enough.

One of the Government's basic propositions in this Bill is that the people who benefit most from the education they receive should make some contribution towards it. The reality of HECS which is in place in this country is that the sort of contribution they make is really only about 20 per cent. The student obviously gains the greatest benefit from that sort of scheme. There is a public benefit and obviously we recognise that, with the public tax system paying about 80 per cent. But there is a real necessity, if we are to generate the number of places we want in this country, to create a situation where the people who benefit from it pay something towards it.

The same sort of principle tends to apply with Austudy and Abstudy. We have a situation where students are not being forced to move onto a loans scheme; they can stay on Austudy and Abstudy. But if they want to provide a little better for themselves during their time of study, they can trade in $1 in grant for $2 in loan, up to $4,000. The effect of that is that they can support themselves at a higher standard of living during that time and they can pay the money back when they start earning.

Through the HECS mechanism, which this Government introduced and which the Opposition supports, there is an arrangement in place where people can pay back—in a relatively painless way—the money they have received under a Government scheme. I am quite interested in some variations on that scheme. For example, the New Zealanders have introduced a scheme they call Studyright, where students are allowed to extend their loans and almost tailor-make the loans they want according to their needs, not only for fees but also for income support. It seems to me that that sort of direction is ideal because it gets back to what Senator Sowada was indicating earlier on: people, because of cost, should not be limited from the possibility of entering education. Providing students have the financial arrangements balanced in such a way that they can pay the money back easily, cost really should not deny anyone access to higher education.

We can look back to the time when the Whitlam Government brought in free education. There was an implied statement in what Senator Sowada said that the socioeconomic mix would change if we change these income arrangements. The Whitlam Government free education scheme for universities showed that there was no such change in the socioeconomic mix. I think it would be hard to prove in any way, or project in any way, that there will be a change in the socioeconomic mix if we move in the other direction, provided that we set the scheme up in such a way that people can pay it back easily, and that has been done through the HECS arrangements. The Opposition basically supports the broad direction of the Government in following the recommendations of the Chapman scheme in relation to funding for Austudy and Abstudy.

As I mentioned before, this Bill does go some way towards what we have proposed in the Fightback policy. It probably does not go far enough, but to the extent that the Government is amending the legislation to allow this breakthrough in funding, with the ability to transfer a grant to a loan on a two for one basis, we believe the Government is heading in the right direction. We do have a number of criticisms of the scheme broadly that the Government is still operating under Austudy and Abstudy. In particular, I draw the attention of the Senate to the Government's failure to take adequate action to target financial assistance available under the scheme or to recover overpayments.

Presently, funding allocated to the Austudy and Abstudy program is very poorly targeted and is not available to help the students in the greatest need. It has been clear for some time that there are many students receiving Austudy who are not in great financial need. There are many other students in obvious financial need who are ineligible for aid because of the rules of the program. Many of these are students in rural areas who are excluded from assistance by the operations of the assets test. In addition, it is evident from the reports of the Auditor-General that substantial losses are occurring as a result of inadequate accounting practices and overpayments.

Only recently, DEET compliance surveys found that between 12 and 27 per cent of students were being overpaid. This is not acceptable and must be properly addressed. The Minister's poor attempt to collect only $7.2m through this Bill is disappointing, to say the least. The coalition accepts that the basic objective of student financial assistance should be that no student with the capacity and the will to continue his or her education should be prevented from doing so on financial grounds alone. Given this, it is clear that significant changes are required to Austudy and Abstudy. A number of these changes were announced in the Opposition's Fightback package.

One of the worst rorts currently in use occurs when wealthy families arrange their finances so that they fall within the Austudy income tests. Through Fightback, we undertake to replace the definition of `income' as taxable income with the concept of total remuneration, which would also take into account fringe benefits and other income. Another rort occurs when parents sign a statutory declaration stating that they will no longer support their child, in order to make that child eligible for Austudy at the higher independent rate. This occurs, as do other rorts, under the exceptional circumstances provision of the Austudy regulations. This loophole will be removed under Fightback.

A significant efficiency in targeting the problem is the cost of administering large numbers of small payments which simply do not constitute the difference between a decision to pursue or not to pursue the education course. We have undertaken, when elected to Government, to eliminate payments of less than $30 per week as being inconsistent with the objectives of the Austudy scheme. It is interesting to note that the Government has moved to $20, so it is actually moving towards our policy.

In relation to overpayment and fraud, we will implement much tighter benefit control procedures with the objective of saving approximately $80m. Since Fightback was launched, the Government has summoned up the courage to adopt several of the coalition's proposals, at least in part. The measures outlined in this Bill are an example of this. The scheme proposed allows students who are eligible for Austudy or Abstudy to trade in their allowances for a loan up to a total of double the allowance. It is repayable within five years and repayable through the tax system, the same way as HECS. Loans will be paid to the student fortnightly and loans will be available between $500 and $4,000. The loans will also be available to those students who would otherwise have qualified for the allowance, but for the parental income test, whose parent income is less than $50,000.

The loan scheme is based on the recommendations of the Chapman report. This report was presented in April this year and confirms the Opposition's criticism of the poor targeting of the Austudy scheme. Dr Chapman found that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is little doubt that there is little sensitivity shown to the varied financial needs and circumstances of the potential clientele.
The essential challenge for reform is to improve the targeting so as to ensure that the right amount of assistance is delivered to those who most need it.

The Chapman report found that rorts did exist, including the manipulation of taxable income. The general thrust of the report was in line with the coalition's repeated criticism that student financial assistance has been poorly administered and inadequately targeted. These loans will improve the targeting of student financial assistance.

PARA.TAB: The Government has also followed the Fightback policy by including fringe benefits when assessing parental, spouse and personal income tests. This is not the only example. The Government has moved quickly to adopt our policy of increasing the real value of the boarding allowance for isolated children, though it has persisted with its determination to retain the asset test on the means tested portion.

In the Budget, the Government acknowledged that there were savings to be made by redefining taxable income—including fringe benefits—and by establishing a minimum payment level, which it set at $20 a week. It even acknowledged that there were savings to be made by more effective actions in recovering overpayment, a matter which Minister Baldwin denied at the time when the Fightback package was released.

In assessing the amendments proposed by this legislation, it is significant that nothing whatever has been done by the Government to realistically open access to education for rural students who would be excluded from Austudy by the assets test. These students do not have access to the loan arrangements set up by the Government, despite the fact that the Chapman report suggested that they should. It is also significant that the Government has presented to the Senate 28 amendments to this Bill. It is really a re-run of some of the things that I saw when I first came into the Senate. I was absolutely amazed in my first few weeks here to be presented with the Education Export Bill, a Bill to which we eventually moved 28 substantive amendments. This was only an eight-page Bill. This was an appalling example of mismanagement of legislation.

The fact that this legislation has already been amended so severely by the Government shows that it has been very hastily put together, and probably not thought out all that well. The amendments are probably the result initially of poor drafting. I believe that all Bills that come before this Parliament should be much more carefully considered. I am finding this more and more with legislation, as a member of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, and see it across a wide range of government departments.

The amended Bill and the further amendments that are proposed go some way towards addressing the problem of access and targeting of Austudy and Abstudy. As I have indicated, they really do not go far enough. Under Fightback, the coalition is committed to fully reviewing financial assistance when we get into government. We will create a much more efficient, accessible and fairer income support arrangement for students.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to begin my reply tonight by noting that student assistance has grown significantly over the past five years under this Government. In 1992-93, assistance to students under these schemes will total over $1.5 billion, an increase of over 10 per cent over last year. This does not include the funds available under the supplement introduced by the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1992. This will add $143m, bringing the total of student assistance funds to $1.725 billion, or an increase of 20.7 per cent over those funds available to students in 1991-92. This growth in funding translates to an extra 52,000 students, a 10.3 per cent increase, which takes the total number of students receiving support to 564,000.

PARA.TAB: As I have mentioned, this Bill introduces the Austudy supplement, a loan facility which enables students to trade in up to $2,000 of their Austudy grant for a loan of $4,000, if they so choose. In addition to this change, the Government is also introducing a range of improvements to the Austudy grants scheme, a number of which have been asked for by the student body for some time. Key amongst these is the lowering of the age of independence. The Government is lowering the age of independence to 22 by 1995, with the age dropping to 24 in 1993 and 23 in 1994. Further, we are increasing the amount recipients can earn before their benefits are affected—from $5,000 to $6,000. Finally, we are also indexing Austudy grants in legislation.

There are a significant number of improvements to the Austudy grants scheme associated with this Bill in addition to the introduction of the Austudy supplement. As well as all this, the Bill also makes student financial assistance available to students who do not presently receive Austudy because their parents' income may be just above the parental income test but still below $50,000 per annum. These students will be able to access up to $2,000 per annum through the Austudy supplement.

An important feature of these loans is that no real rate of interest is charged on the loans, which are only indexed to maintain their real value. Further, no repayments at all are due for the first five years after this supplement is taken out. After this time, students only repay when their income reaches above average weekly earnings. At the 1993 level of average weekly earnings—$27,748—students only repay 2 per cent of their income, or a little over $10 a week.

I now turn to some of the comments made during the debate. Senator Sowada made a number of comments about the desirability of institutional loans, as opposed to voluntary loans paid directly to students from the Commonwealth. The supplement provides a national framework of eligibility to ensure equitable and uniform access. The supplement is intended to extend the flexibility of the existing Austudy and Abstudy schemes and enhance the operation of the grants based scheme. It is fair to say that the introduction of the supplement has assisted in improving the grants scheme itself, quite apart from the additional funds made available to students through the supplement.

On the other hand, an institution-based approach could not guarantee this national access and uniformity of delivery. While this lack of uniformity is often held as a strength of institutional loans, the level of funds available to individual students would depend on how competent a student was at depicting their level of need to the institution concerned.

In addition, the establishment of a scheme with the same level of funds as the supplement will provide to students being delivered through institutions would require comprehensive accounting requirements within the institutions and would not provide the consistent audit and financial machinery that the proposed arrangement would provide. However, the Government has provided funds for tertiary institutions to make emergency loans available to their students. But the additional funds available under the supplement should ensure that existing funds are less strained by student demand.

I come to the question of the amendment that Senator Sowada has indicated she would like to move to have the Student Assistance Act index the amount of income that students can earn before their Austudy is reduced. The issue boils down to whether the level of the threshold should be included in the Act or left to regulations, as at present. Many other features of the Austudy scheme are contained in the regulations. Senator Sowada does not seem to have a problem with that. In fact, the Government has increased the threshold much more rapidly than would have occurred under simple indexation. The latest Budget, for example, includes a 20 per cent increase in the threshold, well above any indexation increase.

Senator Sowada's amendment would therefore result in a lower level of personal income test threshold than that decided by the Government. Our legal advice is that her amendment would preclude any amendment to the regulations to make increases outside indexation. I am sure Senator Sowada does not have that as her primary intention.

Senator Sowada also went on to make a few other comments, basically claiming that the HEC scheme has been a major disadvantage to low income students and quoted surveys to that effect. I would appreciate it if she would send me those surveys. I would like to look at their methodology because I have had no anecdotal or other evidence to see that particular point backed up.

It is a constant refrain in this chamber—sometimes on my side—that all education should be free and that students are being indebted into the future. As I have already made clear, the indebtedness is by no means great, and people who have the privilege of being educated to the level at which they are should have no difficulty in repaying something to society. I also think of those people who do not go on to tertiary education, who work on the factory floor or elsewhere and wonder why they are the ones who have to pay the taxes to send everyone else to university. It is not as though we are asking for a large repayment either through HECS or through an income supplement, in which case one is doing it on a voluntary basis. In other words, it is not compulsory.

Senator Sowada also indicated that she is supporting the Liberal amendment; nothing surprises me in that. But the amount of times in this chamber that we are having the Democrats support Liberal amendments for entirely different reasons than those put forward by the Liberals is very passing strange indeed. The Democrats can always find a set of iconoclastic reasons to support a Liberal Party amendment whilst they attack the rationale behind the Liberal Party amendment. But anyway, it is no great loss. Second reading amendments are not worth the ink they are printed in, so I will not give the matter any more time.

Senator Teague asked for some additional information concerning the selection of financial institutions. On August 25 an advertisement was placed in the Australian Financial Review seeking expressions of interest from financial institutions to provide lending facilities for the supplement. A letter was also sent to the chief executive officers of 36 financial institutions informing them as to seeking similar expressions of interest. A detailed invitation to provide submissions was sent to all responding financial institutions.

An evaluation committee of officers from the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of the Treasury was established to provide a recommendation to Minister Baldwin concerning the preferred institution to provide the lending facility. It is expected that this process will be finalised and eventual contracting of the institution will occur by late November. No public announcement can be made until after the form agreement with the financial institution is signed after late November.

One or two other matters have come up during the debate. Senator Sowada has complained about the amount of Government amendments. They really fall into three areas. One is the area of normal drafting corrections, which seem to be inevitable with legislation these days, but there are two other large areas. The first is bringing the social security amendments into this Bill rather than in a separate social security Bill. They can certainly have passage of the two chambers much earlier than if they were in a social security Bill. Therefore, I think it is justified that they be brought in here.

The second raft of amendments relates to matters raised by financial institutions. Those amendments are not necessary in the legal sense for the Bill, but they will make negotiations with the successful institution much quicker because they clarify matters that those institutions have raised. It was not essential that those amendments be in the Bill, but for the facilitation of those negotiations they will prove quite useful.

I come to my final point. I agreed with a lot of the first part of Senator Tierney's speech. The second part was an unpaid advertisement for Fightback! in which the new in-word is `targeting'. I recall when we introduced the concept of targeting in the mid-1980s involving the assets test, et cetera, Senator Tierney's then leader, Mr Peacock, made the greatest song and dance about it ever. So I welcome Senator Tierney aboard to the modern times of targeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called `efficiency' in government.

—Well, it is just a pity that was missing from 1975 to 1983. Senator Tierney obviously went to sleep on this particular issue there. Nearly every time in the mid-1980s when we introduced targeting measures, the old troglodytes on his side opposed them. Obviously he is the new breed. I welcome Senator Tierney to the Senate. It is good that he is starting to adopt these policies, that he is jumping on the bandwagon of modern efficient bureaucracy. We welcome him there.

PARA.TAB: We do not condemn Senator Tierney, because he was not here in the good old days of the troglodytes opposite who always opposed every element of targeting, every area of middle class welfare. Every time we targeted, all we got were squeals like stuck pigs from those opposite saying, `You can't do this and you can't do that'. I often wondered whether the then Opposition would ever be able to cut a Budget by $10m, let alone the $10 billion that it promised. The Opposition has never been able to do it in the past; it has never been willing to target. It was always the case in the gutless Fraser years that the then Government would give everyone the benefit and try to get a few votes out of it.

I summarise by saying that the Government appreciates the position that those opposite have taken on this Bill. We are sorry we have disappointed them in that we will not go further, but we will argue about that another time. As for the Democrats, as always they are motivated by the twin driving forces of principle and political opportunism. Maybe in this case they coalesce; I doubt it very much. The big hint in Senator Sowada's speech was that she is trying to dig in as many of the students votes as possible. She is working on the old principle that it does not matter if one offends 90 per cent as long as one can get the 10 per cent. The used car salesman's approach to selling cars on TV is once again made apparent here as one sectional interest is always pushed forward above the national interest.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the motion, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one question that follows on from my speech during the second reading debate. I thank the Minister for the answers he gave regarding the financial institution and the announcement that will occur in a few weeks. But there was one question I asked that was not answered and that concerns the estimates by the Government of the financial savings to the Budget in all of the next 10 financial years.

PARA.TAB: In his second reading speech the Minister made estimates for the first three financial years—in which there are escalating savings—and also with regard to 10 years away. He vaguely foreshadowed that there would be charges to the Budget as a result of this Bill five years hence. The precision with regard to those estimates has not been given. I am confident that those estimates have been made, and I ask that the Minister give those estimates now. That is the first matter.

The second matter that Senator Ray might address concerns amendment No. 8. Essentially, amendment No. 8 of the 28 amendments before us gives a guarantee or safety net to the financial institution that protects the validity of the contract between the student and the participating corporation from the operation of other laws; that is, all laws applying in a State or Territory, whether Commonwealth or Territory laws.
I can see the intention of that amendment and, indeed, amendment No. 8 replaces words that are already set out in these terms on page 9 of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) The validity of a financial supplement contract is not affected by any other law (whether written or unwritten) in force in a State or Territory.
Amendment No. 8 is a strengthening of that expression in the original version of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: I just want to ask whether the Government is confident that there is not an unintended consequence in this amendment; that is, there may well be quite proper State and Commonwealth laws that would give safeguards to students or the banks which will be made invalid by this amendment. I am really asking the Minister whether the Government has addressed the full repercussions of this waiver of all other laws that might bear upon the matter.

For the Opposition's part, we support the 28 amendments that the Government is moving. I only express surprise that this Bill was able to pass through the House of Representatives in the hands of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and did not have these 28 amendments. These 28 amendments do meet requests for safeguards by the financial institutions involved. No doubt those were part of the negotiations in the last weeks. Amendment No. 28, which is in 16 parts, deals with the integration of this Bill with the Social Security Act. It is all admirable stuff, but I just express surprise that these matters were not addressed when the Bill was first before the House of Representatives.
Having examined all of these amendments, the Opposition is happy to support them. Therefore, I leave only the two questions that I have raised with the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not an oversight that I did not respond to Senator Teague's second matter that he raised during the second reading debate. I had noted it. The figures projected to the year 2000 are based on assumptions far more than they are for the next three years. I think that before the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) can provide that answer he must clear it, and he has not done that at this stage. The answer will be provided and the information on this subject will be sent to Senator Teague. I think the Minister wants to clearly define what the assumptions are so that no-one can misinterpret the answer. It was not overlooked; it was simply a matter of timing.

PARA.TAB: Senator Teague raised a second question relating to amendment No. 8. This matter was gone into with Parliamentary Counsel and the Attorney-General's Office. Essentially, it is to deal with students under the age of 18. That is what the amendment is targeted at. I do not think it is targeted at an exemption from all State laws per se, but at those related to under 18-year-olds. I think there will be provisions in State Acts that suggest that minors cannot be bound by certain contracts. I do not think there would be a large number of cases—there are few under 18-year-olds undertaking tertiary education; it would only have applied to me for about a month, I think—but it does apply to some people. That is what it is targeted at—making sure that provisions that protect under 18-year-olds are not in some way used to undermine this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer on both counts. I will be most grateful to receive the full answer to the other question when it is cleared by the Minister. It would seem that there is no limitation on the words that are to be substituted in the Bill. They are:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . A financial supplement contract is not invalid, and is not voidable, under any other law (whether written or unwritten) in force in a State or Territory.

Whilst I note that the explanatory notes refer to a primary concern for persons under 18, and I can see that that is the intent of the Government, the words before us do not have that restriction. I just express one last note of scepticism, and I would be happy for some clarification in my mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier, the matter has come before us targeted at those under 18. I am informed that it is rather difficult to be quite that specific in that requirement. Therefore, I suggest to Senator Teague that if the matter is in any doubt in a legal jurisdiction anywhere, people will look to the explanatory memorandum for the explanation and, further, they will look to our exchange of views—as they do—and see that this provision is intended to cover minors. I am informed that it also might cover an area where someone has entered into a contract and is not mentally capable, in terms of mental stability. They are the two areas it covers.

—I thank the Minister. I make the further passing remark that 10 years ago the Minister, Senator Ray, and I happened to be serving on a Senate standing committee on education and the arts. It was proposing a Fraser Government-initiated scheme to extend benefits for student assistance. It involved going to financial institutions and it was unanimously accepted by that Senate committee. It was in a form which, if implemented, would have been of assistance to students. Senator Ray and I both agreed on the terms of that reform.

PARA.TAB: It happened that the incoming Hawke Government chose not to implement that scheme, even though the legislation for it was in place. I now see, 10 years later, perhaps on the eve of the passing of another government, that we have a student loan scheme that is even more carefully prepared than the one that we had 10 years ago. I wish the provisions of this extended amendment to the benefit of Australian students every success.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Teague for his views. We did have the privilege of serving on the same committee and coming to a unanimous view. I said at the time that the view would prevail, and here we are, 10 years later, and it has. Senator Teague is again in 1992, as he did in 1990, 1987 and 1984, presaging a conservative government just over the horizon. He was wrong in 1984, he was wrong in 1987, he was wrong in 1990 and he will be wrong in 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be opposing these amendments. They are, as we have been told, of a technical nature and do, apparently, take into account the concerns of financial institutions. However, I express the same concern that Senator Teague mentioned earlier. It is surprising that within a fairly short space of time the Government has seen fit to present to the Parliament five pages of amendments which were not included in the Bill when the legislation passed through the House of Representatives. However, we see the need for the amendments and, given that we will have a student loan scheme, we will not oppose them.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make a small comment on a remark that Senator Ray made regarding studies that have been conducted on the impact of HECS, while we are on the subject of HECS, HECS-related loans and so forth. I refer him to a study conducted in 1990 by Messrs Robertson, Sloan and Bardsley entitled, The impact of the higher education contribution scheme (HECS), which was conducted by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, published by the AGPS. This 1990 study found as follows:
