DEBATE.TITLE: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS BILL 1992SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the Service and Execution of Process Bill and the Service and Execution of Process (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. The service and execution of process is a fundamental part of our judicial system. The founding fathers of Federation recognised that State borders should not be barriers to justice. Therefore, the Commonwealth, pursuant to section 51 (xxiv) of the Constitution, has the power to make laws with respect to the service and execution of process. The obvious necessity for such laws in a federation of States of independent legal nature ensured that this was one of the first subjects of legislation after Federation in 1901.

PARA.TAB: As a result of changes in Australian society in the past 90 years, particularly in terms of advances in transport and communications technology, it has long been apparent that the 1901 Act has become outdated in many ways. It is 10 years this month since the Acting Attorney-General at the time, my friend the Hon. N.A. Brown QC, referred the operation of the Service and Execution of Process Act to the Law Reform Commission for examination.

The Commission reported in 1987, recommending the drafting of a new Act to include changes in the procedures for interstate service and execution process within the scope of the Act and in the procedures for the interstate enforcement of judgments. It was also recommended that the scope of the Act be broadened to enable interstate service and execution of the process of investigative and adjudicative tribunals. This latter change was implemented last year in the Service and Execution of Process Amendment Bill 1991, the passage of which was supported by the coalition.

Now, some five years after the Law Reform Commission's report, the Bills before us largely implement the report's recommendations. Their purpose is to repeal the existing service and execution of process arrangements in the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 and to institute a new scheme.

The Service and Execution of Process (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 provides for the repeal of the 1901 Act and also for the continued application of some sections of that Act. The Service and Execution of Process Bill 1992 is the more substantial of the two Bills. It replaces the 1901 Act as the principal piece of legislation dealing with the interstate service of legal process and the enforcement of court judgments and tribunal orders outside the State or Territory in which they are known. It sets out new procedures relating to interstate service of processing civil and criminal proceedings; interstate service of subpoenas; interstate service of process of tribunals; interstate execution of warrants; and enforcement of fines imposed by courts of summary jurisdiction. It has been a long, tiring process. It was 10 years since the matter was referred to the Law Reform Commission and five years since we have got to this stage. Perhaps we are all a little tired of it.

Clause 9 of the Bill sets out the procedures for service of a document on a company. The provisions are the same as those in section 220 of the corporations law. Clause 11 of the Bill deals with proof of service. It specifies the matters that have to be proved in order to prove service of a document, although any of the requirements may be dispensed with if the court or tribunal is satisfied that service was effected.

Clause 15 sets out the rules for service of initiating process in respect of civil proceedings, and clause 24 sets out the rules for criminal proceedings. Initiating process issued in one State may be served in another State. Service on an individual is to be effected in the same way as service of such process in the place of issue.

Combining with existing cross-vesting legislation, the provisions will enable cases to be determined in the most convenient venue. A person served with initiating process may apply to the court of issue for an order staying the proceedings. The court may grant such an order if it is satisfied that a court of another State is the appropriate court. Further provisions relate to the service of subpoenas, both generally and those addressed to people in prison.

Part 4 of the Bill deals with service of process of tribunals. Division 4 of part 4, which relates to service of subpoenas in the performance of investigative functions, replicates the effect of the 1991 amendments to the Service and Execution of Process Act.

The rules relating to initiating process and service of subpoenas are similar to those which will apply in respect of courts. A subpoena issued by a tribunal may only be served interstate with leave of the court of the State of issue. `Court' is defined to include a magistrate or judge who is a member of the tribunal which issued the subpoena.

The coalition raised the question in relation to the 1991 amendments to the service and execution of process legislation, whether the Commonwealth has the power to legislate with respect to the service and execution of process of State tribunals. I understand that the Government has received advice from the Solicitor-General that these amendments are within constitutional power.

Clauses 81 to 90 of the Bill provide for the execution of warrants. A person who is named on a warrant may be apprehended in another State and must then be brought before a magistrate as soon as practicable. Unless the warrant is invalid, the magistrate must either remand the person on bail to appear in the place in which the warrant was issued, or order that they be taken in custody to that place.

Further provisions of the Bill relate to suppression orders. Under the present Act a magistrate does not have the power to make a suppression order. Under the new provisions a magistrate conducting a proceeding under clause 83 with respect to a person apprehended and brought before them under a warrant will have the power to order that a part of the proceeding or review held in public, or a finding publicly made, not be published or broadcast. For this provision to apply, the magistrate must be satisfied that publication or broadcast would give rise to a substantial risk of prejudice to the fair trial of a person; of death, injury or property loss to a witness; of prejudice to law enforcement or national security; of identification of the victim of a sexual offence; or of identification of a child in proceedings concerning his or her welfare; or where the child is the victim or the alleged offender.

Pursuant to clause 97 a suppression order remains in force until revoked. It is arguable that this provision is not within the Commonwealth's power to make laws with respect to the service and execution of process, and is therefore not constitutional. This is because it purports to extend suppression orders beyond the service of process or extradition of a person into and beyond the conduct of the proceedings themselves.

Apart from the two points of constitutional argument that I have just mentioned, as I indicated at the outset, the coalition is supporting the passage of these Bills. We believe them to be a sensible, and indeed overdue, updating of the Commonwealth procedures for the service and execution of process.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are speaking this evening on the Service and Execution of Process Bill 1992 and the Service and Execution of Process (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992, which were introduced into the Senate on 10 September 1992. The purpose of the service and execution of process Bills is to replace the Service and Execution of Process Act 1901 as the principal piece of legislation dealing with the interstate service of legal process and the enforcement of court orders outside the State or Territory in which they are made.

PARA.TAB: As pointed out by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in his second reading speech, the Service and Execution of Process Act is an important piece of legislation, as it was the eleventh enactment of this Federal Parliament way back in 1901. It shows the importance to which interstate service and execution of process should attach. The Australian Democrats are very mindful of this fact tonight.

As one of the original enactments of this Parliament, it was a matter of course that in 1982 the Attorney-General gave the Australian Law Reform Commission a reference which required it to inquire into and report on the adequacy of the law relating to the service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the States and Territories. The reference followed representations by the Attorneys-General of a number of States concerning certain deficiencies in the original Act, including the lack of provision in the original Act for the service and execution of process and decisions of State and Territory tribunals which are not courts but exercise adjudicative functions similar to them and the difficulties in the interstate service of information for minor criminal offences which do not require the attendance of the defendant.

The Australian Law Reform Commission's report was tabled in Parliament in December 1987 and, due to numerous delays and minor technical problems, we finally have the Bill before us tonight. This Bill, by and large, adopts the major recommendations made by the Australian Law Reform Commission. Those recommendations include: first, the abolition of the rules requiring a connection between the cause of action and the State or Territory in which the proceedings are commenced; secondly, that the initiating process generally be served personally, but in the case of corporations it be possible to do so by electronic means, and in all cases facsimile copies of process be sufficient; thirdly, that service of subpoena be ineffective unless enough money is given or tendered to the person served to meet his or her expenses of complying with the subpoena; fourthly, if a challenge is made to a plaintiff's choice of venue, the court is to consider which is the most appropriate venue, having regard to certain matters, including the location of the parties, their likely witnesses and the subject matter of the proceedings; fifthly, provision for the interstate service of subpoenas and execution of warrants of State or Territory investigative tribunals; sixthly, the defences or objections to enforcement of a court order be litigated only in the State or Territory in which the order was given; and seventhly, that facsimile copies of process be allowed for the purpose of extradition proceedings.

I interpolate here that the use of facsimile copies becomes highly relevant with respect to the amendment that the Democrats will be wanting to move at the committee stage. The Australian Democrats welcome this modernised Bill, which contains some very useful initiatives to adequately meet the needs of the law as it relates to service and execution throughout the Commonwealth of the civil and criminal process and the judgments of the courts of the State and Territories.

There is, however, one clause in this Bill which the Australian Democrats are concerned about. Clause 83(5), which is contained in part 5, division 1 of the Bill, deals with the procedure after apprehension of a person who has a warrant issued for his or her arrest. Clause 83(5) has the practical effect that, for whatever reason, if the warrant for the apprehension of a person is not produced at the initial appearance before a magistrate, a person may be remanded on bail or in custody for up to five days in order to allow the arresting officers time to produce the warrant. That, of course, is the reason that I drew particular attention to the use of facsimile copies and the electronic transmission of warrants.

My colleague Senator Spindler alluded to this very point when, just over a year ago, this issue was debated in relation to an amendment to the Service and Execution of Process Bill 1991. The amendment at that time, which was moved by the Government and supported by the Opposition, was to remand a person on bail or in custody for up to seven days. As pointed out by Senator Spindler at that time, it was ludicrous for a person, through no fault of his or her own, to be kept in custody for up to seven days—and this is in an age when fax machines, which are specifically alluded to in this legislation, and other means of communication have been updated and are generally available to the community.

Senator Spindler further argued that it was somewhat extraordinary that we should regard what is essentially a very important civil liberties issue in this way. At that time the Australian Democrats moved an amendment to reduce the seven day period to four days. This amendment was unfortunately not supported by either the Government or the Opposition.

Since this amendment was moved by the Australian Democrats, I understand that the Attorney-General's Department saw some force in Senator Spindler's arguments and has since acted upon them by reducing the time limit to five days in the Bill. However the Australian Democrats still do not find this five-day period an acceptable balance between on the one hand protecting civil liberties and on the other hand assisting the authorities in their pursuit to apprehend suspect criminals. The Australian Democrats will therefore be moving an amendment for a four-day period, which mirrors the amendment moved by Senator Spindler last year. Apart from this amendment, the Australian Democrats welcome this new legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I rise to thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for indicating their support for the Service and Execution of Process Bill, which is now before the chamber. Honourable senators are aware that this Bill is important insofar as it recognises yet again what this chamber has been called upon to recognise increasingly over the last several years—that Australia is one nation and that the old jurisdictional boundaries between the States and the Territories should not be regarded as so sacrosanct that they might impede or, in this case, frustrate the way in which the legal system, particularly the criminal justice system, needs to operate. Quite clearly, those who allegedly breach our criminal laws do not have regard for State boundaries as providing any particular impediment to their activity. The idea that they might gain some advantage by seeking sanctuary in another State will be combated by the sort of legislation that we have before us.

PARA.TAB: As has been noted by Senator Hill, this Bill draws very largely on the Australian Law Reform Commission's report of some years ago. It has taken some time to bring this legislation to the Parliament. It is so important that we aid the effective operation of the courts, the police and the correctional authorities of the various States and Territories that I think the time taken to produce the legislation has been worth while. I think the unanimous support that this chamber will give to the legislation is a recognition of the excellent work that has been done by the Attorney-General's Department, in consultation with the States and the Territories. In some instances, some heed has been paid to the comments that have been made even by the Democrats in the formulation of the finer points of this legislation.

The Bill sets out an exclusive method for interstate service of process. It provides many safeguards. But also, as I say, it makes the system of serving documents very much more efficient. For example, solicitors will be able to use the one document for service anywhere in Australia, supplemented by an information notice as prescribed when service is interstate. There are also rules which will enable cases to be determined in the most convenient forum, rather than having to find some particular connection between the cause of action and the State in which proceedings are commenced.
I could go through a whole list of matters—

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech dealt with it pretty well.

—I thank the honourable senator for that. I was not aware that all senators had read it. But if senators like Senator Reid have read the second reading speech with due diligence, perhaps I need not comment any further. Senator Reid might like to comment on this possibility: I read that the judgment will be registered on lodgment of a sealed copy of the judgment or of a fax of a sealed copy.
—That is the modern world, Senator.
—That is the modern world—it is extraordinary, is it not? I do not entirely understand that, but there we are. I must also mention, though, that we have decided to move some amendments which—
—Why couldn't you have got it right after 10 years?

—Well, it really came to a drafting matter. The amendments that I will put forward to this Senate at the committee stage seek to amend clause 114(1) of the Bill. They propose the insertion of new clause 114(1)(a) to better provide for the application of State bail laws to a person apprehended under an interstate warrant or apprehension for the non-payment of a fine.
—You would think that after five years of drafting you would have got it right.

—One would think so, Senator, but it did not occur in this case and it is just as well that we have picked it up. We are now going to provide for the application of the bail laws of the State of apprehension to the granting of bail by either a court of summary jurisdiction or a supreme court on review under clause 116. The State bail laws apply to the apprehended person as if he or she had been apprehended for a summary offence against the laws of that State. I think this clarification is very necessary. I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill. I commend the Bills to the Senate and I will comment on the committee stage amendment to be moved by the Democrats at the appropriate time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: SERVICE AND EXECUTION OF PROCESS BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 83, page 44, subclause (5), omit "5 days", substitute "4 days".

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the Committee to this particular clause because it deals with the procedure after apprehension. It states:

PARA.TAB: As soon as practicable after being apprehended, the person is to be taken before a magistrate of the State in which the person was apprehended.
The warrant or a copy of the warrant must be produced to the magistrate if it is available.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that, as I indicated at the second reading stage, we now have these facsimile machines—a fact to which attention has also been drawn by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate)—it should be possible to produce the warrant or a copy of that warrant very quickly, essentially anywhere in Australia, certainly anywhere a person would be in custody. The section goes on:

PARA.TAB: If the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced, the magistrate may:
(a) order that the person be released; or
(b) adjourn the proceeding for such reasonable time as the magistrate specifies and remand the person on bail or in such custody as the magistrate specifies.

SPEECH.PARA: So we now have a situation in which a person has been apprehended, taken into custody, the warrant has not been produced and the magistrate can now remand that person in custody. The section then goes on to say that if the warrant or a copy of the warrant is not produced when the proceeding resumes, the magistrate may order that the person be released or may further keep that person in custody. The relevant section, of course, is subclause (5) which states:

PARA.TAB: The total time of the adjournments referred to in paragraphs (3)(b) and (4)(b) must not exceed 5 days.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, in this time in which we have these facsimile machines and all these whiz-bang devices to get these documents around the country in very short order, in a matter of milliseconds, we are finding that a person who may indeed eventually prove to be quite innocent can be apprehended, taken into custody and kept in custody for a period of five days and then, presumably, if the warrant is not produced, can be released.

PARA.TAB: We find that, in this day and age, quite unacceptable. It is for that reason that we suggest a lesser period of four days, as I indicated earlier and as Senator Spindler indicated in a debate nearly a year ago. Even that, one could argue, is an excessive time to keep in custody a person who may yet prove to be innocent.

Also, surely this type of thing could encourage those who are involved in the process of apprehension and holding people to be simply sloppy and lazy in acquiring the relevant warrant. Simply knowing that the person can be kept in custody for that period of five days, they could say, `It doesn't matter. We'll just keep the person in custody for another day or so'.

Again, for that reason, it seems to encourage a certain sloppiness on the part of the authorities, which really is not warranted in this day and age when we have these facsimile devices. So I would urge the Committee to accept the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats to substitute a period of `5 days' for `4 days'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering clause 83 which, as Senator Coulter said and as the Committee of the Whole is well aware, deals with that very important matter of the apprehension of a person. It requires, of course, that a person be brought, as soon as practicable after the apprehension, before a magistrate in the State where the person is apprehended. Making a magistrate aware of the apprehension is just a first stage, and a most important one for the liberties of the subject.

PARA.TAB: In the normal course, the warrant—or a copy of it—must be produced to the magistrate, and that would occur in most cases. The clause provides that if the warrant is not produced, the magistrate must either order that the person be released—so the magistrate always has that possibility—or adjourn the proceeding for a reasonable time and remand the person on bail or in custody.

This particular clause provides that that total time of that adjournment awaiting the production of the warrant, or a copy of it, must not exceed five days. Indeed, if at the end of that period the warrant is not produced, then the person must be released. So it is in the context of trying to deal with the very real possibility that Senator Coulter adverts to—that a person could, by sloppiness, as he put it, negligence or even some sort of malice, be kept in detention whilst this warrant was looked for for production before the magistrate.

Originally, a seven-day upper limit was put in this particular provision. As Senator Coulter may know, that went before the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which had expressed concern about it in relation to a previous incarnation of that particular provision. As recently as 16 September, the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills reported that it had received a response from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) in relation to this matter. In that response, it says the Attorney-General agreed to consult with the States and Territories to see whether a shorter period—that is, seven days—might be practicable.

That particular consultation did take place. I think that was because of an undertaking that I had given that that consultation should take place when the Senate was discussing a similar clause some time ago. On being consulted, I am informed that, of those States that responded, New South Wales favoured three to four days—three days being more than ample in the majority of cases—the Northern Territory spoke of difficulties if it was less than seven days; South Australia said that seven days was appropriate; and Queensland favoured five working days. In general, we thought that five days was a reasonable position.

As I am advised, the problem is not so much with getting a copy of the warrant. I must admit that I thought that that was the problem—in which case the facsimiles and the electronic transmissions should be able to deal with the matter in milliseconds. I am advised that the problem is not so much getting a copy of the warrant to the court in remote areas, but getting the arrested person to a magistrate in remote areas where there has been an adjournment and the magistrate has moved on, which is an interesting further point which I had not considered in relation to outback and remoter areas of Australia.

So the period of five days seems to be an upper limit, which I believe is a good protection for the apprehended person and for the administration of justice. It is also interesting that the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, on which I believe Senator Coulter's distinguished colleague Senator Bell may sit, in reporting to the Senate on this particular Bill stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is therefore pleased to note that in the Bill now before the Parliament a limit of 5 days is prescribed.

It seems that the Committee was satisfied enough with the five days. I agree that, if four or six days were chosen, perhaps it could be argued either way. But a limit of five days seems to be what came out as a reasonable result or conclusion from the consultations which were undertaken with the States and Territories. I believe the Committee of the whole should accept the results of that consultation. It appears to have been accepted by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee as a reasonable result. Therefore, the Government is looking for the support of the Committee of the Whole for the clause in the Bill and a rejection of the Democrats' proposal for a reduction to four days.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the explanation of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) somewhat unconvincing. It seems as though the Government has been prepared to settle for an arithmetic mean of the figures between the various States but, on his own admission a moment ago, Senator Tate said that New South Wales had indicated a period of three to four days. Surely, if New South Wales indicated that three to four days were an acceptable period, it says something about either the adequacy of the availability of the faxed warrants or, as the Minister has indicated, the inadequacy of the provision of magistrates who are on circuit to actually pick up this matter. Are we to assume that the magisterial system in New South Wales is so much better than it is in the Northern Territory that the Northern Territory is opting for a much longer period?

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that, under these circumstances, if one State can meet a shorter period, we should be arguing strongly that the other States should come into line. It is not just a matter of convenience here; it is a matter of civil liberties. People are being held in custody, without a warrant being produced, for a long period—for a day longer than necessary. I remain unconvinced by the use of an arithmetic mean rather than the more desirable acceptance of what clearly can be achieved in one State—the minimum period—as a period which should be therefore imposed on the other States so they pull their house into order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think much more can be added to the argument. This is going to be as rare as hen's teeth. As Senator Coulter says, the fax will get the copy of the warrant to the magistrate on the day 99 times out of 100. Whilst New South Wales was, in the consultation, prepared to go for three or four days, it is interesting that it was the States with much larger outback, remote and rural areas which are served by magistrates on a less regular basis—this particular proposal led the Northern Territory to say that there were difficulties with less than seven days; South Australia seven days; and Queensland five working days—that went for an upper limit. We were not exactly looking for an arithmetic mean; we were trying to deal with what we were told were difficulties in States of that type with huge outback areas.

PARA.TAB: I had not particularly given weight to that in the earlier discussion that we had about a year ago on these matters, but it does appear to be a concern. Nevertheless, we have to try to protect the civil liberties of the person who has been apprehended; that is why Government has reduced its original proposal of seven days to five days. As I say, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee seemed to find that that was a reasonable course of action, following from the consultations, so I still commend it to the Senate as a reasonable provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the argument. It is marginal between four and five days; the five days was reduced from the earlier suggested seven days. I hope that it would only be in exceptional circumstance that it would be necessary, but it is a safeguard to provide that element of security in exceptional circumstances. I do not think the five days is unreasonable. On this occasion, we therefore have not been persuaded by the Democrats' argument.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Button:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 removes the uncertainties about the enforcement of laws concerning the labelling of wine. In 1989, legislation to implement a wine labelling integrity program was carried with coalition support. The program was developed at industry request and required manufacturers to keep records to support labelling claims on the vintage, variety and region of origin of the wine. The records must be made available for audit upon request of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation. The first inspections were in the Clare Valley of South Australia in 1990 and no breaches were detected.

PARA.TAB: However, 200 audits have shown the following technical deficiencies which make enforcement of the legislation difficult. Firstly, while the Act requires that records be kept, there is no requirement that these records be accurate and complete. Secondly, the manufacturer must provide the records even if they are self-incriminating, but the manufacturer is then protected from prosecution should the records disclose false labelling. There is therefore doubt whether a successful prosecution concerning false labelling could be launched under the present Act.

This Bill does four things. First, it makes it an offence to knowingly or recklessly fail to make and keep such records or make and keep false, misleading or incomplete records. Secondly, it amends the clause which requires a person to provide information to the Corporation on request, but indemnifies that person from prosecution where such information is furnished. The amendment removes the labelling integrity program provisions from section 42, but otherwise leaves the section unchanged.

Thirdly, it allows a person with reasonable excuse to refuse a request for the Corporation to provide their records. It would be a reasonable excuse if the records are self-incriminating. Where a person chooses with reasonable excuse not to provide the records, the Corporation must obtain a warrant to obtain the records. This will allow those records to be used to initiate the prosecution, thus achieving the original intention of the legislation. The Bill enables the Corporation to retain records for 60 days or, if a prosecution for a label offence is initiated within 60 days, until proceedings and appeals are ended. A person will be able to inspect or copy the records given to the Corporation.

Fourthly, the Bill honours a commitment the Government made to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to enable a person to copy evidence seized by an inspector, and reduce the period of validity of an offence warrant from one month to a maximum of seven days.

The Australian wine industry is one of the great success stories of Australian industry at present. It does not matter whether one sees it as a primary industry, a manufacturing industry or one marketing a product. On behalf of the coalition parties in the other chamber, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Bruce Lloyd, has already congratulated everyone associated with this very great industry in this country because it epitomises growth and geographic and varietal diversity. I am pleased to be associated with this industry, as is my colleague the honourable member for Riverina, Mr Noel Hicks, whose electorate encompasses a large proportion of Australia's wine growing regions.

Not only is production increasing, but also because of where it is located in many different areas of Australia it is providing some interesting developments and differences in variety and type of wine produced. The wine industry obviously has quality control as a high priority: hence this legislation. It is one of our best examples of value adding of a product. It is also one of the best examples of a growth industry for exports.

There is a lesson for some other industries in relation to the organisation of the industry. In 1990, the Winemakers Federation of Australia came into being to bring together three different industry organisations. They now cover 95 per cent of production. As a result, the industry is now able to speak out on different issues of concern. The 1990-91 report of the Winemakers Federation of Australia, which highlights the damage being done to the industry by invisible taxes, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Taxation on domestic production bleeds into export costs as input items are inflated through a whole range of invisible taxes.
The impact of these invisible taxes should not be underestimated and have been estimated as high as 30 per cent of all taxes.

In that report, the industry made the point that one of its major challenges for the future and its ability to grow and prosper is to tackle issues such as taxation that will affect our capacity to remain internationally competitive.

PARA.TAB: This is where the coalition's Fightback policy comes in. In a number of discussions with the industry, it has been very positive in relation to the impact of Fightback. Input taxes are removed under Fightback. As the industry indicated, there are many taxes that are more or less hidden at present but they are there nevertheless. These taxes are removed under Fightback, which means that the industry can be more internationally competitive.

As production increases and the percentage of exports increases, that international competition requirement increases also, particularly where the Australian industry is competing against other countries which already have similar tax incentives. I think of New Zealand and France as two examples where, by having a GST or VAT system, those import taxes are removed. Of course, for exports, the GST or VAT is fully rebated and that is a very significant factor when one looks at the competitive situation of different countries and export markets.

At present there are hidden export taxes on our wine, as there are on every other export from Australia. That has been calculated as equivalent to a 5 per cent export tax. Senator Button has been quoted where he has acknowledged that there is this export tax which has been calculated by Treasury at $1.8 billion per year. The French, the New Zealanders and others have this system, and where those inputs are rebated at the point of export have a considerable advantage over our wine exporters. That is one of the reasons why the industry is enthusiastic about Fightback!—as, of course, are so many other individuals and industries throughout Australia.

Last year the industry exported $234m worth of wine, which is a 10-fold increase in six years. After something of a false start a few years ago, this export growth is very soundly based. It is anticipated that by the year 2000 the industry could be one of our major export earners, with $1 billion a year in export income for Australia.

One of the other important features of the industry is that it is value adding to an excellent degree and in a logical and natural way. In a recent article by Andrew Clark in the Australian Financial Review, referring to developments in the industry in Europe, he made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian wine export story is a successful grafting of old-fashioned business values with hi-tech.

He also said that Australian wine is achieving a real premium on the British market because while it has only 2.7 per cent in volume in that market, it has 12 per cent of wine costing more than $12.50 per bottle. The industry has a far better percentage in relation to the quality section of the market than the volume section, and that is what value adding is about. One can look at other markets where the Australian wine industry is increasing not only its volume of exports but also the value of those exports to an even greater degree. This comes back to the importance of quality control with value adding, brand marketing and responsibility for individual labels. That is why this legislation is being supported.

PARA.TAB: The coalition parties support the legislation and wish the wine industry a very successful and expanding future, not just in Australia but as one of the major export industries for this country in the coming years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill 1992 and say a few words about the very good news that wine exports are for this country. It is also important that something like 60 per cent of Australia's wine is produced in my State of South Australia and, I say shamelessly, that is where the best wine comes from.
—The Hunter Valley has some beautiful wines.
—Yes, it has excellent wines, but most of the best comes from my State.

PARA.TAB: In my own State of South Australia we are blessed with a newspaper called the Advertiser, which seems to be devoted to finding bad news stories and fails to report any good news stories. Today there is a report in the Advertiser which would probably make most South Australians fall over. It is a good news story about Wolf Blass reporting that wine sales will soar. I am delighted that at last the huge increase in exports of Australian wine to overseas markets has been acknowledged by the Advertiser, but it ought be acknowledged by all Australians. The points that Senator Tambling has made, excluding his comments about the GST, which I will come to in a minute, need to be endorsed.

Because of the time constraints confronting us and the attempt to pass this Bill tonight, I will not toil over all of those figures again. The growth of exports of Australian wine is quite remarkable. It is a fantastic turnaround from a few years ago when we were actually digging out vines. At present winemakers are concerned as to whether they will be able to meet the demands that they anticipate in the next few years.

What is most important, and why it is so opportune to speak under this legislation, is that Australia is marketing its wine as quality product. Even the bulk wines or the cask wines that Australia sells overseas leave most of the bulk competition for dead. So we are able to hold our heads high, whether we are talking about the cask wines or the particularly splendid labelled wines that leave our shores. We now have markets established in the United Kingdom, Sweden, the United States, New Zealand, Canada and Japan, and all of those set to grow. People cannot get enough of Australian wine. It is quite clear that there is a tremendous opportunity for increasing this market and even perhaps achieving the goal of $1 billion from exports of Australian wine by the year 2000.

A few years ago, too, the then editor of the Adelaide Advertiser, Piers Ackerman, was running a campaign in that paper to remove the stock valuation tax from wine which was particularly, he argued, offensive for the small boutique wineries. I suppose I got held personally responsible by Piers Ackerman for killing that campaign. I asked a question about it of Senator Peter Walsh, then a Minister in this place, and, as only he can, he gave a splendid and devastating answer. The money that would have been recouped was about $16m, a very small amount. I have had absolutely no request made to my office from the wine and brandy growers or producers in South Australia. When I rang them to ask whether I was right I was told, `You are, Senator. We are not concerned about the removal of the stock valuation tax; we are concerned about assistance for export marketing'. That is exactly what the Government has given them.

What we have seen here with this growth in exports is the best example of assistance by government to an industry that has its own quality product—an industry which has got out there, sought those markets and won them. As Wolf Blass says, the challenge now is to keep the supplies coming, to keep the quality and to maintain and service those markets. But the industry said to me then, and it still does, that what it wants is further assistance of the sort that goes with export market development grants and the benefits that Austrade has been able to provide. I think those are very important. Indeed, what we have here is, as Senator Tambling says, the industry value adding, producing a splendid quality product that is being very much sought after overseas, and that being done with the assistance of government. That is the very best kind of combination.

In the one minute left to me, I want to take issue with Senator Tambling on the benefits of the GST to this industry. I understand Senator Tambling to be saying that under the GST all hidden taxes, as he calls them—they are not too hidden, really—will be removed and there will be a reduction in the costs for wine that is to be exported from Australia. But I would ask Senator Tambling: at what price? The price is a 15 per cent GST on all the wine that is drunk in Australia by Australians. If Senator Tambling calls that fair, I think that is a very exciting argument to put. We also know that one of the industries that will be enormously hurt by that will be the tourist industry—yet another way in which this invidious, all-embracing, all-encompassing GST will not be of benefit to Australians at all.

Senator Tambling's campaign on all the difficulties confronting this industry with the current taxes is hardly borne out by the figures. Under the present regime this industry, as he says, has gone from about 11 million litres or thereabouts in 1985-86 to 77.6 million litres worth $234m in 1991-92; they are the exports only. If we just consider that growth in exports under the current tax regime and if we see the enormous increase in the production of wine in this country and in its sales—although there was a slight dip in the domestic purchasing, domestic sales have now gone up again—it is hardly a good case to say that this industry is burdened by tax.

This industry is a glowing industry. It is an acknowledgment of the very best that Australia can do. It is not a sob story that we have here; it is a success story. If the current tax regime is so crippling, I think we would find a different story to tell in terms of production and sales. I just remind people of the benefits of this legislation because, as Senator Tambling has said, it will ensure the quality of Australian wine is maintained, and the truth in labelling will make that quality known. It is a story of success, a story to celebrate and not one to threaten with a GST.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been told by Senator Tambling in full flight what the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Amendment Bill actually does, and I will not take the Senate's time to remind my colleagues of that detail. However, it is worth while to be reminded that this legislation corrects existing legislation which required manufacturers to keep label integrity program records but did not require that those records be accurate and complete. In that way this is very much amending legislation. The Democrats, of course, will be supporting this legislation and joining in the congratulations which have been issued towards the wine industry by previous speakers.

PARA.TAB: Here we have an Act of parliament which belongs to this particular industry. This industry has its own Act of parliament. It has inspections to ensure that that Act of parliament is followed; a bureaucracy to enforce those inspections, to keep records and keep

SPEECH.PARA: track of it and those records; and now we have amendments to make sure that that all fits together well. That is all very wonderful. But why is it that it is only the wine industry which is given this sort of attention? Why is it that we stop with the wine industry? Why is it that we do not recognise the immense value to Australian producers there would be in having this sort of attitude apply across a number of Australian horticultural industries?

PARA.TAB: At the moment we do not know what percentage of Australian peanuts there is in peanut butter, for heaven's sake. We do not know with any degree of accuracy what percentage of Australian tomatoes are present in tomato sauce which can be labelled `Product of Australia'. We have been given the famous example of the tracksuit that is made in Hong Kong, essentially, and comes to Australia with 2 centimetres of seams yet to be sewn up and a label put in, `Product of Australia'. These sorts of examples have abounded through Australia in the last few months with the great flurry and fervour to buy Australian. But here we have the perfect example, a model of the sort of legislation which should be enacted across Australian industries.

Australians are eager to buy genuine products of Australia. But we are not doing enough in this place to encourage Australians to do so. We do not make that purchasing action easy. There are many Australians who are still misled by the labels on the products that they buy in the supermarkets—people who think they are buying Australian to assist our economy and to contribute to the welfare of this country but who are being deceived by the label and its inadequacies. I am pleased to note that our Australian Customs Service is doing something about that; it is taking a much more active and effective role in protecting Australian consumers from these deceptive labels. But we need more.

I am pleased also that Senator Meg Lees, a Democrat senator for South Australia, has taken an initiative in bringing forward her own labelling scheme, to operate in some Foodland Supermarkets in South Australia, which assists consumers to make the decision to buy Australian. The success of Senator Lees's program easily demonstrates that if only we had the same sort of attitude towards other horticultural and food producing industries that we have towards the wine industry, if only we could replicate the sort of attitude that we have demonstrated here for the wine industry—and it is a good attitude, one that is demanded by Australian consumers—we might find that we would not be importing food products costing $2 billion into Australia each year—food products which, of course, can be produced in Australia and can produce jobs in Australia, and food products which, of course, Australians actually want. That has been demonstrated in those Foodland Supermarkets by Senator Meg Lees's program.

If that sounds like an excuse to bring into this argument something which is not strictly relevant, I submit it is most relevant. I submit that, as Senator Crowley has said, the wine industry has done well from Australians being proud of their product, from Australians recognising that this is a value adding industry which is useful to the country, and from Australians therefore buying that product and being proud enough to encourage people overseas to buy their product.

This very day the Tasmanian Development Authority proudly demonstrated this to the people across Bass Strait from Tasmania—and I understand Senator Harradine supported this move by attending—by putting on an exhibition of fine Tasmanian produce in this very city. That produce speaks for itself in its quality. When people buy it, they know that they are buying fine produce.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN WINE AND BRANDY CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the question was put, I was speaking about the fine produce from Tasmania, produce which is easily identifiable in its origins and produce which, like the Australian wine product which is well labelled, is supported very strongly by the consumers who wish to discriminate in favour of fine produce. Therefore, legislation such as that now before the Senate should be supported. That is what we are going to do, and there should be more of it.

—This debate has had everything. We had a cheerio from Senator Tambling to his colleague the member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks). We had a cheerio from Senator Bell to everybody in Tasmania. It is good that we are finishing in such good humour this week. I thank senators for supporting the Bill.

PARA.TAB: It is a small, but important enhancement of a growing and important industry. Senators have spoken about it accurately in terms of the industry's success, its export success and its potential. I would be delighted at some other stage to have a lengthy debate about GST and the wine industry. Senator Crowley said most of the things I wished to say and, given that we have negated the adjournment, I will not start it all again.

I am concerned that we should not overlook the evidence—the not surprising evidence—that beverage consumption such as wine is very price sensitive in the domestic market. There would be some reasonable concern for apprehension in the wine industry about the demand impact of the domestic price effect of the GST on wine consumption in Australia. We all share the hope that, irrespective of extraneous issues such as tax, the wine industry will continues to grow and to succeed as it has. I am sure many of us will pledge ourselves to do our bit to assist it.

Also everybody has indicated quite accurately the merit and success of the label integrity program. I am advised that our wine label integrity program legislation has drawn praise at home and abroad for underpinning the integrity of our wines and for providing the platform for fair trading in wine. The label integrity program is seen as a tough and effective deterrent to fraud.

The amendments proposed in this Bill will ensure that the legislation can be enforced in the courts and will safeguard our hard-won international reputation for high quality, value for money, true-to-label wines. It is not surprising on that basis that the Bill has the unanimous support of the Senate, but nevertheless I thank senators for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take this opportunity to express concerns about ongoing human rights abuses in Vietnam and to express the wish that the Australian Government would make more effort to apply pressure with like nations upon the Government of Vietnam to improve its human rights performance.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to incorporate a list of 275 political prisoners in Vietnam. This list was released by the National United Front for the Liberation of Vietnam, Directorate of Overseas Affairs, on 1 July 1992. This list provides the names or identification of prisoners, their prison location and the penalty under which they are serving.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: [THE DOCUMENT IS OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGES 2442-45]

TALK.START.PARA: —Vietnam is economically liberalising and has been in that process since 1986. That is something that we applaud. At present Australia's trade with Vietnam might still be reasonably modest, but it is an increasing trade and there are increasing investment opportunities for Australia in Vietnam. It is a relationship that has the potential to grow and broaden in the years ahead.

PARA.TAB: It does seem to senators on this side of the chamber that the development of that relationship will be retarded by Vietnam's human rights performance. We would like to think that other nations that similarly abhor human rights abuses and comply with the international covenants to protect human rights would also be of the view that their future relations with Vietnam will suffer as a result of the current practices. We would hope that with concerted action the international community might be able to encourage improvement in that performance by Vietnam.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that earlier this year Australia became the first nation to reinstate a bilateral aid program with Vietnam. We were concerned that that seemed to have been done without any real effort—again with like-minded nations—to use the leverage to seek an improvement in the behaviour of Vietnam in relation to its own citizens. We have also been somewhat concerned that much of that program, as we understand it, will not benefit the poorest of Vietnam's people.

It did seem to us to be an opportunity lost. Against the background of Australia now providing Vietnam with foreign aid and of an expanding trade relationship, unfortunately the position of that country on human rights does not seem to have significantly improved at all. For example, I refer to the Amnesty International reports of 1991 and the annual report of 1992. They bring to our attention the fact that there are still hundreds of political prisoners and prisoners of conscience imprisoned in Vietnam, and that long term political prisoners—that is, over five years—include writers, poets, journalists, Roman Catholic priests, Buddhist monks, professionals, business people, civil servants, politicians and former military personnel who are still detained in so-called re-education camps. It reminds us that there are tribal peoples of Vietnam who are still imprisoned. These reports also bring to us information on an increasing crackdown on intellectuals and also on critics of the Government.

Amnesty's concerns, which seem to be largely supported by other organisations such as Asia Watch, are principally: the continuing detention without charge or trial of opponents or critics of the Government, including those detained for the peaceful expression of their political, religious and other beliefs; and also that political trials continue with restricted rights to defence, restrictions on the media, reports of torture and ill treatment, and death sentences.

I said that this information is supported by the recent reports I have read of Asia Watch which dealt with dissent and repression among human rights activists, writers and artists in Vietnam. Asia Watch has also raised the issue of continuing detention in re-education camps, where those detained perform hard labour under conditions of malnutrition, abuse and lack of medical care; the fact that these periods of detention are indefinitely renewable; and also the fact that these prisoners are deprived of basic documentation essential for the conduct of everyday life. Vietnamese people generally are subjected to police surveillance and restricted movement in some cases—in other words, the denial of normal civil rights and entitlements.

What I ask the Australian Government, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in particular, to do is to examine this list of detainees in Vietnam—so defined as prisoners of conscience—that I have had incorporated in Hansard tonight, and come back to the Senate in the not-too-distant future and inform the Senate as to whether it is of the view that the list is correct. Also, it should inform the Senate of what action the Australian Government will take both on its own account and, as I said, in conjunction with like-minded nations, to apply greater pressure than is currently being applied to Vietnam to improve its performance in this important area.

In summary, we would argue that the Vietnamese Government particularly needs to institute reform by immediate and unconditional release of prisoners of conscience who are currently being detained; the immediate cessation of punishment of critics through detention without trial, and denial of basic civil rights; and the recognition, and protection in the law, of the rights of its citizens to peacefully express their views.

We would argue that that is the very minimum that should be sought of the Vietnamese Government. I hope that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will take this matter seriously, because I get the impression that the Australian Government is turning a blind eye to these abuses. I think it is out of fear that it might in some way prejudice the growing relationship of Vietnam with Australia. If that is so, that is a fundamentally wrong way in which to approach the expanding relationship. Once we demonstrate through our performance that these basic human rights are not of the importance that we tend to say they are, then we will not find that they are respected by places in the world that are seeking international recognition and support, such as Vietnam.

As I say, I hope the Minister will take this request seriously and that when the Parliament returns, if it does return, in February—perhaps even before—he can give the Senate a full report of the Australian Government's assessment of the list that I have had incorporated, and what action the Australian Government has been prepared to undertake and, in fact, has undertaken, to apply greater pressure to Vietnam in this important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September at the Senate Estimates Committee B hearing I asked officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: What is your view about what is likely to happen to the high profile boat people whose applications for refugee status have recently been refused? What is their likely fate when they return to China?
That appears on page 354 of the Estimates Committee Hansard. In response to that, Mr Irvine, a very senior officer in the Department, had this to say:

In the last year or so and more recently, the Chinese Government has made a number of public statements to the effect that, if students who have stayed away in other countries were to return home, they would suffer no legal consequences. We have, in fact, encountered little evidence of an illegal deportee from China, having applied for refugee status in Australia, for example, and having returned to China, being subject to harsh treatment.

Mr Acting Deputy President, my question related in that instance to the high profile boat people. You will recall that concern was being expressed by refugee organisations that certain of these people were going to be deported. In fact, that occurred on 23 October 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Department chartered an RAAF aircraft and deported seven Chinese refugee applicants who had arrived in Australia by boat. On 29 October I issued a press statement in which I said that the Government was naive in accepting Chinese assurances. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government would be proven foolish and gullible if claims that seven Chinese deportees had been jailed on their return were true. . . The Government had naively accepted the assurances of the Chinese Government that the deportees would not be punished as a result of their illegal departure from China. . .

Mr Acting Deputy President, you will recall that the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) had said that the Government was `satisfied with these assurances'. Those seven asylum-seekers, by the way, included a two-year-old child.

PARA.TAB: I have it on very reliable authority that the seven have been imprisoned on their return to China. I am not absolutely certain today, 5 November, as to what is their fate, but I am most concerned about it. There is a growing number of people in Australia who are concerned about the Government accepting the assurances given by the PRC Government, and not monitoring the fate of those refugee applicants who have been forcefully deported.
At that same Estimates Committee hearing I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What about Xing Jian Dong?
As the Senate knows, Xing was a Chinese student, and he also was forcibly deported on 14 August.

PARA.TAB: I have in my hand a published copy of a letter in the handwriting of Xing Jian Dong which shows the reverse, what has happened to him. I knew that on his return he was put in the slammer for nine days. The Department, after my questioning of it, stated that that had occurred. The Department went on to say that he had gone home, and Mr Irvine stated:

SPEECH.PARA: He is at liberty at home, I am advised.
I asked:
At liberty at home. So is he under house arrest?
Mr Irvine said:
I do not believe so, but we will find out.
Estimates Committee B has received a response from the Department. The response was included in documentation tabled by the Chairman of the Committee. That response is as follows:

In discussions with our Consulate-General in Shanghai, Mr Xing said that he had been held at Guangzhou airport for nine days on his return to China while Chinese authorities investigated the circumstances surrounding his deportation. Mr Xing said that he had had no contact with the Public Security Bureau or other authorities since his return to Shanghai and had not been placed under house arrest in Shanghai. Mr Xing further confirmed that neither he nor his wife had suffered persecution or harassment from authorities since his return to Shanghai.

I do not know whether the Consulate-General's office in Shanghai is naive, but I would have thought one would need to be very careful were one a Chinese citizen in Shanghai in talking to persons from foreign governments.

PARA.TAB: The letter that has been sent to friends of Mr Xing in Australia tells a quite different story. I have the letter here and I will read an English translation of that letter. It is addressed to `All Australian Chinese Students Organizations'. He expresses his heartfelt thanks for their efforts on his behalf. He says he mourns deeply for the two students who died in the process of protesting forced deportation.

I remind the chamber that those two students were amongst those who sought to come down from Sydney to protest here about the deportation. Few honourable senators would have known that two of them were killed on the way down in their desperate attempts to make members of parliament aware of the plight of refugee applicants and their frustration and concern about the fate of those who are going to be deported. Mr Xing expressed in the first paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: I mourn deeply for the two students who died in the process of protesting forced deportation. If the dead have some relatives in Shanghai, please give me addresses and I'll pay a visit to show my concern and to comfort them.
I'm writing to you today to inform you of my situation after I returned to China in an effort to get your concern and help.

As for human rights, I was detained illegally for nine days upon my arrival by Guangzhou customs police. (Please forgive me for not providing details here). Then my aging mother and wife arrived in Guangzhou from Shanghai, paid the so-called "boarding fees" and got me released. Before my release, my passport and my flight ticket were confiscated. We went back to Shanghai by train for two days and one night. As a result, we all fell ill. The most important thing is that all my identification papers are gone (attached is my temporary ID, but it is already no longer valid). I really dare not to go to the Shanghai Security Bureau fearing this may cause further trouble. So I stay at home all day, seldom going out.
He then makes a couple of other points. I seek leave to incorporate the English translation of this document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

All Australian Chinese Students Organizations:

I mourn deeply for the two students who died in the process of protesting forced deportation. If the dead have some relatives in Shanghai, please give me addresses and I'll pay a visit to show my concern and to comfort them.
I'm writing to you today to inform you of my situation after I returned to China in an effort to get your concern and help.

As for human rights, I was detained illegally for 9 days upon my arrival by Guangzhou Customs Police. (Please forgive me for not providing details here). Then my ageing mother and my wife arrived in Guangzhou from Shanghai, paid the so-called "boarding fees" and got me released. Before my release, my passport and my flight ticket were confiscated. We went back to Shanghai by train for 2 days and one night. As a result, we all fell ill. The most important thing is that all my identification papers are gone (attached is my temporary ID, but it is already no longer valid). I really dare not to go to the Shanghai Security Bureau fearing this may cause further trouble. So I stay at home all day, seldom going out.

As to my health, as I was brutally beaten by [Australian] Immigration Officials I always feel dizzy, and feel like vomiting all the time. Last week, I went to see a doctor and had a CT scan of my brain, thus costing me quite a lot of money. When the medical report is ready, I'll mail it to you. That'll probably be proof for lawsuits.

I have no idea whether this mail will reach you in Australia or not, therefore I'm writing to you very briefly about me. Detailed information will be provided to you by mail and I hope to get your concern and help.
Best Wishes,
Yours,
Xing Jian Dong (Signature)
Attached: 1. Receipt for "Boarding fees" for 9 days.
2. Certificate by Baiyun Customs (Guangzhou) for confiscation of papers and travelling documents.
