SPEECH.PARA: Translated by Professor Han Shang Xiao NAATI Interpreter and Translator No:19262

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr Acting Deputy President, I remind you of what Mr Xing says:

SPEECH.PARA: The most important thing is that all my identification papers are gone . . .

Everyone knows what occurs in China, in the PRC, when all one's documentation has gone. If one has not got any documentation, one cannot obtain a job; one cannot move around the country; and one's movements are restricted. Of course, I asked the wrong question of the Department. Mr Irvine said:
He is at liberty at home . . .
I said:
At liberty at home. So is he under house arrest?
Mr Irvine said:
I do not believe so . . .

That is not prevaricating, but it is not telling me the story that I wanted. If the Department knew the story, that this man's documentation had been taken, it was misleading, in my view, to say to me, `No, he is not under house arrest'. Whilst, strictly, that is true, the Department should have known what occurs to a person in the PRC who has no documentation at all. It is worse than being under house arrest. I come back to what the Department said to me. The Department said:

In the last year or so and more recently, the Chinese Government has made a number of public statements to the effect that, if students who have stayed away in other countries were to return home, they would suffer no legal consequences.

What is being put in gaol for nine days on return if it is not a legal consequence? I remind honourable senators that he was detained illegally, because under Chinese law a person can only be detained for 24 hours. What about the confiscation of the legal documentation of this individual? That is a legal consequence and harsh treatment indeed. Where are those seven boat people? Are they still in prison? Why have we not monitored what is occurring to the people that this nation forcibly deports to the PRC?

PARA.TAB: Are we going to accept at face value the PRC's statements—the statements from a government which started off by saying that nothing happened in Tiananmen Square? Are we going to continue to accept its assurances? This is a matter of great concern to a large number of people, particularly to the Chinese refugee applicants and those that have been given refugee status in Australia.

The day after the deportation of those seven refugee applicants a number of Chinese nationals who are members of the Chinese refugee self-rescue action group came down to Parliament to demonstrate peacefully. They are still outside making a peaceful demonstration and very few of us know about it. They have been outside on hunger strike since 24 October. I did not know about it; I only found out last night when I was walking along and I bumped into a group of Chinese and a well-known person in Canberra whom I know. It was only then that I was told the story. I went to their tent in the rain. It has been very cold there. These people are suffering, they are on hunger strike and they are expressing themselves in the interests of humanity and solidarity with their fellow human beings.

I believe that we have a great responsibility. This document was translated by Professor Han Shang Xiao, as will be seen when it is incorporated into Hansard. Professor Han has had a refugee application in for over two years and it still has not been processed. He is not the only one. What are people supposed to do—put their lives on hold for four, five or six years? That is inhumane.

More inhumane is the fact that we are sending people back to the PRC. We are forcibly deporting them without knowing their fate. Here are two examples. We know for sure in one case that the person has suffered harsh treatment. In the other case, I am reliably informed that the person was imprisoned upon return to China.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you know how difficult it would be for Chinese refugee applicants to prove a well-founded fear of persecution. Where do they get their witnesses? But they certainly have a well-founded fear. I believe that any civilised country that is committed to the protection of individuals' human rights has a responsibility to make absolutely sure that the rights of these refugee applicants are preserved and that they are not subjected to harsh treatment if their applications do not succeed.

Chinese refugee applicants are people; they are human beings. I am afraid that, mixed up as we are with our own concerns, sometimes we tend to forget that. My appeal to the Minister, to the Government and to us all, including myself—I did not know that they were there until last night—is to bear in mind that they are human beings. Though they do not know how to go about protesting, we ought at least to have regard to their plight and the plight of those for whom they are making such sacrifices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about the questionary which was circulated to the various political parties by the conservation groups prior to the 1990 election with respect to the environment and the sorts of promises and offers which were made by the various parties to organisations such as the Australian Conservation Foundation. This questionary was comprehensive in its coverage of environmental issues. Questions ranged from concerns over green issues such as biological diversity, national parks and wilderness areas, Antarctica, World Heritage and forestry to the so-called brown issues such as environment protection, the greenhouse effect and ozone depletion.

PARA.TAB: Of the 93 questions asked, 104 responses were received, as some questions had several parts. The ALP answered yes to 76 of those questions, or almost three-quarters of the survey. Further, the ALP gave a qualified yes to 17 questions, or 16 per cent of the survey. Eleven responses were listed as undecided. The ALP avoided answering no to any of the questions.

Looking back over this Government's term of office, it is obvious that the ALP deliberately bought the green vote at the last election, that it clearly had no intention of carrying out its promises and that the Australian public has been duped by such a cynical exercise. The ALP has fulfilled only 26 of its promises, or 25 per cent of the responses. The Government has defended its position on Antarctica and World Heritage areas.

There is no doubt that the Government has kept its word on the protection of Antarctica and on World Heritage nominations such as Kakadu, Fraser Island and Shark Bay; yet on the protection of World Heritage areas the Government has failed to act appropriately. When the Government was provided with information that past and present quarrying operations had indisputably damaged part of the Exit Cave karst system in the Tasmanian wilderness World Heritage area, the Government allowed quarrying operations to continue.

The Government's record shows a sorry tale of broken promises. Nowhere is this more transparent at the moment than on the issue of threatened species protection. The ALP promised to promote the case for the Commonwealth to be given increased powers to make laws with respect to the protection of a species of flora or fauna from extinction. Indeed, the Government promised to use all the powers available to it under the Constitution.

The Government has failed miserably in this regard. The final draft of the Government's endangered species legislation is a pale shadow of the sort of legislation which is required to truly protect Australia's threatened species—the sort of legislation put forward in my private member's Bill, which was voted against during the last sitting fortnight by the Government and the coalition and which, if accepted, would have fulfilled the promise made by the Government at the time of the last election.

There are many other matters on which the Government has failed to live up to its list of cynical promises. It has failed to make any advances to curb greenhouse gases—indeed, it has walked way from the original Toronto target of a 20 per cent reduction of greenhouse gases by the year 2005—even though an unprecedented consensus was achieved last year on this matter among the ESD working groups on measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Its commitment to the Toronto target was never anything more than a sop designed for domestic consumption and a hollow promise to appease environment groups. No action has been taken to significantly improve energy efficiencies and to substantially increase funding to renewable energies, even though technically Australia could rely in 30 years time on renewables to meet two-thirds of its energy demands.

Australia used to take a strong leadership role in international negotiations on ozone depletion. We have now slipped behind and are likely to only endorse the UNEP policy position at the forthcoming review of the Montreal Protocol in November. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table the document entitled `Environment: How the ALP failed'.

On constitutional issues, the ALP promised to assume increased powers in relation to land, air and water quality standards and to use the trading corporations power to regulate companies that harm the environment. In practice, the Government has shunned a leadership role, even though the Australian people want the Commonwealth to assume such a role on environmental matters, as indicated in the recent ANOP survey of people's attitudes to the environment. Incidentally, that survey cost the Australian taxpayer a quarter of a million dollars through the Department of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

The Government has also developed the so-called new federalism which constrains the Commonwealth from taking action until all the States have been consulted and at least two-thirds of the States have agreed. This is clearly an action which ensures that the lowest common denominator is achieved with respect to the environment. Australia needs strong and decisive Commonwealth government action to take the necessary steps to protect and conserve species and ecological systems—not a government prepared to engage in endless consultations while Rome burns with little or nothing to show for it at the end of the day.

We are now told that Mr Keating is due to release an environment statement around mid-December. No doubt this will contain another round of cynical promises to buy green votes, but this time I am sure that the Australian people will not be fooled. They know that there is only one national party with strong green credentials in Australia today and that is, of course, the Australian Democrats. I hope that this performance assessment will help to expose the green dishonesty engaged in by this present Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on an answer given by Senator Cook today in the Senate to a dorothy dixer from one of his colleagues. In that answer Senator Cook made remarks about the coalition's Jobsback policy, which is engineered to do nothing more than improve the unemployment position in this country and to do it in a way whereby people will get an increase in real wages coming with an increase in productivity—
—Ha, ha!

—Senator McMullan laughs over there. He has had an accord that goes back some years. As a result of that accord, we have had a reduction in real wages and record unemployment. It is reprehensible that Australia, with the inherent wealth and unlimited opportunity that it has, should have so many people unemployed. That is the background of what Jobsback is about.

PARA.TAB: But, in his response, Senator Cook pointed out that under the Jobsback policy a person who went on a workplace agreement would receive the lowest level as spelt out in the award. There are none so blind or stupid as those who will not see. Senator Cook has slowly recognised what we are all about. Initially, he was saying that there was no bottom; that people would be attacked by unscrupulous employers. At least he has now got to the stage—although he is wrong—of saying that it will be the lowest level of the award.

Let me point out what the Jobsback policy is all about. It is a transition process. It throws out an inflexible system of industrial relations that over the years has caused massive unemployment. The problem in Australia—and I point this out very clearly—is not one of wage rates, per se; it is one of lack of productivity. If one looks at the wage rate in Australia today, one sees that it is approximately half the average wage rate of Japan. Japan has a highly productive work force, one which relates to its own place of employment. There is a recognition that the health, virility and success of those who work in a company depend on the success of that company and that, if there is a falling away of productivity in that company, the workers' own jobs could be at risk.

Under the coalition's Jobsback policy, there will be a transition process and three groups of employees will emerge. Firstly, there will be those who, along with their employers, choose to remain within the award system—and they will be permitted to do that. Just as an aside, I can think of—but I had better not name them—those who will not move out of the system because they have an intransigent closed shop system. Secondly, there will be those who will agree with their employer to enter workplace agreements; and, thirdly, there will be those whose award entitlements will be converted to workplace agreements. This is not an attack on the trade union movement, although the trade union movement will be thrown into the same competitive field as everyone else in a world society that has become ultra-competitive.

I heard Senator Childs make a remark here the other day about the sorts of union operations in which he was involved 30 years ago, and his remark was quite correct. In those days there was no compulsory unionism, per se, if my recollection is correct. There were some closed shops, but very few, and unions did not have the power that that they have today—and I mean raw power and control over their own workers. Workers themselves today have very little power; in fact, they do not count for anything.

Going back to those three stages, the first one is simple: employees remain within the award system and retain their status quo. The second one is where employees voluntarily entering into workplace agreements are protected by the statutory minima as spelt out in the Jobsback program. These are minimum wage, annual leave, sick leave and maternity leave. In addition, they are guaranteed public holidays—and I point this out because, again, in answer to a question by one of his other colleagues, Senator Cook said that public holidays would go. Dealing with this issue, the Jobsback package indicates that:

SPEECH.PARA: State legislation governing long service leave, public holidays and issues of occupational health and safety will continue to apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will they get paid if they work on public holidays?
—If they are within the award system, they will continue under the award system. If they go into a workplace agreement where they make some agreements on that, they will also continue.
—There will be no minimum guarantee of what they will get paid if they work on a public holiday?
—Of course they will have a minimum guarantee as to what they will work because, as has been spelt out in Fightback, the minimum rate will be based on an hourly rate.
—Just a normal hourly rate?

—Yes, and it is up to them whether or not they work. I point out that in most cases the minima will be irrelevant—and this is something that honourable senators must bear in mind—since employees would not consent to enter into a workplace agreement which did not improve their existing wages and conditions. Senator McMullan shakes his head. Let me give him two very good examples of this in my own State of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Before the Labor Party was elected in Queensland, there were two organisations that entered into workplace agreements. The example I cite was a greenfields project, and it is a lot easier to do these things when one starts a greenfields project. One of the organisations was Power Brewing Co. Ltd. Workers had flexible working hours and they got rid of all the ridiculous work practices that applied at other breweries. I can give Senator McMullan one ridiculous work practice that I remember very well. If a truck pulled up at one of the other breweries to load beer and the truck driver needed a hand, if anyone who worked in that brewery put his or her hand on the truck, everyone was out the gate. If one went down to Power Brewing, one would find that, if the truck driver needed a hand, they would give him a hand.

Employees were able to work flexible hours. Most of these employees had young families—and bear in mind the location of the Power Brewery; it is about halfway between Brisbane and the Gold Coast—and they lived somewhere within the environs of the Gold Coast. It suited them to start work early in the morning, get home when the children came home from school and take them to the beach, go fishing or do any other recreation that they wanted to do. The fascinating thing about the Powers Brewing case is that, while employees did not work any additional hours compared with the other breweries, they made something in the order of $10,000 a year more. That is a factual figure that can be checked if anyone wishes to check it.

I think it is worth going back a little and explaining how that agreement was put in place. There was no intent in the first place to have a workplace agreement. As a greenfields project, discussions were held not just with the workers on the site but with the actual union delegates on the site. An agreement was reached that suited them all very well. Things became unstuck when they were told by the Trades and Labour Council to go off to the appropriate union—I suppose it was the liquor trades; I am not sure which one it was—and get it approved. The people who did not work in the brewery—the third party group from the trade union movement—turned up on site. When it was suggested by the management that the delegates participate in the discussions, the union leaders from head office in Brisbane indicated that they would not engage in discussions with management in the presence of the union delegates. Out of that was spun the workplace agreement.

The union delegates were advised that they were not welcome and that they had no role to play, and were thrown out. Of course, the delegates said, `Well, we don't need you either'. In the short interim phase before the Labor Party was elected in Queensland they were able to enter into a workplace agreement.

Much the same thing happened with Metway. Metway was able to gear its working hours to fit the customers and also to fit its own employees. I know that this is very strange for people in the Labor Party because they are used to entrenched power within the hierarchy of the union movement. No matter where one looks, one finds that anything that is agreed to at the workplace must get the blessing of the leaders of the union, who in fact do not work at the organisation at all.

The other day I gave the example of Gazal enterprises on the Gold Coast. I will not go into detail on that again except to say that here again an agreement was reached between the owner of the enterprise, a Mr Gazal, and some 125 of his employees. Those employees could not realise the significance of their own importance. Ms Anna Booth from Melbourne turned up and told the employees of this little enterprise on the Gold Coast, `You cannot do this'. Many of us saw on the television screen the pitiful example of the employees of Gazal saying to Ms Booth, `Please go back to Melbourne. Leave us alone. All we want to do is go back to work'.

Without the flexibility that was agreed to by both the employer and the employees—incidentally, I understand that there was a great relationship between the two parties—the option was that Gazal enterprises would shut down and instead of producing textiles or whatever it would import. That is an indication of the sort of thing that we have seen go on in this country, not just over the past 10 years but over the past 10 to 20 years. I am not singling out a certain period. I am referring to an historical arrangement that has caused us in Australia to move away from the very thing that we all want—that is, value adding and producing goods that people want to buy rather than importing them.

The minimum wage is the minimum hourly rate applicable to an employee according to the relevant award classification. It is a series of minima. It is not what Senator Cook said—and he should know better. As I indicated earlier, I presume that Senator Cook does not want to see this happen. It is a case of none so blind as those who will not see. His whole background is such that, no matter what he might believe in his own heart, he must support the very organisation that he has been in all his life—that monolith, the trade union movement. He has an obligation to continue to support it.

I could not help but notice, even in the remarks made tonight by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), that when a coalition government is elected in Australia the Labor Party will not oppose in the Senate the goods and services tax but will oppose the Jobsback program. That is just blind ideology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your side makes the same distinction. Why don't you understand that?

—The Parliamentary Secretary has a commitment back to a part of his machine—a handful of people—that says, `You, Senator McMullan, are part of the political arm of the trade union movement. You will fight in the trenches and you will fight to the death if anyone dares in any way to touch our power base'. The view of the Labor Party is, `To hell with the workers, to hell with the jobs that will be created and to hell with Australia'. It is about time that the blinkers were removed and a little commonsense was brought into this whole situation.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook also remarked—I think I might have covered it—that the public holiday entitlement is, by definition, an entitlement to paid public holidays. To suggest otherwise is fatuous and mischievous. It is important that we put on the record and clarify a position that obviously Senator Cook cannot or will not see or is unable to accept simply because of a power structure through which he came to get into this place, which keeps him here and which, to a large extent, keeps the Labor Party in existence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming, as I do, from north Queensland, I have a commitment to the people of that area and particularly to the people of north-west Queensland who currently are being fairly poorly represented by the honourable member for Kennedy, Mr Hulls. Because I have that commitment to the people of north-west Queensland, I want to correct some misrepresentations—I suppose that is the politest way of putting it—that Mr Hulls made tonight when speaking in the other chamber. I would not want the people of the north-west to be misled by anything that Mr Hulls might say—not that I think they would; I do not think too many people up there take too much notice of him.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hulls made a number of quite factually incorrect statements. First of all, he claimed that the Labor Party was the party of the bush and the party that rural Australia supports. That is just factually incorrect. If he looks at the figures he will see that the Liberal Party holds 24 rural and regional seats; the Labor Party 18 rural and regional seats; and the National Party 14. So the coalition between them hold something like 38 rural and regional seats compared with 18 held by the ALP. So it is just quite ridiculous to suggest that the ALP is the party of the bush.

Mr Hulls made these remarks when he was speaking about the zone rebate during a debate on tax legislation. He did not mention in his contribution that for seven years under his Government, between 1985 and 1992, the zone rebate fell in real terms. That is the commitment of the ALP to the people of north-west Queensland. Each year the people of the remote parts of Australia look to see what the Labor Party is going to do; they look to see whether it is going to increase the zone rebate to a level that will at least keep it in line with inflation. But each year they have been forgotten.

It was not so long ago that the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, backed away from increasing the zone rebate. He did so while he was in Charters Towers, which is in the electorate of the honourable member for Kennedy. I am glad that Senator McMullan is in the chamber because in June 1991 Senator McMullan, as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, visited Mr Hulls's electorate and again ruled out any increase in the zone allowance. The North West Star of 12 June 1991 reported:

SPEECH.PARA: Neither a revision of the Sales Tax on freight nor an increase in the Zone Rebate are on the Federal Government agenda, according to Senator McMullan, Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer.

It was only after Fightback was released in November 1991 and a commitment was given for an increase in the zone rebate of at least 25 per cent that the ALP suddenly realised that it had not done anything for too long. In other words, it had continued deliberately to ignore the situation. It was a classic case of `me too' type politics. So it is quite ridiculous for the honourable member for Kennedy to take credit for the zone rebate decision of his Party; he should be thanking the Liberal and National parties for raising the issue and for making a commitment in Fightback. It was only when that commitment was made that the Government chose to follow along, as it has done with so many of the things in Fightback!, to try to catch up.

PARA.TAB: If Mr Hulls were interested in the people of north-west Queensland, he would be getting the Labor Party to have a look at and do something about the iniquitous fringe benefits tax on the basic necessities for workers in north-west Queensland. The fringe benefits tax means something to the fat cats in Melbourne or Sydney, I imagine, but to the workers of north-west Queensland it is a very iniquitous tax on the basic necessities. If Mr Hulls had some interest in those constituents, he would get his Government to have a look at it.

Mr Hulls did go on to say that the one thing his constituents did not want was a GST. He is quite wrong about that because the average family under the GST regime would be $30 to $40 a week better off, even after they have paid the GST. For that reason, all people in Australia would be quite silly if they did not support that scheme because, even after paying the GST, the average family is going to have $30 to $40 more in their pockets as a result of Fightback than at present.

What Mr Hulls should have said was not that his constituents did not want the GST, but that they really did not want another three years under Mr Keating. He forgot to mention that even he was telling the media in north Queensland last year that he would find it impossible to sell Mr Keating in the bush. As I think Mr Hulls said, `You could not give him away'. He told the North West Star:

SPEECH.PARA: I would have some difficulty selling Mr Keating and I've told him that.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hulls went on to try to illustrate the impact of a GST on people buying a loaf of bread in Burketown. Typical of the Labor scare campaign, he simply added 15 per cent on top of all existing prices; so he picked the price of bread in Burketown and added 15 per cent to that. He knows that is wrong and Senator McMullan knows that is wrong, but they continue to peddle that misinformation knowing that that is not right. When one removes seven existing taxes that impact upon that loaf of bread in Burketown, one goes right back to when the seed was first planted for the wheat that makes that bread. When one adds payroll tax, sales tax, petrol tax and training guarantee levies, one realises what an enormous impact there already is on that loaf of bread in Burketown from the taxes that this Government continues to put in place.

Mr Hulls did not mention that under a coalition government seven taxes will be removed from that loaf of bread. Of course, that will make most things less expensive than they are now. Even with the addition of a GST, the average increase in cost of living for all Australians will be about 4 per cent. They are not my figures; we did some figures and arrived at 4.4 per cent. Senator McMullan and his Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) got the Treasury to check our figures. They came back and said, `You are wrong, it is not 4.4 per cent, it is only 3.6 per cent'. That is their figure, not ours. So whatever it is—3.6 or 4.4—it is about 4 per cent. But when one takes into account the compensations—the 30 per cent reduction in income tax, the 8 per cent increase in pensions, the doubling of family allowances, the fact that everyone will be able to fill up their car with fuel for about $10 to $12 less per tankful—one can understand how the average family will end up with $30 to $40 more in their pockets after Fightback than they currently do.

Mr Hulls is crying crocodile tears about the residents of Burketown because they pay 75c more now for a loaf of bread than people in Brisbane do. But has he ever wondered why they do that? It has a lot to do with the price of petrol and the cost of freight. But Mr Hulls did not bother to tell his constituents tonight that under the coalition petrol will be 26c a litre cheaper for trucks taking bread to Burketown. If he had told them that, they would have realised how people will be better off.

A further point to be made is that the graziers in north-west Queensland pay an enormous amount in fuel tax to get their cattle to the market. Figures have been prepared, which are pretty widely available now, which show that an average truckie would save at least $40,000 a year in operational costs, particularly up in those areas. The National Farmers Federation did a survey which showed that a grazier in the north-west of Queensland would have 22 per cent more disposable income in his pocket as a result of the Fightback package. These are all the people up in Mr Hulls's area who would benefit substantially from the Fightback package.

The fact that all the people in the Burketown area—or in any part of Mr Hulls's electorate—will pay some 30 per cent or a third less income tax will certainly mean they will be much better off. I do feel a little sorry for Mr Hulls. I quite like him; he is a likeable enough sort of person, particularly for a Melbourne lawyer. I feel sorry for him because he really is going to be the classic oncer. The Liberal Party candidate, Dave Cashmore, will win that seat from him and Mr Hulls will have to go back to law. Mr Hulls would be far better at law than demonstrating economic policy and the cost of living in his area. He either does not know the situation or deliberately misrepresents it. Although the hour is late, I thought it important to put those facts on the record, so that the people of north-west Queensland will have the true situation put before them when they wake up in the morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish tonight to make some comments on the question put by Senator Childs to Senator Cook in Question Time today and to refer to the Minister's answer. I do this because I am sick and tired of the misrepresentation which comes from those on the other side. Last night I corrected some comments made the day before by Senator Childs in the urgency debate, and I informed him that I intended to do so. Yet today he came in here and asked a question which clearly misrepresented the situation after the record had been put straight. I did inform him that I would be raising this matter tonight. Last night I said that Senator Childs had stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the difference between their classification rate and the lowest base rate in the award is significant. It would be financially devastating for them. This is not worker friendly; there is no way it can be. For example, the minimum award rate for a metal industry trades person would fall from $417.20 per week, including supplementary payments, to $284.80 per week with no supplementary payments.
That is what Senator Childs had to say. I then went on to say:

I want to make it quite clear that the minima, in fact, will be the classification rates. That is the position we had at the last election with our industrial relations policy. While there have been some changes in that policy, in this particular area there has been no change.

That is about as clear as one can state a policy position. I then went on to outline a significant amount of detail. Senator Parer has also outlined a significant amount of that detail tonight. I will not go over that again.

PARA.TAB: Despite the fact that last night I said I would give Senator Childs the benefit of the doubt that he misunderstood the policy and did not deliberately misrepresent it—I said that I did not give the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, or Mr Willis the same benefit of the doubt since they consistently misrepresented our policy positions—I have to withdraw my generosity of last night. I am sorry to have to do that, but Senator Childs had the opportunity to look at the situation and understand it. I do not believe that he is that thick up top that he could not understand what I said last night.
I want to refer to the question which Senator Childs asked today. I will not quote the whole question because it is on the record. Part of the question stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . John Howard, said that the minimum wage for workers on individual employment contracts under a coalition government would be based on their award classification rate?
This is as a result of an article that was in the Australian Financial Review. He went on:
Following this shift in policy by the Opposition, does the Government now intend to adopt a similar individual employment contract policy?

The first point I make is that there has been no shift. I made that quite clear last night. That is also borne out by an article in the Sunday Telegraph on 25 October, five days after the release of our policy position, Jobsback, in Sydney. That position was spelt out and was clearly on the public record.

PARA.TAB: There was a deliberate misrepresentation of our position. In fact, I would call it a misleading of the Senate because Senator Childs knew what the position was. It was perpetuated in the Minister's answer because the Minister knew as well. He would have been informed. It was a devious scheme to try to grab a little bit of television time to mislead the Australian population. It is because of the actions of people such as Senator Childs and Senator Cook that parliamentarians are held in such low regard. Eventually these things catch up with them. People find out that they have not been prepared to tell the truth. I quote part of Senator Cook's answer. Once again, I will not read the whole answer because it is on the record. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What the policy proposes is that, irrespective of the classification a worker or employee is on, they will go to the lowest rate in the award. That is what the policy says and that is why the Opposition is backtracking. That is why these points of order have been taken today to try to conceal that. It is clear in the policy and it is misrepresented in the press release.

The points I make about that are, first, that it is absolutely and totally wrong, as I pointed out in relation to the article in the Sunday Telegraph and, secondly, that we have not changed our position in that area of policy. There is no backtracking whatsoever. It is typical of the way this Minister answers questions. I can go through a whole litany of questions that I and other people have asked in this place relating to Robe River or the situation where we had to have three corrections to the payments made to the BLF in Western Australia. They are still not right.

PARA.TAB: Not only do I find it very sad but also I think it quite disgraceful that this type of misrepresentation is deliberately put on the public record. Had one not raised this issue last night, one could say that maybe the Minister did not see the article in the Sunday Telegraph. He was aware of the fact that I had put the record straight last night. As I said in my opening comments, it is shameful for Senator Childs to ask a question like that when he knew the premise on which the question was being asked was wrong. He knew the record had been put straight last night. He was informed that the record would be put straight last night. That question was a deliberate set-up to mislead the Australian public who will be watching the television replay tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even though the hour is late, I feel obliged to respond to both the weightier contributions made early in the adjournment debate and the later ones. Senator Hill and Senator Harradine spoke at length about serious and sensitive matters to do with international relations. I indicate to both of them that it is not appropriate for me to start an off-the-cuff discourse on these two issues which they raised, but I will make sure that the issues which they raised are drawn to the attention of the respective departments and Ministers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter set out to make a major speech about the Labor Party and the environment, but I think he made fairly clear that his real concern is that there might be some other green party emerging to undermine the position of his group. On this occasion, I do not think it was even his bete noir Senator Macdonald; I think it was Bob Brown lurking over his shoulder that was more relevant to the speech that was made. But it is a free country and he is entitled to make it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us you are going to vote for the GST.

—Fortunately, I will never have to worry about that. Senator Parer and Senator Crane made speeches trying to justify the unjustifiable. I do not intend to get into the debate; we have lots of opportunity for that. I simply make two points: first, the fundamental misunderstanding is that there is some belief that there is an equality of bargaining power between workers and their employers; secondly, the fundamental flaw is that a guarantee of an hourly rate is a guarantee of the wage. It means that every worker's income is guaranteed until they work an hour of overtime, an hour on the weekend, an hour of shift work or an hour, as Senator Parer made clear today, on a public holiday. Therefore, seven days a week, 52 weeks a year, shift workers would find themselves drastically disadvantaged by that proposal. As it is the right of a party to put it forward in a debate, it is our right to expose its shortcomings.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald attacked Mr Hulls. I think his speech was about as misleading as his assurance that he was going to speak for only five minutes. I think the integrity of Mr Hulls will stand him in good stead in comparison with his detractors. My final point is that Senator Macdonald continues to be enthusiastic about quoting the Treasury report that says the impact on prices of the GST would be only 3.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said 3.6 per cent.

—It is 3.9 per cent actually. Senator Macdonald never quotes the subparts of it which say that included in that 3.9 per cent—some luxuries would fall a lot, so that brings the total down—is food, which would go up by 8.8 per cent, clothing, which would go up by more than 10 per cent, and electricity, which would go up effectively by 10 per cent.
—What about petrol?

—Including the impact of petrol, which Senator Macdonald tries to mention. It says that food will go up by an average of 8.8 per cent. He is concerned about the fact that the reality may get out and that Mr Hulls was improving the prospects for that happening. At ten minutes to 12, that is quite enough for all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has a study ever been carried out into the impact of the Lucas Heights Research Laboratory on the health of nearby communities; if so, what were the results; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No. However, a comprehensive, independent survey of the health of employees of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (or ANSTO; but, at the time, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission) was conducted by Professor D Ferguson of the School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at the University of Sydney between 1974 and 1979. Many of these employees lived in the nearby communities. This survey revealed no adverse health consequences beyond those to be expected in any similar large industrial complex.

In 1991, the then Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, at the request of ANSTO, and in view of the time which had elapsed since the completion of the Ferguson report in 1979, raised with the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council (AIRAC) the question of an epidemiological health survey of ANSTO staff and members of the public living near Lucas Heights. AIRAC responded to the Minister recently.

AIRAC advised that on the basis of information provided by ANSTO and the NSW Radiation Advisory Council, they believed a survey was not warranted as the size of the population that would need to be included in an epidemiological study to produce statistically significant results is far greater than the population in the immediate vicinity of Lucas Heights.

AIRAC also advised that they are of the view that the reported doses are so low that they would need to be in error by several orders of magnitude to warrant any reconsideration as to whether any epidemiological study would be meaningful in detecting any enhanced incidence of serious illnesses as a result of the operations at the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 23 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) In the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's major review of its network of overseas posts resulting in the decision to close three European posts, what criteria were used to determine the closures.
(2) Which diplomatic missions were listed for Cabinet consideration and on what grounds was each mission considered.

(3) Given that Australia maintains seven diplomatic missions in the United States of America, what consideration was given to closing any of these in preference to sole missions in countries such as Portugal and Czechoslovakia.
(4) From which missions will Australian interests in Portugal and Czechoslovakia now be represented.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Relevant criteria were:
any impact on Australia's trade and investment relationship with the affected countries, including the potential cost to tourism and the export of educational services;
any impact on our influence within the relevant region as a result of our diminished ability to voice concerns directly to particular Governments;

any impact on our influence within multilateral forums (eg the UN, the Commonwealth and the Cairns Group) as a result of our diminished ability to influence a particular country (or countries where a post had responsibility for a number of countries);
the volume of consular and immigration workload;
the reduced quality of information on political and economic developments within a country or a region;
the savings flowing from particular post closures.
(2) Cabinet considered closure of a number of posts including Berne, Lisbon and Prague. In each case possible post closure was assessed against the set of criteria provided above.

(3) In addition to the review of our network of posts as a whole a separate examination of the role of the six consulates-general in the United States concluded that responsibility for the consulates-general in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston and Chicago should be transferred from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to Austrade over the next two to three years. The decision to restructure the consulates-general in this way, with a view to enhancing Australia's trade promotion and investment capacity in the United States, was taken separately to the decision to close three European posts. The possible transfer of the consulate-general in New York to Austrade is still under consideration.
(4) The Australian ambassador in Paris has non-resident accreditation to Portugal and it is proposed that Warsaw will have non-resident accreditation to Czechoslovakia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 6 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the fact that the annual cost of osteoporosis to the health budget is between $200 million and $500 million a year, and that the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 2033 (Senate Hansard, 18 August 1992, p.144) regarding the medicare rebate for bone densitometry was heavily based on the National Health Technology Advisory Panel (NHTAP) recommendations on bone mineral assessment published in 1989, and on utilisation of this technology for population screening:
(1) Is the Minister aware that more data is available for an up-to-date review of this matter; if so, why did he not base his answer on more relevant information; if not, why not.
(2) Is the Minister aware that dual photon X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) is now available at considerably more centres and at a lower cost than when the NHTAP report was published; if not, why not.

(3) Is there a well defined list of risk factors for osteoporosis, one of the greatest being reduced bone mass in daughters of women with osteoporosis (Seeman et al NEJM 1989:320:554-558); if so, is it clinically relatively simple to target women at high risk of having low bone density at the time of menopause.

(4) Considering more recent reviews on the subject and that the DEXA technology is highly sensitive and specific, and is available at significantly lower cost than determined by the NHTAP, why does the Federal Government persist in its refusal to extend medicare benefits to menopausal women for densitometry as a preventative health measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Minister's previous reply was based on up-to-date information and quoted a review published in 1992. Since the release of the 1989 NHTAP report, the Minister has: closely monitored research developments overseas and in Australia; funded a range of Australia specific research on osteoporosis; and examined and consolidated available evidence on osteoporosis.

Given developments in recent years, both in Australia and overseas, the Minister convened a workshop in August 1992 to bring together leading experts in the osteoporosis field to establish what is known and not known about the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of osteoporosis.

(2) Yes. The selection of appropriate equipment for bone densitometry measurement is related to the issue of determining the appropriate site for measurement. Opinion is still divided in the medical community about whether the forearm, spine or hip is the best site for the measurement of bone density.

(3) Population studies have identified a number of factors which, on average, appear to be associated with lower bone density eg. smoking, high alcohol intake, genetics. However, the significance of individual factors is still unclear. Moreover, these factors are not considered to provide a clinically reliable indication of risk of low bone density or, more importantly, risk of fracture.

(4) The Federal Government is developing a comprehensive and responsible approach to the issues of osteoporosis and its associated fractures, aiming for a policy which addresses the prevention, effective diagnosis and treatment of the disease. Unrestricted access to and funding for a diagnostic technology is not considered by the Government to be an appropriate response to the complex issues. Inappropriate use of bone densitometry technology would cost a significant amount of public funds without demonstrable outcome assessed by the reduction of fractures.
A sound policy would cover prevention, diagnosis and treatment, and the Government is currently considering expert advice in the development of an osteoporosis policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the reasons behind the Australian Customs Service increasing its fees for its electronic document interchange by a staggering 36 per cent, far outstripping the national inflationary rate.
(2) Why have there been system outages totalling 9150 minutes, about three weeks of working days, in a half year period.

(3) Is the Minister aware that unless this system failure figure is further substantially reduced, Tradegate and PAXUS Corporation Limited could lose credibility with the Australian Trading community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The 36 per cent increase referred to in the question relates to the Electronic Entry Processing Charge (EEPC) and not to Electronic Document Interchange (EDI).

The EEPC has historically comprised two components, the COMPILE user charge and the Electronic Initiatives Supplement, and is calculated by dividing the target revenue for any year by the number of entries Customs expects to process in that year. As a result of negotiations between Customs and the Customs Brokers Council of Australia, two new elements were included in the EEPC calculations for 1992/93. These were:

that revenue targets would be declared and where variations in the number of entries processed gave rise to either over or under collection, those sums would, after CPI adjustment, be carried forward to the following year; and
that all brokers would be given access to the TAPIN (Tariff Advice and Precedents Information Network) system and an amount included in the EEPC to cover its cost.
The EEPC target revenue for 1992/93 has been adjusted by:
an increase to the COMPILE component in line with the Consumer Price Index;
an increase in the Electronic Initiatives Supplement as specified in the Schedule of Outcomes agreed with the Department of Finance;
the inclusion of a new component to cover the cost of providing TAPIN access; and
an amount included to recover the 1991/92 revenue shortfall of $1.7m occasioned by a discrepancy between the number of entries expected (1.73m) and the number actually processed (1.6m).
The increase in the EEPC for 1992/93 is due to the above changes and to a reduction in the number of entries expected to be processed during 1992/93.

(2) On the basis of the information supplied, it has not been possible to identify the outages referred to. However, the period January-October 1992 has seen some outages due to the high level of change to the Australian Customs Service systems undertaken this year. These changes have been made to provide improved facilities to the user community. Two new mainframe computers have been installed, together with significant software upgrades, and there have been some periods of instability in the commercial applications as a result. Although the outages required for implementation of new hardware, systems and software are scheduled as far as possible in times which will cause least inconvenience to the commercial users, there have been occasions on which outages have occurred in peak times. These have been rectified in a timely manner and scheduled availability on all commercial systems has dropped below 98% in only one month.

(3) The Australian Customs Service provides access to its computer systems through the Tradegate Network for which PAXUS Corporation Limited is the carrier. Access is provided primarily for customs brokers, freight forwarders and cargo handlers and regular meetings are held with representatives of the network users to discuss problems with access and availability.

At the most recent meeting, held in October 1992, the user community was understanding of the problems faced in implementing new computer environments and accepted that there had generally been only minor inconvenience to users.
Nevertheless the ACS is aware of the impact of reduced availability on the high level of acceptance by the user community of the services provided through Tradegate and PAXUS Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(2) Mr Gultano was detained in public by plain clothes Philippine National Police officers.

(3) The Australian Embassy in Manila has made inquiries concerning the detention of Sisencio Gultano with the Philippine Department of Justice, the Philippine Commission on Human Rights, union organisations and the Philippine Alliance of Human Rights Advocates (PAHRA), a grouping of over one hundred human rights non-governmental organisations in the Philippines. According to PAHRA, on 7 July Mr Gultano told Task Force Detainees, a prominent human rights non-governmental organisation, that he did not require assistance. To date, Mr Gultano has not lodged any complaint concerning his detention with either the Department of Justice or the Commission on Human Rights.

(4) According to Philippine law the maximum period a person can be detained without a warrant is 36 hours. If a warrant is not issued in this period the arresting officer is liable under the penal code and the person detained has to be released immediately. The Australian Embassy in Manila has been instructed to inquire if a warrant was issued for Mr Gultano.

(5) While the Government has welcomed the significant gains made in the Philippines in the restoration of formal democratic institutions and freedoms following their prolonged suppression by the former Marcos Regime, the Government nevertheless has been concerned about persistent reports of human rights abuses perpetrated by the military, vigilante forces and left-wing insurgents. Accordingly, the Australian Government has maintained a regular dialogue with relevant Philippine authorities, raising individual cases as appropriate. It will continue to do so.

In addition to this dialogue, the Australian Government has pursued a strategy of encouraging the Philippine military and police to provide human rights training to their personnel. As part of this strategy, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade contributed $10,700 last year to fund a series of seminars equipping approximately 600 Philippine military and police trainers with the skills and the knowledge to teach human rights principles. The human rights seminars were the first time that the Philippine military had agreed to participate in such training. The seminars have drawn praise from representatives of the Ford Foundation and UNESCO in the Philippines. Moreover, there is evidence that the courses are genuinely appreciated and utilised by the Philippine military and police.

As a follow-up to the training program, the Government allocated an additional $10,500 this year to the International Committee of the Red Cross to supply human rights texts to Philippine military and police schools, individual units and military and police trainers. These will serve as basic international humanitarian law texts for the schools. In the military and police units they will serve as a core library of human rights reference material. The four texts involved cover the essentials of the law of armed conflict, rules for behaviour in action, training programs in international humanitarian law and the basic rules of the Geneva Conventions and Hague Treaties as they relate to international standards of conduct and the protection of civilians in situations of armed conflict.

The Australian Government will continue to monitor closely the human rights situation in the Philippines, and will look to the Administration of President Fidel Ramos to sustain the gains made by the Aquino Administration in the area of human rights. We are encouraged in this regard to note that in the first months since his election President Ramos has pursued broad policies of national reconciliation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 8 October l992:

PARA.TAB: Will the Minister explain the apparent discrepancy between the answer to Question on Notice No. 1711 (Senate Hansard, 30 March l992, p.1364) which states that Ms Jane Singleton is paid $800 per day for 6 days per month for a 12 month period for chairing the Interim National (Child-care) Accreditation Committee and the Health, Housing and Community Services Annual Report which states that Ms Jane Singleton was paid $76,800.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Ms Singleton's contract as Chairperson of the Interim National Child Care Accreditation Council provides for an average of 6 days per month, at the agreed rate of $800 per day over the 12 month period of the contract. As the demands on the Chairperson's time were uncertain at the time of signing, the contract also included a provision to extend the contract by up to 24 additional days work at the agreed daily rate.

The figure of $76,800 shown in the l991-92 Annual Report of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is the `agreed, contract price for each whole consultancy' and not the amount paid during 1991-92. Ms Singleton received $33,600 in fees and $754 in incidental expenses to the end of June 1992.

The figure in the Annual Report included funding for the extra 24 days, as at the time of writing the Annual Report it was obvious that the increased workload caused by the extension of the public consultation process and the need for additional public meetings in each State and Territory would require the additional days to be worked.
A more recent assessment of the time required indicates that a further 35 days work will be required to complete the Terms of Reference of the Interim National Child Care Accreditation Council.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 13 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many Nimrod 486-33 computers have been purchased for Parliament House offices, and how many have been installed.
(2) What was the cost of purchasing and installing each machine.
(3) At the time of purchase was it known that the machines did not include a floppy disk drive.
(4) Is it considered that machines are able to perform adequately without a floppy disk drive.
(5) Will the 486-33 Nimrod machines be modified or replaced so that they include a floppy disk drive; if so, what will be the cost of the replacement or modification.
(6) Will these additional costs be met by the supplier or the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) A total of 142 Nimrod 486-33 computers have been purchased by the five parliamentary departments. Of those purchased by the Department of the Senate, 75 have been installed in senators' offices and 13 in departmental offices.

(2) The cost of the computers ranged from $2811.05 to $3291.05, according to the number of optional components included in each machine. The cost of the computers installed in Senator's offices was $3191.05 each.

(3) All Nimrod 486-33 computers purchased by the parliamentary departments included a floppy disk drive. All the computers installed in senators' offices were initially equipped with a 3 1/2" floppy disk drive.
(4) It is considered that for the purposes required by most senators and parliamentary staff, a floppy disk drive is necessary.

(5) Most senators' offices are supplied with at least two computers. Nine senators have elected to have only one machine in their Parliament House office. In those cases, and to ensure compatibility with the floppy disk drives in the computers in their State offices, the computers in their Parliament House offices have been modified by the addition of a 5 1/4" floppy disk drive, at a cost of $100.00 each.
(6) The cost of the additional floppy disk drives, a total of $900, was met by the Department of the Senate.
